HEADLINE: Tiny Songbird Poses Big Test Of U.S. Environmental Policy

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RANCHO SANTA MARGARITA, Calif., March 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is facing the first test of its promise to save endangered species and serve economic interests. And the instrument of that test is a four-inch-long songbird that meows like a kitten and lives in what is left of the coastal sage scrub of Southern California.
The blue-gray bird, the California gnatcatcher, has emerged as a national symbol of a possible new method of saving such species while preventing what Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt calls "national train wrecks" like the dispute over the northern spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest.
 
Looking for Compromise
 In a rare arrangement, developers, conservationists and Federal and state officials are working together to preserve an entire ecosystem, rather than haggling over emergency measures prescribed by the Endangered Species Act to save single species. 
 They are trying to find a compromise in which developers would be allowed to destroy parts of the birds' habitat if they agree to set aside enough crucial land to sustain the bird and the ecosystem in which it lives. The theory holds that this approach will protect not only the gnatcatcher but also other associated plants and animals before they become endangered, thereby averting repeated legal battles over them. Last month, Mr. Babbitt told a Congressional hearing that he considered the California plan a model for the nation.
But before the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, part of the Interior Department, has had a chance to work out an agreement with the developers, it faces a Wednesday deadline to rule on whether the gnatcatcher is endangered or threatened. So the new Interior Secretary is likely to let the deadline pass, Federal and state officials say, allowing more time to study the delicate issue.
The success of the new method is crucial in this increasingly urbanized state, where the potential for environmental conflicts probably looms larger than anywhere else in the country. The gnatcatcher makes its home in about 250,000 acres of the most valuable real estate in America, prime housing land in Orange, San Diego and Riverside Counties. Thousands of construction and other jobs are at stake in the region, which is suffering its worst economic slump since the Depression.
While the sides are working out the details of the gnatcatcher plan, major landowners like the Irvine Company and the Santa Margarita Company in Orange County and Newland California in San Diego have voluntarily stopped further destruction of the parts of their land that sustain the gnatcatcher.
 
A Favored Alternative
 Federal wildlife officials have indicated that when they do reach a decision they would consider listing the gnatcatcher -- Polioptila californica californica to scientists -- as threatened, a lesser classification that could offer more flexibility to cooperate in the California plan than would be possible under the stringent rules protecting "endangered" species in the Endangered Species Act.
The concept of protecting the homes of multiple species is fast becoming the favored alternative to decades of conflict under the act over saving individual species. It is being studied to revive the Midwest prairie ecosystem, and already local governments in San Diego County are well advanced in establishing four such habitats in that area.
Mr. Babbitt's spokesman in Washington, Jay Ziegler, said the Secretary "looks at the process in California as a good example of the kind of collaborative problem solving we need across the country to balance the need for sound ecosystem planning and economic progress."
Originally proposed in 1991 by Gov. Pete Wilson the California plan is called the Natural Communities Conservation Planning Program. The outcome of the gnatcatcher dispute is being closely watched for lessons when Congress votes on reauthorizing the Endangered Species Act this year.
Probably no other state faces more environmental demands and disputes than California. Decades of water pumping have brought the winter-run chinook salmon and delta smelt to the brink of extinction, forcing major diversions of water away from irrigated farms. Two-thirds of the 2,350 species that are candidates for Federal listing are in California.
 
Hurdle of Federal Law
 "The conflict between the needs of people and species is only going to increase," said Michael A. Mantell, Under Secretary of the California Resources Agency, which oversees the new conservation plan. "This plan is a way to resolve it before a crisis hits. Once a species is on the list or about to be listed, the options are very limited. This is an attempt to get ahead of the curve, to take an entire ecosystem and work with local governments and landowners to allow for a species to flourish while providing for economic development."
A crucial question, he said, is whether the Federal Government will or can cooperate, since the law does not allow the Government to make agreements governing land use until after a species is listed as endangered or threatened. "This is the initial test of how the new Administration wants to go on single species management versus ecosystem planning," he said.
But even within California, getting cooperation from competing interests will not be easy. Though they have participated in the planning process, environmental groups remain wary.
"In theory it's a good program, but in practice it has not amounted to much yet," said Joel R. Reynolds, a lawyer in Los Angeles with the Natural Resources Defense Council, which petitioned for the endangered listing, along with Jonathan Atwood, a Massachusetts ornithologist. "There have been negotiations for two years, and the gnatcatcher has not been protected. We have refused to drop our petition because the threat of listing is driving the collaborative process."
Indeed, the big developers concede as much. "Developers want to be able to see the future," said Laer Pearce, executive director of the Coalition for Habitat Conservation, which, despite its name, is financed by big landowners fighting the gnatcatcher listing.
"One road is an endless chain of species-listing petitions in which they will always be paying attorneys and biologists to fight," Mr. Pearce said. "The other road is to pay up front, to look at all the habitat and all the populations, set aside enough land and say the species is protected and then say none of the other populations are important to the protection of the species. It is very costly, but it frees up land."
Environmentalists contend that up to 90 percent of the gnatcatcher's scrub habitat has been destroyed, leaving only 2,000 pairs of the birds in California. Developers have challenged that assertion and have sued to thwart the endangered listing on the ground that the bird is not a separate species but the same species that flourishes nearby in Baja California in Mexico.
Still, the Resource Agency says more than 70 private landowners and local governments have placed a voluntary moratorium on development and other activities on 77,000 acres of the chaparral-like sage scrub favored by the gnatcatcher until next November in four counties. Even with the moratorium, more than 2,000 acres of habitat were bulldozed between August 1991 and last April, the Fish and Wildlife Service says.
Later this month a special state-sponsored scientific review panel is expected to issue guidelines governing the amount and distribution of development for the next five years while the habitat is studied. During that time, developers are to stay away from areas with heavy concentrations of rare plants and animals.
 
Preferable to Legal Costs
 It is unclear how the guidelines will be enforced, but Richard M. Broming, vice president of the Santa Margarita Company, said his company preferred such compliance to the costly legal and scientific work to get permits under the Endangered Species Act.
The company, which owns 40,000 acres of gently rolling scrub country between the Santa Ana Mountains and the Pacific Ocean, hopes to develop more than 6,000 acres for more of the manicured "planned communities" like Mission Viejo and Rancho Santa Margarita, built earlier out of what was once a cattle ranch.
Though environmentalists embrace the multiple-species habitat concept and are cooperating in the state plan, they are skeptical. Dan Silver, coordinator of the Endangered Habitats League, a coalition of conservation groups, said the state plan had been "hijacked" by developers with close ties to Governor Wilson, that they had enrolled lands for habitat preservation that they did not plan to develop anyway and that the emerging compromise had little teeth to enforce compliance by private or public landowners.
"There really is no area out there that is not under development threat," he said.
Underlying the dispute is the question of how a developer will be compensated for land that is ruled crucial to an ecosystem. While land swaps are possible, money, a scarce commodity here, will undoubtedly be needed.
The issue is also complicated by plans to build a 17.5-mile toll road in Orange County from Newport Beach to San Juan Capistrano. On Feb. 26, the Fish and and Wildlife Service said the road posed no jeopardy to the species.
The Building Industry Association of Southern California and the Orange County Transportation Corridor Agencies, which are planning toll roads in the area, have asked for a preliminary injunction to prevent the wildlife service from listing the gnatcatcher. A hearing is scheduled in Federal District Court in Washington on Tuesday.
In all this, many people are hoping the Clinton Administration can bring the encouragement to bring the sides together. "The tough part is to create something that never existed before," said Stephen P. Johnson, director of land management for the Nature Conservancy in California. "One of the bright spots is that the Clinton Administration is thinking in the same direction as the state. The state was already there. Now it's just a matter of getting all these sides together."

HEADLINE: U.S. Gives Britain a Warning In Approving USAir Deal

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
The United States today approved a $300 million investment by British Airways P.L.C. in USAir Group Inc., but warned that the British carrier would not be able to increase that stake unless American carriers receivedgreater access to British airports.
The announcement, by Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, signaled a tough new approach to foreign investment in America's airlines. 
 Mr. Pena also announced plans to renegotiate the aviation agreement between the United States and Britain, which he said placed American carriers at a disadvantage.
"The U.S. Government must take an assertive position to defend the rights of U.S. carriers abroad and work toward a global level playing field in aviation," Mr. Pena told a news conference.
Mr. Pena's remarks follow stiffening economic competition between the United States and Europe and a series of tough positions taken by the Clinton Administration on trade policies.
Last Friday, Mickey Kantor, the trade representative, promised to restrict European access to Government contracts in the United States, in retaliation for a new European regulation giving preference to European companies for government contracts. In January, the United States announced import tarrifs on European steel in retaliation for what it called European subsidies of its steel industry and unfair pricing.
Aviation holds a special place in these disputes because the industry is heavily subsidized and involves both high-technology and manufacturing jobs. Last month, President Clinton vowed to take a tougher approach toward Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, because of what he considered unfair government subsidies.
The nation's airlines, which lost $10 billion in the last three years, are increasingly looking abroad for cash. USAir, the nation's sixth-largest airline, has 46,000 employees. Last November, the Bush Administration approved a request by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines to merge its operations with Northwest Airlines, after completion of an "open skies" agreement under which each nation's carriers could fly where they wished in either country. Continental has a relationship with Air Canada, and Delta Air Lines has a relationship with both Swissair and Singapore Airlines.
Today's decision will have an impact far beyond the question of access to Heathrow Airport in London, said Kenneth Quinn, a former chief counsel to the Federal Aviation Administration during the Bush Administration who is now with Mercer Management Consulting.
"It's a watershed event in the airline industry," Mr. Quinn said. "This cements British Airways' position as a global mega-carrier, and will increase pressure on the Big Three U.S. airlines to form competing global alliances."
One matter of concern in the USAir plan has been whether the United States can allow substantial foreign investments in its airlines and still retain control of the industry.
"Our preliminary finding is that the $300 million investment by British Airways does not impair USAir's 'citizenship,' " Mr. Pena said.
He suggested that his approval of British Airways' initial investment would put pressure on Britain to open up its airports. The arrangement "binds the parties to work for an amicable agreement," he said.
Some aviation experts believe that Britain knows it has to allow greater American access to British airports, although few expect an "open skies" agreement.
 
Opposing Voices
 The British Airways' proposal to invest in USAir had been strongly opposed by the strongest American carriers -- American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta. American said today that Mr. Pena's action gave the British carrier "inappropriate, insuperable and, by any standards, unfair competitive advantages."
Robert L. Crandall, chairman and president of American, said the agreement "will have an adverse impact on the U.S. international trade balance."
"Moreover," he continued, "it will shift passengers, revenue, profits and jobs from U.S. carriers to British Airways at a time when the U.S. economy and U.S. workers need active and vigorous support."
But some aviation experts contended that the other carriers were trying to increase pressure on the Administration to pursue a new round of American-British negotiations.
Clark Onstad, a Washington aviation lawyer who is a former airline executive and chief counsel of the F.A.A., said, "The real test of this arrangement is not in code sharing or the initial investment, but whether the United States and the British can reach a more liberal bilateral agreement."
Under the agreement approved today, British Airways will receive 19.9 percent of USAir's voting stock and the authority to name 3 of USAir's 16 directors. The American carrier's domestic market will be linked with the British carrier's international destinations under a system called code sharing for a one-year test.
 
Legal Obstacle
 British Airways plans to invest $200 million more within three years for a total of 34 percent of USAir's voting stock, and $250 million more within five years for a 44 percent stake. These additional investments would require a change in American law, which limits overseas investors to 25 percent of an airline's voting stock and 49 percent of its equity.
Some Congressional leaders believe that Congress should relax these restrictions only if foreign carriers reciprocate.
The General Accounting Office, the research arm of Congress, has found that a major reason for the restrictions -- protection for a fledgling industry -- no longer applies. But national security may still be an issue, the office said, recommending that the Department of Defense be required to study the issue.

HEADLINE: Clinton Promises Rabin He Won't Cut Aid to Israel

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Despite pressure to cut foreign aid as he reduces domestic spending, President Clinton assured Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel today that he would oppose any attempt to reduce military and economic assistance to Israel for years to come.
Senior aides said that Mr. Clinton pledged to continue current aid levels not just in the coming budget as Secretary of State Warren Christopher said last week, but in the years to follow. The aides also suggested that if Israel made peace with its neighbors, it would be compensated even further for its sacrifices, just as both Israel and Egypt were guaranteed hefty American aid packages after the 1979 Camp David treaty. 
 "The President made it clear that we would make our best efforts to maintain those levels beyond those years," a senior White House official said, referring to the period beyond the 1994 fiscal year, for which a budget is now being planned. "And of course, if there is indeed a breakthrough to peace in the region, I think that will transform the environment, and there's a sense in which the United States would then be prepared to help compensate Israel for the risks it would take to make peace."
 
Effort to Prove U.S. Friendship
 The assurances were part of a deliberate attempt to prove to Mr. Rabin in his first meeting with President Clinton that he not only has a friend in the White House, but a particularly close friend. A striking feature of their joint news conference today was that the President, unlike his predecessors, made no conciliatory gestures to the Arab side to balance his pro-Israeli remarks.
Shortly after Israel deported 400 Muslim fundamentalists to Lebanon in December, Mr. Clinton, as President-elect, criticized the action, saying he was concerned that it might imperil peace talks. At the time, the balanced statements were welcomed by Arab countries and the Palestinians, who were worried that the new President would favor Israel.
But when he was asked today about the expulsions, Mr. Clinton said bluntly, "We did not discuss that.
"As far as I'm concerned, the Secretary of State and the Prime Minister reached an agreement on that," he said, a referring to a compromise Mr. Rabin and Mr. Christopher struck last month to speed the return of the deportees.
Last week Palestinian leaders rejected an American and Russian invitation to a new round of peace talks in Washington next month, saying Israel had to resolve the deportation issue first.
Mr. Rabin and Mr. Christopher have predicted that the Palestinians will come to the two-week talks, which are to begin on April 20, but the Palestinians still hope to persuade Washington to further speed the return of the deportees and to extract a pledge from Israel to end such expulsions. But in choosing not to address the issue, Mr. Clinton is sending a clear signal that such pressure will not be forthcoming.
 
An Arab Journalist's Question
 At another point in the news conference, an Arab journalist told Mr. Clinton that "the Arabs think that you favor Israel against them," and asked, "What are you doing to balance this situation?"
Mr. Clinton replied that Mr. Christopher had taken a consistent message to all parties on his recent trip to the Mideast and that the United States "can be counted on to keep our word" if an agreement is reached.
Mr. Christopher, during his discussions with Palestinian leaders in Jerusalem last month, pledged to work with Israel to improve its human rights record in the occupied West Bank and Gaza, but Mr. Clinton did not say whether he had raised the issue today.
If today's meeting is any indication, the President and the Prime Minister will get along much better than their predecessors did. Tension today seemed limited to the effect of the new White House no-smoking policy on the chain-smoking Mr. Rabin during three and a half hours of meetings and lunch.
Before addressing reporters, Mr. Rabin extended his hand and offered a smile to Mr. Clinton, gestures that for the normally taciturn, all-business Israeli war hero are the diplomatic equivalent of a tight embrace. Contrary to the reservations he has expressed about an expanded American role in the peace negotiations, in his prepared remarks today Mr. Rabin said that he had heard "with satisfaction" the American concept of "the role of full partner as an intermediary," adding, "Mr. President, you will find us to be full partners."
 
Israel's 'Qualitative Edge'
 For his part, Mr. Clinton nodded with apparent approval when Mr. Rabin said that Israel would not be able to "win the battle for peace without a qualitative edge" over its neighbors' military forces.
During their appearance together, Mr. Rabin said he was "ready for compromise" and repeated his offer to surrender part of the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights to Syria. But he reiterated the position he has often stated that Israel would not negotiate a withdrawal of troops from the strategic plateau territory without knowing Syria's peace terms in advance.
Mr. Clinton endorsed Mr. Rabin's conditions, saying that any peace must include open borders between Israel and Syria and full diplomatic relations, and pledging to maintain Israel's military edge over the Arabs as an inducement for a settlement.
Mr. Rabin also thanked Mr. Clinton for promising to oppose any cuts in aid to Israel, which totals $3 billion a year. That aid and the $2.1 billion that goes to Egypt account for 36 percent of the American foreign aid budget.
"We do appreciate and greatly value the decision to maintain the current level of aid to Israel," Mr. Rabin said. "This decision will help us integrate new immigrants into our society and to bear the heavy burden of our security."

HEADLINE: Elderly Care: The Insurers' Role

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
The insurance industry believes it has one answer to the high cost of health care: policies to cover home and nursing home care for the elderly.
The trick is to get young Americans to buy these policies now, just as they buy life insurance policies, and spread the heavy costs over many years. 
 In fact, many companies have begun to sell such policies, which have become the fastest-growing type of health insurance sold in recent years.
"The key issue is that this nation is going to be in big trouble if we try to fund this on a pay-as-you-go basis," said David E. Hughes, a senior vice president of the UNUM Corporation, an insurer based in Portland, Me. "The private sector can play a crucial role here, particularly if Americans start to think about this problem years before they retire."
But consumer groups are skeptical. They have attacked private long-term care as deceptive, vulnerable to inflation and appropriate only for the most affluent Americans, perhaps less than 20 percent of the aging population. In addition, they question whether insurers can estimate accurately what long-term care will cost decades from now.
"Private long-term care insurance is a good option for some people, but is not the answer for everyone," said Susan Polniaszek, director of national services for the United Seniors Health Cooperative, a consumer group in Washington. "It is certainly not the answer for financing long-term care for the country. Individuals have to ask whether they can really afford it."
By all accounts, the costs of long-term care are mammoth, and growing quickly.
In 1990, long-term care cost $42 billion for Americans in nursing homes and $8 billion for care at home, not counting care given by family and friends, said Donald M. Charsky, the president of Life Plans, a long-term care consulting company in Walthham, Mass. By 1992, he calculated, nursing home costs had jumped to $50 billion and home care costs to $10 billion.
 
2020: $500 Billion a Year
 If current trends continue, Mr. Charsky estimates the nation will be paying $500 billion a year for long-term care in today's dollars by the year 2020, when the baby-boom generation becomes the elder boom.
In 1900, only 4 percent of the population was over 65, according the Census Bureau. In 1990, 12.5 percent of the population was. By 2050, 20.6 percent of Americans will be over 65. And many of those people will be forced to seek long-term care.
At age 65, a person stands a 40 percent chance of spending some time in a nursing home, and a 23 percent chance of living in a nursing home for a year or more. Costs of nursing homes average $30,000 a year and go as high as $100,000 a year in some urban areas. In addition, the cost of a visit by a so-called home aide, who might help with bathing or dressing, averages $50 nationally. Visits by trained nurses average about $100.
Nursing home costs are already taking a terrible toll on Federal and state governments. Contributing to soaring Medicaid are the nursing bills for middle-class people who "spend down" their life savings so that they qualify for Medicaid -- a program designed for the poor -- to pay their nursing bills. In spending down, people either sell their assets or transfer them to family members.
Officials of the President's Task Force on National Health Care reform have disclosed that the Administration is contemplating a new, Federal Government role in the long-term care problem.
 
Financing a Problem
 Some aides have urged a Government-subsidized program that could cost as much as $34 billion over the next four years, reports say, although one Administration official, asking for anonymity, said the financing for such an extensive program was unlikely to be found. Another possibility is Federal encouragement or assistance for buying private insurance.
New York State recently announced a partnership with private insurers to make private long-term care policies available. The program, which would help many people avoid reducing their assets to qualify for Medicaid, follows a similar program in Connecticut and is being contemplated by other states.
At issue, though, is just how much of the job the private insurance companies can do.
In the last six years, more than 100 private insurers have rushed into what they see as a potentially enormous market. Since 1987, the industry has sold more than 2.4 million policies. Last year, the policies accounted for $1 billion in premium sales, up from virtually nothing a decade ago. And large companies and state governments are increasingly offering employees the option of buying the policies.
Although other major insurers like Aetna, CNA and Amex Life, an American Express company, have entered the field, the industry estimates that less than 5 percent of the elderly and 1 percent of the population have bought long-term care insurance.
 
Not a Pressing Thought
 In part, the reason is that even now, few people think about nursing care and home care until they approach retirement and the premiums for long-term care policies -- like some types of life insurance -- are far cheaper when the insured is younger.
The Health Insurance Association of America says the average annual premium charged to a 50-year-old by leading long-term-care companies was $852 in 1991. Such a policy pays $80 a day for nursing home stays, $40 a day for home care and offers increased protection to keep up with inflation at a compounded rate of 5 percent a year. For a 65-year-old person, however, premiums were roughly double.
By its estimate, some 60 percent of all elderly Americans can afford private policies. The Health Insurance Association said 61 percent of those with long-term insurance paid less than $1,000 a year for premiums.
But Ms. Polniaszek of the United Seniors consumer group in Washington says that the costs of long-term care insurance are prohibitive for the majority of Americans, even for those in their 50's.
A person 68 years old will pay on average $3,400 a year for a well-designed policy, according to her group's research.
"At several thousands dollars a year," Ms. Polniaszek said, "if you don't have much in the way of assets you could spend all your assets to protect your assets."
Ms. Polniaszek argues that the policies are advisable only for people with significant assets to protect: a minimum of $40,000 to $50,000 for individuals, more than $100,000 for a couple. (Medicaid will pay for nursing home care and still allow a married couple to protect half their assets, up to $70,000, for the spouse who does not need long-term care.)
 
Other Demands on Funds
 The cost of the same policy for someone 55 years old, she added, would be only $1,400 and should remain relatively low as the person ages. But even then, she said, most middle-age people worrying about college tuition and health insurance may find such a premium prohibitive.
A recent study by the Families USA Foundation, another Washington consumer group, said that policies that paid for two years of nursing home care were unaffordable to 81 percent of Americans from age 55 to 79 -- a figure that the Health Insurance Association bitterly disputes.
But other issues have also plagued the fledgling long-term care insurance business.
A study in June 1991 by Consumer Reports, for example, rated 94 policies and concluded that many of the policies included "traps" that should make consumers wary.
Trudy Lieberman, a senior editor of Consumer Reports, said that in visits with more than a dozen agents, she found they often did not warn customers that inflation could undermine the value of a policy. If inflation for care in the next quarter century matched that of the last 25 years, the effect on policy values, particularly for younger policyholders, could be devastating.
 
Adjusting for Inflation
 Some companies offer the option of having the amount of coverage grow at a rate of 5 percent a year on a compounded basis, but that option costs considerably more. Other companies allow consumers to purchase additional coverage every few years, a problem, Ms. Lieberman said, because the coverage becomes more expensive as the insured ages.
A related issue, Ms. Lieberman said, is the stability of rates. Although insurers say their rates in recent years have not risen significantly, consumer groups warn that insurers have the right to raise premiums in the future, which is not typical of other insurance coverage.
In addition, Consumer Reports expressed concern about restrictions that determine who is eligible to receive benefits. For example, some policies require that care be "medically necessary" because of sickness or injury. But many people who need custodial care may not have such a medical condition.
Perhaps an even more troubling question facing companies and consumers alike -- and one that may not be answered for decades -- is whether the actuarial assumptions underlying the new industry are correct.
Unlike life insurance, where more than a century of study has given insurance companies a highly accurate ability to predict death and calculate the cost of the insurance, the problem of predicting what nursing care costs will be decades in the future is, as yet, an unproven science.
 
Premiums Could Rise
 Those companies that charge premiums that are too low now to cover future costs could be forced to raise premiums suddenly in the future or could go out of business. Consumer Reports said that a third of the companies it rated in 1988 for long-term care policies were no longer selling those policies by 1991.


GRAPHIC: Long-term care policies typically cover services ranging from custodial through skilled nursing care. Some just cover stays in nursing homes; others pay for services at home. Some cover both.
Chart/Graph: "Aging and Higher Premiums"
 The average premium of leading long-term care companies for a 50-year-old was $852 in 1991, the Health Insurance Association of America says.  Graph shows dollar amounts of a basic plan, a basic plan with inflation protection, and a basic plan with a nonfortfeiture clause for 50, 65, and 79 year-olds.
 
Here are some tips, offered by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, on buying long-term care insurance:
 Check with several companies and agents. Compare benefits, the types of places you have to be in to receive coverage, the limitations of coverage, the exlusions and the premiums.
 Check the inflation benefits of policies to see what happens when nursing home costs rise.
 Check to see if there is a provision that allows you to stop paying premiums once you are in a nursing home.
 Check nonforfeiture benefits to see if you can get back some investment if you stop paying premiums.
 Don't be misled by agents who say your medical history is not important. In some cases, companies have used inaccurate of incomplete reporting of medical conditions to deny payments.
 Check the financial stability of the company you are considering. Among insurance rating services are A.M. Best Company (900) 420-0400; Moody's Investor Service (212) 553-1653, and Standard & Poor's (212) 208-1527.

HEADLINE: Aspin Tells Base Panel to Harden Hearts

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Signaling his support for closing more military bases than he recommended last week, Defense Secretary Les Aspin today urged a Presidential commission to resist efforts by lawmakers and local communities to spare their installations.
"Almost all bases that are going to be appealed to you will have a story to tell and a case to be made," Mr. Aspin said at the first hearing of the 1993 Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which will make the difficult decision. "If you buy into their criteria, you will agree to take that base off the list. Pretty quick you end up with no bases on the list at all." 
 The eight-member commission, set up to insulate Congress from angry constituents on such decisions, can alter the Pentagon's list by adding or subtracting bases. The panel must submit its final recommendations to President Clinton by July 1. Mr. Clinton, and then Congress, would have to approve or reject the entire package.
Mr. Aspin last week recommended shutting 31 large military installations and shrinking or consolidating 134 other depots and smaller sites. Mr. Aspin said that once the Pentagon spent $1.7 billion to clean up and close those installations, it expected to save $3.1 billion a year starting in the year 2000.
 
Following Bush's Lead
 This round of proposed closings, which has provoked an uproar among lawmakers whose districts would lose bases and thousands of military and civilian jobs, goes no further than bringing the number of installations in line with the cuts in troop levels made by the Bush Administration's final budget.
"Using the Cheney-Bush base force as the basis for this round means we're going to end up closing bases, but probably not enough," said Mr. Aspin, who later called his recommendations "modest," even though they are larger than the base closings in 1988 and 1991 combined.
Mr. Aspin said the Administration was beginning a comprehensive review to reduce military budgets and troop levels through 2000, but he told the commission that the review would not be finished until mid-summer, after the panel's deadline.
The comments by Mr. Aspin and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, suggested that the Pentagon would approve of more closings -- as long as it did not have to be the bearer of bad news. Shutting more bases would free money to protect troop levels and modernize weapons.
 
Panel to Visit Bases
 "If the commission were to find bases we don't need that were overlooked by the Defense Department process, I'm sure that would be looked on with favor," said one senior Pentagon official.
The commission's chairman, James A. Courter, a former Republican Congressman from New Jersey, said that commission members would visit the 43 large bases considered for closing or reduction and that 9 or 10 regional hearings would be held.
Mr. Courter said "not everybody is going to be happy with the results," but he said the panel's responsibility was to insure that everyone was "at least satisfied with the process under which we arrived at that result and those conclusions."
One obvious hot potato that Mr. Aspin dropped into the commission's lap was McClellan Air Force Base, which the Air Force proposed closing but which the Defense Secretary pulled from the final list, citing the "cumulative economic impact" on parts of Northern California already suffering from bases closed in previous rounds.
 
Take a Look, Take a Look
 McClellan is one of five big Air Force maintenance depots nationwide, and both Mr. Aspin and General Powell said the Air Force could afford only four now. "One of them has to go," said Mr. Aspin. But when commission members asked which one, Mr. Aspin smiled the smile of a salesman who has just sold a clunker to a patsy and said, "I'd urge you to take a look at that."
A senior Pentagon official said the next likeliest depot to close would be Hill Air Force Base in Utah.
Arguing for Mr. Aspin's choices, General Powell recommended that the commission "adopt the proposal in its entirety, or at least in the same quantity as the Secretary has noted after you have made your puts and takes."
Mr. Aspin, a former Wisconsin Congressman who headed the Armed Services Committee, expressed relief that he didn't have to make the final decision.
"I don't envy you, the work that you are undertaking today, but boy am I glad you're doing it," Mr. Aspin said.
That was clear in one exchange between Mr. Aspin and a commission member, Robert D. Stuart Jr., who asked why the same "economic impact" argument that spared McClellan Air Force Base -- Mr. Aspin said the impact of the base closing on that state's weak economy would amount to "piling on" -- was not applied to Charleston, S.C., where several installations are slated for closing.
"I just wondered whether South Carolina, for example, didn't have a little bit of the same piling-on implication," Mr. Stuart said.
Mr. Aspin replied, to laughter in the hearing room: "It's your choice, sir. The ball's now in your court. "

HEADLINE: Chinese Minister Denounces Britain

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 15

 BODY:
Prime Minister Li Peng accused Britain today of "perfidiously" trying to create disorder in Hong Kong and trying to impede the territory's smooth return to China.
Mr. Li used the occasion of a two-hour policy address, opening the annual session of the National People's Congress, to step up the attack on Britain's proposals to increase democracy in Hong Kong. His voice rising in outrage, Mr. Li departed from the advance text of his speech to warn that China would hold Britain fully responsible for the consequences of the dispute. 
 The speech also indirectly accused the United States and France of "having deliberately created obstacles to China's peaceful unification" by selling arms to Taiwan. While Mr. Li specifically referred only to "certain foreign elements" it was clear that he meant Washington and Paris. He also warned that China was ready to take "strong measures" -- apparently meaning full military force -- to prevent Taiwan from proclaiming itself an independent country separate from China.
Communist Party leaders have worked together for several months on the speech, which is equivalent to a state-of-the-nation address. It thus represents the views of the entire leadership, not just those of Mr. Li, and as such it is one of the best indications available of what vision the party has for China's future.
But this year the speech seemed to have more slogans than vision. While Mr. Li called for officials to "emancipate the mind" and hasten economic liberalization, he spoke in Communist cliches that undermined the message. "We should dare to think and act, boldly experimenting with new reforms, so long as we act with prudence," Mr. Li said, in a typically fuzzy passage. "We should evaluate our experience at every step, continuing to do what is right, correcting what is wrong and improving what is imperfect, so as to avoid losses, great losses in particular."
The speech affirmed China's current course, but its lack of vision underscored the extent to which the initiative in economic policy has passed from the central Government to the provinces. At a party this evening attended by many Chinese officials and business people, none of those questioned had bothered to listen to the speech. "Frankly, no one really cares," a businessman said, then changed the subject.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A Fast-Paced Sport's Fast-Paced Demise

BYLINE: By John Tierney

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
WHEN Bridgeport Jai Alai opened in 1976, its owners enthused about presenting the world's best players in the world's largest arena for the world's fastest game. Critics complained that it was making too much money. Today most of the seats are empty most of the time, and its owners are enthusing about tearing it down.
You can argue that all of this might have been foreseen: Who got the idea that Americans were dying to spend their evenings watching Basques in white pants throw a ball against a wall and chase it with baskets on their arms? But that's not quite fair, because the sport was never the point of it all, at least not in Bridgeport. 
 No, the chief purpose of jai alai was to enable citizens to turn over their betting money -- 18 percent at a time -- to politicians and promoters, and as a gambling diversion jai alai compares favorably with Americans' other options. Before you insult jai alai, try explaining the intrinsic excitement in watching horses, greyhounds, and roulette balls go around in a circle. Or the sheer thrill in seeing someone pick a Lotto number.
Somehow, though, the competition has done in the Bridgeport fronton. After the first season, attendance steadily declined as the novelty wore off, star players were lured away, and other gambling opportunities arose -- casinos in Atlantic City, more and more state lottery games. The problems were compounded in 1988, when the Spanish players went on strike and the fronton used inferior American substitutes.
"The strike crippled us," said Robert L. Beslove, the fronton's vice-president for public relations. "It lasted three years, the longest strike in the history of professional sports. By the time we settled it, the economy was in terrible shape, and that hurt us. Then came the last nail in the coffin, the Indian casino. The Indians killed us."
Mr. Beslove estimated that a quarter of the fronton's bettors have gone up the Connecticut Turnpike to the casino run by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe in Ledyard, which opened in February of last year. "I tell our customers the road to the Indian casino is paved with our tax dollars," he said, lamenting the tax exemptions enjoyed by the tribe. "Don't get me started on the Indians."
After reporting a loss of $1.5 million last year, the fronton's president, A. Robert Zeff, is hoping to abandon jai alai and beat the Indians at their own game. Together with Mirage Resorts, he has proposed tearing down the fronton and putting up the Bridgeport Sporting Club, a complex that would include a casino, greyhound track, hotel, shops, movie theaters, ice rink, and bowling lanes.
The prospects for that proposal are unclear, but the State Legislature has already given Mr. Zeff permission to build a dog track next to the fronton, which is on the Pequonnock River across from downtown Bridgeport. Plans call for construction of the dog track to begin in the fall, with the fronton to be closed and torn down as soon as the track opens.
So the fronton's future looks bleaker than the present, which is saying something. The scene on Friday night, when the weather was still clear, was fairly typical: 1,655 people in an auditorium built to hold 9,000, and some not even following the jai alai games. They were there to bet on the horse races being shown on television screens, a recent innovation that has increased attendance but provided the ambience of an off-track betting parlor.
There was a listlessness in the air much of the time, but every now and then the crowd roared at a particularly lovely shot soaring the 176-foot length of the court, and you could understand why some Americans are actually getting nostalgic about jai alai.
In the stands, when they were not grumbling about their losing bets, fans talked wistfully about the days before the crowds and the star players had left. Over and over they mentioned Francisco Churruca, the Basque who at age 40 was still the game's greatest player when Bridgeport opened. He retired in 1983 -- "I knew it was time to quit when my eyes were quicker than my legs" -- but has remained at the fronton as the players' manager.
"It will be very sad for me if this closes," Mr. Churruca said as he followed the action Friday evening. "When we opened, it was incredible. We had the best players, the people loved the game, and we could feel the excitement. Now we have lost that. The attendance is less, and I don't think the young players are as fully dedicated to the game. But we are trying to rebuild."
He and Mr. Breslove gazed at the empty seats. "I used to stand here in the '70's and look out at 8,000 people," Mr. Beslove said to Mr. Churruca. "You were up there catching it between your legs. I remember how you'd jump up the wall, catch it, and throw it before you landed. Well, we can't live in the past, I guess. But, boy, it was bedlam in here. You still had hair, too."

HEADLINE: School Board Challenges Aid Formula

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
New York City and the Board of Education sued the State of New York yesterday, charging that the state's school aid formula discriminates against city students and has cost city schools at least $274 million this year.
The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, comes as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Board of Regents, acknowledging inequities in the formula, are proposing separate plans to change it. But there is no guarantee that New York City would fare better under either of the two proposals, which are given little chance of passage in the Legislature. 
 City and Board of Education officials said they filed their suit in hopes of accomplishing what they expect the Legislature will not.
 
Inequitable Aid Formula
 The 50-page complaint says 37 percent of the state's public school students are enrolled in New York City, but the city receives only 34 percent of the state's education financing. That and other inequities, the suit argues, violate state education laws and the equal protection clauses of the Federal and state Constitutions and Federal civil-rights laws.
In one argument that appears to break new legal ground, the suit goes beyond earlier attacks on state educational formulas in New York and in other states by contending that the formulas are not only inequitable but racially discriminatory.
The New York suit argues that the state's public schools are "severely split between urban and suburban areas, between one world that is largely African-American, Latino, Asian-American and poor, and another that is largely white and prosperous."
By attacking racial and economic inequalities that have resulted from the division of New York into cities, where students are mostly poor and nonwhite, and suburbs where students are largely white and affluent, the legal action parallels a lawsuit now being tried by a state court in Hartford. The Connecticut lawsuit, however, asks a judge to rule that segregated conditions are unconstitutional, whereas New York City's action seeks fairer school aid formulas.
The New York suit names as defendants Mr. Cuomo, the State Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, the State Taxation and Finance Commissioner, James W. Wetzler, and the majority and minority leaders of both houses of the Legislature.
"For years, New York City, along with most of her sister cities in the state, have had to endure a state aid allocation system that has been grossly unfair to its schoolchildren," Mayor David N. Dinkins said in a statement. "With the filing of today's lawsuit, our city loudly and strongly notifies the State Legislature of its intent to not put up with this inequity any longer."
 
Similar Challenge Rejected
 O. Peter Sherwood, New York City's Corporation Counsel, whose staff drafted the suit, said that the State Court of Appeals, rejected a similar challenge to school financing formulas in a 1982 suit filed by the Board of Education of Levittown, L.I., holding that the state Constitution does not guarantee equalization of educational resources.
In the 11 years since the failed Levittown suit, however, the prospects for a similar suit have improved because the inequalities in the state's education formulas have worsened, Mr. Sherwood said.
Similar suits challenging state education formulas have been brought in New Jersey, Texas, Kentucky, Arkansas, Montana, West Virginia, Washington, Mr. Sherwood said.
"We have exhausted all of the political remedies to get our fair share of aid, with very little progress being made," Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said in a statement. "Our city's children have no choice but to seek the protection of the courts."
The suit does not demand a specific increase in state financing for New York City's schools. But Michael J. Petrides, Staten Island's representative on the seven-member Board of Education, estimated that the inequalities built into the formulas result in city schools being shortchanged by nearly $350 million a year.
 
$7.5 Billion Budget
 The Board of Education received 43 percent of its $7.5 billion annual budget for the present school year from state funds, said James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for Mr. Fernandez. The city financed 47 percent and about 10 percent came from the Federal Government, he said.
Because city students are mostly nonwhite, the suit says, the state consistently allocates less state aid to nonwhite pupils than to white pupils throughout the state.
Anne Crowley, Governor Cuomo's press secretary, said yesterday that the Governor had not seen the suit and would not comment on specific allegations. But she added: "The Governor has said repeatedly over the years that this is an inequitable formula and the Legislature should change it. And if the Legislature won't, maybe the courts should."
Asked about the timing of New York City's suit, Mr. Sherwood said it was filed yesterday because it only recently became ready for litigation after months of preparation. A Board of Education official, however, said that the filing had been timed to coincide with a new phase in the Board's annual lobbying campaign in Albany, which begins today.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Fall Again

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell again yesterday as traders and investors tried to gauge the impact of the unexpectedly large jump in producer inflation reported Friday and waited for tomorrow's release of data on consumer prices.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 12/32 , and the yield jumped to 6.89 percent. Earlier in the day the price had been off a full point, with the yield up to 6.93 percent. In the last two trading days, the price of the bond has fallen almost a point and three-quarters, and the yield has leaped from 6.76 percent. 
 Prices of notes also fell yesterday, but not as much. The discount rates on three-month and six-month Treasury bills rose to their highest level since early January at the weekly auction yesterday.
A sharp rise yesterday in the closely watched Commodity Research Bureau Index of commodity prices, another barometer of inflation, added to concern. And there was selling by portfolio managers who decided that the inflation data were an excuse for them to take profits after a strong rally that pulled the yield on the 30-year bond down from its 1993 high of 7.47 percent on Jan. 12 to 6.72 percent, its low, on March 8.
 
Is Rally Over?
 It is not clear yet if the rally is over, or simply pausing. But even if the rally has ended, analysts are not predicting that long-term interest rates will rise sharply, because the basic fundamentals for low interest rates are still in place. These are moderate growth, contained inflation and prospects that President Clinton will be successful in cutting the Federal budget deficit. So forecasters say the yield on the 30-year bond should rise only to 7 percent or a little higher.
"I don't think rates are going up a whole lot or going down a whole lot," said Glenn E. Murphy, chief investment officer at the Travelers Asset Management International Corporation in Hartford.
Mr. Murphy has sold 10-year Treasury notes recently because "the pendulum of sentiment had swung past the equilibrium point." But he said his decision was tactical, not a change in sentiment. "I am looking for a re-entry point," he said. "I am bullish for two or three points on the price. And that is essentially what we have given up since the peak."
While inflation is worrying investors, it is not from concern that the rate of price increases is suddenly skyrocketing. Instead, it is a worry that an earlier assumption -- that the rate of inflation will decline this year -- will not be borne out.
The Consumer Price Index rose 3 percent last year and some analysts have said they think that this year it could slow to around 2.5 percent or even lower. One of the reasons for this forecast is that the rate of increase in unit labor costs is being held near zero because of gains in productivity.
But other analysts argue that the January increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index and the four-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Producer Price Index reported Friday does not fit with an inflation rate falling below the 3 percent level for the year. And the concern yesterday was that the Consumer Price Index for February will confirm this view tomorrow.
 
Decisions to Make
 What is happening now is that investors and traders are being forced to reconsider the expectations about inflation. They can decide that everything will be O.K., either by concluding that inflation will move lower or that a 3 percent rate should not get in the way of a move of long term rates to levels like 6.5 percent.
For this to happen, however, investors will probably have to get some support from other data and developments. For example, if the economy appears to have slowed slightly in the last two weeks of February, which some data have indicated, this could provide some comfort. A slower economy means there is less chance for prices to move higher.
Investors could also get support from progress on President Clinton's deficit reduction plan.
If the Consumer Price Index for February is higher than expected, then this reconsideration will be more difficult. According to a survey by Bloomberg Business News, forecasters expect an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent. For the first two months of the year, that would mean an average increase of four-tenths of a percent, which at an annual rate equals 4.8 percent. To get the rate to 3 percent would take average increases of around two-tenths of 1 percent for the rest of the year.
Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, still expects inflation to decline this year so he predicts that long-term interest rates will continue to fall.
He also said he would not worry about the recent surge in the Commodity Research Bureau index unless it broke through 225. The index ended yesterday at 210.19, up 2.40.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction yesterday of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Nike's Quarterly Profit Exceeds Estimates

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Whether it was because of Michael Jordan leaping from one planet to the next, Andre Agassi wearing fluorescent colors to pummel tennis balls or Bo Jackson doing almost anything, Nike made a favorable impression, with a 8.4 percent earnings increase for the fiscal third quarter.
Nike, one of the world's leading marketers of athletic footwear and apparel, said yesterday that sales growth in the United States shoe market helped raise earnings to $89.5 million, compared with $82.5 million in last year's third quarter. 
 Investors reacted favorably to the report, sending Nike shares up $4.625, or 6.4 percent, to $76.375, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
But several analysts who follow Nike expressed a bit of skepticism over the market's reaction, noting that Nike warned analysts last month that third-quarter results would be lower than previously forecast.
The fact that the results turned out better than the gloomy predictions probably contributed to the bullish response in trading yesterday, and some analysts said they expected Nike's stock to give back a significant portion of its gains when trading resumes today.
"Their earnings were really no surprise," said Gary M. Jacobson, who follows the stock for Kidder, Peabody. "They were modestly above recently revised lower expectations."
The earnings report also indicated soft growth in foreign sales, which were up only 4 percent after five previous quarters in which foreign sales had grown between 19 and 49 percent.
The analysts attributed the decline to the exchange rate of the dollar and to economic sluggishness and even recession in Europe, Nike's largest foreign market. European retailers slowed their orders of Nike products for the quarter.
But Nike said in a statement that orders for athletic footwear and apparel scheduled for delivery between now and July had increased 21 percent, to $1.65 billion, a figure that would have been as high as 26 percent, the company said, had the exchange rate for the dollar remained unchanged from a year ago.
"We are especially pleased by the strength of our U.S. footwear business, which grew 15 percent, our strongest quarter in two years," Philip H. Knight, Nike's chairman, said in a statement. "Solid increases in basketball, outdoor, cross-training and women's categories account for most of these gains."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trading Is Mixed; Gold Prices Up in New York

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly mixed yesterday in listless trading as dealers turned their attention to events, including this week's economic data.
Gold for current delivery rose $1.30 from Friday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, settling at $329.30 an ounce. The Republic National Bank gave a late price of $329.25, up $1.25. 
 The successful completion an agreement to distribute the cost of German unification among government, business and labor, lent the dollar some underlying support on speculation that it gives the Bundesbank the leverage to cut rates at its council meeting on Thursday.
While Helmut Schlesinger, president of the German central bank, has said rate moves will not be decided by specific events, dealers said the poor state of the German economy, potential volatility in the European Monetary System and easier German money market rates pointed to a rate cut this week.
Dealers said a rate cut was already largely priced into the dollar, so few are predicting a big rally if the Bundesbank does act.
Dealers said they were also looking forward to the British budget announcement today, American consumer price data tomorrow and the French elections next weekend.
The dollar ended at 1.6631 marks in New York, down from 1.6640 on Friday. Earlier in London, the dollar ended at 1.6635 marks, down from 1.6655 on Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar ended at 118.18 yen, up from Friday's 117.85. In London, it rose to 118.34 yen from Friday's 117.70. The dollar rose to 118.65 yen in New York, versus 118 on Friday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4327, from $1.4350 on Friday. It firmed in New York to $1.4350, up from $1.4337 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday, included: 1.5230 Swiss francs, up from 1.5181; 5.6540 French francs, down from 5.6550; 1,606 Italian lire, down from 1,607, and 1.2476 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2444.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Storm Brings a Price Surge For Citrus, Sugar and Hogs

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 15

 BODY:
Orange juice, sugar and pork futures soared today amid concerns that severe storms over the weekend had damaged crops and hog farms, analysts said.
On other commodity markets, wheat, coffee, cocoa and lumber futures advanced. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities, a widely followed gauge for inflation, closed above the 210 level for the first time since June. 
 Crude oil for April delivery closed 13 cents lower at $20.16 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heating oil for April delivery finished 0.92 cent lower at 57.28 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline ended 0.54 cent lower at 58 cents a gallon.
Orange juice for delivery in May rebounded sharply amid worries about damage to the citrus crop in Florida, which ranks second among the states in orange juice production. But initial reports from Florida indicated that groves sustained only minimal losses, analysts said.
Below-freezing temperatures during the weekend did not affect the crop, but the high winds that trailed the storm blew 5 percent to 7 percent of the fruit off the trees, a spokesman for the Florida Department of Citrus said.
May orange juice closed 3.20 cents higher at 78.10 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Sugar for delivery in May extended recent gains, fueled by worries that shipments from Cuba, the world's third-largest producer of sugar cane, would be disrupted because of storm damage to ports, analysts said.
May sugar closed 0.95 cent higher at 11.50 cents a pound, after setting a life-of-contract high at 11.85, at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
Livestock traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange pushed pork futures higher after reports of storm-related damage to hog farms in North Carolina, an important pork-producing state, analysts said.
Live hogs for delivery in April closed at $49.07 per hundredweight, up $1.18. Pork bellies, or uncured bacon, finished at $49.25 per hundredweight, up $2, the most the contract is permitted to gain in one session.
Wheat futures led soybeans and other grain futures higher at the Chicago Board of Trade in response to the Agriculture Department's report on Friday that it would donate 520,000 metric tons of wheat and 87,000 metric tons of rice to Russia under the Food for Progress Program. The donation was valued at $102 million.

HEADLINE: Colorado Agency's Top Yield Is 5.60%

 BODY:
The Platte River Power Authority, Colorado, tentatively priced $149.6 million of electric revenue and power refunding revenue bonds yesterday with a maximum yield of 5.60 percent, which is for a serial bond due in 2008.
Yields on the remaining serial bonds ranged from 2.60 percent for a bond due in 1994, to 4.3 percent in 1998, 5.10 percent in 2003 and 5.50 percent in 2007. For investors in a 31 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent yields of these securities range from 3.77 percent in 1994 to 6.28 percent in 1998, 7.39 percent in 2003 and 8.12 percent in 2008. 
 Underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company said the financing would refund debt previously sold when interest rates were higher.
The debt is rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
MIKE WALLACE is lending a hand to his old school, Brookline High School, at a benefit -- unusual for a Massachusetts public school -- in New York tomorrow evening. Mr. Wallace, class of '35, will interview the school's acting headmaster, Dr. ROBERT J. WEINTRAUB, at a cocktail party that is expected to draw 60 or so Brookline graduates to the University Club on West 54th Street.
The purpose is to help meet the $150,000 goal of a yearlong campaign tied to the 150th anniversary of the school. 
 "We are in the midst of a financial crisis," Dr. Weintraub said yesterday. "We have had major cutbacks and have lost 13 percent of our staff over the last four years."
The year is being bracketed by two celebratory weekends -- one last June, one this June -- that include class reunions. Last year's event brought more than 2,000 graduates back to the school, including Mr. Wallace, Alan Rachins, a star of "L.A. Law," and former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and his wife, Kitty.
"Brookline was a superb place to grow up, and the school was always good, so we are trying to raise dough for a variety of activities that go beyond the basic curriculum," Mr. Wallace said yesterday.
Dr. Weintraub seemed unperturbed by the prospect of being interviewed by the usually hard-hitting "60 Minutes" correspondent. "I deal with The Brookline Citizen, the local weekly, on a regular basis, so I am prepared for Mike Wallace," he said.

HEADLINE: Computers Make People More Employable;
Training Holds Key

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jeremy Rifkin speculates that the Clinton Administration's 36-page plan to rejuvenate the economy by spurring high-tech industries "runs the risk of creating a new and dangerous America -- one in which a small high-tech elite of corporate professionals exist in a nation of the permanently unemployed" (Op-Ed, Feb. 24). 
 One can certainly argue that this small high-tech elite already exists. Is the question then that this elite group will become smaller? Will it have more political clout? Undeniably, there are social and economic dangers in high-tech madness, but is it fair to characterize all high-tech industry as socially irresponsible and elitist? All technology, high and low, suffers from the trickle-down syndrome, and society must come to terms with the uses of technology.
To say that new technologies are beginning to force a reorientation of the job market, with no new jobs waiting for the displaced worker may oversimplify. Perhaps Mr. Rifkin underestimates the ability of Americans to compete in the high-tech job market. Retraining the work force can be effective if it is a "training" program. Industry, high- and low-tech, and Government agencies need to take the steps to insure that employees are adequately trained for jobs, whether they are semiskilled, clerical or support staff.
Most professionals would rather have a personal assistant than be tied to their personal computer. Properly trained staff members with computer-friendly systems will keep a clerical staff employed and result in a more skilled clerical work force. The problem is not that technology is forcing a decline in the need for clerical workers, but that their training is often inadequate. Let us not neglect the potential of the semiskilled and clerical worker to participate in high-tech industry.
 
SHEILA MACHADO
Medford, Mass., Feb. 28, 1993
 
The writer is a graduate student in urban studies at M.I.T.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Computers Make People More Employable;
Where the Jobs Are

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jeremy Rifkin's atavistic reasoning (Op-Ed, Feb. 24) is reminiscent of the labor riots in the 19th century at the start of the Industrial Revolution. Workers feared permanent displacement by machinery. 
 Many living Americans remember when unions fought to lower the workweek to 60 hours. Today the average workweek is 40 hours, with a much higher standard of living. More leisure industries have been created, employing millions of workers.
While a strong defense posture is still a sine qua non, it must be commensurate with the perceived threat, plus a safety margin. However necessary our military spending is in this highly volatile world, such spending is inflationary since it diminishes the product available for resale.
The Pentagon should not be used as a make-work employment facility. The two strongest creditor countries, Japan and Germany, have spent less than 1 percent of gross domestic product on defense since World War II, whereas we, the largest debtor country in the world, have been spending about six times as much.
We are a long way from having a dearth of necessary projects in this country requiring the full spectrum of skilled, semiskilled and unskilled workers. Our decaying infrastructure will require hundreds of billions of dollars and millions of construction workers for the next 10 to 20 years.
We have a crying need for millions of low-priced dwelling units. In New York State alone, there are 240,000 applicants for low-cost housing. At the present pace of construction it will take 20 years to fill this void. This should be speeded up for completion in five years, putting hundreds of thousands back to work. There are similar needs throughout the country.
The Clinton Administration intends to add 100,000 to our country's police forces. This could be doubled if we are to make a serious dent in combating crime. The bulk of the added police should be drawn from the discharged military personnel. The transition from the military to police work should be relatively simple.
Upgrading our second-rate educational system will put back to work thousands of teachers forced to take semiskilled and unskilled employment, thus opening replacement opportunities for the unemployed.
We can further technological innovation, the key to raising living standards, while creating millions of low-tech jobs for health care, housing and energy conservation. Our country is decades from filling all our job requirements.
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
New York, Feb. 24, 1993
 
The writer has served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Why Italy Finds Itself In a Peculiar Position

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Don't Blame Fate. Blame the Italians" (Op-Ed, March 9) by Enzo Biagi, instead of merely reinforcing a stereotype image of Italians, should have explained that corruption scandals in Italy were also caused by: 
 * The peculiar position of Italy during the long cold war: halfway between the free West and the totalitarian East. The first illegal contributions to the Italian parties were made by the United States to "defend" the country from Communism. The Soviet Union and its satellites financed the Italian Communist Party to undermine democratic institutions.
* Italy's peculiar economic structures: Half owned by the state and nearly half by a small group of powerful individuals, with little room for competition. Within this restricted environment of welfare state and false capitalism, kickbacks and bribery were easier than anywhere else in the West. At the same time, the Italian Communists shared the benefit of the same political and economic system that they preached to destroy.
* The peculiar nature of the current political crisis, marked by arrests, convictions and suicides, but also by a strong willingness of judges, citizens and a new breed of politicians and entrepreneurs to clean house and start with new political and economic rules.
 
ROBERTO PESENTI
U.S. Bureau Chief, Il Messaggero
New York, March 9, 1993

HEADLINE: Avoid a Bloodbath in Haiti;
Declare A Deadline

BYLINE: By Jean-Bertrand Aristide; Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the President of Haiti, is author, most recently, of "Theology and Politics."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Last summer, Haitians hungering for democracy were filled with hope when candidate Bill Clinton declared that the U.S. should "use its unique position to support freedom, whether it's in Haiti or China."
Today, I will discuss with President Clinton the plan initiated by Haiti's constitutional Government and endorsed by the U.S., U.N. and the Organization of American States. It can convert his moving words into an effective policy to "support freedom" by restoring the democratically elected Government, ending more than 17 months of bloody dictatorship and bringing a solution to the refugee crisis that takes my fellow citizens' lives. 
 Through international cooperation, we have already seen the deployment, under U.N. auspices, of the International Civilian Mission to Haiti to stop human rights violations and to facilitate the swift return of our constitutional Government.
Despite the thousands of deaths and cases of torture and arrest, the Haitian people continue to make clear that there is no alternative to the restoration of the Government they elected. That sentiment is palpable from the remotest rural hamlet to the heart of Port-au-Prince.
The cornerstone of our plan is for the U.S., working with the U.N. and the O.A.S., to set a date certain for the restoration of the elected Government -- to specify the day when democracy will be re-established. That and only that will convince the coup regime that the international community will not tolerate its unlawful and violent usurpation of power.
The solution to Haiti's crisis is not elusive. Visas of the leaders and financiers of the coup regime can be annulled and their international assets frozen. Instead of simply blockading Haitians inside the country, the U.S. could use its Navy to make the economic embargo effective, stopping the delivery of all oil and weapons. The democracy embraced by Haitians will endure if the international community remains firm.
The events of recent weeks remind us that this climate of liberty has yet to be reached. The vicious attack on Bishop Willy Romelus after funeral services for victims of last month's ferry disaster and the subsequent mass arrests and beatings of church worshipers plainly refute any assertions that the small U.N.-O.A.S. presence has already succeeded.
Bishop Romelus was beaten in front of members of the International Civilian Mission. Mourners at the funeral, fearing identification by the military and its collaborators, put bags over their heads and were escorted to the safety of the cathedral by diplomats and other foreign officials. Even so, several young people vanished into the detention centers to face torture and other ill-treatment. It is evident that the widespread terrorism in Haiti necessitates a larger number of observers than are now present.
With each passing day, the Haitians languishing in Guantanamo desperate to go home move closer to death.
We must act quickly. The intensifying violence, in open defiance of the International Civilian Mission, is a test of the international community's resolve. If the world fails to respond, it is not only Haiti that perishes but the hopes of all nations that in this new world order, democracy -- at all costs -- will be cherished.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Drug Makers Propose Self-Control on Prices

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Under strong criticism from President Clinton that has sent drug stocks tumbling, the pharmaceutical industry last week formally offered to limit average price increases to the general inflation rate.
Similar moves have already been announced by Merck & Company, Pfizer Inc. and eight other large drug companies. 
 While attempting to stave off the Government controls advocated by their critics in Congress and the Administration, the drug companies appear resigned to end more than a decade of extraordinary profits. In the last four years their pretax profits were five times as high as those of other industries and their sales rose 50 percent, to $55 billion in 1992.
 
Managed Competition Backed
 In statements to White House and Justice Department officials, the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group in Washington, also endorsed a national system of managed competition among large purchasers, which could force drug makers as well as hospitals and doctors to roll back prices for products and services. And it urged the Administration to add a comprehensive drug benefit to the Medicare program for 30 million elderly and disabled Americans.
Under the voluntary plan, each company's pricing would be checked by outside accountants and submitted for review to the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the General Accounting Office of Congress. If a company exceeded the price limit, it would have to make up the excess by lowering prices the next year.
The association said the proposal was based on the assumption that market conditions would be stable and Government policies would support "innovation" in drug research.
 
Monitoring Called Difficult
 But drug industry critics in Congress and economists familiar with White House health-care plans said the industry plan would be hard to monitor and enforce and would not help most elderly people, who must pay for drugs themselves.
"I am skeptical about any voluntary effort by the pharmaceutical industry to restrain their prices," said Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California and chairman of the House energy and commerce subcommittee on health.
President Clinton recently blamed the drug makers for helping to make health care unaffordable for many Americans. And a study for Congress said last month that the industry had made "excess profits" of more than $2 billion a year.
Several pharmaceutical stocks dipped yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after an upward bounce last week. Merck was down 50 cents, to $38.625; Eli Lilly lost $1, closing at $50.75, and Johnson & Johnson was off 12.5 cents, to $43.50. Pfizer was unchanged at $62.125 and Bristol-Myers Squibb gained 37.5 cents to $57.625.
 
An Interim Arrangement
 The association offered its proposal as an interim arrangement that would expire if a national health-care system were enacted.
It said the price average would reflect discounts and rebates, which are already provided to large buyers and state Medicaid programs. But industry analysts said the averaging would leave the door open for continuing price increases in pharmacies. About 40 percent of drugs are bought by people with no drug insurance.
Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who has criticized drug pricing as head of the Senate Committee on Aging, said any voluntaryagreements would have to lower prices "for the average cash-paying buyer of medications."
Drug company executives say their prices are based on benchmarks that include the number of potential users, the return on investments in research, the number of years of patent protection remaining and the product's advantage over existing therapies. Unique new drugs usually are priced high from the start.
Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, chairman of Merck, said that when a new drug is medically superior, "we would like to have a price somewhat higher than what is out there."
 
High Risks, High Costs
 Drug companies say they have to charge stiff prices to pay for costly research that often leads nowhere.
"We have the highest risks of any industry I know," Dr. Vagelos said. "We are betting on things that may or may not mature and become available to the public in 10 or 15 years. That has to be rewarded."
But the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment insisted last month that "in recent years the financial rewards from R.& D. have more than offset its costs and risks."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 17, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about drug prices misstated an increase by Pfizer Inc. for its heart drug Procardia XL. The increase on Feb. 1 was 4.5 percent, in line with Pfizer's voluntary limit on price increases in 1993.
