HEADLINE: 'Year of Unity' for Weary Europe Is Splintered by Public Uneasiness

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, March 11

 BODY:
For most of Western Europe, 1993 -- the year the European Community was finally supposed to come into its own as the world's largest free-trade market -- has started off badly, with a dispiriting recession, a spate of scandals and the most serious loss of self-confidence in 20 years.
In almost every European country, polls show that ordinary people no longer believe in the parties that have dominated politics since World War II, concluding that they are not up to the new challenges of the post-cold-war era. The consensus of a decade ago in Britain, France and Germany has been replaced by seemingly endless bickering and near-paralysis. 
 The contrast with the apparent rejuvenation brought about by President Clinton has struck many European politicians and commentators, who see in him traits that they do not see in their own leaders: boldness, decisiveness, most of all an ability to solve problems that have stumped everybody else.
 
Different Strokes
 Though success for Mr. Clinton is by no means assured, European leaders say they have been impressed by the way he has shaped the debate on his deficit-reduction plan, mobilizing support across the political spectrum.
If Mr. Clinton succeeds in even a few of his endeavors, the respected French editor Andre Fontaine wrote in Le Monde, Europeans would do well to emulate "the amazing shot in the arm he is giving to the United States and, and the same time, to democracy."
The contrast between the public images of Mr. Clinton and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany could not be greater, and not just because the President is 46 years old and the Chancellor is nearly 63. What is most telling to the Germans is the contrast between the ways the two men have shaped the national debate in each country over the need to sacrifice.
The view in Germany is that Mr. Clinton asked almost all Americans above the poverty line to make sacrifices to reduce the soaring budget deficit and got a favorable reception because the requests seemed fair.
Mr. Kohl also asked for national sacrifice to pay the unexpectedly overwhelming costs of reunification, estimated at close to $1 trillion over the next decade and a half.
But, largely because he began by proposing cuts in welfare and unemployment benefits just as steelworkers and others were losing their jobs at a record pace, the debate in Germany has degenerated into a clash between poor and rich, between western German haves and eastern German have-nots.
According to recent polls, Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic-Free Democratic coalition, re-elected with a handsome majority in 1990 when unification seemed like a dream just come true, would not be returned to office if there were an election today.
A survey in January by the Allensbach Institute found that 48 percent of the 2,264 people questioned were concerned that politicians could not handle the country's most serious problems, and 53 percent were worried about the spread of far-right extremism.
Much of the public doubt has come from the Government's seeming inability to do anything about a flood of asylum-seekers from the Balkans and elsewhere. Last year, when nearly 450,000 arrived, some right-wing extremists took the law into their own hands, killing 10 Germans and 7 foreigners in more than 2,200 attacks.
 
While the Politicians Talk . . .
 After bickering with one another for years about whether a change in the country's Constitution was necessary to stem the influx of asylum-seekers, the coalition parties and the Social Democratic opposition agreed late last year to eliminate the constitutional guarantee of asylum.
But the change is still being debated in Parliament, and 74,350 more asylum-seekers poured in during the first two months of this year.
Just the exhaustion of being in power too long may be another reason for Western Europe's demoralization.
French commentators say President Francois Mitterrand, who is 76 years old and has held office since 1981, is trying to distance himself from the major defeat his Socialist Party is expected to suffer in this month's legislative elections.
The Conservative Party, which has been in power in Britain since 1979, has become deeply divided over whether it wants to be in on the stalled movement toward greater European unity.
The biggest corruption scandal in the postwar history of Italy has gravely weakened the Christian Democrats and Prime Minister Giuliano Amato's Socialists, who between them have governed the country since World War II. Mr. Amato has won a string of votes of confidence in Parliament only by threatening to resign and force the major parties into new elections.
 
The Drain in Spain
 The Socialists who have ruled Spain since 1982 are hanging on to power by their fingernails, and polls indicate that they will lose the next elections, which are due before October. The Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez must answer for corruption scandals that have riddled his party, and the Spanish economic boom of the late 1980's has turned to bust, with rising inflation and high unemployment.
Indeed, the most important reason for the demoralization of Europe may be the recession, which is steadily deepening here just as the United States has finally begun to pull out of it.
One major reason is that Germany, which all its partners thought would pull them along into a boom after unification in 1990, has slumped.
Bankers and opposition politicians all agree that the slump was caused by a jump in Government and private borrowing to finance the unexpectedly high costs of unification, forcing the Bundesbank to raise interest rates to prevent inflation.
 
In the Depths of Debt
 According to a recent report by Smithers & Company, a British financial consulting concern, the German Government deficit, officially estimated at 3 percent of gross national product, or $58.8 billion, is actually higher -- perhaps 8 to 9 percent of G.N.P. when borrowing by Government agencies like the railroads and the postal service are considered.
Western Germany will have to subsidize the East for decades with $60 billion to $80 billion a year, according to estimates here. Mr. Kohl's Government will have to raise taxes to provide the money, and investment funds will be scarce for years to come.
[On Monday, leaders of Germany's major political parties reached a consensus on the need for a 7.5 percent income-tax surcharge in 1995 to pay part of the cost of unification. They decided that cuts in welfare and unemployment benefits would not be necessary but left many details unsettled.]
With all the European economies now tied closely to one another, slow growth in Germany means a long and painful period of recession elsewhere in Europe. Some countries are beginning to feel that they are having to do just what Mr. Kohl assured them in 1990 that they would not have to do -- pay for Germany's unification.
Shimon Peres, the Israeli Foreign Minister, said today at the end of a visit to Bonn, "We don't share the German pessimism about Germany."
But, he said, with the collapse of Communism, the West had lost an enemy and gained a set of new problems, and "it's more complicated to solve a problem than it is to deal with an enemy."

HEADLINE: Oregon Health Plan Stalled by Politics

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 16

 BODY:
Marina Anttila, an unemployed mother of three, still has no health insurance even though she lives in Oregon, a state that long ago came up with a plan to provide medical care for all its citizens.
The problem is that the Oregon plan has been snagged on the shoals of Presidential politics. The Bush Administration rejected the proposal last summer. This week, President Clinton is to decide what do with the Oregon proposal -- the first attempt by a state to provide broad coverage through rationing of medical procedures. 
 If the White House approves it, Ms. Anttila and thousands of other Oregonians who currently have no insurance would be eligible for health care. For the rest of the nation, the decision could set the tone for the Administration's universal health-care proposal, which it is scheduled to disclose this spring.
As a candidate, Mr. Clinton promised to quickly approve Oregon's plan. But his position was at odds with an influential children's advocacy group whose board members included, until three months ago, Hillary Rodham Clinton, the President's health-policy chief.
 
Slicing a Small Pie
 The state was not planning to substantially increase Medicaid spending, said the advocacy group, the Children's Defense Fund. In effect, in the group's view, a small pie of benefits would be sliced even thinner and distributed among more people.
Approaching the Friday deadline for the decision, aides to the President and Mrs. Clinton say there is no dispute in the First Family. Both Clintons support the gist of the Oregon plan, though they are not prepared to say what the final decision will be, White House officials said.
A central element of the Oregon plan is a ranking by the state of all medical procedures, ranked by a cost-benefit formula. That system has drawn intense criticism because it rations care, limiting coverage to procedures ranked above an arbitrary point on the list. As currently proposed, 568 of the 688 procedures listed would be covered. Others, considered too costly and beneficial to only a few people, like operations for people with terminal illnesses, would not be covered.
Even the harshest critics of the plan say Oregon has done a service by trying to sort out which procedures are important to most people and which ones are dragging down the system with high costs and little benefit.
 
'Send a Message'
 "This may be the most important decision made by the Clinton Administration because it will send a message about which way they are going to go on health care," said Robert Griss, a health-policy analyst for the United Cerebral Palsy Associations, and a leader of the groups opposing the Oregon plan.
Indeed, as most attention has been focused on the health-care tour of Mrs. Clinton, a huge lobbying effort has centered on the Oregon decision.
Formally, the decision will come in a response to Oregon's request to waive the Medicaid laws. What Oregon is trying to do is cover all citizens who do not have health insurance but make too much money to qualify for the Medicaid program, which is financed by Federal and state funds. In most states, Oregon among them, Medicaid only covers about half of all the people who are living near the poverty line.
The Oregon list would also be the basis for a minimum level of coverage, which all employers would have to provide their employees by 1995.
 
Focus on Shalala
 The waiver decision will be made by Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Like Mrs. Clinton, Ms. Shalala was a board member of the Children's Defense Fund.
Through a spokeswoman, Ms. Shalala said today that Oregon's plan had been changed substantially from the version the Children's Defense Fund opposed, another hint that the Administration may go along with Oregon's plan. In one change, Gov. Barbara Roberts, a Democrat, promised last week that for the first two years no one now receiving health benefits would have those benefits reduced.
A major legislative opponent, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California and chairman of a committee overseeing Medicaid, said on Friday that he would no longer try to block the Oregon plan. He said he remains opposed to it, but that enough changes had been made that he would not try to stop it.
Mrs. Clinton met on Friday with Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, who has been trying to lay the groundwork for approval.
"She was particularly interested in the relevance of Oregon's plan to a national health-care proposal," Mr. Wyden said. "Mrs. Clinton did not give a yes or no on the Oregon plan, but the overall tone was encouraging. I'm very optimistic we will get the waiver."
 
What the Critics Say
 A spokesman for Mrs. Clinton, Lisa Caputo, said the First Lady is not ready to say how much of Oregon's or any other plan would be used to shape the Administration's proposal.
Opponents of the Oregon plan say it is a radical break with the past, and that it is unfair to the disabled, people with terminal AIDS and others. "I think every medically necessary service should be covered by our health-care financial system," said Mr. Griss of the cerebral palsy group. "I think it would be a terrible mistake to break with what is now the best health system in the world."
When President George Bush rejected the proposal in August, he cited opposition by groups representing the disabled. They objected because the list of procedures covered was based, in part, on a telephone survey of Oregonians and their values about health care. But that survey has been thrown out and the list has been revised.
Some care and procedures that were not covered -- intensive care for extremely low birthweight babies, liver transplants for alcoholics suffering from cirrhosis, some stages of terminal AIDS -- are now covered. By changing the list, which was initially drawn by computers but has since been through subjective review, Oregon officials have satisfied many opponents.
"We used to be neutral, but we have taken a formal position in favor of it," said Janna Starr, executive director of the Arc of Oregon, which represents mentally retarded people. "There is a lot of misinformation about this plan. It does not shortchange the developmentally disabled."
 
Governors Take Stand
 Last month, after President Clinton urged the states to experiment with health-care plans, the National Governors Association passed a resolution urging Federal approval of the Oregon waiver.
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton was unequivocal in his support of the plan. On several visits to Oregon, he criticized President Bush's rejection.
"If I were President, I would give the waiver to them in a heartbeat because I think they deserve it," Mr. Clinton said last May. But he also expressed reservations about the rationing system, saying it might not work for the rest of the nation.
The wait for a Presidential decision has angered Ms. Anttila in Portland. "I had hoped to have health care by the first of the year for my family," she said. "But now it has taken so long that it is getting very frustrating."

HEADLINE: China Raises Military Budget Despite Deficit

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 16

 BODY:
The Government today announced a 15 percent increase in the military budget for this year, adding to a series of increases in military spending that is alarming neighboring countries.
Although China no longer faces a major threat on its borders, its military budget is almost double the figure for 1988. Other Asian countries fear that China is trying to intimidate its neighbors and resolve longstanding boundary disputes in its favor. More fundamentally, some diplomats suggest, China is trying to fill a vacuum in the Pacific after the collapse of the Soviet Union and the withdrawal of United States forces from the Philippines. 
 Chinese officials made no attempt today to justify the increase in military spending. But on Monday, Prime Minister Li Peng told the National People's Congress that China needed to turn the three-million-member army into "the best armed forces that China's conditions permit." Without citing any threats, Mr. Li said the army must "constantly increase its combat effectiveness and defense capabilities under modern warfare."
The spending figures were included in a budget speech today by Finance Minister Liu Zhongli to the congress, a rubber-stamp parliament that is meeting in its annual session. Mr. Liu said the military budget was 42.5 billion yuan, or $7.4 billion. That compares with military budgets of 37 billion yuan last year and 21.5 billion yuan in 1988.
Military spending increased even though Mr. Liu released figures indicating that by Western accounting methods the budget deficit grew to $19.8 billion, or 27 percent of revenues last year. Other areas like education, culture and health care increased much less than military spending.
In fact, the publicly announced military budget includes just half of all military spending, experts say. It does not include money spent on acquiring new equipment, on weapons research or on relocating and supporting retired officers. Those amounts are disguised in other areas of the budget. In addition, the military has other substantial sources of income, including arms exports and the sales of the refrigerators, radios, clocks and other civilian items made by military-owned factories.
Even so, total military spending probably accounts just only a bit more than 3 percent of the gross national product, a smaller share than in many other countries. Other Asian countries are nervous largely because China has boundary disputes with at least seven neighbors and has lately been aggressive in pressing its claims.
Diplomats and other military experts say among the improved weapons that China is building or obtaining from Russia or other countries are fighter planes, surface-to-air missiles, destroyers, frigates, tanks and radar equipment. Chinese documents also say the country will acquire an aircraft carrier.
Distressed by suggestions abroad that China is becoming a threat, officials in Beijing have mounted a vigorous counteroffensive. "Recently, some people in Western countries have deliberately spread slanderous rumors that China is building up its national defense to a level 'seemingly beyond a capability for defense,' " the official New China News Agency complained a few weeks ago.
Mr. Li referred to such analyses in a meeting last month with former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and added, "All these fabricated rumors and absurd tales are totally ridiculous."
The New China News Agency asserted last week that critics of increased military spending here were "simply unhappy that there is no chaos in Asia, and they are trying to drive wedges among the Asian nations."
One Chinese official cited inflation as a factor in the rising military spending. But according to official statistics, retail prices rose less than 7 percent last year, and they have increased 32 percent since 1988, the same period in which the military budget has increased 98 percent.
Sympathetic diplomats, usually from countries that are not adjacent to China, also say it is natural for a country to increase its military spending as its overall economy grows.

 BODY:

 The Air Force made illegal payments to McDonnell Douglas in 1990, a Pentagon official says in testimony prepared for a House hearing today. He is expected to recommend disciplinary action against three generals and a former procurement official. [Page D1.] 
 Volkswagen named Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the former purchasing chief for G.M., as its No. 2 executive. [D1.]

The Economy

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Advance in Price

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose yesterday after a little help from the Federal Reserve. But all eyes were really looking ahead to today, when the Labor Department releases the Consumer Price Index for February.
That report may help settle the question of whether the current rate of inflation is low enough for a continued decline in longer-term interest rates, or whether inflation may be higher this year than some have anticipated, which could slow or even halt any decline of long rates below their recent lows. 
 The price of the 10-year note jumped 18/32 , as the yield dropped to 6.87 percent. The price of the 30-year bond rose 8/32 , and the yield slipped to 6.87 percent, from 6.89 percent Monday.
Matthew Alexy, a government trading strategist at the First Boston Corporation, said that a lot of the activity was traders getting into a neutral position before the C.P.I. release. This meant that traders who were short, or who had sold Treasury securities in anticipation of a decline in price, bought some yesterday.
According to Bloomberg Business News, the consensus forecast for the C.P.I. in February is a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent. That would follow a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in January. The January increase was a surprise but was dismissed at the time because part of the rise was attributed to special factors.
But since then, the February jobs report, released March 6, showed that the economy was stronger than expected. This has put much more focus on the inflation rate because a lot of investors who have been buying Treasury securities have assumed that the rate of consumer inflation will decline toward 2.5 percent this year, below 1992's 3 percent.
The help from the Federal Reserve yesterday was the central bank's buying of short-term and intermediate-term Treasury notes, in what is called by traders a "coupon pass." The Federal Reserve regularly does such buying when it wants to add reserves to the banking system to prevent normal seasonal flucuations in the demand for money from making its monetary policy too restrictive. The coupon pass was expected; the timing was a little of a surprise.
In a separate development, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York asked for reports from primary dealers on the trading of the current five-year Treasury note because of a possible squeeze.
 
Bond-Payment Vote
 Voters in Brevard County, Fla., yesterday decided by a narrow margin to stay in a controversial government office complex in Viera, choosing not to default on a $23.9 million bond issue to pay for the complex.
The results should have a calming effect on the $65 billion market for certificates of participation, a kind of tax-exempt municipal bond for which the principal and interest payments have to be appropriated on a annual basis. The C.O.P.'s are controversial in Brevard County because they were used to avoid a general vote on the bond issue for the new office complex.
The threat of a community voting to default on such an issue had raised the yield or cost for such issues recently by as much as 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
The referendum was in two parts. First the voters were asked if they wanted to stay in the office complex. If they said yes, they were asked if they wanted to retire the controversial certificates of participation by issuing general obligation bonds. A recent study by the board of commissioners said retiring the old bonds with new ones would lower costs for the county because interest rates had declined so much since the sale of the original certificates of participation.
According to the supervisor of elections, the vote for staying in the office complex was 46,290 to 43,017, and the vote against refinancing with general obligation bonds was 47,930 to 38,270.
The vote was a victory for the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, which spent more than $370,000 -- or about 90 percent of all the contributions reported -- in an effort to persuade the voters not to default on the $23.9 million bond issue the company has insured.
According to reports filed with the supervisor of elections, M.B.I.A. contributed $361,600 in cash and $12,375 in other contributions for a total value of $373,975. The contributions went to three organizations that are in favor of the county remaining in its office complex in Viera and, therefore, not defaulting on the bonds sold in 1989 to pay for the offices.
Most of the contributions went to the Brevard Taxpayers Association. The B.T.A. received $240,000 in cash and $8,625 of in kind contributons from M.B.I.A. An additional $70,000 in cash and $1,875 of in-kind contributions went to the Melbourne-Palm Bay Political Action Committee. And $51,600 in cash and $1,875 of in-kind contributions went to the Cocoa Beach Area Chamber of Commerce. The contributons are through March 11, the last date the organizations could accept money for the campaign on the referendum, unless they continue as permanent groups after the election.
Michael C. Ballinger, a spokesman for M.B.I.A., said that the donations were made in response to requests from groups "attempting to educate voters on this very emotional issue." He said that the total amounts to a little less than $1 per registered voter.

HEADLINE: A New Breed of Hired Hands Cultivates Grass-Roots Anger

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
The era of electronic vox pop, when radio talk shows help drive out a prospective Attorney General, has meant boom times for at least one species of Washington insider: consultants who deliver populist rage.
Consider Bonner & Associates, which occupies an entire floor of one of Washington's pricier office buildings. From a distance it looks like the boiler room of any telephone sales company, with fresh-faced young men and women in narrow cubicles reading intently from typed scripts. 
 But these operators are not pitching Veg-O-Matics or life insurance. They are prospecting by phone for that most elusive of Washington commodities, the hometown pressure points that representatives or senators are loath to resist.
This company is among a new breed of Washington firms that has turned grass-roots organizing techniques to the advantage of its high-paying clients, generally trade associations and corporations.
Unlike old-fashioned letter-writing campaigns, which rained easily identifiable form letters on lawmakers, the new campaigns are sometimes intended to appear spontaneous. Jack Bonner, who founded Bonner & Associates in 1984, says he always lets his targets know of his activities. But the rise of this industry has made it hard to tell the difference between between manufactured public opinion and genuine explosions of popular sentiment.
Or as they put it in the lobbying industry: is it grass roots or Astro Turf.
 
The Zoe Baird Case
 The real thing helped bring down President Clinton's first choice for Attorney General, Zoe Baird, when thousands of angry citizens, apparently without the benefit of outside encouragement, called their members of Congress to complain about her hiring of an illegal immigrant couple as a baby sitter and driver, and her failure to pay the helpers' social security taxes
But Bonner Associates specializes in seizing on unformed public sentiment, marshaling local interest groups and raining faxes, phone calls and letters on Congress or the White House on a few days' notice. Some competitors rely more on a retail approach. They phone potentially irate citizens, deliver detailed briefings and then transfer the newly aggravated callers directly to the office of the relevant senator or representative.
"The golden age of grass roots has arrived," Mr. Bonner said. He has mobilized public opinion against limits on credit card interest rates when he was working for the banks, against tougher fuel efficiency standards when he was on the side of the auto makers, and against triple-trailer trucks when he was hired by a railroad.
Mr. Bonner reports a surge in potential clients in the last two to three months. "In the past," he said, "a lot of businesses wouldn't go to the grass roots because they thought they could contain their problems in D.C., either by lobbying or by George Bush vetoing anti-business legislation. Well, that veto isn't there any more."
 
Technique Is Developed
 Through the early 1980's, environmental groups and others on the fringes of the Washington establishment relied on letters, petitions and other manpower-intensive methods to counter the power and connections of big corporations.
But by the end of the decade, specialists like Mr. Bonner, as well as several Washington political consultants and lobbyists, had begun to co-opt the strategy, a trend that gathered even more momentum when Ross Perot and Bill Clinton tapped into the electronic babble of dissent that is talk radio and television.
"What some of these trade organizations are asking now is: How do we find these Perot-type people and get them to speak out on our issue?" said R. Nancy Clack, vice president of a political consulting company called The Clinton Group, which has been operating since the 1960's and has no ties to the current Administration. "How do we fit into this talk-radio democracy?"
Jeff Eller, director of media affairs at the White House, who is one of the Clinton Administration officials responsible for keeping a finger on the public pulse, said he had a practiced ear for detecting stage-managed campaigns. Mr. Eller said that on an average day, 65,000 people weigh in by telephone with their opinions about President Clinton's economic plan, and another 700 a day use computers to send electronic mail.
 
'From the Heart'
 "You can tell if you listen to the phone calls and read the mail which is preprogrammed and which comes from the heart," he said. "If a bunch of phone calls saying the same thing come in at the same time, you know."
Or do you?
Ms. Clack said The Clinton Group used computer data banks to identify people with specific leanings. Her company generally works for Democrats and can set in motion a wave of sincere, unscripted phone calls.
The technique, called "patch through," works like this:
Say, for example, the National Organization for Women opposes a nomination to the Supreme Court because the candidate has an equivocal record on abortion rights.
The Clinton Group will take the membership rolls of the group, and match names to phone numbers. It might also use its computer to cross-reference magazine subscriptions, data on personal purchasing habits, and precincts with particular voting and income profiles, to come up with a bigger list of sympathetic people.
 
Computer Dialing
 At the company's phone bank in Louisville, Ky., a computer dials the numbers. When someone answers, an operator comes on the line and explains NOW's position, offering to transfer the caller, at no charge, to the White House switchboard or local member of Congress.
"Progressive groups have got to do this," Ms. Clack insisted. "The right wing doesn't. They've got the Christian Broadcasting Network, the 700 Club and about 1,200 radio outlets. All they do is print a press release, read it on the air."
The quality of this kind of briefing is crucial. Mr. Bonner, 44 years old, who was a political aide to the late Senator John Heinz, a Republican from Pennsylvania, employs as many as 200 "issue junkies" to explain matters to a local business or interest group. He often asks the people he called to call him back after they are through talking to their Congressional office, to test whether any unforeseen questions arose.
Mr. Bonner's 12,000-square-foot offices occupy an entire floor, through which he walks with the pride of a high-tech craftsman. He shows off the million-dollar phone system, which can keep 300 lines humming at once, and walks a visitor past rooms of phones.
 
Methods of Enlistment
 Mr. Bonner tries to enlist local people. Sometimes it is a straightforward matter of getting local bankers or small businessmen to call their Congressman. Other times the connection is a bit more oblique, like the time he persuaded local handicapped groups to attack proposed fuel efficiency standards for auto makers. (Smaller cars would be arguably harder for handicapped people to get into.)
His services do not come cheap. A campaign aimed at a handful of lawmakers on a subcommittee could cost in the tens of thousands of dollars, but one trade association in an uphill fight on the Senate floor paid $3 million for a single month's work.
Prodding of public opinion, whether by talk show hosts or Washington experts, has touched off its own backlash and complaints that the reborn democratic spirit is being subverted.
"Give me a break," Mr. Bonner replied. "Most communications to the White House or the Hill are prompted. Whether by the Sierra Club, the National Rifle Association or the American Association of Retired People is not the point."
At the White House, the switchboard has already been equipped with that favorite high-tech wrinkle of corporate America: the voice mail system, which allows callers to register views by pressing numbers on phones.
"Thank you for calling the White House; we appreciate your call," intones a man's voice. "If you would like to make a comment or express your opinion, please press one now."
There's not a lot of room for nuance. "Do you support or oppose the President's economic program," the message begins. The next three selections allow voters to assess the Clinton plan for its size of deficit reduction, cuts in Government spending and the fairness of the tax burden proposed for upper income taxpayers. In each case, the choices range from "too far" to "not far enough" to "about right."
Callers are invited to talk with an operator if they have further thoughts.

HEADLINE: Wider Investment Tax Credits Urged

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
A council of experts that Congress and President George Bush had appointed to recommend ways of increasing the nation's competitiveness called today for broader investment tax credits than President Clinton proposed, a stepped-up program to spur exports, and a revamping of the nation's high schools.
In a report, the council of business, labor and government officials praised President Clinton's economic package but said stronger measures were needed to increase investment. 
 "The United States continues to face major competitiveness problems," the Competitiveness Policy Council said, pointing to the nation's huge trade deficit. "The problem has been developing for two to three decades. It cannot be solved overnight."
The panel called for a permanent investment tax credit on equipment, saying the President's proposal for a temporary two-year credit does not go far enough. The council also said that the tax credit on research and development should be expanded to include research into improving manufacturing processes.
Viewing exports as a way to create high-wage jobs, the report urged the Administration to increase export credits to $20 billion a year to help American industry compete against foreign rivals. That would be an increase from $12 billion at present and would involve an annual outlay of about $1.2 billion to subsidize interest. France spent $1.99 for every $1,000 in nonfarm exports in 1990, the report said, while the United States spent 59 cents.
"The United States really lags behind in export finance," said C. Fred Bergsten, chairman of the council and president of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research group. The council also includes Rand V. Araskog, chairman of ITT; John J. Murphy, chairman of Dresser Industries; Edward V. Regan, a Republican who is Comptroller of New York State; Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, and Lynn R. Williams, president of the United Steelworkers of America.
Giving low marks to the American education system, the council recommended developing nationwide performance standards, a uniform nationwide high school transcript and increasing the importance of school records for colleges and employment. The council complained that high school students had little incentive to do well because employers paid scant attention to how well they did in school.
"Our high school students perform far worse than their counterparts abroad," the report said. "Twenty percent of our adults are functionally illiterate. A country cannot compete effectively unless its human resources are world class, and ours are falling toward the bottom of the league."
 The report said the Government should provide financial rewards to schools and districts that achieve high standards. It also said aid to colleges should be linked to raising their admission standards.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mark Time in More Light Trading

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Traffic on the stock exchanges yesterday seemed to move as cautiously as on the nation's icy roads, with the major market averages virtually unchanged in slow-motion trading.
Investors were fretting about today's consumer price report, traders and strategists said. The stock market's recent gains to record levels have been built on the bond market's strength, which could crumble on clear signs of inflation. The low yields available on bonds and other interest-bearing investments have prompted investors to seek higher returns from stocks. 
 Yesterday, the bond market's brightness after several gloomy days helped the utility stocks, which are sensitive to interest rates. But medical issues, up a bit lately, resumed their downward course.
 
Dow Up 0.54
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose just 0.54 point, to 3,442.95. The Standard & Poor's 500 was fractionally lower, the Nasdaq fractionally higher and the American Exchange index up by a hair to a record. Big Board volume of 218.8 million shares, though up from Monday's 195.9 million, was still light.
Analysts' metaphors seemed to outnumber trades. "The market was very goosey, very itchy, very nervous," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisors.
Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News estimate that consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in February. After producer prices came in higher than expected last Friday, investors are especially alert for evidence that the economy's expansion is reviving inflation.
"People are saying, 'Whoops, I'm going to wait for more evidence to come in to reinforce some of the market themes I was confident about three weeks ago,' " said Robert Heisterberg, global policy analyst at Alliance Capital.
 
Some Could Benefit
 Today's number could move some stocks much more than others, perhaps even in different directions. Cyclical issues stand to benefit from indications of economic strength, analysts said, even if inflation rises mildly.
Nancy Lazar of the International Strategy and Investment advisory firm was one of several strategists who said that any damage from today's report would be only momentary. "Even if tomorrow's number is bad, there seems to be plenty of evidence that there is downward pressure on prices," she said, citing stable gold prices and labor costs.
Among the market's shiniest sectors yesterday, the Dow Jones utility average of electric and natural gas companies rose 1.19, to 237.79, led by Consolidated Natural Gas, up 7/8, to 47 7/8. Many telephone stocks continued their gains, with Ameritech up 1 3/4, to 76 1/4, and BellSouth up 3/4, to 55.
 
 
 
SECONDARY LIFT

 
For all the recent enthusiasm about heavy-industry stocks, the Nasdaq composite index has quietly gained about twice as much as the Dow over the last several weeks. The Nasdaq biotechs have stablized somewhat and the computer issues have rebounded, leaving the Nasdaq index less than 2 percent below its Feb. 4 high.

HEADLINE: War on Ice Uses Sun And Muscle

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
An army of shovel-wielding laborers fanned out across New York City yesterday to liberate sidewalks, intersections, fire hydrants and catch basins from the icy snow left by the weekend blizzard.
Aided by rising temperatures, more than 800 laborers hired by the Sanitation Department at about $8 an hour smashed and scooped and pushed to clear the way for pedestrians and motorists. 
 "It's a little strenuous, but if you're physically fit, it's easy to deal with," said Fred Sanders Jr., 26, as he and two other men muscled through the thick sheets of ice covering the corner of 135th Street and Lenox Avenue in Harlem.
"This is pretty much my backyard here," he said, pointing toward his apartment two blocks away. "I like to keep my backyard clean for other people."
Like nearly all his fellow laborers, Mr. Sanders, a veteran of the Persian Gulf war, is unemployed and learned about the job from the radio and newspapers.
 
'Just Chipping It Out'
 His partner, Michael Tillman, 32, an unemployed chef who lives in Harlem, agreed. "I had nothing to do," he said. "I was bored sitting at home. Maybe if I do something for the city, they'll do something for me."
Emily Lloyd, the city's Sanitation Commissioner, said the department was relying on the laborers, who should number about 1,000 by today, because its more than 1,700 plows and salt spreaders were running into so many difficulties removing the snow.
"This is going to be a day-by-day dig-out," she said, noting that the department last hired day laborers after the blizzard of 1983. "We're really just chipping it out a piece at a time."
Most of the laborers were men, but a few women signed up.
"This is for the community and for safety," said Brendina Ellington, 25, of Harlem. "And it's something for me to do to earn a little extra money. I can fulfill the needs as good as a man can because I'm not lazy."
Pedestrians slogging through the mounds of sludge applauded the laborers.
"We've had a lot of trouble because we can't get across the ice," said Evelyn Telbrot, 60, who walks with a cane. "But now that they're cleaning it up, nobody will fall."

HEADLINE: Rise in Starts Only 2.5% for New Homes

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments rose moderately in February, the Commerce Department said today, though not enough to recover from a sharp January slump.
 The annual rate of starts of new homes increased 2.5 percent in the month, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.21 million units. That modest upturn came after a revised fall of 8.4 percent in January, which was larger than than the 7.2 percent decrease previously reported by the department. 
 The gains in February construction were widespread, with only the South reporting fewer starts of new homes. But over all, the February starts level was 6 percent lower than the seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.29 million units in the month a year earlier.
 
Strengthening Is Seen

Analysts expect housing to strengthen however, helped by mortgage rates that are at the lowest level in two decades despite edging up last week after nearly three months of declines. Last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rates inched up to 7.47 percent from the previous week's 7.44 percent.
 Sales of new homes had weakened sharply in January after rising strongly in the second half of 1992 as the economy began growing once more. Housing is still expected to be a source of strength in the relatively sluggish expansion.
 Federal Reserve banks across the country, surveying the economy last week in the Fed's periodic "beige book," report, cited "almost universally positive" reports about home sales and construction prospects.
 Today's report showed that construction of single-family homes declined eight-tenths of a percent in February, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.05 million units, after falling 6.4 percent in January. New apartment-building construction jumped 33.3 percent, to an annual rate of 156,000 units, after dropping 23.5 percent in January.
 
Permits Decline
 Applications for permits to build new homes and apartment buildings dropped in February for a second straight month, down 3.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.14 million units. Permit applications fell 1.7 percent in January.
 Permits for single-family homes fell in February by 4.1 percent, to a 956,000-unit rate, after a 4.5 percent decline in January. Permits for apartment buildings rose to 188,000 from 183,000 in January.

HEADLINE: Bank Yields Mostly Down For Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by banks on money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the week beginning today are down slightly compared with the previous reporting period, with the New York market only a little off the pace of the downticks recorded at 20 major banks nationwide.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest-rate publication in North Palm Beach, Fla., the average New York market yield for a six-month certificate of deposit remained unchanged compared with a decline of 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, in 20 major banks across the country. The average decline in a money market account was the same in New York as it was across the county. 
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, where rate fluctuations are often the harbinger of trends in deposit rates, bills were sold with higher discount rates than the previous week. The rate for a three-month bill rose 2 basis points, to 3 percent, while the rate for a six-month rose 3 basis points, to 3.12 percent.
In The Bank Rate Monitor's latest survey, the average New York area money market account is down about a basis point, to 2.58 percent, with certificates of deposits unchanged at 2.69 percent for a three-month maturity and 2.9 percent for a six-month maturity.
For the third consecutive week Chase Manhattan Bank was named among the New York banks posting the sharpest changes in deposit rates this week. The bank raised the yield on both its three-month and six-month certificates of deposit, with a three-month up by 25 basis points, to 2.63 percent, and a six-month up 26 basis points, to 2.69 percent.
National Westminster Bank lowered the yield on its money market accounts 10 basis points, to 2.53 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks were down a little more sharply when compared with the New York market; an average money market account slipped 1 basis point, to 2.56 percent, and a six-month certificate of deposit dropped by 2 basis points, to 2.89 percent.

HEADLINE: KITCHEN BOOKSHELF;
Irish Food That Won't Turn You Green

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
IRISH food gets but an annual nod in America, on St. Patrick's Day, like the fruitcake at Christmas. It's no wonder, given the inevitable plates of gray stew or sodden cabbage with corned beef. Food like that does not begin to reveal Ireland's invitingly rustic culinary soul.
Consider instead, for starters, pristine oysters sparkling on a bed of seaweed with slices of earthy hearth-baked brown bread spread with hand-churned butter and accompanied by glasses of rich, dark stout. Other possibilities: Crusty, butter-browned triangles of potato bread with bowls of pleasantly peppery wild-nettle or watercress soup, thick cuts of poached fresh salmon, casseroles of sausages with potatoes and onions, and desserts drenched in cream. 
 Ireland boasts a peasant cuisine based on the wealth of superb fresh ingredients that come from its rich soil and surrounding seas. Mussels, oysters, prawns, salmon, potatoes, carrots, greens, lamb, beef, butter, cream, oats, apples and berries are used frugally among people haunted by memories of famine.
This year, Irish cooks and writers have produced an appealing crop of cookbooks to explain it all.
THE FESTIVE FOOD OF IRELAND by Darina Allen (Roberts Rinehart, $12.95), a slender volume decorated with color photographs, paintings of food and Celtic motifs, is a fine primer. The author, who runs the cooking school started by her mother, Myrtle Allen, at Ballymalloe House in southern Ireland near Cork, covers the essential highlights of the cuisine according to a calendar of holidays. She also examines the lore and legends surrounding the culinary traditions.
Thanks to the Broadway drama "Dancing at Lughnasa," some Americans now know that in addition to St. Patrick's Day the Irish celebrate Lughnasa (the word is pronounced LOO-nuh-sah) to mark the beginning of the harvest. That holiday, as well as St. Bridget's Day, May Day, Threshing Day and Michaelmas, are among the 14 that are given lively descriptions, often from the author's childhood memories, each accompanied by a few apt recipes.
Reading instructions like "mash them straight away" for the potatoes that go into fadge, a deliciously savory potato bread, you can sense the author at your side.
At the same time, even though this is an American edition of the book, no alternatives are offered for ingredients like Bramley cooking apples (dry-textured apples), sultanas (golden raisins) and demerara sugar (brown sugar). Ms. Allen, who welcomes an American clientele to her school, must know that such terms are unfamiliar in the United States.
A certain comfort in the kitchen is also necessary to execute recipes that do not specify whether onions are to be sliced or chopped to make a soup nor give step-by-step details on how to fashion pastry. As for the plain brown soda bread, it required nearly twice the four cups of buttermilk listed in the recipe. (Half the flour might have been better still.) But recipes for boxty pancakes, fadge and poached salmon with Irish butter sauce worked fine.
IN AN IRISH COUNTRY KITCHEN by Clare Connery (Simon & Schuster, $32) takes a more encyclopedic approach, nearly exhausting the repertory with its 150 recipes. In addition to exploring Ireland's culinary traditions, the author -- a home economist, food consultant, chef and broadcaster in Belfast, Northern Ireland -- provides a detailed overview of Ireland's history, farming and fishing.
The plodding prose, which lightens up when recipes are described, is no match for the glorious color photographs of the countryside and dishes sizzling on a hearth or arrayed on a farmhouse table.
But mining the recipe sections yields a trove of things like silky carrot soup smoothed with butter, rabbit stew bolstered with English mustard, crusty parsnip cakes and excellent scones and oatcakes.
A TRIFLE, A CODDLE AND A FRY , subtitled "An Irish Literary Cookbook," by Veronica Jane O'Mara and Fionnuala O'Reilly (Moyer Bell, $18.95), presents gastronomic profiles of 20th-century Irish writers. The authors live in Dublin and share an avocational interest in food.
Relying on anecdotes and excerpts from the works of 11 writers, they have cobbled together mini-biographies describing the writers' personal tastes and quoting from food-related passages in their works. The 11 include James Joyce, Samuel Beckett, Sean O'Casey, Bernard Shaw and Elizabeth Bowen, as well as some less prominent figures like Oliver St. John Gogarty and Mary Lavin.
Most of the recipes, some of which are forced companions to the literary portraits, were written by the two compilers. Their descriptions of how much their families enjoy this or that dish, often in the third person, add a jarring, pretentious note to an otherwise charming concept that succeeds best in the chapters on Joyce, that author of food-filled works, and George Moore, a gastronomic snob.
The recipes are a mixture of the good, the odd and the out of date. Rarely do they come from the literary figures themselves, not even from Molly Keane, who has produced a cookbook. And scales are required, since measurements are usually given by weight rather than volume. But the result can be worth the effort, especially for the simple but lush chocolate cake iced with melted candy bars and the apple duff (said to be a favorite of Joyce and his wife, Nora Barnacle Joyce), which consists of apples stuffed with raisins and baked in excellent pastry made with a touch of wheat germ.
Finally, a tiny gem, HOW TO MAKE A PERFECT CUP OF COFFEE (Stone Street Press, $3), is one of the many engaging hand-printed books that Malachi McCormick, an Irish author and calligrapher who has written books about Irish food, produces at his press on Staten Island. The 20-page booklet, covered in textured, speckled paper that suggests whole wheat, describes a variety of ways to select, grind, store and prepare coffee. The only recipe, at the end of the book, is a simple one for Irish coffee.
The author's exacting standards -- remember, he's writing about perfection -- are illustrated by an anecdote about an acquaintance who has the right equipment but the wrong tastes and by the fact that no mention is made of decaffeinated coffee. They can be summed up in this line: "Coffee will get no better than when it's just made."
 
Apple Duff
 
Adapted from "A Trifle, a Coddle and a Fry"
 
Total time: 1 hour 30 minutes
 
 1 1/2 cups flour
 1/2 cup wheat germ
 1 teaspoon salt
 6 ounces (1 1/2 sticks) cold unsalted butter, in small pieces
 1/3 cup cold water (approximately)
 4 medium-size apples
 4 tablespoons light brown sugar
 1/2 cup raisins
 Cinnamon to taste
 1 beaten egg
 Whipped cream or heavy cream (optional).
1. Sift the flour into a bowl and mix with wheat germ and salt. Cut in the butter using two knives or your finger tips, until the pieces are the size of peas. (This cutting can also be done by pulsing briefly in a food processor.)
2. By hand, lightly stir in most of the water and mix until the ingredients cling together to form a dough. Add water if necessary. Turn the dough out onto a floured board, knead briefly until smooth and cut it into four equal pieces. Shape each into a round patty.
3. Peel and core the apples, scooping out the core well but not cutting through to the bottom.
4. Mix the brown sugar, raisins and cinnamon together, and fill the apples with this mixture.
5. Preheat oven to 400 degrees.
6. Roll out the portions of dough on a floured board to form circles about 8 inches across. Put an apple in the center of each and brush the edges of the dough with some beaten egg. Draw the pastry up around the apples to enclose them completely and press the edges together to seal. Brush the outside of the pastry with the remaining beaten egg and put the pastry-wrapped apples on a baking sheet.
7. Bake about 40 minutes, until golden brown. Serve warm with whipped cream or heavy cream.
Yield: 4 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving (not including cream): 715 calories, 40 grams fat, 145 milligrams cholesterol, 560 milligrams sodium, 10 grams protein, 85 grams carbohydrate.

Carrot Soup
 
Adapted from "In an Irish Country Kitchen"
 
Total time: 1 hour 30 minutes
 
2 tablespoons butter or vegetable oil
 1 large onion, sliced thin
 1 clove garlic, crushed
 1 pound carrots (about 4 large ones), peeled and sliced
 3 1/4 cups chicken or vegetable stock
 Sprig of fresh thyme, sprig of parsley and bay leaf, tied together
 Pinch of ground mace
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 2/3 cup half-and-half or light cream
 1 tablespoon finely chopped parsley
 1 cup freshly fried croutons.
1. Heat the butter or oil in a large saucepan. Add the onion, garlic and carrots. Cook over low heat until the onions are soft but not brown, about 10 minutes.
2. Stir in the stock and add the herbs and mace. Season with salt and pepper. Bring to a boil, lower heat to a simmer, cover and cook until carrots are very tender, 45 minutes to 1 hour.
3. Puree the soup in a blender or food processor; then force it through a sieve into a clean saucepan. Stir in the half-and-half, and adjust the seasoning if necessary. Bring to a simmer, and serve with parsley and croutons sprinkled on top of each portion.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving (using butter): 175 calories, 10 grams fat, 25 milligrams cholesterol, 260 milligrams sodium (before salting), 5 grams protein, 15 grams carbohydrate.

Fadge
 
(Potato bread)
 
Adapted from "The Festive Food of Ireland"
 
Total time: 1 hour
 
 2 pounds Yukon gold or other boiling potatoes
 1 egg, beaten
 7 tablespoons butter, softened
 1/2 cup flour
 1 1/2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley, chives or lemon thyme, or a mixture of them
 1 to 2 tablespoons whole milk
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
1. Put the potatoes in a saucepan, cover with water, and boil until tender. Drain, peel and mash in a bowl.
2. Stir in the egg, 3 tablespoons of the butter, 3 tablespoons of the flour and the herbs. The mixture should hold its shape but not be too stiff or dry. Add a little milk if necessary. Season well with salt and pepper.
3. Put the potato mixture on a work surface, knead it briefly, and flatten it into a round about an inch thick. Cut it into eighths.
4. Spread the remaining flour on a dish and season with salt and pepper.
5. Just before serving, dip each potato piece in the flour to coat lightly. Grease a griddle with some of the remaining butter or melt the butter in a large, heavy skillet, preferably cast iron. Fry the pieces of fadge over medium heat, about 4 minutes on each side, until crusty and browned. Serve at once.
Yield: 8 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 220 calories, 11 grams fat, 55 milligrams cholesterol, 115 milligrams sodium (before salting), 4 grams protein, 30 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: Save Nafta. But Don't Roll Over.

 BODY:
During the Presidential campaign Bill Clinton talked tough, vowing to hammer out bold protections for the environment and U.S. workers before he would approve the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada. At the time, his demands sounded like potential deal-busters. Now he's facing up to the difficulty his campaign rhetoric poses for completing negotiations on the trade pact.
In Congressional testimony yesterday the President's chief trade negotiator, Mickey Kantor, took a tougher stance than he did the week before. But the proposals he outlined were cautious, even timid. Negotiations on final details begin today with the Mexicans and Canadians; if Mr. Clinton doesn't stiffen his demands, Nafta might run into trouble among Congressional Democrats. 
 Mr. Clinton is under pressure from environmentalists, labor and industry groups to win additional concessions from Mexico and Canada. But the pact signed by President Bush is sound at the core. By knocking down tariff and other trade barriers, Nafta would lower prices for hundreds of millions of consumers and help Mexico solidify its pro-market reforms.
It would protect U.S. workers from surges of Mexican imports. It is the most environmentally sensitive trade pact ever negotiated -- protecting U.S. standards against easy challenge. And while U.S. businesses will continue to move to Mexico, the flow should not rise much above current levels.
Yet there are areas where the agreement comes up short. It would provide no long-term funding to clean up polluted border areas. Nor would it force improved environmental codes and working conditions -- though in general the three countries have set high standards.
The glaring problem is Mexico's appalling record of enforcing standards. Here Nafta won't help much, because it provides no sanctions against a country that persistently violates its own environmental and labor laws. Lax enforcement becomes a trade issue when it permits companies to produce at lower costs, which can be passed along to customers as lower prices.
Mr. Kantor has offered useful, if incomplete, ways to address the problem. He's called on Mexico to give citizens easier access to courts to challenge environmental violations. He has also called for trilateral commissions to negotiate better environmental and labor standards and trigger investigations of alleged violations.
But what if a country consistently violates its own laws? In yesterday's testimony Mr. Kantor refused to say whether the commissions should levy trade sanctions. Such sanctions raise tricky issues of sovereignty. Is the U.S. prepared to have sanctions applied to companies because an international tribunal finds them guilty of polluting the air over Los Angeles or hiring illegal aliens?
Trade sanctions can also ignite protectionist maneuvers: businesses would be tempted to trump up charges against a foreign competitor in the hope that a tariff would be imposed on its exports.
Though tricky, these problems are solvable. Gary Hufbauer and Jeffrey Schott of the Institute for International Economics would allow panels to impose sanctions -- but apply them to all exports from the offending country, not just those from the offending companies. That way, companies from, say, the U.S. would gain little by bringing frivolous charges against Mexican competitors; yet Mexico would still be pressured to correct the violation because thousands of innocent exporters would feel threatened by across-the-board tariffs.
Nafta is a good deal for the U.S. even without improvements. And it would be a foreign policy blunder to let it die. Fortunately, the Administration seems well aware of the stakes. Still, there's room to get tougher without busting the deal.

HEADLINE: Northern Irish Talks Must Include Sinn Fein;
MacBride Principles

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your March 9 interview with Prime Minister Albert Reynolds of Ireland on the eve of his visit to the United States says that the MacBride principles "seek to discourage American investment in Northern Ireland companies that are deemed to discriminate against the Roman Catholic minority in the province." 
 The Irish National Caucus -- with the blessing of Sean MacBride -- initiated the MacBride principles in November 1984. The first thing we stated was that they do not call for disinvestment or divestment, reverse discrimination or quotas. The MacBride principles -- a nine-point set of fair employment, affirmative action principles -- seek to encourage United States companies not to be part of the pattern of anti-Catholic discrimination in Northern Ireland.
Since the MacBride campaign began, it has proved to be the most effective effort against anti-Catholic discrimination in Northern Ireland. The principles have been passed into law by 13 states; and more than 40 cities have passed or endorsed them.
The British Government acknowledges it spends millions of dollars in the United States to combat the MacBride campaign. Too bad it doesn't spend that much trying to create jobs for oppressed Catholics in Northern Ireland.
 
(Rev.) SEAN MCMANUS
Washington, March 9, 1993
The writer is president of the nonviolent, nonsectarian Irish National Caucus, which does not support any group or party in any part of Ireland.

HEADLINE: Paul C. Barkley, 63, Ex-President of Airline

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: EL CAJON, Calif., March 16

 BODY:
Paul C. Barkley, an early advocate of low-cost air fares who weathered deregulation as president of the old Pacific Southwest Airlines, died of cancer on Monday. He was 63.
Mr. Barkley joined the airline in 1967 as vice president of finance and became president in 1979. He retired as chief executive in April 1989 after helping to negotiate the sale of the company to USAir. 
 He once said that the most difficult year for Pacific Southwest was 1978, when deregulation of the airline industry was announced, clearing the way for his company to fly outside California. It was also the year that a Pacific Southwest jet collided with a private plane over San Diego, killing 144 people, including 37 employees of the airline.
After retiring, he remained a member of the board of the PS Group Inc., which specialized in aircraft leasing, travel retailing and oil services. He was also chairman of the California Tourism Corporation and commissioner of the California Tourism Commission, and a director of the San Diego Economic Development Corporation.
Mr. Barkley, who was born in Minneapolis, graduated from San Diego State University.
He is survived by his wife, Jessie; two daughters, Anne Benson of Rochester, Minn., and Lynne Watkins of Lemon Grove, Calif.; two sons, Paul C. Barkley 3d of Winston-Salem, N.C., and John Barkley of El Cajon; his mother, Irene Novak of Minneapolis, and six grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 18, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Paul C. Barkley, a retired executive of the old Pacific Southwest Airlines, misstated his employment record in some editions. He joined the airline in 1967 and became its president in 1979.

HEADLINE: Report Calls Cholesterol Tests in Young Unjustified

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
National guidelines for routine cholesterol screening of the nation's 80 million young adults may cost the nation billions of dollars a year and could end up harming, rather than helping, the people who are screened, a group of medical experts said in a report today.
In an article published in the Journal of the American Medical Association reviewing and reanalyzing existing data, Dr. Stephen B. Hulley, an epidemiologist at the University of California at San Francisco, and his colleagues say that there is no justification for routine cholesterol tests before age 35 in men and age 45 in women. They said that even if a young adult's cholesterol level is elevated, he or she will reap almost all the benefits of cholesterol-lowering if they wait until middle age to start a diet or drug treatment. 
 Moreover, Dr. Hulley said, such screening might actually do more harm than good. Early screening may lead young adults who are unable to control their cholesterol levels by diet alone to embark on a regimen of drug therapy. "We think that it's not a good idea for low-risk young people to begin a drug treatment that can last three, four or five decades," he said. "We have no idea what drugs do in such a long-term setting and there is evidence that makes us quite concerned that the harmful effects in a low-risk person might outweigh the benefits."
 
U.S. Panel Stands Firm
 Dr. Hulley is a member of the National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel, a 25-member group established by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, a Federal agency. The panel has recommended that all adults over age 20 know their cholesterol levels.
Other members of the treatment panel, asked to comment on Dr. Hulley's conclusions, said they stood by the recommendations. Dr. Claude Lenfant, director of the Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute said he was "appalled" by the article. By denying young people cholesterol tests, he said, doctors would "deny them an opportunity to do something" about high cholesterol levels.
But some experts in heart disease said they felt the criticism of the national policy was on target.
The panel's recommendation "is quite seriously misguided," said Dr. C. David Naylor of the University of Toronto, who wrote an editorial accompanying Dr. Hulley's article. "There is a narrow window where cholesterol testing and treatment makes sense -- in the middle aged until around age 70."
 
Early Intervention Questioned
 Agreeing with that view were Dr. David Jacobs, an epidemiologist at the University of Minnesota, and Dr. Michael Criqui, a professor of family and preventive medicine at the University of California at San Diego. "I've been saying that for a long time," Dr. Criqui added.
And a Canadian task force, the Toronto Working Group, determined in 1990 that cholesterol screening of young adults was unwarranted. Its recommendations were distributed to all doctors in Ontario.
The guiding philosophy of the American guidelines is the belief that the sooner a person with high cholesterol realizes it and take steps to reduce it, the better off the person will be.
Dr. Basil Rifkind, who directs lipid research at the heart institute, recited a simple sequence supporting early intervention. "Atherosclerosis is a cumulative process," he said. "We know that 20 or 30 or 40 years of these deposits precede a heart attack. So it is logical that if we bring down cholesterol levels and fatty deposits early in life, we will be better off."
Dr. Scott Grundy, who is director of the Center for Human Nutrition at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas and the American Heart Association's representative to the national task force that sets cholesterol screening guidelines, agreed: "The point is, if you can slow atherosclerosis over your whole lifetime, you are going to get less atherosclerosis in the end than if you started in middle age."
And Dr. James I. Cleeman, coordinator of the National Cholesterol Education Program, said that "it beggars the imagination" to say that people will be just as well off starting a cholesterol reduction program later in life.
 
Benefits at Issue
 But, Dr. Hulley said in an interview that data from clinical trials lead to the opposite position. Several large and well regarded studies that involved middle-aged people with high cholesterol levels consistently showed that for every 1 percent drop in cholesterol level, there is a 2 percent drop in the risk of heart disease.
Dr. Hulley and his colleagues calculate that if people lower their cholesterol early in life, they would achieve two-thirds of the maximum benefit that could be expected. Moreover, the improvement occurs within two years of starting treatment. Since no one has ever studied the effect of starting cholesterol lowering early in life, Dr. Hulley said, it is not known whether it would even be possible to do as well in reducing heart disease by beginning cholesterol-lowering earlier.
"There's a belief structure that we've all grown up with that makes us want to believe in the benefits from early intervention," Dr. Hulley said. In fact, he said, "the evidence, that almost everyone would agree with, is that you get most of the benefits starting in middle age."
But, Dr. Rifkind asked, what is wrong with starting early and possibly getting a little more benefit? After all, he noted, the panel guidelines emphasize low-fat diets to reduce cholesterol, which certainly will not cause harm.
 
Possible Harm Seen
 The problem, Dr. Hulley says, is that some people will forgo diets for drug therapy, which may be harmful. Dr. Alan Garber, a co-author of Dr. Hulley's paper who is a specialist in internal medicine and a health-care economist at Stanford University, argues that the logic of the national guidelines, combined with human nature, "inevitably lead to drug treatment." Moderate low-fat diets, he pointed out, "don't usually lead to large reductions in cholesterol."
Although there are no national data on the number of young people now taking cholesterol-lowering drugs, Dr. Hulley said that a survey conducted by the Centers for Disease Control several years ago indicated that 200,000 people between the ages of 20 and 35 were taking them. Cathy Kernen, a spokeswoman for Merck & Company, the maker of lovastatin, one of several cholesterol-lowering drugs, said that 2.8 million Americans take lovastatin and that 308,000 of them are between the ages of 35 and 45. She said 56,000 of those who take lovastatin are under age 35.
In Dr. Hulley's opinion, virtually no young adult should be taking the drugs. He and his colleagues are concerned about the possible adverse consequences of drug treatment that begins at an early age. Since the drugs would be given to otherwise healthy people, "we must be sure we're doing more good than harm," Dr. Hulley said.
Drug intervention is justified for the 1 in a million young people who inherit a rare disorder, type II familial hypercholesterolemia, that can cause heart attacks very early in life. But Dr. Hulley says that their numbers are so few that, for example, even if all women aged 20 to 24 were screened and treated only two deaths from heart attacks would be spared in the entire nation.
But Dr. Lenfant, the director of the heart institute, said the argument was "just ridiculous." He said he believed that young people who know their cholesterol levels will be more motivated to follow the low-fat diets that are recommended for all Americans.
"Are we going to tell people, 'Don't worry about your cholesterol because you may not be able to do something about it?' " Dr. Lenfant asked. "I just don't accept that as a philosophy every individual is entitled to be informed about his or her condition."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 18, 1993, Thursday

An article yesterday about cholesterol screening rendered a statement by Dr. Claude Lenfant, director of the Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, incorrectly. He said: "Are we going to tell people, 'Don't worry about your cholesterol because you may not be able to do something about it?' I just don't accept that as a philosophy. Every individual is entitled to be informed about his or her condition."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Shifting the Computer Jobless to Software

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, March 16

 BODY:
In Massachusetts, where more than 46,000 high-tech jobs have disappeared over the last three years, an innovative internship and training program is trying to help workers displaced from the computer, military and electronic hardware industries find jobs in the state's rapidly growing software industry.
At a time when so much of the storied Route 128 high-tech corridor outside Boston has fallen on hard times, the software industry in Massachusetts is expected to add 33,000 jobs in the next three years. 
 The internship program, announced on Monday, is sponsored by the Massachusetts Computer Software Council, a trade association, with cooperation from the Massachusetts Department of Employment and Training. The idea is to match unemployed high-tech workers from troubled computer giants like the Digital Equipment Corporation and Wang Laboratories, with software companies like Lotus Development, Banyan Systems and Credit Technologies.
Each fellow, as the interns are called, will spend six months at a software company learning the technology, acronyms and issues in on-site work projects. Though there are no guarantees of permanent job offers, there is hope that the match will result in a new career.
"We think we have the opportunity to pick up some terrific people out of the minicomputer community," said Frank Ingari, vice president of marketing at Lotus. "The knowledge generated by those companies is extremely relevant to us today -- large-system installation, internetworking, troubleshooting. We're very likely to end up employing these people."
The first group of 15 fellows will begin work immediately. Supporters see the program as a potential national model for pursuing the Clinton Administration's goal of training and retraining workers.
Joyce Plotkin, director of the Mass Software Council, said she believed the program was the first of its kind in the nation. To be eligible, an unemployed worker must have 8 to 10 years' experience in a computer, electronics or military business.
"Some of these people have worked only in the mainframe area," Ms. Plotkin said, "which is very different from the PC software area. Those worlds don't cross very often."
Each participating software company must contribute $10,000 per fellow to cover costs of administering the program and pay a weekly $350 stipend to each fellow over the course of the internship.
John Phelan, with 25 years in the computer industry, is among the first fellows. Out of work for 18 months, Mr. Phelan, 48, will start his internship with Credit Technologies in Waltham this week. To qualify, he had to make it through a screening process with the state agencies and interviews with companies.
"The job picture has been really gloomy," Mr. Phelan said. "This offers a pretty strong ray of hope."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joyce L. Plotkin, director of the Mass Software Council, which is sponsoring an internship program to match unemployed high-tech workers to computer software jobs in Massachusetts. (Bachrach)
