HEADLINE: SENATORS APPROVE A BILL THAT EASES VOTE REGISTRATION

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
In an effort to encourage voter registration, the Senate today passed legislation that would allow a person to register to vote when applying for a driver's license.
The quick and relatively lopsided approval of the bill, by a vote of 62 to 37, belied the two angry weeks of partisan sniping that preceded it. Passage came only after the Senate's 57 Democrats conceded that they lacked the 60 votes needed to halt a Republican filibuster against the bill, and after they gave in to demands for small but politically important changes that must now be negotiated with the House before the bill can become law. 
 Without the concessions, the Democrats would have been unable to break the filibuster. That would have been an even deeper embarrassment for the White House, which had declared the voter-registration bill a priority in the new Congress. President Clinton himself had worked the phones on the issue, lobbying swing-voting Republicans for days.
 
The 'Motor Voter' Bill
 The bill, nicknamed "motor voter," would require states to permit every adult over the age of 18 to register to vote simply by filling out a form while they obtain a driver's license or apply for disability benefits. It would also establish a nationwide system of voter registration by mail.
Under Republican pressure, the Senate removed provisions that would have required voter registration at welfare and unemployment offices. But the bill, heavily favored by Democrats who believe it would increase turnout in poorer precincts, where their support is concentrated, would sharply increase the number of registered voters. Ninety percent of American adults have a driver's license.
Thomas Mann, a political scientist at the Brookings Institution, estimated that the bill would increase turnout in major elections by five percentage points. Only 50 percent to 55 percent of all eligible voters now go to the polls in major elections.
 
Why Republicans Objected
 Republicans, who filibustered the bill for two weeks, have called the bill a partisan scheme to lard the voter rolls with new Democrats and to heap the cost -- up to $20 million annually, by Congress's estimate -- on state and local governments. They also objected to the notion of imposing a Federal mandate on what has historically been a matter of state discretion.
The final vote came after a furious bout of amending and political horse-trading. Among other changes, the Republicans weakened a clause that would have signed up as new voters millions of predominantly Democratic welfare recipients, and the Democrats rejected a bid to automatically register hundreds of thousands of predominantly Republican military workers.
George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, later dismissed suggestions that the Republicans' success presaged more trouble for the Democrats on other vital legislation, such as Mr. Clinton's budget and his $31 billion package of economic stimulus measures. "Different bill, different issue, different circumstances," Senator Mitchell said.
Senator Wendell H. Ford, the Kentucky Democrat who sponsored the bill, said the Democrats had preserved 90 percent of what they sought in the legislation and had produced "a reasonably good bill."
But his Republican colleague from Kentucky, Senator Mitch McConnell, who led the fight against the bill, said his party had just begun to flex its muscles. "This week we demonstrated that we can improve a bill," he said. "There may be future instances in which we will have to defeat a bill."
The Senate will now try to reconcile the legislation passed today with a broadly similar version that the House passed last month. The finished product will go to Mr. Clinton, who has promised to sign it. A similar bill was approved by Congress last year but vetoed by President George Bush.
As part of today's compromise, Democrats pledged a good-faith effort to persuade the House to accept the Republican amendments when the two versions of the bill are melded. But the chief Democratic sponsor of the House bill, Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, immediately signaled that that would not be easy.
"The Senate has sold the farm and dramatically undermined the hope that the House bill offered," he said in a statement, adding that the House "ought to reject the Senate bill."
 
Decline in Voter Turnout
 The legislation aims to reverse a 30-year decline in voter turnout in American elections. About 9 out of 10 registered voters go to the polls in Presidential election years. But the turnout in major elections is much lower because many people do not register -- 70 million of 180 million prospective voters.
Both the Senate and House bills would dramatically increase the share of citizens registered to vote, largely by making registration an almost seamless part of everyday tasks like getting a driver's license.
Everyone over 18 who applied for or renewed a driver's license or sought public assistance for a disability would register to vote, simply by signing an affidavit appended to each application. Military recruitment centers would develop their own procedures to routinely sign up new servicemen and women as voters. The bill also orders states to adopt a standard procedure for registering new voters by mail.
 
Modest Impact Predicted
 But outside experts suggest that the actual impact on Election-Day turnout at the polls will be more modest.
"Given what we know about states where motor-voter has already been implemented, you're really looking at a five to 10 percentage-point increase in turnout, and that's at the most," said Ruy A. Teixeira, a sociologist at Brookings Institution scholar who is the author of "The Disappearing American Voter" (Brookings, 1992).
"A lot of these people are somewhat disconnected from political issues and the political process," he said of the nonvoters. "There's no guarantee that they're going to go out and vote just because you sign them up."
To the 57 Senate Democrats who voted for the bill, and to many civics and civil rights groups as well, the legislation is nevertheless a historic expansion of the constitutional right to vote. Republican opposition to expanding that right, Senator Mitchell said today, was "pathetic."
But the Republicans were incensed by the Democrats' zeal to register the jobless and welfare recipients, who would have been added to the voter rolls more or less automatically in the original bill. And the Republicans were equally dismayed by the Democrats' omission, at first, of any plan to register members of the military.
Senator John McCain of Arizona, a Vietnam war hero, said 200,000 servicemen and women are denied a chance to vote each year because of registration problems related to their nomadic lives. Today he carved out the Republican position with a broadax, offering an amendment that would have automatically registered every member of the armed services.
The amendment was tabled, largely on a party-line vote. But, under Republican pressure, the legislation was changed to insure that recruits are signed up to vote in nearly automatic fashion.

HEADLINE: Saving Lives and Money Too: Doctors Say It Can Be Done

SERIES: A Search for Limits -- A periodic look at prescriptions for an ailing health-care system. A Search for Limits -- A periodic look at prescriptions for an ailing health-care system

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DANVILLE, Pa.

 BODY:
Dr. James C. Blankenship, a cardiologist with a health-maintenance organization in central Pennsylvania, performs costly, risky procedures in which tubes are pushed to the heart to help find whether coronary vessels are clogged.
In his catheterization laboratory, he studied X-rays revealing a partly blocked artery in a 55-year-old man. "What are the chances this will shut off, causing a heart attack, versus the risks of surgery?" he asked. "The studies differ." 
 "I'll advise him to watch and wait," said the doctor, whose salary would not be affected one way or the other. "I want to do everything that's necessary, but not too much."
As Americans consider a more frugal medical future, possibly dominated by competing H.M.O.'s or other forms of "managed care" that limit consumer choice, urgent questions are rising about the quality of care and how to protect it. Will people be pushed into health plans staffed by sullen, rushed doctors whose decisions are second-guessed and who are paid extra to scrimp on costly tests and operations?
Or will they find sensitive doctors who have no financial incentive to do too much or too little, have ready access to the best technologies and hold down costs by preventing illness and avoiding procedures with little benefit?
 
Room for Judgment
 Medical experts are scrutinizing better health plans around the country to see how large savings might be gained through efficiency and prudence, not through shortchanging the sick. And the evidence suggests that institutions that foster physicians like Dr. Blankenship and allow them to exercise professional judgment may be in the best position to pursue that goal.
At his organization, the Geisinger Foundation in Danville, the decision about how much is enough is left to the doctors. Their cautious style of medicine has held costs well below the national average. Increases here have still averaged 8.6 percent in recent years, though, raising questions about whether the country will be able to tame medical inflation without cutting into the quality of care.
The 530 salaried doctors who work here, and offer care through a prepaid insurance plan, do receive prodding from above. But it involves not constant second-guessing or rewards for scrimping, but rather a steady flow of research news and tips that helps suffuse the institution with an ethic of conservative care.
"Here, we don't police; we trust our doctors," said Dr. Howard G. Hughes, who directs the H.M.O., the Geisinger Health Plan.
In the case of the 55-year-old man, some doctors would have recommended immediate surgery, but Dr. Blankenship felt sure that a trial period of drug therapy was in his patient's best interest.
 
Covers Wide Area Of Pennsylvania
 In Danville, a town of 6,000 people, Geisinger runs an advanced 577-bed hospital as well as a network of clinics over a wide area of central and northeastern Pennsylvania. Its growing H.M.O. serves 142,000 members, while the same doctors and clinics also provide the same style of care to hundreds of thousands more people covered by government or other insurance.
The doctors insist that their brand of medicine improves on a system laden with incentives to overuse procedures.
And they are saving money. The H.M.O. has the lowest rates in Pennsylvania, according to the state insurance department, with monthly premiums this year of $109.70 for individuals and $285.22 for families for a plan covering nearly everything but prescriptions.
But the numbers suggest, too, just how severe the challenge is. The health plan's charges have risen by an average of 8.6 percent a year since 1985, Dr. Hughes said. That is a good record compared with that of most insurers: nationwide, H.M.O. rates grew by an average of 11.7 percent per year from 1986 to 1992, and rates for traditional fee-for-service plans rose annually by 14.2 percent, according to A. Foster Higgins & Company, a consulting firm.
But it remains well above the national goal of steady real spending set by President Clinton. Recent increases have mainly reflected the rising cost of nurses, technicians and other personnel, the soaring price of new drugs and other factors, officials said.
Geisinger doctors and administrators, most of them practicing physicians, insist that through steady refinement they can save much more without compromising care. Just how much and how fast, though, no one is sure.
"If this model can't hold down prices enough, then I'm not sure it can be done in a way that fulfills the medical expectations of society," said Dr. Stuart Heydt, president of the Geisinger Foundation.
While America's medical costs are increased by administrative waste, excess equipment, incentives to use procedures lavishly and outright fraud, in the end spending mainly reflects the routine decisions of physicians. They decide when a patient needs a $70 electrocardiogram, when to order a $100-dollar antibiotic instead of a $10 one, and when $40,000 bypass surgery is truly likely to improve a patient's chances of survival or quality of life.
"The best way to control costs and preserve quality is to have the physicians do it," said Dr. Arnold S. Relman, the former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine. "The whole health-care system is built on the behavior of doctors, and that behavior is greatly influenced by the way health care is organized."
Dr. Relman, who has been studying health plans around the country, praised Geisinger for high doctor morale and a system of mutual review that promotes excellent care.
While no organizational structure guarantees quality care, Geisinger has several traits that promote it. The bedrock, officials here say, is the careful selection of doctors who share the group philosophy and are happy to work for a salary. Since they are not paid piecework, they make decisions with no direct financial interest at stake. (Nationally, doctors are salaried in some but not all H.M.O.'s or other forms of managed care.)
The salaries here are enough to support an affluent life in this rural region, but for many doctors they are well below potential earnings in private practice. Primary-care doctors have starting salaries in the range of $75,000 to $90,000, while among the most experienced specialists who might earn several times as much elsewhere, "very few go beyond $300,000," said Dr. Laurence H. Beck, senior vice president charged with improving efficiency and quality.
 
Less Reliance On the Specialists
 Morale rests on the pleasures of patient care, collaboration, teaching and research, said Dr. Francis J. Menapace, the director of cardiology. "We look for a different type of physician, one who still looks at medicine as a profession, not a business."
As in most H.M.O.'s, all patients must choose a primary-care physician. Usually trained in family practice, internal medicine or pediatrics, these doctors provide most care and refer sicker patients to specialists only when necessary.
Now about 30 percent of the plan's doctors provide primary care, but studies suggest the proportion should rise to close to 50 percent, Dr. Beck said. This means cutting back on specialties, a painful and controversial topic among the medical staff.
Dr. Ernest W. Campbell, a primary-care physician and head of the Geisinger clinic in the nearby town of Bloomsburg, had been in independent practice for 18 years before he and his partner decided to join the salaried group in 1985.
"We looked at the H.M.O. and liked what they were saying," he said. "It's more geared toward preventive medicine, keeping people healthy rather than just meeting the acute needs as they arise." He said the switch involved a significant loss in income, but offsetting this was a drop in work time to 60 to 70 hours a week. Since patients are in a prepaid plan, he said, "now we can tell them they have no excuse for not coming in when they are ill."
A large unified system like Geisinger's can also avoid duplication of costly equipment and readily monitor its use. For example, all cardiac catheterizations, which are Dr. Blankenship's diagnostic specialty, are performed at the main hospital in Danville, as is open-heart surgery. This does mean, though, that some patients have to travel up to 100 miles for major procedures.
With central control, too, can come imbalances in staffing, sometimes causing long waits. Currently, for example, because of a shortage of gynecologists in the group, an appointment for a routine pelvic checkup can take several months. Officials insist that that is a temporary side effect.
But in surveys of H.M.O. patients that generally find high satisfaction with care and doctors, intermittent difficulty in getting quick appointments has been the most common complaint, said Dr. Duane Davis, medical director of the health plan.
 
When Supervision Is From Within
 For all its emphasis on efficiency, Geisinger does little of the routine oversight that is now so prevalent in the health-insurance industry and so annoying to doctors. Instead, the doctors are expected to watch themselves.
"We have a high awareness of what our colleagues are doing in the next room," Dr. Blankenship said. "There's lots of intercommunication, lots of informal second opinions."
Peer review is, however, increasingly backed up with research and suggestions from above. The H.M.O., for example, keeps track of prescribing patterns and sends out newsletters urging physicians to prescribe cheaper drugs or generic versions where they have been shown to be equally effective.
In another example, officials studied whether patients who were put on an expensive cholesterol-lowering drug were first asked to experiment with dietary change. By sharing the results with other physicians and stressing the recommended course, doctors found that the proportion of patients trying diet changes had risen. Some will end up needing the drug anyway, but some will avoid indefinite use of a drug that can have dangerous side effects.
Dr. Campbell, the primary-care doctor, said he welcomed these "timely reminders," and stressed that he remained free, without any pressure, to prescribe a costly alternative when he felt it was indicated.
When a doctor's prescribing and referral patterns diverge significantly from the norm, a senior doctor might ask why. In one case, a doctor who has since left for private practice was found to be ordering twice as many tests and costly drugs as his colleagues. Asked to explain, he said, "I'm a Cadillac; can you afford a Cadillac?" recalled Dr. Robert M. Haddad, who oversees seven primary-care clinics.
"But I would say he overused tests," Dr. Haddad said. "A 30-year-old man doesn't need an E.K.G. every year."
The continuous search for "better" ways of doing things is not simply a code word for "less," Dr. Beck said. "What our physicians insist on is to look at the outcomes and make them as consistent and good as possible," he said. "If we do things the right way, and reduce variation, we will end up with savings."
The question is how far even the best-organized providers can trim without choking off tests and treatments of significant benefit.
Dr. Beck said he believes that Geisinger and other similar groups still have large opportunities to wring out expense. Increasingly important, he said, will be reliance on clinical guidelines that reflect research, done locally or nationally, on what sequences of tests and treatments work best.
Still, Dr. Beck said, "At some point there will be tradeoffs between cost and quality." If price controls are too severe, he said, society will have to openly face the issue of rationing. "Those are decisions the individual physician can't make in his office."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Gain Despite Inflation Data

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved higher yesterday as traders and analysts dismissed bad news in the consumer inflation report for February as an aberration.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, helped with his interpretation of the three-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index. In response to a question at a Congressional hearing, Mr. Greenspan said, "While we must clearly remain vigilant, my inclination is to view the latest data as aberrations." 
 Some traders seemed to focus on the fact that a large part of the increase was caused by a 1.5 percent jump in clothing costs, which are notoriously volatile. They seemed little concerned that consumer inflation excluding energy and food prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent, following an identical jump in so-called core inflation in January.
 
 
'More Inflation'
 "Clearly, people are looking at the C.P.I. and saying there are one-time factors that will be reversed," Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities, said. But he said he was still hard-pressed to explain why Treasury prices rose because for him, the data said "the inflation trough is past. Anyway you slice or dice these numbers, we have more inflation in 1993 than we had in 1992."
The problem for traders and investors is not that inflation, which eats away at the fixed returns from Treasury securities, is about to soar. Even with the February report, analysts see inflation rising only a little more than the 3 percent of last year. The issue is that many forecasters are expecting inflation to decline this year, which has become one of the supporting factors in the bond market rally.
The price of the 30-year bond, which had dropped sharply with the prices of Treasury notes just after the inflation report was released, seesawed through the day to end up 3/32 point, as the yield slipped to 6.86 percent, down from 6.87 percent Tuesday.
The price of the five-year note was up 10/32 , as the yield fell to 5.18 percent, from 5.26 percent the day before. The five-year yield is now below where it was before the producer inflation report sparked a sell-off Friday.
The demand for the five-year note is so strong that the Federal Reserve is examining whether there is a squeeze at work. Traders said they thought the squeeze was natural, not illegal, and was caused in part by selling to hedge against corporate bond holdings.
Despite the demand, the Treasury will auction just $11 billion of new five-year notes next Thursday, the same amount as last month. On Wednesday the Treasury will auction $15.25 billion of two-year notes.
 
 
Municipals
 Traders and analysts said yesterday that the certificate of participation market will be helped by Tuesday's narrow election victory in Brevard County, Fla. Voters approved a referendum that would keep the county government in its office complex and prevent the default on the certificates of participation that were sold to pay for the complex.
But some also warned that the vote did not end the threat of some local governments deciding to walk away from these special bonds, which have to have their interest and principal appropriated every year.
"It stops a bad situation from getting worse," said Robert J. Froelich, director of municipal research and investment strategy at Van Kampen Merritt Investment Advisory Group in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill. "But the problem has not gone away."
Traders said that there was no immediate reaction in the market because there was little trading in certificates of participation yesterday.
The Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, which insured the bonds and would have had to make the interest and principal payments if the county had defaulted, applauded the victory.
M.B.I.A. contributed $373,975 to three groups opposing the default. With 46,290 people voting in favor of not defaulting, that works out to $8.08 a vote. But for the county at large, where there are about 400,000 residents, it is just under $1 dollar a person. The vote to default was 43,017.
 
 
New York City
 Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman yesterday named the new team for managing the city's bond sales for the next regular rotation, which lasts about 18 months.
Included among the list of 22 co-managers are seven firms run by women or minority groups, which is the first time such firms have been chosen by the city. These firms are Artemis Capital Group; Carmona, Motley & Company; Grigsby Brandford & Company; W. R. Lazard; Pryor, McClendon, Counts & Company; Samuel A. Ramirez & Company, and Muriel Siebert & Company
The seven senior managers are Bear, Stearns & Company; the First Boston Corporation; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Lehman Brothers; Merrill Lynch; J. P. Morgan, and Prudential Securities.

HEADLINE: Democrats, Sensing Victory, Hunt Votes for Clinton Economic Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Democratic leaders scoured the Capitol for votes today in hopes of delivering a big victory to President Clinton as the House debated the Administration's economic plan.
"Rank-and-file Democrats want to give this President a victory," said Representative John Lewis of Georgia, who like other members of his party's leadership predicted passage of Mr. Clinton's economic-revival agenda. 
 With outnumbered Republicans arrayed solidly against them, top Democrats coaxed and cajoled fellow Democrats in an effort to solidify majorities for the President's proposals.
His plan was embodied in two measures the House considered: the outlines of a $510 billion deficit reduction and a $16.3 billion jobs bill.
 
Debate in the Senate
 The Senate debated its own $502 billion deficit-cutting blueprint. As in the House, Democrats arguing that the President's plan should be enacted were pitted against Republicans saying that its spending cuts and tax increases would not spark a recovery.
"That's not going to happen with a deficit-reduction plan that is essentially cutting defense and taxing the American people," said Senator Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico.
The House seemed certain to approve the budget-cutting package on Thursday, while Senate approval was likely next week. But the fate of the jobs bill, on which the House also planned a vote on Thursday, seemed less certain.
Conservative Democrats were hoping to trim the jobs measure, arguing that it would add too much to budget deficits that are setting records every year. So they were particular targets of party lieutenants hunting for support.
"Their sales pitch is: 'It's part of the President's overall plan' and 'We can't let the whole thing fail,' " said Representative Timothy J. Penny of Minnesota, one of the conservatives hoping to reduce the spending for jobs.
Mr. Lewis, his party's chief deputy whip, said he believed that enough conservatives would fall into line to insure passage.
But at least some conservatives showed no signs of quitting.
"Since when is a good fight among Democrats damaging to the legislative process?" Representative Charles W. Stenholm of Texas asked reporters.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As Democrats sought to garner the votes for President Clinton's economic plan, Republican members of the House Budget Committe called for the panel's demise. The committee "is no more than a doormat," said Representative Bob Franks of New Jersey, center, and should be "radically overhauled or totally abolished," because it has allowed the national debt to skyrocket. With him at news conference yesterday were Representatives Dan Miller of Florida, left, and Nick Smith of Michigan. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

The Economy

HEADLINE: New Group Considering Bid for Post

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
A group of investors with access to hundreds of millions of dollars could provide the first serious alternative to Abraham Hirschfeld or Steven Hoffenberg as the buyer of The New York Post.
The group, which includes an investment banker and a former New York City Deputy Mayor, Kenneth Lipper, and the real-estate multimillionaires Larry and Zachary Fisher and other major investors, was assembled by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Lipper said yesterday. 
 The Fisher brothers have been major builders and property owners in New York for decades. In 1988, Forbes magazine estimated their fortune at $800 million. But Larry Fisher told the magazine that his family was worth more than $1 billion.
 
Examining the Books
 "The Fishers and I have been approached by the Governor and this is a totally exploratory effort," Mr. Lipper said. Mr. Lipper, people involved in the situation said, went to The Post late yesterday to examine its books, with Mr. Hirschfeld's permission.
At a news conference yesterday, Governor Cuomo said the group consisted of "formidable and successful business people." He did not name any participants and some people involved said there might be more than one new group interested in buying The Post.
Others involved in the talks said the group that includes the Fishers and Mr. Lipper was considering an investment of $20 million to $30 million and a long-term commitment to make The Post profitable. They said Mr. Lipper, 51, would probably be the publisher if the group were to acquire the newspaper.
 
Unstable Situation
 Eric Breindel, The Post's former editorial page editor, who has been involved in financial negotiations with potential buyers, said Mr. Lipper's expression of interest marked a sharp change in what he described as an unstable situation since Mr. Hoffenberg first appeared in January.
Mr. Lipper's interest, Mr. Breindel said, demonstrates "that you have a valuable franchise at The New York Post even from the standpoint of a serious financier who has actually looked at the numbers."
The Post's bankruptcy filing this week, people who have talked with the Fishers and Mr. Lipper said, has made the paper more attractive as an investment. In bankruptcy, the court has broad powers that could permit it to reduce some of the massive liabilities that have helped discourage potential buyers. The court could also permit The Post to renounce its union contracts, forcing employees to renegotiate with new owners.
New bidders could come to court tomorrow during a bankruptcy-court hearing. But it was not clear yesterday whether the Lipper-Fisher group would make a bid then or wait until the newspaper's situation is even more desperate.
Although Mr. Hirschfeld has a contract to purchase the newspaper, he could change his mind. At least until Mr. Hirschfeld formally becomes the owner, and possibly even after that, a bankruptcy judge could decide that a better-financed buyer would be likelier to help the newspaper survive.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Lipper stressed that the group had been assembled only this week and its four or five members had not all talked yet. He also said the investors would insist on cooperation from employees, union leaders and others at The Post. He did not use the word "concessions," but he indicated the group would try to drive a hard bargain.
"This effort will only be successful," Mr. Lipper said, "if it's a totally team endeavor, where all levels of management and workers participate with the owners in developing a long-term-stability plan for The Post. There is no value in a short-term fix."
The Fishers did not return telephone calls yesterday. But Mr. Lipper said he had their permission to confirm their interest in exploring a purchase of The Post.
People involved in the negotiations that are being led by Vincent Tese, Governor Cuomo's chief economic development adviser, said a central condition of the Fisher-Lipper group was that all of its investment be applied to building The Post.
Until now, Peter S. Kalikow, the current owner, Mr. Hirschfeld and Mr. Hoffenberg have all been focusing on who would shoulder current debts of the newspaper, like a $4.1 million past-due tax bill, and possible shutdown costs, such as severance pay, estimated at $20 million or more.
People involved in the talks said the Lipper-Fisher group appeared convinced that, in bankruptcy court, many of the newspaper's debts and future liabilities may be negotiable and that there are new opportunities to reduce operating costs.
If the Lipper-Fisher group does buy The Post, it would be a successful conclusion of the unusual involvement of Governor Cuomo in the travails of the newspaper. In what he said was an effort to save jobs, and a journalistic voice that he said he did not particularly like, Governor Cuomo began searching for buyers when Mr. Kalikow said he would have to close the Post in January.
Governor Cuomo was said to be partly responsible for bringing Mr. Hoffenberg to the Post, and the situation quickly became politically embarrassing as Mr. Hoffenberg was charged with investor fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The political thicket grew denser with the arrival of Mr. Hirschfeld, who has sometimes been a mischievous foe of the Governor.
The Lipper-Fisher deal could free the newspaper of both Mr. Hoffenberg and Mr. Hirschfeld and leave the Governor, once again, in the position of being able to claim credit for helping to save The Post.
Mr. Lipper has had a relatively low profile in business, making tens of millions of dollars as an investment banker at Lehman Brothers, Salomon Brothers and, since 1986, as chairman of Lipper & Company.
 
Taste for Public Life
 But he has shown a taste in the past for a more public life. He was a deputy mayor under Edward I. Koch, ran unsuccessfully for City Council president in 1985 and wrote the novel "Wall Street," which was the basis for the Oliver Stone film of the same title. Mr. Lipper was an adviser to Mr. Stone on the film.
Last night, Pete Hamill, The Post's acting editor in chief, said on PBS's "Charlie Rose" show that Leon H. Charney, a lawyer who owns several commercial buildings in Manhattan, and Ronald S. Lauder, the former Republican candidate for Mayor of New York also remained interested in buying the paper.
Peter Faris, The Post's senior vice president and top administrator, was asked in an interview yesterday whether a bid from a new group could stabilize The Post. He said he believed a critical date is this Friday, when the bankruptcy court may give Mr. Hirschfeld permission to move ahead with his purchase.
The mood at The Post is so hostile to Mr. Hirschfeld, Mr. Faris said, that new bidders who fail to move quickly might not have a paper to buy. "It might be dead later," Mr. Faris said.

Conrad/The New York Times); Kenneth Lipper, a former New York City deputy mayor and one of a group of investors considering buying The Post, in his office yesterday. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: South African to Lobby for U.S. Impartiality

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 15

 BODY:
South Africa's Foreign Minister has cautioned the Clinton Administration against a sentimental tilt toward the African National Congress, saying that playing favorites in South Africa could increase tension in the country.
The Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, also endorsed "the framework" of a new Washington peace plan for Angola, but appeared to differ with some elements of the proposal. 
 Mr. Botha, who has led the Foreign Ministry since 1977, spoke in an interview before leaving for Washington, where he will size up the Clinton Administration's leanings in Africa and try to persuade the new President not to discount his governing National Party just because of its apartheid past.
President F. W. de Klerk's Government is uneasy that Mr. Clinton's election means a greater sympathy in Washington for the African National Congress. Nelson Mandela, president of the congress, was the first foreign political figure invited to meet with Secretary of State Warren Christopher after the inauguration in January.
"I can understand there is a sentiment," Mr. Botha said in a conversation at the Foreign Ministry guest house outside Pretoria. "It will be a pity if that continues much longer."
Mr. Botha once would have bristled at the suggestion America could play a role in South Africa's domestic affairs. Now, with the white Government on the brink of surrendering power to a nonracial democracy, he argues that the United States should use the leverage of foreign aid to insist that democratic principles, free-market economics and minority rights are securely enshrined in a new constitution.
"It was one thing to fight apartheid," he said. "But what must be emphasized now is whether those who opposed apartheid support democratic values."
Mr. Botha said he would ask, for example, "where does the United States Government really stand" on the A.N.C.'s alliance with the South African Communist Party.
South Africa was for many years Washington's partner in sponsoring the Angolan rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, in his war against the Marxist Government in Luanda, which in turn drew support from Cuba and Moscow.
Washington has cut off support for Mr. Savimbi, and has said he is principally to blame for plunging the country back into a civil war that has reportedly killed tens of thousands of Angolans.
The war resumed after Mr. Savimbi refused to accept his party's defeat in parliamentary elections last September, asserting that the votes were rigged. In a presidential election held at the same time, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos outpolled Mr. Savimbi, but fell short of a majority.
South Africa has also ended official support for Mr. Savimbi and has criticized the rebel leader for refusing to comply with the election results, which were deemed generally fair by United Nations observers.
But Mr. Botha said he opposed those -- including the United States Ambassador in Angola -- who have urged Washington to bolster the Angolan Government by giving it formal diplomatic recognition.
Mr. Botha argued that recognizing the Angolan Government would amount to proclaiming Mr. Dos Santos the winner before a presidential runoff has been held. "It will not make a negotiated settlement easier," he said.
Mr. Botha's main mission in Washington will be to explain that his National Party is not to be counted out in South Africa, especially since the African National Congress has agreed that all parties with a substantial showing in the elections should share in a coalition government.
Indeed, Mr. Botha, who is also the party leader for the Transvaal, South Africa's most populous region, said if anyone in Washington asks he will be happy to explain his theory of how the National Party might emerge victorious from the elections, in coalition with allies like the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party -- a view even many in the Government find far-fetched.
"I do not think a single party will get an outright majority," he said. "But the National Party, together with other parties who share our basic principles, certainly stand a good chance."

HEADLINE: College Chief Is Reported Picked to Run U.S.I.A.

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
President Clinton has selected Joseph D. Duffey, president of American University and an old friend, to head the United States Information Agency, Administration officials say.
No date has been set for the appointment. But it is expected that when Mr. Duffey, long active in the Democratic Party, is named, the appointment will be coupled with an announcement that his deputy will be Penn Kemble, a conservative Democrat, the officials said. 
 Mr. Duffey, 60, and Mr. Kemble, 52, said that they had discussed appointments with the Administration, but that they could not provide details.
The selections, on the one hand of Mr. Duffey, who was in top educational and cultural posts in the Carter Administration, and on the other hand of Mr. Kemble, who is counted in the conservative camp, appear to create an ideological balance at a critical moment. The information agency, with 8,900 workers and a $1 billion annual appropriation, is being buffeted by crosswinds over its mission and budget.
Advocates of the agency, including the bipartisan United States Advisory Commission on Public Diplomacy, endorse a proposal by Mr. Clinton to consolidate all Government-sponsored international broadcasting operations under the U.S.I.A., which sponsors the Voice of America. That would mean phasing out Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty.
Defenders of the stations in Munich, Republicans and conservative Democrats began campaigning recently to preserve them as preferable to the Voice of America.
The conservative Democrats have complained bitterly that none of their number had been named to a high post in the new Administration. Recently some carried their complaint to Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, and his deputy, Samuel Berger, saying at least one favorite, Representative Dave McCurdy, Democrat of Oklahoma, or Richard Schifter, a former chief of human rights at the State Department, deserved a choice post. They got nowhere, said Ben Wattenberg, the conservative columnist.
Proposals have also been made to take the Voice of America from the U.S.I.A. and turn over its foreign educational-exchange programs to a foundation while placing its remaining functions in the State Department. But officials at the agency took heart from Mr. Clinton's strong support for instruments of "public diplomacy."
Mr. Duffey became acquainted with Mr. Clinton when he was running for the Senate in Connecticut in 1970 against Lowell P. Weicker Jr., then a member of Congress. Mr. Duffey had been a Congregational minister, chairman of the Americans for Democratic Action and a participant in Eugene J. McCarthy's Presidential campaign in 1968. Mr. Clinton, having just completed studying under a Rhodes Scholarship at Oxford, was attracted to Mr. Duffey through opposition to the Vietnam War and went to work in the ultimately unsuccessful campaign.
The two stayed in touch through Mr. Clinton's career in Arkansas politics and Mr. Duffey's Carter years as Assistant Secretary of State for Educational and Cultural Affairs and chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. Before being called to head American University, Mr. Duffey was chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
On Monday the Clintons and the Duffeys had supper together with the actors Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward in a restaurant here. Mr. Duffey's wife, Anne Wexler, was Deputy Under Secretary for Commerce in the Carter Administration and is a prominent lobbyist.
In the weeks after Mr. Clinton's inauguration, there was a wide-ranging competition for the top U.S.I.A. job involving public figures and former Government officials who were put forward by others or put themselves forward. They included Mary Bitterman, a former director of the Voice; Rozanne L. Ridgway, a former ambasssador; David Gergen of the Reagan White House, Martin Peretz of The New Republic, Bill D. Moyers of the Johnson White House, Pierre Salinger of the Kennedy White House and Mr. Wattenberg.

HEADLINE: Lilco's Emissions Sale Spurs Acid Rain Concerns

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Long Island Lighting Company wants to sell the right to emit pollution to a fuel supplier that would resell the pollution rights to any of a dozen utilities scattered around the Midwest, South and West, according to documents made public yesterday and people involved in the deal.
Disclosure of the name of the buyer, Amax Energy Inc., opens a new chapter in a mystery that has concerned environmentalists for weeks. Many people upstate worry that if the ultimate buyer is a company upwind of New York, a result could be an increase in the acid rain that blows into sensitive areas, especially the Adirondacks. 
 Several trades of emission allowances, essentially purchases of a right to pollute, have been announced in the last few months, but this is apparently the first in which the buyer plans to resell them.
Such a complex trade is just the kind of transaction that economists envisioned when they helped convince Congress that an open market in emissions would find the cheapest ways to reduce pollution.
But environmentalists say this situation also illustrates their fear that a ton of pollution can cause more damage in one location than another.
A spokesman for Amax Energy, Kevin A. Feeney, said the company planned to sell the allowances in a package with its coal or natural gas, essentially offering them as incentives to encourage the sale of energy products that create comparatively high levels of pollution, particularly coal, which has a high sulfur content.
"It gives us another marketing tool to use in marketing our products," he said. In practice, with the Clean Air Act of 1990 making it harder to burn high-sulfur coal, offering the fuel with the allowances will simplify compliance for utilities.
All Lilco has sold is an option to buy the allowances, not the allowances themselves. The New York State Public Service Commission could still step in and stop the deal.
Sale of the allowances is permitted under the Clean Air Act, but environmentalists are concerned that such deals could allow utilities in the Midwest to burn dirtier coal, resulting in more acid rain blowing back into New York.
The news yesterday would greatly increase the difficulty of predicting the effects of the sale.
"This is exactly the worst-case scenario from the point of view of protecting New York State," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat from Westchester County who is the chairman of the committee on environmental conservation.
Lilco previously said it had concluded a deal to sell options on the emission allowances, but had sought to keep the details secret. The Public Service Commission, in a ruling that took effect yesterday, said that Lilco did not have to disclose how many allowances the option covered, or at what price, but that the buyer's name must be made public. The buyer, Amax Energy of Greenwich, Conn., is a subsidiary of Amax Corporation, a conglomerate based in Manhattan. Amax Energy's Indianapolis-based coal company says it is the nation's third-largest producer of coal; another subsidiary, in Houston, produces oil and natural gas.
Amax produced 41 million tons of coal last year, much of it high-sulfur coal from Tennessee, Indiana and Illinois. It also produces low-sulfur coal from West Virginia and Wyoming. Mr. Feeney said the company's coal customers include Ohio Edison, Kansas City Power & Light, the Public Service Company of Indiana, the Central Indiana Public Service, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Public Service Company of Colorado.
 
Way of Meeting Standards
 The Midwestern utilities are the ones likeliest to need allowances to meet the Clean Air Act limits on sulfur dioxide, which take effect in 1995. Some will build "scrubbers" -- devices that filter sulfur dioxide and other pollutants out of smokestacks -- on their plants, others will switch to lower-sulfur fuel and still others are expected to buy allowances.
The allowance trading system was approved by Congress at the urging of economists and some environmentalists, who said it would improve efficiency in pollution reduction. The intent is to encourage that reductions be made in the cheapest way possible while not affecting the amount of emission reduction nationwide.
The act gave Lilco a windfall because a New York State law forced it to reduce emissions in the 1980's to levels below what the Federal law will require. As a result, Lilco has 40,000 to 50,000 allowances a year to sell, each representing one ton of sulfur dioxide, beginning in 1995. Publicly announced trades have pegged the price of an allowance at $250 to $400.
 
Potential for Damage Seen

Lilco said it would use the income to lower its rates, which are now the highest in the mainland United States.
But environmentalists said a result would be to hurt the vulnerable Adirondacks. "There is the potential for extreme damage from a sale like this," said John Sheehan, a spokesman for the Adirondack Council. "Part of our problem with this process is there is an inherent lack of accountability as far as what will result from the trading of allowances," he said.
The solution, he said, was for the Environmental Protection Agency to set limits on the amount of acid rain that could be deposited, and review each trade to see whether it would push any area over the limit.
Assemblyman Brodsky is the author of a bill that would permit the Public Service Commission to block such trades if it found them harmful to New York State. The Public Service Commission has jurisdiction already but the standards it can use are "hazy," he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plan's 2 Aces: Fed and the Bond Market

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
As the House of Representatives prepares to vote Thursday on President Clinton's deficit-cutting plan and stimulus package, Republicans are still trying to shoot down the stimulus program, contending that it would be a waste of money and may give the economy too much of a push.
But many economists say the biggest problem about the President's package is not that it will speed up growth dangerously, creating fears of inflation, but that it will slow growth too much. 
 That is because the plan to cut the deficit by $473 billion over five years will have a much bigger effect on the $6 trillion economy than the $16 billion in stimulus. The plan's tax increases and spending cuts, economists agree, are likely to be a drag on growth and job creation from 1994 to 1997.
This could create some tricky political problems for Mr. Clinton should he run for re-election, because, by some estimates, the negative effects of his deficit-cutting plan could hold down employment growth by more than one million jobs in 1996.
But two outside forces might save the President: the bond market and the Federal Reserve.
 
Bond Market Delighted
 The bond market, so far delighted by the President's plan, has cooperated more than the Administration dreamed, pushing down long-term interest rates to their lowest level since the 1970's. In the view of many economists, the stimulus created by the steep drop in rates more than outweighs the slowing effects of the tax increases and spending cuts.
The President's stimulus package will increase growth slightly this year, economists say, but when the deficit reduction measures pick up steam in 1995 and 1996, their slowing effects, known as fiscal drag, will start to take a big bite out of growth. At that point, Mr. Clinton might need more than help from the bond market to keep the economy chugging.
That, many economists predict, means the President will press Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to keep short-term interest rates low.
"I believe the Federal Reserve's role is pivotal," said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company. "If this program is passed, then the Federal Reserve should be prepared to lower rates to make sure we get the maximum benefit out of the program."
Many forecasters have concluded that the package, by bringing about lower interest rates and more investment, will not produce faster-than-anticipated growth until late this decade, that is, growth faster than the baseline projections of the Congressional Budget Office.
"The emphasis on investment is good for the long run, but the long run doesn't arrive in four years," said Roger E. Brinner, research director at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm in Lexington, Mass.
 
Little Help for Short Run
 Laurence H. Meyer, who runs his own economics consulting firm in St. Louis, added, "If you do a better job educating kindergarten students, that's not going to generate higher growth by 1996."
The deficit-cutting plan is expected to hurt growth because tax increases, like the proposed broad-based energy tax, generally hurt investment and consumer spending, while cuts in Federal spending, like closing military bases, mean layoffs and less consumption.
Conservatives argue that Mr. Clinton's plan will hurt growth especially because tax increases represent the lion's share of the deficit-cutting measures.
"I don't see how the President can create jobs by raising taxes," said John H. Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute. "I think the plan could mean trouble for him in 1996."
Fears that the plan could undermine growth help explain why Mr. Clinton warned Congress last week not to go overboard in cutting the deficit beyond what he has proposed. Several economists said that neither the $510 billion deficit reduction plan approved by the House Budget Committee nor the $502 billion plan approved by the Senate Budget Committee would do much additional damage to growth.
 
Risky for Clinton
 In many ways the Clinton plan is a risky experiment in which the payoff of faster growth and higher living standards might not be seen until after the 1996 elections.
Mr. Clinton's economic advisers say the plan will raise the nation's long-term underlying growth rate to 2.5 percent in 1997, up from its current level of about 2 percent. Long-run growth will climb, his advisers say, thanks to lower interest rates, increased investment and improved job training.
But many economists assert that the plan will not increase long-term growth that soon or that much, although most believe the plan is worthwhile, despite the damage it does to growth in the mid-1990's.
"If you gave me the choice of two economies to inherit on Jan. 1, 1998, one with a large deficit or one with deficit reduction, I'd take the one with deficit reduction, which means we will have lower interest rates," said Robert F. Wescott, an economist with the WEFA Group, a consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. "That should lead to higher levels of investment and help make the standard of living much better over the next 10 years."
According to DRI/McGraw-Hill, the plan's tax increases and spending cuts would, without the help of lower interest rates, cause employment to grow by 1.1 million fewer jobs in 1996 than it would have without the plan, while the economy would expand by a meager 1.7 percent, well below the Congressional Budget Office baseline of 2.7 percent.
But DRI predicts that if the bond market and Federal Reserve keep rates low, then 1996 will see much brighter results: employment growth of 260,000 above the baseline and economic growth of a healthy 3.2 percent.
 
Forecasts Can Be Way Off
 Such forecasts are often off by a wide margin because economists' hyper-complex computer models try to factor in many unpredictable ingredients, such as how consumers and the dollar will behave and how much Congress and the President will actually hold down spending.
Mr. Sinai of the Boston Company made a forecast in line with DRI's, saying that with the Clinton plan, the economy would grow by 2.2 percent in 1996 and employment would rise by 254,000 fewer jobs than baseline projections if the Federal Reserve does not hold down rates. But Mr. Sinai said that if the Fed cooperated, growth would be 2.5 percent in 1996 and employment would grow by 309,000 jobs more than the baseline.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen has said many forecasts may understate the plan's positive effects because they do not sufficiently take into account the sharp drop in long-term interest rates. Using a rule of thumb that he said had come from Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Bentsen said every drop in interest rates of 10 basis points or one-tenth of 1 percent meant $10 billion in economic stimulus. Because long-term rates have plunged 100 basis points since November, that means $100 billion in stimulus.
Mr. Wescott of WEFA said that in 1994 the stimulus from lower rates would outweigh the drag from the modest deficit reduction, but he predicted that low interest rates would not offset the drag created by the larger deficit cuts scheduled for 1995 through 1997.
"The program is definitely a minus for growth in 1995 and 1996," he said. "The spending cuts and tax increases really start to ramp up as you go further out in the plan."

HEADLINE: Assembly Plan on Transit Would Put Issue to Voters

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 17

 BODY:
With the state's budget deadline two weeks away, Assembly Democrats have proposed a new transportation financing plan that would require voter approval to borrow money for road, bridge and mass transit construction.
Assembly aides said the plan, which would raise the money through the sale of general-obligation bonds, had only recently been floated in closed-door negotiations with aides to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and with the Republicans who control the State Senate. 
 "It is an idea that the Speaker is considering and discussing with the other leaders," said Steven A. Greenberg, a spokesman for Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat. "He believes it's a way to deal with the transportation issue and with debt reform, because going to the voters for permission to issue debt is the ultimate debt reform."
In the last three months, both Mr. Cuomo and the Senate Republicans have released their own transportation financing plans, which outline ways to preserve the $1.25 fare on New York City subways and buses, pay for improvements needed by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and subsidize road and bridge construction around the state.
Mr. Cuomo's plan would spend $21.4 billion in state, Federal and local money over five years. The Senate plan, which was issued last week by Senator Norman J. Levy, the chairman of the Transportation Committee, would spend $24.2 billion.
 
Seeking Voter Approval
 Both plans would rely heavily on the sale of revenue bonds, which would be backed by revenue sources like an existing tax on petroleum and tolls on Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority crossings.
The Assembly plan would differ because general-obligation bonds, unlike revenue bonds, must be approved by the voters. Assembly aides said today that the transportation plan would be presented in a package with a debt-reform proposal, including a Constitutional amendment that would prohibit the use of quasi-governmental agencies to sell bonds that raise money for the state's general fund.
But the notion of letting the voters decide also introduces an element of risk not present in Mr. Cuomo's or Mr. Levy's plan. Voters in New York have rejected the last two general-obligation bond acts, an economic development bond act in 1992 and an environmental bond act in 1990.
While the Assembly has not decided how much money the transportation bond act would have to raise, state leaders agree that the amount would be large. And if voters rejected the bond issue, it would be politically difficult for the Legislature and Governor to then turn to revenue bonds as a financing mechanism. The state would be left to pay for transportation improvements solely with money produced by tax revenues, a relatively small sum compared with the state's needs.

HEADLINE: Core Inflation Climbs 0.5% For 2d Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Consumer prices climbed a moderate three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Labor Department said today, but "core" inflation rose an unnerving five-tenths of a percent for the second straight month.
Many analysts considered the results, combined with last Friday's report of the biggest jump for producer prices in two years, fairly solid evidence that inflation was no longer on the wane. 
 "I think we've troughed out," said Alan C. Lerner of the Bankers Trust Company, referring to an inflation rate that retreated from 6.1 percent in 1990 to 3.1 percent in 1991 and to 2.9 percent last year.
 
Sharp Inflation Rise Doubted
 Few analysts, however, believe a sharp pickup in inflation is likely soon.
A second report today showed that industrial production rose in February for the fifth straight month and that gains for November, December and January were a bit higher than previously estimated. The report, from the Federal Reserve, showed that industry ran at 79.9 percent of capacity, two-tenths of a point higher than in January and the highest rate since September 1991.
The news of higher-than-expected core inflation initially sent bond prices down, but the market recovered, apparently when traders and investors realized that apparel accounted for much of the increase. Clothing prices, which account for 6 percent of the Consumer Price Index, are notoriously volatile, but are included in the underlying, or core, inflation rate. Food and energy prices are excluded.
In another reassuring sign, all major categories except for apparel posted smaller price increases in February than they had in January.
"We do not feel that the two-month, five-tenths of 1 percent increases in core consumer prices is the beginning of a new upward-drift pattern," said Donald E. Maude, an economist with Scotia McLeod Inc. in New York. "We expect a significant moderation in these prices over the months immediately ahead."
Other analysts agreed, noting that the price index has tended to post sizable increases in the first months of recent years. Allen Sinai, an economist for the Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc., said that the best news on inflation was probably past, but added that "a permanent and significant reacceleration of inflation is unlikely."
This view is based on generally weak economies abroad, an apparent slowdown of American economic growth and very slow increases here in unit labor costs, among other reasons.
In the longer run, however, economists see a potential for higher inflation if the Clinton Administration moves to raise the minimum wage, engages in protectionist trade policies and seeks to provide health insurance for 35 million people now without it.
 
Apparel's Impact
 Apparel prices, with a 1.5 percent jump, accounted for about one-quarter of the overall rise in the price index. Other significant influences on the index were a sharp downturn in the price of fresh fruits and vegetables, a 2.2 percent increase in airline fares and a decline in energy services that more than offset an increase in gasoline and other petroleum products.
Medical costs rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month, about the same 6.3 percent annual pace that has prevailed for the latest three-month and 12-month periods. Hospital and related services, however, surged 1 percent in February.
Prices for services rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, while commodities rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Each gain was one-tenth of a point less than the January advance. Services account for 56 percent of the index, commodities for 44 percent.
 
Purchasing Power
 For urban consumers, the price index now stands at 143.1, which means a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in the 1982-84 base period now costs $14.31. Stated another way, the value of the 1982-84 dollar slipped last month to 69.9 cents from 70.1 cents in January.
The four-tenths of 1 percent rise in industrial output -- the production of the nation's factories, mines and utilities -- was largely as expected.

HEADLINE: As Japan Chip Talks Near, U.S. Turns Up the Pressure

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 17

 BODY:
The semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan has reached a critical juncture, and once again Japan is being criticized for a failure to live up to the goal of opening 20 percent of its market to foreign-made computer chips.
But for Japan, the real concern might not be that the agreement has failed to increase foreign companies' share of the market, but that it has worked so well. 
 While it is true that American and other foreign manufacturers still do not have 20 percent of Japan's market for computer chips, these companies' combined share has doubled since the first semiconductor trade agreement was signed in the middle of 1986 -- from 8.6 percent to an estimated level of 17 percent or more for 1992. And this increase, American executives say, would never have happened without the agreement.
"The opinion of our industry, collectively, is absolutely unambiguous," Norman P. Neureiter, director of Texas Instruments Japan, said today. "The existence of this agreement has made a big difference."
The consensus is significant as American and Japanese officials from government and the chip industry prepare to meet in Hawaii next week. Given the pattern so far, the Americans are likely to try to keep the pressure on Japan without threatening the progress already made.
But some Japanese officials fear that this success might encourage American companies or the United States Government to ask for specific market-share goals in other industries in which Japan is said to be closed to foreigners.
The prospect of "managed trade" has the Japanese worried, especially since some in the Clinton Administration are thought to be more receptive to such an approach than was the Bush Administration.
Sozaburo Okamatsu, director general of the trade policy bureau at Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said, "I think that this is a bad example of an arrangement between two free-market economies, so I don't want to accept or extend this type of arrangement to other sectors."
Mr. Okamatsu said that specifying a market-share percentage in the semiconductor agreement had led to numerous misunderstandings, because the United States regards the figure as a commitment while Japan considers it only an expectation. But asked if foreign companies' share of the chip market in this country would have risen as much without the specific goal, Mr. Okamatsu declined to answer a "hypothetical" question.
 
Pressure Is Building
 Already, there is some pressure to move toward managed trade. Japanese companies have agreed to a monetary target for all the American automobile parts they will buy in a few years. And the Ford Motor Company's chief executive, Harold A. Poling, among others, has called for a policy requiring Japan to reduce its trade surplus by a certain amount each year, leaving it up to the Japanese to figure out how to do it.
This country has always been reluctant to set specific goals. Its 1986 semiconductor agreement with the United States included acknowledgments by Japan of the United States' expectation that foreign chip makers could achieve 20 percent of the market by the agreement's expiration in mid-1991. However, that language was contained not in the main text of the treaty, but in an unpublished side letter.
In mid-1991, with the market-share goal unmet, the agreement was renewed, with the 20 percent goal being postponed until the end of 1992 and being put into the main text of the treaty.
Market-share figures for the last quarter of 1992 are expected to be announced shortly, but it is already clear that they will fall short of 20 percent. Using the formula favored by the United States, the share is likely to be about 17 percent; using the formula advocated by Japan, perhaps 19 percent.
American Government and industry officials are already complaining, blaming Japan for a failure to adhere to the accord. There have even been discussions about whether sanctions should be levied.
 
Americans in Japan Differ
 Given that view, it seemed surprising to hear what several Japan-based executives of American semiconductor companies said at a press luncheon here today. While there are still difficulties in selling chips in Japan, they said, by and large the trade agreement has worked well in opening the market.
Until the agreement, the executives said, many Japanese companies would not even consider buying foreign-made semiconductors. Keith M. Kolerus, president of National Semiconductor Japan, said that in the past his company's executives were not even allowed inside the gates of a Japanese automobile company to make a sales pitch.
And William O. Howe, president of Intel Japan, recalled that Japanese chip purchasers "would basically stare at us with a big smile."
"They had absolutely zero intention of buying a foreign semiconductor," Mr. Howe said. "None." But the trade agreement forced Japanese companies to at least let would-be foreign competitors seek business, he said.
Keiske Yawata, president of LSI Logic K.K., the Japanese subsidiary of the Silicon Valley chip maker LSI Logic, said that the company would usually have had to wait 10 to 15 years to establish itself as a trustworthy supplier in Japan and begin receiving large orders. But aided by the trade agreement, he said, business started to flow in about three years.
 
Progress Is Still Significant
 Until 1986, foreign executives have said, their market share in Japan never rose much above 10 percent and was only 8.6 percent when the chip agreement was signed in 1986. But by the third quarter of 1992, foreign companies, which are predominantly American, had 15.9 percent by the United States' formula.
With Japan's semiconductor market worth about $20 billion a year, a 17 percent market share instead of 8.6 percent translates into an extra $1.7 billion in sales each year for the foreign manufacturers.
And because the Japanese market has grown since 1986, foreign sales of semiconductors here in 1991 were actually triple the level in 1986 -- about $3 billion compared with $1 billion -- according to the Electronic Industries Association of Japan.
The trade agreement has also contributed to a vast increase in the number of foreign computer chips being designed as part of Japanese products and in the number of alliances between American and Japanese companies.
Some of these gains, of course, might have occurred without the trade agreement. Intel, for instance, has rapidly increased its share of the semiconductor market throughout the world because of its near-monopoly on microprocessors used in personal computers.
 
Getting Down to Specifics
 But American executives say that the market-share goal was a very important part of the agreement because it represented a specific standard against which to measure progress. In past agreements, they said, Japan emphasized vague measures like setting up new procedures, new committees or new meetings to help open its market.
"They would count the successes by the number of people who attended the meetings," not by the increase in foreign-product sales, said Roger C. Mathus, the representative here of the Semiconductor Industry Association, the American chip-industry lobbying group.
Setting a high target and then holding Japan's feet to the fire has resulted in higher sales for the foreign manufacturers, even if the 20 percent goal has not been met. In fact, in mid-1991, when the second semiconductor agreement was signed, many assumed that the goal would not be reached by the end of 1992. That would have required foreign companies' market share to rise as much in 18 months as it had in the previous five years.
The big question is what to do next.
"We don't want to add fuel to the fire, but if the fire is put out, we may collapse," said Mr. Yawata, the LSI Logic executive. "So I think it's good to have a fire."
Although sanctions to punish the Japanese might harm relations between the two countries, some Americans caution that postponing the 20 percent goal again could have the effect of taking the pressure off. "You can't keep resetting the clock forever," said Mr. Mathus of the American trade group.
That is why there are various compromise proposals afloat, like raising the market-share target in exchange for more giving the Japanese more time to meet it. James Norling, the chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association, has proposed perhaps a 20 percent average share for all of 1993, meaning that foreign companies would have to be above 20 percent by the end of the year.
 
A Theorem: Coercion Works
 Japan, however, is not expected to agree to any new numerical targets -- unless it is threatened with sanctions by the United States. The Japanese are likely to propose programs to increase access, such as offering to help American companies design chips for consumer-electronics products, which now use a lot of chips made in this country.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Gains Abroad, Then Stalls in U.S. Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed on world currency markets yesterday, rising overseas and then losing some ground in uneventful domestic dealings.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $329.30 an ounce, up 20 cents from Tuesday. But the Republic National Bank said gold slipped 5 cents, to a late price of $328.80. 
 The dollar advanced in European trading ahead of today's scheduled meeting of the policy-making council of Germany's central bank. Traders were divided over whether the German officials would lower interest rates, and activity seemed to stall when trading shifted to the United States.
"The general expectation of a rate cut is priced into the market at this point," said Hillel Waxman, chief dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company.
The Government released figures yesterday on inflation and industrial output that would generally be viewed favorably by currency traders, but Mr. Waxman said the data "didn't really have much of an impact on the market."
He noted that currency dealings have been "sluggish for a couple of days now."
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 116.95 yen, down 0.83 yen from Tuesday's close. It was quoted later in London at 117.40. In New York, the dollar settled at 117.20 yen, up from 117.00 Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4515, from $1.4465 late Tuesday. In New York, a pound cost $1.4525, up from $1.4485 Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6615 German marks, down from 1.6635; 1.5325 Swiss francs, up from 1.5260; 5.6460 French francs, down from 5.6535; 1,605.00 Italian lire, down from 1.608.00, and 1.2509 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2508.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $329.35 an ounce, from $329 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold closed at $328.55, down from $328.80. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 11 cents to close at $329.15 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcies Hit a Record

BYLINE: by The Associated Press

 BODY:
For the eighth straight year, filings for bankruptcy protection in United States courts hit a record high in 1992, the American Bankruptcy Institute reported yesterday.
The rate of increase slowed, but the Washington-based research institute said anecdotal evidence showed no abatement in filings and no indication that underlying economic weakness was improving. 
 Record filings have been set every year since 1985. In 1992, 971,517 bankruptcy petitions were filed nationwide. Nonbusiness or personal bankruptcies accounted for 92 percent.
Using figures from the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, the institute said 1992 filings increased by less than 3 percent from 1991 filings, while 1991 filings rose by nearly 21 percent from 1990.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Funds Show Mixed Changes in Yields

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Changes in the yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were mixed in the latest week, according to the most recent survey by IBC's Money Fund Report.
Walter S. Frank, IBC's chief economist, expects that rates will remain stable for some time to come. 
 "The Fed isn't going to do anything while the President and Congress are working the budget, restrained by political policy," Mr. Frank said. "This means investors are going to find this area of the market not very attractive compared to alternatives like bonds, and some cases the stock market." "
Tax-exempt yields were up modestly in the week ended Tuesday, as a heavy supply of new municipal issues pushed yields higher.
Assets of tax-exempt funds declined by $230 million, to a total of $102.7 billion. The size of the decline was not considered meaningful, according to IBC analysts.
Portfolio managers made few changes in the week, and the average number of days left to maturity of the securities in their portfolios was unchanged at 54.
The IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Average seven-day compounded tax-exempt yield rose 6 basis points, to 1.81 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield up 7 basis points, to 1.80 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
IBC statisticians calculate that over a 30-day period, the compounded yield averaged 1.83 percent and the simple yield, 1.82 percent.
Ignoring state and local taxes, the taxable bond equivalent yield of the average seven-day compounded tax-exempt yield is about 2.51 percent for an investor in a 28 percent tax bracket and about 2.62 percent for the 31 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets exceeding $100 million, the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund was, for the second straight week, the best performer, with a yield of 2.55 percent.
 
Drop in Taxable Funds

 
 Assets of taxable money market funds fell $2.1 billion in the week ended yesterday, to $484.5 billion. Institutional fund assets were down $3.9 billion, to $166.6 billion, and retail assets rose $1.8 billion, to $317.8 billion.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable portfolios fell to 60, from 61.
The average seven-day yield on a taxable fund was down 2 basis points, to 2.69 percent, while the seven-day simple yield was down a basis point, to 2.66 percent.
Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, distributed by Olde Asset Management Inc. in Detroit, had the highest return among general-purpose taxable funds, at 3.49 percent.
Banks, which compete directly with money market funds for investor cash, were offering an average yield of 2.64 percent on their money market accounts.
