HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Foreign aid may be the glue that will keep Russia in one piece.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WILL Russia negotiate the tortuous path to capitalism without a detour through hyperinflation and depression? Can outsiders do much to keep it moving in the right direction?
Fatalism, tinged with skepticism, seems to be the fashion of the day. While Bill Clinton and his counterparts in Europe and Japan are certainly rooting for Boris Yeltsin to pull off a miracle, most of the technocrats working in the trenches scoff at the idea that Western cash and know-how can make much difference. 
 Most, but not all. Jeffrey Sachs, an economist at Harvard who is advising the Yeltsin Government, thinks there is room for a deal among Russia's warring domestic interests that could ease the way to competitive free markets. And he thinks foreign aid could be the glue that keeps the deal in one piece.
Even those peering at the Russian economy through rose-colored glasses find it hard to ignore the gloom. Inflation is pushing 30 percent a month. The tax system is not generating anything approaching the revenue needed to balance the budget. Oil and gas output is falling for want of modern equipment. Great industrial enterprises are running on empty, using inflationary credit extorted from Moscow to pay suppliers and meet payrolls.
Worst of all, no one seems to be in charge. The Yeltsin Government issues decrees that hostile bureaucrats and enterprise managers ignore at no particular peril. Economic policy is set by committees whose power ebbs and flows with the latest skirmishes between the Office of the President and the apparatchik-dominated Parliament.
The prevailing wisdom says that Mr. Yeltsin can win only by vanquishing the old order -- in particular, the big enterprises of the military-industrial complex that have banded together to lock the credit spigot in the open position. Just how (or whether) this can be accomplished is anybody's guess. As Keith Crane, the research director of the Planecon consulting firm in Washington sums it up, "They'll have to live through their own hell."
But Mr. Sachs, who has brokered stabilization plans in Poland and Bolivia, demurs. An interest realignment that ends the political stalemate is possible, he argues, and for two reasons.
First, the inflation dragon is close to consuming its own children. The trillions of rubles gushing out of the central bank and into politically connected enterprises are doing little more than making up for continuing losses in the purchasing power of enterprises' working capital. Meanwhile, trade between enterprises has become a financial crap shoot: a few weeks' delay in payment can wipe out even the most generously calculated profit margin.
Second, the Government's gain need not be the enterprises' loss. Those who see this contest as a zero-sum economic game, Mr. Sachs suggests, neglect the fact that Russia is hemorrhaging real resources to both former Soviet republics and foreign creditors.
Russia continues to subsidize the impoverished republics with both cheap resources and ruble credits to buy Russian industrial goods. This may suit Russia's foreign policy apparatus, which long ago learned that low-cost oil equals influence. And it may please the West, which is worried about the vacuum of power in Central Asia. But by Mr. Sachs's calculation, it is costing Russia 10 percent of national output -- 10 percent the economy can ill afford to sacrifice at a time when hard currency export revenues are tumbling.
Then there is the matter of servicing hard currency foreign debts. The big creditors are asking Russia to pay back $6.5 billion in 1993, some $4 billion more than Moscow is offering. This $4 billion represents about 4 percent of national income at the current exchange rate.
Mr. Sachs imagines a deal in which all the old enterprise debts to the banking system are canceled and the short-term credit spigot is shut off. The clean slate might then be used as a platform to restructure sectors of the Russian industrial economy with very high potential payoffs, notably energy, high-tech military and agricultural processing.
Long-term financing would come from a combination of increased Western aid and the redirection of resources from the periphery of the old empire. If these struggling republics need outside help, Mr. Sachs argues -- and presumably they do -- it should come from the West, not Russia.
Not every enemy of economic reform could be bought off with this formula, Mr. Sachs concedes. But many enterprises -- enough to build a winning political coalition -- ought to be willing to take their chances on a fresh start in an environment of stable prices and fiscal discipline, where capital is available to those who have a prayer of paying it back.
Is he right? Certainly the prevailing view is that more dollars going into Russia will lead only to more dollars going into very private bank accounts. "They would just be shoveling money into Switzerland," Mr. Crane said.
But the prevailing view is, by no coincidence, the most convenient view, Mr. Sachs contends, the one that gets hard-pressed Western governments off the financial hook. "On the eve of every successful stabilization," he insists, "it looks this hopeless."

HEADLINE: Bronzing Memories Happily

BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN

 BODY:
SIXTY years ago, parents who got the notion to preserve Susie's or Timmy's first walking shoes besought the local trophy maker or auto-body specialist to electroplate the shoes in between making loving cups or car parts.
The process consisted of stiffening the shoe with a lacquer-based -- and water polluting -- solution, then coating the leather with a conductive material, usually copper, which adhered when voltage was applied in a plating bath. Polishing, the final step, gave the shoes an antique finish, from which came the term bronzing. 
 But by the 1970's, with more stringent environmental standards, most such mom-and-pop resources got out of the plating business, unable to afford updated machinery. The large electroplating factories found the novelty shoe market too small to support such a labor-intensive practice. And the custom often fell prey to haphazard operations; customers experienced delays or even fraud. By the 1980's, many children's shoe stores had stopped their referrals.
"Bronzing can be a big scam," said Nadia Obeid, assistant manager of the Stride Rite store in Manhattan, at 730 Columbus Avenue (95th Street). She warned that unscrupulous vendors could disappear with the deposits, adding: "Shoes are picked up by the vendor and never returned. The parents wait months, call the vendor, and no one answers. They're out their deposit and shoes. What a trauma."
While some shoe store owners refuse to become the middlemen for bronzers and their customers, a majority of 20 Manhattan store owners interviewed now work with two shoe-preservation companies that, they say, do the job reliably, quickly and with a minimum of environmental damage. (For example, shoe-stiffening solutions are now water based to comply with waste-treatment regulations.) Even skeptics like Miss Obeid are taking their first baby steps toward become brokers.
The biggest and oldest provider of shoe bronzing in the United States is the Bron-Shoe Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio. It was founded 50 years ago by Violet Shinbach, who is credited in the shoe industry with being the first to commercialize the bronzing of baby shoes. To date, it has bronzed shoes for more than 12 million clients; its 100 artisans plated 400,000 shoes last year.
These days, preserving baby shoes is big business. Bron-Shoe projects $10 million in sales in 1993 in what Bob Kaynes Jr., its executive vice president, described as the "invigorated second baby boom." Many people bronze a single shoe, others pairs.
"Baby shoes are our bread and butter," said Mr. Kaynes, who is a grandson of the company's founder. "We had exponential growth in the 1950's. We're becoming very high profile, again."
Bron-Shoe markets its service in four ways, to appeal to parents' various senses of style, budgets and definitions of convenience. The American Bronzing Company, the company's "economy" division, solicits business from new mothers through direct mail. A single shoe costs about $20 to bronze-plate; a pair, $35. The customer mails in a reply card and receives a padded mailing envelope. (All four divisions require about eight weeks for processing.)
Thicker plating and a variety of finishes are available from the Bron-Shoe division. Copper-plating of a single shoe is about $25; a pair, $48. The burnishing that creates the bronze patina costs $2 more per shoe. Other metals cost more: sterling silver, $33 a shoe; 14-karat gold, $47.
The service is sold in infant and jewelry areas of department stores. In Manhattan, Bron-Shoe is available at Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's. Customers browse through a portfolio; the store forwards shoes to Ohio and notifies customers when they're ready to be picked up. Sears, Roebuck and J. C. Penney stores also offer the service.
The company's Senti-metal division offers the same finishes but has higher prices -- about $59 a shoe ($99 a pair) -- because the service is sold by appointment through 400 representatives, who receive referrals from children's shoe stores. They show samples of finished shoes, as well as stands and bases. The latter cost $15 to $150, depending on the material -- from plastic to marble. The company can incorporate shoes into bookends or picture frames.
In 1992, Bron-Shoe, through its Royal Bronzing Company, began selling a gift pack through mail-order catalogues, shoe and department stores, and added a toll-free number: (800) 783-9507. The pack includes a certificate for the antique-bronze finishing of one shoe for $30, or a pair for $50, using the thickest coating available.
The newest thing in shoe preservation is called porcelainizing. "We've got a younger market out there interested in a nonantique look and getting away from what their parents did," Mr. Kaynes said. For this new group of consumers, Bron-Shoe and Senti-metal offer a porcelainlike finish, baked onto shoes several times over, like a ceramic finish, to create the appearance of fine china. This finish -- in white, pastel pink or blue -- is about $34 a shoe; engraving is extra.
The other big preserver of baby shoes is Memory Lane, in Watertown, Mass. The company offers porcelainizing only, with a patented material it calls Dresdenite. "It's for people who want the shoe to look like the original," said Phyllis Fields, president of the 40-year-old company. Since the mid-1950's, she and her husband, Melvin, who is a chemist, have also been using the porcelainizing process to preserve patent-leather Mary Janes.
The company operates with a network of service representatives -- often the same stores used by Senti-metal (typically Buster Brown and Stride Rite outlets). Or customers can call Memory Lane directly, at (617) 926-3036, to have a sales clerk call on them.
Memory Lane's 25 artisans can match any shoe color, from pink ballet slippers to three-color high-top sneakers. They even improve on the originals. Shoelaces are typically accented with gold edging. Some artists can render a perfect Keds insignia; others will replicate Superman on the vamp. And a few have mastered lace borders for christening slippers.
Memory Lane prices start at $75 to $100 a shoe, depending on the detailing. Typical orders take about a month to complete. Memory Lane says it preserves about 400 pairs of shoes a month.
Robyn Feldman, manager of the Little Eric children's shoe store at 1331 Third Avenue (77th Street), has displayed samples of both Senti-metal and Memory Lane bronzing for seven years and is convinced of the companies' reliability. "I wouldn't trust my customers to any other companies, which can be, frankly, cut-and-run places," she said.
The Better Business Bureau for the Watertown, Mass., area and the Ohio Attorney General's office said they had no complaints about the companies on file.
Joe Hernandez, co-owner of Jack's Shoe Center, 669 Ninth Avenue (47th Street), also provides referrals to Senti-metal. He said the system worked smoothly.
Stride Rite stores that do refer their clients most often use Senti-metal. Based on experiences at her store, good and bad, Miss Obeid advised: "These are legitimate establishments, with addresses, track records, their own factories, a secretary. You'll know where they are taking your shoes and your money."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Put Stock in Off-Season Additions

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 17

 BODY:
They were minor deals the Mets regarded as major steals. Mike Maddux, journeyman reliever, and Joe Orsulak, consummate role player, were added to the roster this winter. As parts, they would make the whole greater, the organization proclaimed.
Orsulak, a 30-year-old left-handed batter with great instincts and intangibles in the outfield, offered insurance against an injury to Vince Coleman or a flop by Ryan Thompson. Maddux, having rescued his career from a near washout, was the kind of pitcher who could answer any number of bullpen emergencies -- setup right-hander, spot starter, long relief. 
 For the two additions -- modest by most standards, vital according to the Mets -- the early spring returns have been mixed. Orsulak has been everything the Mets had hoped he would be when they signed him as a free agent. He has hit. He has played all three outfield positions, his center field outings a pleasant surprise for even his most enthusiastic backers. He has offered his experience to an outfield otherwise loaded with inexperienced youngsters (Thompson and Darren Reed) and unpolished veterans (Vince Coleman and Bobby Bonilla.)
 
Bad Luck, Bad Calls
 "He's good and greedy, and a pro," Barry Foote, the Mets' first-base coach, said of Orsulak.
Maddux, on the other hand, has had an uneven first month with the Mets. He has given up at least two runs in each of his three outings, yielding four his first time on the mound against the Braves and three Tuesday night against the Phillies. Manager Jeff Torborg, though, has said he liked the essential tools he has seen. Maddux talks about bad luck, infield hits, umpire's calls.
"I've come to lots of spring trainings trying to win a job," said Maddux. "But I'm to a point where I can use the spring to get myself to where I want to be for the start of the season."
Two seasons ago, Maddux thought he was at the end of his career. There had been two rounds of elbow surgery, more than three times as many games in the minors as in the majors, fat earned run averages and a slim chance at a future. He asked the Padres for a tryout, won a job and methodically went about becoming the only National League reliever to post a 2.50 e.r.a. or lower in each of the last two seasons.
 
A Curious Decision
 The Mets were evidently overwhelmed enough by his recent success to discard the underwhelming total picture of his career, and so the club, which could have taken Maddux to arbitration, wound up signing him for two years and roughly $2 million. It was a curious decision, given the tight economics of the game and the often difficult-to-discern quality of middle relief pitching numbers.
"I think I've kept the baseball in the infield for the most part, and if I'm doing that I don't call it struggling," said Maddux. "Some of the results just haven't been there."
Orsulak is all about results, and not at all intrigued by public relations. The outfielder, who tied for the Orioles' lead in batting average three of the last five seasons despite being mostly a platoon player, has hit .347 this spring, homering once and driving in four runs. He has spoken almost not at all.
"What you see is what you get, and what you get is a guy who gives away nothing at the plate," said Paul Gibson, the left-hander who faced Orsulak regularly when in the American League. "He's always at the plate when you don't want to see him. He's made a career of taking advantage of other people's failed opportunities."
He has made the most of his opportunity here so far, and there is every likelihood, given Coleman's susceptibility to injury and Thompson's rawness at the plate.

 
 
 
INSIDE PITCH
 It was not the ideal outing for the man in the middle of multimillion-dollar contract negotiations. BRET SABERHAGEN was smacked around for five runs in four and two-third innings and removed before he could get the final out of the fifth inning because he had reached the outermost reaches of his pitch limit. "I threw 82 pitches, and it felt like 82 pitches," Saberhagen said. There were a couple of pitches, though, with added intent. "I keep hearing from Al that my curveball isn't sharp," said Saberhagen, in reference to the club's general manager, AL HARAZIN, and the man negotiating his contract extension. "I got a few off today." DWIGHT GOODEN pitched for the first time since injuring his toe and reported no great pain and no great worry about whether he will be able to start on Sunday. "A big relief to pass that test," said Gooden, who threw to MEL STOTTLEMYRE for 15 minutes. TIM BOGAR, the backup infielder, injured his left shoulder Tuesday night and will be sidelined for two to three days.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
VONS EXPECTS BAD PUBLICITY WILL HURT SALES

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Vons Companies said its first-quarter sales are expected to drop about 8 percent, in part because of negative publicity from contaminated fast-food hamburgers. Vons, Southern California's largest supermarket chain, said yesterday that other factors for the projected sales drop included the poor economy, store remodeling and competitors' recent changes in pricing and promotions. But in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Vons said it did not expect operating earnings or cash flow for the quarter ending March 28 to "decline materially" because of the expected sales dip. 
A Vons subsidiary, Vons Meat Service Center, processed meat into frozen hamburger patties for Foodmaker, parent company of Jack in the Box. The product was implicated in the E. coli outbreak in which at least two children died and more than 500 people fell ill.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ANHEUSER EXPECTS NARROWER FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would fall 7 percent as beer sales have been hampered by the sluggish economy, last week's storm and a change in the company's delivery system. The St. Louis-based beverage giant expects to earn about 69 cents a share in the period, compared with earnings of 74 cents a share for the similar period a year ago. 
 The company's forecast is 16 percent below the mean Wall Street estimate of 82 cents a share for the quarter, according to Zacks Investment Research. Shares of Anheuser-Busch fell $2.25 yesterday, to $50.75, equaling the stock's low price for the last 52 weeks.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Asian Arms Races

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
Westerners barely noticed the announcement last month that Indonesia had bought a third of the former East German Navy at a bargain-basement price. And perhaps only stockholders paid attention as McDonnell Douglas and General Dynamics scrambled to Malaysia recently to hawk discounted fighter aircraft in a losing price war with Russia, which was willing to be paid partly in palm oil. Eyebrows raised only at the specter of nuclear war in Korea this week.
If the end of the cold war produced a geostrategic peace and a rush to cut military spending in Europe, it prompted new uncertainty and anxiety in East Asia -- and set off a colossal shopping spree for arms. 
 Now that the Soviet Union has collapsed, East Asians are far less sure who will attack them -- or who will protect them now that the U.S. is reducing its presence overseas. And they are now rich enough to buy a lot of firepower insurance.
East Asian nations made 35 percent of all major weapons purchases in 1991. Even so, they lag far behind Europe in modern military punch. But if Europe continues to slash arms spending and Asian trends continue, East Asia will be the world's most heavily armed area by century's end.
China has raised defense spending a whopping 50 percent over two years, and just announced a new 15 percent hike. Japan was the only industrialized country whose arms budget increased last year. Singapore's rose 23 percent in 1991. Taiwan, Malaysia and Thailand followed suit with double-digit spurts. So did South Korea, where alarms continue to sound about North Korean nukes.
To be sure, much of this buildup is routine. East Asian economies have been booming, and Asians can afford expensive modern arms. Most of the big spenders can also legitimately claim the need to modernize ancient equipment.
But these nations are not simply refurbishing. Some are becoming major arms makers and exporters, and many more are expanding their capacity to attack as well as defend.
South Korea has good reason to beef up. Dying North Korea, one of the last Communist states and by far the most dangerous, is capable of anything. The nuclear crisis here requires immediate attention. And minor conflicts could explode later.
Like China. Freed from the Soviet threat and less concerned with American power, Beijing might be tempted to flex its new muscles, as it's been doing in the oil-rich Spratly Islands.
At least as alarming is the mounting China-Taiwan face-off. Taipei is shopping for arms like there's no tomorrow. It bought 150 F-16's from the U.S. and wants about half again as many modern French fighters. It is also buying up submarines, anti-sub helicopters and naval vessels.
This is Taiwan's way of asserting its independence from the mainland. And that is the one thing that no Chinese leader, reformer or unreconstructed Communist, can stand for.
Japan, by far the most modern military power in the region and with a military budget soon to exceed any Western European country's, is unsettled by all these events. Other countries fear its unease may translate into military aggressiveness. But Tokyo has been a leader in trying to tamp down anxieties.
Above all, Japan and its neighbors want the U.S. to maintain a strong presence in East Asia. And they will be happy to hear the Clinton Administration's wise decision to make only small cuts in U.S. forces here, even as it slashes troops in Europe.
For some time, Japan and the others have also wanted to talk to each other about mutual security, only to be blocked by the U.S. The Reagan and Bush Administrations couldn't stand the idea. They clung to the old Pacific security network, based on direct security links between individual Asian nations and Washington, which kept the U.S. central but did not weave regional trust.
The Clinton team has already quietly ditched that ostrich policy, encouraging the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, to talk about common military problems at a May meeting. It will be an informal discussion of who's buying what and why. Asean members will then reach out for similar talks with Russia, China, Japan and the U.S. That's a good start toward preventing the East Asian shopping spree from becoming a shooting spree.

HEADLINE: Timber Industry Wants You to Hate Owls

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Lumber Prices Are Soaring on Shortages and Owl Feud" (Business Day, March 11): According to all the timber industry sources you cite, an 8-inch, 22-ounce owl is responsible for one of the greatest stampedes the lumber market has ever witnessed. In reality, there is no evidence that environmental protection measures are driving up lumber prices.
Lumber prices today are lower than in 1975, when adjusted for inflation, as a new analysis of lumber prices by the Congressional Research Service confirms. 
 Even a leading timber industry economist agrees lumber is a bargain for consumers. The Spokane (Wash.) Spokesman-Review has quoted Fred Reseburg, economic services director for the Western Wood Products Association, as saying, "The public has really been getting a bargain on lumber."
He added that lumber is being sold at or below 1970's price levels.
The demand for housing, especially in postrecession years, is the single largest factor affecting lumber prices. When housing starts rise, so do lumber prices, and when housing falls off, lumber prices decline. Finally, lumber prices rise every spring as builders stockpile inventory for the new construction year.
The biggest influence on lumber prices this year has been the hysteria whipped up by timber companies with a well-financed national campaign. This tactic has panicked the lumber markets, which these groups hope to exploit to create political backlash against Federal environmental laws.
There is a crisis in America's national forests, but it's not the one timber companies want you to think. Years of overcutting, neglect, mismanagement and cozy industry-Federal deals have left many national forests in tatters. More than 365,000 miles of logging roads slice through what remains of the public's forests. And when timber companies log these public lands, the Government loses millions of dollars. In 1992, taxpayers lost more than $350 million on timber sales from 111 national forests.
 
KARIN P. SHELDON
President, The Wilderness Society
Washington, March 11, 1993

HEADLINE: When Publishers Unite, Authors Must Worry

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"In a highly unusual marriage of convenience and commerce, Random House and Simon & Schuster will jointly publish the joint campaign memoirs of James Carville, President Clinton's chief strategist, and Mary Matalin, a top political aide to President George Bush" (Business Day, Feb. 23).
This joint purchase is a great marketing gimmick. But the publishing deal is bad news for writers and ultimately for the reading public. This deal was reportedly conceived by bidders in the middle of an auction in which they were bidding against each other and other parties. Why should this practice not be considered a restraint of trade? Doesn't this kind of deal avoid competition between two competitors and permit them to cut, if not set, a price? 
 The deal, which reportedly guaranteed an $850,000 advance, ended up costing two competitors half of what one of them would have paid if it had won the auction alone. Probably less than half, because if the auction played itself, the price could well have gone higher. I can understand why the publishers like the gimmick, but not why any writer would.
Publishers, bemused by the recession, are buying fewer serious books and paying less money to serious writers, while they run after celebrities, offering huge advances. For most writers, the pool of available money to publish books is diminished.
Publishers dislike auctions of books, often blaming lawyers, who now represent many authors, for using the technique to escalate prices. But writers ought to get the best price available for their work in a free and open market. If publishers can pre-empt the market from running its course by joining forces with competitors, authors will not get the top prices.
 
RONALD GOLDFARB
Washington, March 3, 1993
The writer is a lawyer and literary agent.

HEADLINE: Price War Traps Smaller PC Makers

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Gregory E. Herrick believes he is doing all he can to survive the costly war in prices and customer services that has roiled the personal computer industry since last June, forcing some of his competitors, namely Nippon Steel's Librex brand and Philips Electronics' Magnavox, to abandon the personal computer market in North America and changing the nature of the business for even the strongest.
The Minneapolis-based company he heads, Zeos International, hired a new president, won applause from the trade press for three of several new machines, slashed costs by auctioning small operations and paring inventories, attracted new financing and opened gleaming new assembly lines. 
 Yet Zeos still posted a loss of $28 million for last year, with sales dropping from 1991 levels every quarter. Mr. Herrick says the pricing battles must ease soon because "at some juncture, there is just no more to cut."
Medium-sized manufacturers like Zeos and Advanced Logic Research, which is losing money for the first time after nine profitable years, are threatened by the continuing shakeout in the $60 billion personal computer market. On Monday, the Compuadd Computer Corporation of Austin, Tex, said it would close its 110 retail stores and reduce its work force from 1,170 to approximately 550 people. It also said its revenue could fall, from $524.4 million last year to below $350 million for this year.
"A lot of middle- and lower-tier vendors are bloodied and on the ropes," Steven L. Eskenazi, technology analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, said.
Bigger companies that slashed operating costs last year trying to keep pace with falling prices now find their profits pinched further as they compete on more fronts to capture sales.
"Buyers are looking at brand names, service and support, technological differences and even the financial stability of a vendor itself," said Jim Schraith, vice president at AST Research, in Irvine, Calif., which topped $1 billion in sales last year for the first time. "I would guess that 80 percent of the total PC market will be held by the 10 largest suppliers in five years, up from 58 percent last year."
Larger rivals like Compaq Computer and Dell Computer have applied much of the pressure, not just with well-publicized price cuts, but with costly benefits for customers including next-day repair service, multiple-year warranties on new machines and free telephone consultations. Dell, with sales of more than $2 billion, is 10 times larger than Zeos and Advanced Logic.
To some, those packages are as big a draw as low prices. "They are very buttoned up, on top of everything with all the services they offer nationwide," said Paula van der Geest of Stanfordville, N.Y., who selected Dell as the primary vendor for a new international computer-based service she organized. "I could be telling someone in Maine to get their computer through Dell. There is 24-hour replacement if the machine goes down. Those things are valuable. And the prices are great."
 An overhauled Compaq, vowing to grab the lead from I.B.M. in total worldwide sales, touched off the pricing war last June, when it introduced several personal computers priced below $2,000. Dell and the International Business Machines Corporation followed with cuts that matched Compaq's or went lower.
Compaq slashed prices again last week on several desktop and notebook machines by as much as 15 percent and started a direct-mail operation last Friday. And Wall Street believes that Dell Computer is gearing up for more intensive pricing battles -- and thinner profit margins -- in the months ahead.
These high-profile companies and a handful of smaller peers that have annual sales of nearly $1 billion or more, including Gateway 2000, AST Research and Packard Bell, have the distribution, speed, cash, engineering capabilities and manufacturing efficiency to slug it out, perhaps for years.
Mr. Eskenazi of Alex. Brown estimated that Compaq, Dell, AST and Gateway 2000 increased their share of units shipped last year. Among the majors, only I.B.M. lost ground. But Big Blue reversed that trend after joining the pricing battle late last year. Mr. Eskenazi said the five companies together would increase their share of unit shipments to 34 percent of the global market this year, compared with 27 percent last year and 23 percent in 1991.
 
 
Assembly Shops
 There are also hundreds of assembly shops, ranging from the multiple locations of national computer supercenters like CompUSA to small garage and storefront outposts that compete mainly on price because they commit little capital for parts, research or marketing.
That leaves companies like Zeos and Advanced Logic wedged in what consultants and analysts say has become a very vulnerable middle: with yearly sales barely exceeding $200 million apiece and sliding. In addition to the withdrawals from the market, Everex Systems entered a bankruptcy reorganization. Sales at Northgate Computer Systems plunged 26 percent last year, to $124 million, although the Minneapolis-based company posted a small fourth-quarter profit despite an overall loss of $15.5 million for 1992.
 
 
Discounting Rewrote the Rules
 Michael Nevens, the partner who heads studies of personal computers at McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, said that once these companies discovered that they no longer could price their machines as much as 40 percent or more under the big brands, cracks in their business plans began to spread.
"At some point, the economic rationale for the existence of these smaller players goes away," Mr. Nevens said.
The big companies have virtually insurmountable advantages with their legions of telemarketing specialists and design engineers, as well as brand names that influence major buyers, Mr. Eskenazi said. "Aggressive players like Dell and Compaq may want to cut prices proactively, invest in marketing and sales programs or expand geographically or in production lines in order to deliver the final knockout blow," he said.
 
Looking for Niches
 Mr. Herrick at Zeos, and Gene Lu, chairman and chief executive of Advanced Logic, based in Irvine, Calif., are trying to carve out self-preserving niches. Zeos scaled back a test started last year to sell bare-bones models through Sam's Wholesale Club, where Dell is now entrenched, to concentrate on telephone orders and direct-mail shipments, where it competes head-on with Dell, I.B.M. , Gateway 2000 and soon, Compaq.
While Dell and Compaq's gains have come from tapping small-business and home buyers through sales at rapidly expanding computer supercenters like CompUSA, Circuit City and Computer City, Zeos has held fast to computer-literate shoppers. "Brand names are a refuge for the ignorant," Mr. Herrick said. "Someone who picks up the telephone and makes a decision to spend $2,000 to $3,000 on a computer has a good ability to discern what is good value for the money."
Mr. Herrick, 41, said Zeos had nibbled away at Dell, Gateway and Compaq through advertisements in magazines like PC Week, PC World and PC Computing. Zeos, which sold its first personal computers in 1987, offers immediate shipment of several machines that are similar to popular ones that its rivals cannot keep in stock.
"We call it Computers Now, and it ranges from 10 to 15 different configurations" of Zeos machines, Mr. Herrick said. "We're going after these people who can't deliver."
 
 
Future in Network Building
 Mr. Nevens of McKinsey said the big action in the future would come from businesses building networks of a dozen or more computers that also want a full range of services along with the latest models and low prices.
"The real core of the market is and will remain people who are using their PC's on a network to do more and more complicated business tasks," Mr. Nevens said.
Zeos cut costs and laid off some workers when it moved operations late last year from five different buildings in St. Paul to a refurbished building in Minneapolis once occupied by Unisys, the mainframe maker. The company obtained $12.5 million in new credit from the Congress Financial Corporation in December, a month after Mr. Herrick handed off some of his duties to a new president, Martyn Ratcliffe, from Vtech Computers, in Beaverton, Ore.
 
 
New Ways to Sell
 Mr. Lu of Advanced Logic said the narrowing profit margins last year forced him to rework longstanding relationships with his company's major distributors, specialty retailers such as Computerland , Entre and Micro Integration.
Instead of selling them a completed system, Advanced Logic now patches together a chassis with a few basic parts -- one model for $500 and another for $680 -- to which the retailers add custom chips, peripherals and other equipment before the final sale.
Mail order now accounts for about 10 percent of its $207 million in sales. Mr. Lu also eliminated suggested retail prices and gave its more than 4,000 resellers a cost-plus formula designed to add a few percentage points of profit for the resellers.
"We're still counting on our technology to keep us in the same league, competing for the same business," he said.
Compaq disagrees. "Weaker companies are being confronted with new standards, which they will not be capable of providing," Eckhard Pfeiffer, Compaq's president and chief executive, said. "There is clearly a consolidation under way. Frankly, we hope it will accelerate."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 3, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart accompanying an article in Business Day on March 18, about the price pressures faced by small makers of personal computers, misidentified a company and misstated the loss in its first fiscal quarter of 1993, which ended Dec. 31. The company's name is Advanced Logic Research and it lost $915,000 in the quarter.

HEADLINE: HOUSE DEMOCRATS UNITE TO APPROVE CLINTON'S BUDGET

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, March 19

 BODY:
The House of Representatives, in a late-night session, gave President Clinton two major victories as overwhelming Democratic majorities passed first his plan to cut the deficit and then his jobs bill, designed to foster short-term economic stimulus.
Early today, at 12:38 A.M., a 235-to-190 vote sent the $16 billion jobs measure to the Senate. That bill had been challenged by some conservative Democrats who doubted its ability to spur the economy, but in the end only 22 Democrats deserted their party. 
 About three and a half hours earlier, the House voted 243 to 183 to pass Mr. Clinton's plan to curb the deficit by raising taxes and cutting spending. Only 11 Democrats voted against the plan after Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, told the House the plan would strengthen the nation. "I think we have a President who has a plan," he said. "You may not agree with it, but I think he deserves a chance."
 
Limits on Total Spending
 The budget resolution sets limits on total spending and taxation, with the expectation that it will reduce the deficit, now about $300 billion, to below $200 billion by the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, 1996. Under the procedures of the Congressional Budget Act, votes on specific tax increases and spending cuts will come this summer.
The budget resolution deals with tax and spending decisions affecting the fiscal year that begins this October. The emergency spending bill, once it makes its way through the Senate and is signed by the President, would make money available immediately.
A majority of the House followed the arguments of members like Representative Carrie Meek, a Florida Democrat who said: "Vote for this stimulus package. It's an investment in America."
 
Need to Create Jobs
 And Representative David Bonior, the Democratic whip from Michigan, advised: "Stay with the President. Stay with his total package."
Besides calling wavering lawmakers, Mr. Clinton defended his economic measures publicly on Thursday, describing those who asked that it be cut back as the "status-quo lite" crowd. He said in a speech to Treasury Department employees, "Frankly, I think if we do a little less of everything -- we have a little less deficit reduction, a little less spending cut, a little less tax cut, a little less investment -- we'll get a lot less in results."
"We've got to create jobs on our own here," he said. "That's what the stimulus package is about."
The Democrats achieved remarkable unity in the early voting. None abandoned their party on the vote that set procedures for considering the measure. Only three deserted their leaders to support a plan offered by Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, that sought to cut the deficit without any tax increases. Taxes account for almost half the approximately $500 billion in the Democratic plan's deficit cutting over five years. The Kasich plan was also opposed by 41 Republicans as it lost, 295 to 135.
The Democrats' unity will be repeatedly tested throughout the spring and summer as the general provisions of the budget resolution are translated into painful votes to cut popular programs and increase taxes. As Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader, said, "The real budget work will be done in the trenches of our committees."
Even so, the resolution's overall limits on spending and taxes erect solid walls within which other Congressional committees must operate. It also offers a nonbinding plan on how to achieve its deficit cuts. The committees can choose different priorities, as long as they reach the same result. But the budget plan provides those committees with political cover for doing unpopular things.
While the House voted, the Senate debated a very similar resolution. Both the House and Senate measures would cut domestic spending slightly more than Mr. Clinton proposed, changes that he accepted quickly. The differences between the two proposed resolutions are small enough so that agreement in a House-Senate conference should not be difficult, and Congress may be able to meet its goal of adopting a final resolution before it takes an Easter vacation on April 2.
 
Week of Debate
 Senate rules provide 50 hours of debate on the budget resolution, so decisive action is not expected before next week. Nor will the Senate vote on both the budget and stimulus methods in a single day, a device House leaders developed so that lawmakers can have flexibility in describing their votes to constituents this weekend.
There is also some uncertainty in the Senate over the $16 billion spending program, and Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, announced Thursday that he would try to balance some of it with additional spending cuts. He said he would try to amend the spending bill, but House leaders blocked his amendment from floor consideration on Thursday.
The Senate did take one significant vote on Thursday, defeating an effort led by Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, to eliminate authority for Mr. Clinton's proposed energy tax from the resolution. That vote was 53 to 46.
The House went on to the spending bill only after bitter Republican complaints against the "tyranny" of Democrats in controlling procedures and writing procedural rules that denied the minority the chance to offer any amendments.
They sought repeatedly to cut back on such items as $3 billion for highway construction, $1 billion for summer youth jobs, $4 billion for unemployment benefits, $2.5 billion for community development block grants, $2.6 billion for small business loans and $1.9 billion for college grants.
Representative David Dreier, Republican of California, said, "This gag rule is a clear reflection of a Democratic leadership that opposes open debate, that scoffs at fiscal responsibility, and that pays nothing more than lip service to the rights of peoples' representatives in Congress."
Thursday's debate in the House provided the same sort of oratory that has accompanied votes on these issues for several years.
But if the arguments were old, some of the voices were new.
Representative Eva Clayton, the North Carolina Democrat elected by her party's 63 freshmen to be their leader, called the vote on the Clinton budget "a chance to move America and move it in the right direction."
Representative Deborah Pryce, a freshman Republican from Ohio, disagreed. "Raising taxes on Americans is not the answer," she said. "Higher taxes lead to greater spending, not deficit reduction."
Some familiar voices were also heard with familiar arguments. "This is indeed a defining moment between the two parties," Mr. Michel said. "Democrats prefer to raise taxes on practically everyone, and Republicans do not."
Another Democratic freshman, Representative Cynthia McKinney of Georgia, challenged that definition. Under Republicans, she said, "Government serves the needs of a few of us at the expense of the rest of us."
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, "What makes our budget the best is that it can pass, and we're doing something about the deficit."
With one exception, all of the representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut voted along party lines. The exception was Representative Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat from Bellmawr, N.J., who sided with Republicans. He said he voted against the President's budget plan because it included five years of new taxes. But he said he supported the economic stimulus package because it would create jobs and pay for itself.
While Republicans challenged the plan for its proposed taxes and military cuts, the Congressional Black Caucus offered an alternative plan that would have cut military spending more heavily to provide more money for domestic spending and foreign aid to countries like Somalia.
Barbara Rose Collins, Democrat of Michigan, said the caucus's package would "create jobs, feed children and educate our children."
The plan was defeated by a vote of 335 to 87.
House action was repeatedly delayed by Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, who forced at least four insubstantial roll-call votes that took up at least an hour and a half. He said he did so because the Democratic leaders had not allowed the House to consider a proposed budget of his as a possible substitute. It would have allowed Federal spending to grow by no more than 2 percent a year, and he said it would have led to more than $800 billion in budget cuts over five years.
He explained his delaying tactics in these terms: "If a guy pushes you around the schoolyard and you punch him in the mouth just one time, sometimes he gets the idea that it's better to work with you than against you."
Representative Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, suggested that Mr. Burton was being "petulant and puerile."

HEADLINE: Clinton Health Team Member Is Forced Aside Over Conflict

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The wall of secrecy surrounding the membership of Hillary Rodham Clinton's health policy team was breached today as White House officials finally identified one of its top members, only to disclose that he had been demoted for conflicts of interest.
The adviser, Thomas O. Pyle, was the head of one of 15 committees working for the Task Force on National Health Care Reform. He is also chairman of the Jackson Hole Group, a conclave of health-care executives and policy analysts sometimes described as a brain trust for the Administration. 
 Until today, White House officials had been unwilling to acknowledge that Mr. Pyle was on the staff of the task force. And, under questioning today, they said only that he had been removed from his job and given an undefined "consultant" position because of concern about his stock ownership and service as a director of several companies in the health-care industry.
Mr. Pyle was, in effect, dismissed for crossing a line that is still not visible. In its rush to assemble a health policy, the White House hired many outside experts, temporary employees and consultants who say they do not completely understand Federal personnel laws or ethics rules.
It is now clear that the White House has established conflict-of-interest guidelines for the task force. But it is not entirely clear what those rules are, as the staff of more than 500 people races to devise a proposal to control health costs and guarantee coverage for all Americans. President Clinton has said he will send the proposal to Congress by May 1.
While confirming Mr. Pyle's role, the White House still refused to identify any of the other people employed by the task force, in large or small roles. But because their work could send shock waves through the American economy, trying to discover their identities has become a major Washington pastime.
Trade publications have named roughly 200 of the more than 500 people working for the task force. Of those who head the 15 working groups, about a dozen are known, including six Federal employees, a California state official, a professor of sociology and a policy analyst identified with an advocacy group for elderly people. None of these seemed as likely as Mr. Pyle to have a financial conflict of interest.
Mr. Pyle said that Ira C. Magaziner, the senior adviser for policy development who is serving as manager of the task force operations, had told him he would have to step down as chairman of a panel working on such issues as medical malpractice, training of health-care professionals and ways to measure the quality of care.
Mr. Pyle remains a consultant to the task force. He has much less authority, but retains an office and a telephone in the Old Executive Office Building, next to the White House.
 
Ethical Questions Raised
 His case raises ethical questions that loom over the work of Mr. Clinton's health policy advisers. A White House lawyer has told some people working for the task force that they may have "criminal liability" if they keep their ties to health-related businesses while working for the Government.
But the laws are complex. In its ethics handbook for Federal employees, the Justice Department summarizes one criminal law this way: "You may not participate personally and substantially in a matter in which you, your spouse, minor child or partner has a financial interest. This prohibition also applies if an organization in which you serve as an officer, director, trustee, partner or employee has a financial interest."
Mr. Pyle said he started working for the White House on Feb. 8, assuming he would be paid for his services. But he added, "I have not signed any employment forms, and I have never been paid."
He said he informed White House officials of his business interests and outside activities because he realized they might create conflicts of interest.
 
Told About Business Ties
 "Before coming to Washington, I informed Magaziner and other officials of all my business ties," Mr. Pyle said in an interview. "After coming to Washington, I forcefully and repeatedly brought this issue up -- my situation, my supposed conflicts. But I found it quite difficult to get anyone to pay attention."
He added: "Eventually, it was decided that I did have conflicts. I could not be an employee of the Government, according to various rules established for the task force, some of which are quite ad hoc."
Robert O. Boorstin, a spokesman for the task force, said Mr. Pyle's case showed that the Administration would enforce rigorous standards against conflict of interest.
"Tom Pyle is one of the most talented, innovative health administrators in America," Mr. Boorstin said. "We wanted his input. He was asked to come down and be a 'cluster' leader. But he could not extricate himself from a bunch of boards he sits on."
From 1978 to 1991, Mr. Pyle was chief executive of the Harvard Community Health Plan, the largest health maintenance organization in New England. It now has 540,000 members.
He said he was still a director of the Millipore Corporation, a multinational high-technology company based in Bedford, Mass., and an adviser to the KBL Healthcare Acquisition Corporation, a merchant banking concern in which he owns stock.
Millipore sells a wide range of products to drug companies, biotechnology companies, hospitals and clinical laboratories, among other customers. KBL describes itself as a "publicly traded buyout fund organized for the express purpose of consummating a significant acquisition in the health-care field," and says its initial capitalization will exceed $15 million.
Mr. Pyle is a senior adviser on health care for the Boston Consulting Group, which has many clients in the health-care industry. He said he was also a director of the Chickering Group, which sells student health insurance to universities, and a director of the Controlled Risk Insurance Company of the Cayman Islands, which provides malpractice insurance to doctors.
For 10 years Mr. Pyle has attended meetings of the Jackson Hole Group, which takes its name from its meeting place in Wyoming and consists mainly of people outside the Government.
 
First Open Meeting Set
 The task force, formed on Jan. 25, tentatively plans to hold its first open meeting on March 29. Mrs. Clinton has defended the secrecy of the panel by saying, "We do not want to have health-care legislation in the Clinton Administration written by any special-interest group."
But William G. Kopit, a health-care specialist at Epstein, Becker & Green, a Washington law firm, said: "There is a double standard here. Conflict-of-interest principles are not interpreted consistently. Some special interest groups are more special than others."
"People who have formal ties to trade associations in the health-care industry cannot work for the task force or attend meetings of its staff," he continued. "But some people on the staff of the task force have ties to business and consulting groups whose paying clients include corporations in the health-care industry."
Information about the task force is commercially valuable. "We have received calls from Wall Street investment houses," said Mr. Kopit. "They want to know what health-care companies are well-positioned for health-care reform under President Clinton."
Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, and Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, complained this week that the foundation was acting in a partisan way. In a letter to the foundation, the Republican leaders said such conduct was "inappropriate for a nonprofit, tax-exempt, supposedly nonpartisan foundation."
Thomas P. Gore 2d, a vice president of the foundation, said the charges had no merit. But he added, "It is a concern of ours, that we are seen as being boldly partisan."
 
Some of Those Identified
 Only a handful of the many people working for Mrs. Clinton have been identified. One is Walter A. Zelman, a California insurance official who is supervising the design of the new health-care system. Judith Feder, a health policy analyst who worked in the Clinton campaign last year, is now trying to decide what health benefits should be guaranteed to all Americans.
Dr. Stephen H. Bandeian, a physician with a law degree who worked at the Office of Management and Budget under President George Bush, is in charge of linking the new program to existing programs like Medicare and veterans' health benefits.
Paul Starr, a professor of sociology at Princeton University, is chairman of the panel drafting proposals for short-term cost controls.
Marina Weiss, an aide to Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, is responsible for determining how to pay for the President's ambitious program. Robyn I. Stone, a policy analyst at Project Hope, an international health foundation, is in charge of proposals for long-term care, including nursing homes.
Dr. Bernard S. Arons, a psychiatrist from the National Institute of Mental Health, leads the panel on mental health care. David M. Cutler, a Harvard economist, is in charge of analyzing the economic effects of Mr. Clinton's program.
And Kenneth E. Thorpe, a Clinton campaign adviser now working at the Department of Health and Human Services, is supervising "quantitative analysis" of the proposal.

HEADLINE: U.S. Companies Quietly Returning to South Africa

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, March 18

 BODY:
The advertisement spread across two pages of a Johannesburg newspaper pictures a bottle of pharmaceutical capsules and the announcement: "Now Legally Available."
The product on sale is not a drug, but the Windows computer program from the Microsoft Corporation, the American producer of software that withdrew from South Africa in 1986 when an anti-apartheid boycott was gathering force. For years there was a gray market in Microsoft products, but now the company is back, with a small office and an ad campaign that transforms the long taboo into a marketing come-on. 
 Although the African National Congress is still months away from lifting its injunction against doing business with the white Government, American companies are quietly drifting back into South Africa, most of them on scouting expeditions, but some re-establishing their corporate beachheads in Africa's most promising market.
Already the waning of South Africa's infamy has brought formerly illicit American brands like M&M candies, Tampax tampons and the Compaq Computer Corporation. For the first time since sanctions were introduced, the number of American companies doing direct business here rose last year, from 106 to 119, according to the Investor Responsiblity Research Center, a Washington-based group that monitors compliance with sanctions. For the first time, American exports to South Africa have surpassed their pre-sanctions levels.
So far, however, the big producers, whose dollars and jobs South Africans hope will help pull them out of a deep economic slough, are keeping a wary distance. Economists and businessmen agree that even though the stigma of South Africa is disappearing, chronic violence, political confusion and deep doubts about the economic policies of a future government will deny the country any quick windfall from its new respectability.
"They worry about strikes," said Michelle Cohen, executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce in Southern Africa. "They worry about the violence that is disruptive to business. They worry about prescriptive laws. Above all, they worry about whether there will be a free market."
"Unless the new government has the answer to those economic questions, we can forget about investment," said Thami Mazwai, editor of the black business magazine Enterprise. "Between now and, say, 1996, only gamblers will come in."
The major exodus of American business began in 1985 when foreign banks froze new credits to South Africa. The next year Congress voted over President Reagan's veto to restrict trade, investment and lending by American companies in South Africa. Scores of state and local governments enacted their own anti-apartheid statutes.
 
U.S. Exports Slowly Rising
 The sanctions contained numerous loopholes, and to this day their impact on South Africa is hotly debated. But many American companies sold out and fled rather than face the wrath of shareholders or the loss of contracts with governments at home.
American exports to South Africa plunged from $2.27 billion in 1984 to $1.20 billion the following year, before slowly creeping upward. Exports in 1992 were $2.43 billion.
President George Bush repealed the Federal restrictions on trade with South Africa in July 1991, but 164 state and local governments in the United States still restrict business with South Africa, and anti-apartheid lobby groups have not let up their pressure.
The African National Congress, now alarmed about inheriting a country with a crippled economy, says it will urge the end of all economic sanctions when a date has been set for the first universal elections, and a transitional council has been created to assure a fair campaign. This is expected about midyear.
The congress has given mixed signals about what companies should do in the meantime.
"I suppose I take the view, 'So what?' " shrugged Trevor Manuel, head of the congress's economic department, when asked how the congress feels about companies already opening shop in South Africa. Mr. Manuel said the congress is now more concerned with marketing South Africa as a future investment opportunity than with policing the vestiges of the anti-apartheid campaign.
 
Apple Computer Told to Wait
 Before opening its office here, Microsoft got an informal nod of approval from congress officials, according to a Microsoft distributor. "The people I deal with in the A.N.C. have all kind of accepted that sanctions are gone and we need to move on and create jobs," said the distributor, Dana Buys of Work Group Systems.
But companies that have waited for an unambiguous, top-level signal from the African National Congress have been frustrated. Apple Computer Inc., which says it is eager to open an office here, met with the congress president, Nelson Mandela, last September, and was told to stay out of South Africa until the congress makes its formal announcement.
David de Jong, an independent distributor who handles Apple technology, grumbled that Microsoft's entry may have been smoothed by the fact that both the congress and its most important political ally, the Congress of South African Trade Unions, use Microsoft products, many of them donated by the company.
"They are prepared to give absolution if they receive sufficient benefits," Mr. de Jong suggested. He added that when he approached Mr. Mandela recently to ask about Apple's prospects, the congress leader wanted to know why Apple had not yet delivered the 100 Powerbook laptop computers Apple executives had promised the congress as a gift.
When the congress does call for the resumption of trade, it may discover that repealing sanctions is as cumbersome as imposing them. William Moses, senior analyst with the Investor Responsibility Research Center, noted that 50 cities, including New York and Los Angeles, have rules against giving contracts to banks or suppliers that do business with South Africa.
"If you sell gum or clothing, it's not going to matter to you that Los Angeles or New York won't buy from you," Mr. Moses said. "If you provide food for hospitals or schools, or sell photocopiers, or road-building equipment, it matters a lot."
Mr. Manuel of the African National Congress promised that when the time comes the congress will mount a lobbying campaign to revoke these sanctions, but, he said, "your legislative mill grinds slowly."
And if more militant black groups oppose lifting sanctions, or if some anti-apartheid pressure groups in America insist on replacing the old sanctions with new conditions for South African investment, local governments may be confused.
Last November the congress issued a "platform of guiding principles" for companies that invest here after sanctions, including codes of conduct governing worker rights, affirmative action and environmental policies. To the alarm of American businesses, some lobby groups professing to speak for the African National Congress have begun a push to have these guidelines enshrined in American statutes.
Mr. Manuel, the congress's chief economic spokesman, said any conditions on foreign investment in South Africa should be regulated by South African law and international treaties, not dictated by self-styled allies in America. "I understand the power of groups that have built South Africa as their life's work," Mr. Manuel said. "But we are now in transformation from anti-apartheid to pro-democracy. That process needs continuing support, but it is no longer the time for barging in on shareholders' meetings."
Such confusing signals have contributed to a wider uncertainty about the African National Congress and its intentions if, as expected, it wins the majority role in a new government.
 
Conversion From Socialism?
 Although Mr. Mandela rarely talks any more about socialism and the need to nationalize industries, many businessmen wonder how deep the conversion goes.
"There's a kind of paradox really in the A.N.C.," said one executive whose company is contemplating a major project in South Africa. "There are those who are very welcoming toward investment, but then on the ground one encounters a more old-fashioned approach. When you get down to the operational level you find people aren't necessarily hearing what Mr. Mandela and others are saying."
The companies South Africa most hopes to lure here are big producers like the H.J. Heinz Company, whose food processing plants and canneries already employ 2,000 people in neighboring Zimbabwe. Heinz executives visited Johannesburg last June in search of potential partners, but backed away when negotiations on the country's political future broke down.
Edward Smyth, Heinz's vice president for corporate affairs, said the company is still interested, but before it moves again South Africa must have a multiracial government in place, and "they have to make clear what their rules are for investment and capital."
"There are a lot of other countries around the world that are very supportive and offer incentives," Mr. Smyth said, noting that two months after visiting Johannesburg the company spent $300 million acquiring a food company in New Zealand. "A place like South Africa has to compete with the whole world, and take its chances when it can."

HEADLINE: Clinton Adds Visit From Russian Official on Aid

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
In an effort to support President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and his democratic reform movement, President Clinton is to meet with Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia in Washington next week, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today.
The meeting comes as the Administration is struggling, in the absence of major new financing, to put together a package of small-scale incentives to promote Russia's economic and political reform movement before the Clinton-Yeltsin meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia, on April 3 and 4. 
 The meeting with Mr. Kozyrev, Mr. Christopher said, will be an opportunity to make final preparations for the summit talks as well as "a reflection of the President's support for him and President Yeltsin's Government." Mr. Kozyrev will meet with Mr. Clinton on Tuesday.
Mr. Clinton is likely to announce details of the aid package and to explain why it is necessary in an address to the American people, White House officials said.
At a breakfast meeting with newspaper reporters, Mr. Christopher seemed torn between his desire to stress the positive aspects of Russia's reform movement and his inclination to make realistic judgments.
Mr. Christopher acknowledged that perhaps the United States had taken too rosy a view of Russia's capacity for democratic reform. But, he added, "we need to work hard to keep them cooperating and moving in the direction that will enable us to reduce our defense budget."
Asked whether American policy toward Russia is too dependent on the survival of Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Christopher said, "The situation there certainly does cause one to think about that question." But he reiterated that the Russian leader is the "only freely elected leader in that country," and that others are "only pretenders compared to the legitimacy that he has."
Mr. Clinton's participation in next week's meeting illustrates a broad-based feeling in the Administration that it has to take advantage of every opportunity to help the beleaguered Russian President.
Mr. Christopher acknowledged that there were problems in dispensing the $400 million already committed by Congress for the dismantling of nuclear weapons in Russia and the other three nuclear republics. "This is a basis for disappointment," he said, adding that a combination of factors was to blame, including "perhaps not enough intensity from our side and rather complex decision-making on their side."
On a related issue, Lawrence H. Summers, the Under Secretary-designate of the Treasury for International Affairs, told Congress today that Russia was "perilously close to hyperinflation," adding that that unless Russia's leaders brought down inflation, its democracy might not survive.
Speaking at his confirmation hearing, Mr. Summers said he was optimistic that the Group of Seven major industrial democracies would provide additional aid to Russia over the next few months. "The task of rebuilding the Russian economy is the greatest economic restructuring job since the Marshall Plan," he said.
In Paris, President Francois Mitterrand has proposed that an emergency summit meeting of the Group of Seven nations to discuss economic aid to Russia be held when Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin meet in Vancouver.
French Government officials said Mr. Mitterrand discussed the idea in a telephone conversation Wednesday with Mr. Clinton. White House officials said the President preferred a Japanese idea for a meeting at the ministerial level in April.
Asked today about his conversation with Mr. Mitterrand, Mr. Clinton said, "He thinks we ought to do more and so do I."
Japan, which currently chairs the group and is preparing a previously scheduled summit conference in Tokyo in July, has proposed the lower-level alternative because it wants to keep the focus on the session for which it is the host. Hisashi Owada, Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs of Japan, met with senior officials in Washington to try to head off the possibility of an early Group of Seven summit.

HEADLINE: Doctors' Investments in Home Care Grow, Raising Fears of Ethical Swamp

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Along with a national boom in home medical treatments has come a surge in doctors' investments in companies that provide equipment and medication for such care, raising concerns among medical leaders and government officials about a vast potential for conflicts of interest.
The surge in doctors' investments in home health services coincides with growing Federal and state efforts to ban similar medical investments like clinical laboratories, which critics say drive up the cost of care. 
 But regulatory officials are only now turning their attention to financial ties between doctors and companies in the growing field of home health care, which offers procedures once confined to the hospital, like intravenous drug and nutrition treatments.
The Federal Government is investigating whether some home-care companies and doctors have violated conflict-of-interest rules governing Medicare and Medicaid patients.
And the American Medical Association, which has condemned other kinds of investments by doctors who refer patients, has opened an inquiry into the financial ties between doctors and home-care companies.
 
Rapidly Growing Practice
 No one knows how many doctors have financial ties to the providers of home health care, but while the number appears small there is strong evidence that it is growing rapidly. One of the largest companies, T<2> Medical Inc. of Alpharetta, Ga., disclosed last year that the number of doctors involved in companies it owned or managed was about 2,200 nationwide, up from 650 as recently as 1988.
A study being conducted by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services found evidence that 25 percent of the companies that offer intravenous drug and nutrition treatments in the home to Medicare and Medicaid patients have doctors as investors, said a Federal official involved with the report.
Officials of home-health companies and participating doctors insist that the financial ties do not lead to unnecessary procedures or overcharges. But critics sharply disagree.
"The reason the home-care companies want these relationships with doctors is because the patient goes with it," said Dr. Jean Mitchell, a health economist at Georgetown University who helped write a major study in Florida on investments and referrals by doctors. "That way they have a lock on the referral, and when you have a lock on the system, you can charge higher prices and not worry about service."
The Clinton Administration supports a broad ban on doctors' investing in services to which they refer Medicare or Medicaid patients. A bill now in Congress proposes such a ban and would extend it to private patients as well.
 
Federal Inquiry Under Way
 Most of the investments by doctors in home-care companies are legal. They often take the form of joint ventures in which a company arranges for a group of doctors to form a local business that is managed by the national company. But Federal authorities are investigating two of the largest home-health-care companies to see whether they have violated Government conflict-of-interest rules involving Medicare and Medicaid patients.
Even when legal, the doctors' investments are often unusual because they are open only to physicians, who are virtually guaranteed handsome returns since the patients they refer bring in steady revenue. The cost of some services, like the nutritional feeding of AIDS patients intravenously, can run as high as $2,500 a week.
The home-care companies say doctor-owners of a company can better control the quality of a patient's care at home. Moreover, they note that insurers pay doctors for visiting hospitalized patients, they do not pay for supervising a patient's care at home, so the doctors deserve extra compensation.
"I do not feel that there is a conflict involved in these investments because I treat my patients according to how I feel ethically, not financially," said Dr. Richard Friedman, a gastroenterologist in Atlanta who until recently was an investor in a doctor-owned home-care company managed by T<2> Medical.
Federal and state laws regarding what are known in the profession as "physician self-referrals" are changing. In 1989, the Federal Government barred doctors from owning stakes in clinical laboratories that saw Medicare or Medicaid patients. Last year, a few states, including New York and Florida, banned doctors' investments in some patient services, including clinical labs and diagnostic X-ray and imaging centers. Illinois passed a broader ban on doctors' investments in services to which they refer patients.
The Department of Health and Human Resources also issued rules in 1991 to limit doctors' investments in a wide array of medical services used by Medicare and Medicaid patients. But the large national home-care companies have tried to structure their joint ventures with doctors so that they involve only patients whose care is not paid for by Medicare or Medicaid.
 
Kickback Scheme Investigation
 For the last 18 months, the Inspector General for Health and Human Services has been investigating the incentives offered to doctors by T<2> Medical and another of the largest home-health services, Caremark International Inc. of Northbrook, Ill. The inquiry seeks to determine if they violated the Federal law against paying doctors to induce referrals of Medicare or Medicaid patients. In June, a Federal grand jury in Atlanta took up the investigation of T<2> Medical.
The companies have denied any wrongdoing. The Inspector General's office declined to comment.
Much of the future growth in physician self-referrals may depend on how the American Medical Association resolves an internal debate over the issue. In December 1992, the organization ruled that most physician self-referrals were unethical. But home-health-care companies have contended that they qualify for an exemption that permits doctor referrals to a service from which the doctors benefit if the service is a "direct extension" of their practices.
Dr. Randall Moore, the medical director of Caremark International, said that while a doctor may not visit a patient at home, the doctor is often directing treatment by telephone. "Whether or not the physician is there to lay their hands on the patient is not the issue," Dr. Moore said. "If laying your hands is not essential to the procedure then that should not make a difference."
 
A.M.A. Looking Into Ties
 Kirk Johnson, a lawyer for the A.M.A, said the exemption is supposed to cover cases in which a doctor actually sees a patient, but the organization believes that doctors should be compensated in some way for extensive telephone supervision of home patients.
He said that the A.M.A was opposed to investment plans in which doctors get large returns with little money at risk. To clarify its policy, the A.M.A. started an inquiry in January into the financial ties between doctors and the home-health-care industry.
The debate over home health care comes amid sharp growth in the industry. Sales of drug and nutrition treatments that are administered by patients to themselves or by nurses using intravenous pumps or other devices, called home-infusion therapies, reached $3.1 billion last year, a 19 percent increase over 1991.
Some company officials said they felt compelled by competitors to offer doctors financial incentives. "It is done in a defensive mode," said Donald Millard, vice president for finance of Healthdyne Inc. of Marietta, Ga., which also offers doctors joint ventures.
T<2> Medical, which was founded in 1984, has based its entire strategy on financial alliances with doctors. It recruits about 15 doctors in an area and helps them set up their own home- health-care company, to which the doctors then refer their patients. T<2> Medical manages the business and gets about 24 percent of the profits. The doctors keep the rest.
"We think it is an innovative approach to health-cost containment," said Jeffrey Muir, the company's vice president and general counsel. "The physicians who own companies actively control and manage them."
T<2> Medical gets a one-time fee of $50,000 to set up a doctor-owned company. The doctors each put up $100 in cash and guarantee $15,000 more if needed in order to become shareholders in the joint venture. The doctors seldom have to put up any additional money, as the start-up costs are often quickly paid off by the fees for services.
The doctor-investors can make anywhere from a few thousand dollars to more than $20,000 annually. They can also reap windfall profits when T<2> Medical buys out the units, as it often does.
Dr. Friedman of Atlanta said he and fellow physician-investors each received 5,000 shares of T<2> Medical stock when they were bought out after about three years. That stock is now worth, $100,000 though at one point last year it was worth $338,750.
While Dr. Friedman said he saw nothing wrong with such arrangements, other doctors have rejected entreaties from T<2> Medical.
"I don't like to think that greed in the marketplace was that strong but I guess I was wrong," said Dr. Bruce Feinberg, an oncologist in Atlanta. "It is also one thing when an investor is willing to take a risk but there is no risk here."
The companies also have more traditional means of compensating doctors. Caremark, for example, pays weekly stipends of up to $150 to a doctor for supervising a patient.
Dr. Moore of Caremark acknowledged that the stipends are included in patient bills. He and officials at other companies insisted that charges for their services were a bargain because hospital procedures for the same services were 20 to 50 percent higher.
But Henry M. Weinert, president of Boston Biomedical Consultants Inc., a consulting company in Boston, said such comparisons were hollow because charges for home health care were often far above their true cost.
In 1991, a study by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs found that home-care companies charged up to $9,000 for a month's supply of an intravenous food supplement that cost $1,300.
Dr. Moore called the New York City study misleading because it did not reflect company costs like nursing, delivery and administrative services. But some groups, like health maintenance organizations, have won lower rates recently for home health care.
Still, critics of physician self-referrals said that the problems associated with the practice will not abate until the Federal Government bans it. "Providing doctors these kinds of financial incentives is wrong" said Dr. Mitchell of Georgetown University. "We can't afford these kinds of abuses any more."
