HEADLINE: Eluding Trade Embargo, a Vessel Delivers Gasoline to Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
A ship carrying a huge supply of gasoline has evaded the Western ban on trade with Yugoslavia and delivered its cargo to the Adriatic port of Bar, Clinton Administration officials said today.
The delivery of what is believed to be 50,000 metric tons of gasoline, or about 400,000 barrels, undercuts the Western effort to use economic sanctions to stop the Serbs fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
 "Just when we are trying to ratchet up pressure on the Serbs, this comes along," a Western official said. "It is not a good development."
American officials say the ship was owned by a Greek company called Tsakos and then sold to a concern called Bellingham, which is based in Liberia and which the officials suspect may be a front company. Washington says Greece has promised to investigate the matter.
 
Warships Enforce Ban
 The delivery is one of the most serious violations of the United Nations trade ban on Serbia and Montenegro, the two republics that together make Yugoslavia. It comes as Washington and its allies are trying to persuade the Serbs to sign a peace agreement and stop their attacks on the Bosnians.
With the Clinton Administration shelving threats of military action to slow the killing in Bosnia, the sanctions have become the Administration's main means of inducing the Serbs to seek an agreement.
To enforce the embargo, a flotilla of ships from NATO and the Western European Union has been patrolling the Adriatic. But the delivery of the gasoline to Bar in Montenegro raises questions about the effectiveness of the Western effort.
Ideas of how significant the shipment is to the economy of Yugoslavia vary, depending on estimates of consumption. One American official said the shipment represented three weeks' supply for Yugoslavia, but another said it might be enough to keep the economy running for several months.
 
Under Various Names
 The episode began when the ship, sailing under the Liberian flag, left Pylos, Greece, officials said. They said the ship has used various names, including the East River and the Penelope.
The ship steamed into the Adriatic, where she was challenged by a Spanish warship, the Cataluna, which was enforcing the trade sanctions. The vessel radioed that she was carrying a cargo to Venice, but added that she had encountered mechanical problems and that a crew member had been injured in an accident.
The Spanish warship directed the ship to an anchorage near Durres, Albania, but instead she proceeded to Bar, where she unloaded the gasoline.
The United States has asked Liberia to strip the ship of its registration, and Western warships are expected to seize her after she leaves Bar. But the damage has been done.
This is not the first time that ships have eluded the Western blockade by reporting mechanical problems. In January, a Greek-owned vessel called the Dimitrakis reached Bar after the captain falsely declared that he was making an emergency stop for repairs.
The episode is acutely embarrassing for NATO and the Western European Union. At NATO headquarters, the United States asked its allies on Wednesday to review the procedures for enforcing the embargo to prevent a repetition, diplomats said.
 
Greeks Promise Crackdown
 Greece has promised to crack down on ships violating the embargo. A prosecutor in Salonika, Greece, recently filed criminal charges against two Russian-flag ships, the Dnieper I and the Dnieper II, charging that they arrived with a falsified transit document indicating that they were carrying a Hungarian cargo. In fact, Greek officials said, they were carrying iron loaded in Serbia.
 
Dominican Ship Detained
 Greek officials also say that a Dominican-flag ship, the Rosario, has been detained by port officials in Salonika for possible violations of the embargo.
But the delivery of gasoline to Bar shows that sanctions breaking is still a serious problem for the West.
The Clinton Administration is planning to bar non-Yugoslav companies like shipping concerns that repeatedly violate the embargo from doing business with the United States, but has not yet done so.

HEADLINE: Black-Cuban Rift Extends to Florida Law School

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 18

 BODY:
With Janet Reno gone to Washington to be Attorney General, black and Hispanic lawyers and officials here are competing to dominate Dade County's legal apparatus while quarreling over the location and control of a new state-financed law school.
Gov. Lawton Chiles dismayed some blacks but delighted Cuban-Americans in Miami last Friday when he appointed Katherine Fernandez Rundle, 42, a 16-year veteran of the prosecutor's office, to succeed Ms. Reno as the State Attorney in Dade County, which includes Miami. 
 Frustrated that one of their own was not named to that post, blacks are redoubling efforts to establish the new law school at a black university upstate rather than at one here dominated by Cuban-Americans and recent Latin American immigrants.
The issues are linked, said H. T. Smith, a black lawyer in Miami, because both are "an indication of the turf wars that will have to be fought between blacks and Hispanics for each of us to get a fair share of the pie and of the power."
 
A History of Exclusion
 In both cases, he said, blacks are trying to redress a history of exclusion from the legal system but face competing demands from Hispanic immigrants who began arriving here 30 years ago and who now dominate Dade County's political and economic life. The Hispanic share of the county's population is slightly more than 50 percent; blacks make up just over 20 percent.
Black lawyers and politicians had favored Judge Ralph N. Person of Dade County Circuit Court, who is also is a former assistant United States Attorney, to succeed Ms. Reno.Greg Samms, president of the Black Lawyers Association here, told a local legal publication that black males have historically been victimized by the criminal justice system, and that it is important to have someone at the top who is sensitive to that.
Having failed to place a black official in the job, blacks are now urging Ms. Fernandez Rundle to demonstrate a "commitment to diversity" by naming blacks to senior administrative and prosecutorial jobs in her office. They say they will also be monitoring her treatment of black defendants and how grand jury proceedings are conducted.
"You can only have one protegee," and Ms. Fernandez Rundle was clearly Ms. Reno's favorite, said George Knox, a former Miami City Attorney who is black. What is important now, he added, is that the new State Attorney "look for talented black lawyers" and give them positions of responsibility so that "they will be contenders for the position in the event she moves up or moves on."
Ms. Reno often assigned black lawyers to important cases but did not have any blacks in her inner circle. There have been suggestions that Ms. Fernandez Rundle carries a heavier burden on racial issues because of her Hispanic background. She did not respond to requests for an interview.
"She is a Cuban-American, and relations between Cubans and blacks in Dade County have been strained at best and outright hostile at worst," Mr. Smith said. While he said he thought Ms. Fernandez Rundle would be fair, he added that "the mass of black folks are skeptical about having a Cuban-American as chief prosecutor, coupled with the fact there is nobody black at her left or right hand."
 
Election Next Year
 If Ms. Fernandez Rundle is to serve the rest of Ms. Reno's four-year term, she must win a general election next year. Black lawyers said that their scrutiny of Ms. Fernandez Rundle's performance would be intense, but that she would probably face black opposition no matter what she did.
"The black community will definitely have some input on candidates in the State Attorney's election," said Gary Siplin, a lawyer who is also president of the New Miami Group, which seeks to encourage black leadership in government. "She'll have some other candidates running against her. Blacks have matured in this county and can show some muscle, and that's what we're going to do."
Mr. Siplin said blacks would also continue trying to insure that a new state-supported law school be established at Florida A&M University in Tallahassee, a predominantly black institution, rather than Florida International University here. The state already has two law schools at public universities in Tallahassee and Gainesville, but is willing to set up a third to attract minority students if the Legislature can agree on a site.
"The important thing we have to realize is that we have two large minority groups in Florida that are underrepresented in every area of the legal field, from judges to lawyers to law students," said State Senator Mario Diaz-Balart, who favors placing the new law school in Miami. "The bottom line is that we need to do what is right for both groups, and that is to put the school where the population is and where the minorities are."
 
Minority Status Questioned
 Some black lawyers and elected officials contend that Cuban-Americans in Miami are not a true minorityand should therefore not receive any preferential treatment. Mr. Smith said Cubans are really "white people whose native language is Spanish."
Other blacks have said that Cuban-Americans should be disqualified because they have higher income levels than other minorities.
Hispanic lawyers say those statements are unfair. "We have a tremendous number of minorities, Hispanic students as well as blacks, who cannot afford to attend a private law school or to travel to a place far from home," said Tony Marin, president of the Cuban-American Bar Association. "There are Cubans, Nicaraguans and Colombians from working-class backgrounds who should not have to put their families through severe hardship to get through school."

HEADLINE: Sheik Emerges on TV to Deny Link to Bombing

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

 BODY:
Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, ending more than two weeks of silence about reports linking him to the bombing of the World Trade Center, began a media offensive yesterday denying any involvement in the attack and condemning the media for reporting that he is a suspect in the case.
In a somewhat bizarre twist, the sheik emerged on live television before millions of Americans, ending the mystery of his whereabouts since the bombing and speaking out on the arrest of several suspects who have been portrayed as his followers. 
 In rapid succession, the blind, 55-year-old cleric, whom the United States Government is trying to deport, gave interviews in Los Angeles to Al-Hayat, an Arabic daily based in London, as well as ABC's Prime Time Live and CNN. Previously, as attention had grown about him, his incendiary sermons and his possible involvement in the bombing, the sheik had issued denials of any involvement only through his spokesmen.
In his interview today on CNN, Mr. Abdel Rahman said that he had not been interviewed by any law-enforcement authorities about the World Trade Center investigation. He acknowledged that he had been questioned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation "before" about his connections with El Sayyid A. Nosair, who was convicted of crimes associated with the killing of Rabbi Meir Kahane in 1990. But he did not indicate when the questioning took place.
Mr. Abdel Rahman gave the spate of interviews as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo led the first group of tenants back into one of the twin towers since the Feb. 26 bombing, which killed 6, injured 1,000 and caused hundreds of millions of dollars in damage.
In the investigation, Federal agents were said to have traced several new bank accounts linked to one of the arrested suspects, one of them to a doctor in Germany.
 
Denies Knowing 4 Suspects
 Answering questions through an interpreter, Mr. Abdel Rahman denied knowing the three men arrested in the bombing, as well as a fourth suspect still at large. He left open the possibility that they might have prayed in his mosque.
"I came here and I stand in this arena, not because I've been accused, so I defend myself," he said to CNN. "But I accuse the American mass media of being controlled and racist. And they look for falsifications. They showed my picture hundreds of times accusing me of being a terrorist and to reach, to accuse, Islam through that with terrorism."
Continuing, he asked why the media was connecting "the religious figures of Muslims and the mosques and the Islamic centers and Islam as a whole with those who claim to be Muslims?" The sheik also denied knowing Mahmud Abouhalima, the fourth suspect. The New York Times reported yesterday that Mr. Abouhalima, a German national of Egyptian birth, had been the sheik's driver and personal assistant for many months, according to a Brooklyn man who knew both men.
"I don't know him and I don't know where he is," the sheik said on CNN. I never had a car so he couldn't have driven it for me."
Asked whether his fiery, anti-American messages had inspired violence, he said in front of the cameras on ABC's Prime Time Live: "I did not encourage, I did not know, and I had no relation to this."
 
Mubarak 'Deserves' Killing
 But in a sharp contrast in substance and tone, he applauded the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt in 1981, and said that President Hosni Mubarak, the current leader, "deserves the same thing."
He added, in fact, that his mission in the United States was to confront Mr. Mubarak's regime.
The sheik was tried but acquitted of direct involvement in the assassination of President Sadat. Despite being placed on the State Department's "watch list" and being barred from entry along with a million others, he was granted a tourist visa to the United States in 1990 by mistake. The State Department has admitted that it erred because the sheik's name and other information were not spelled correctly at the consulate where he applied. In a second mistake, the Immigration and Naturalization Service granted him permanent residency status in April 1991 as a religious leader. The agency revoked it in March 1992.
On Wednesday, a Federal immigration judge in Newark denied Mr. Abdel Rahman's asylum appeal and ordered him deported. His lawyer said he would appeal further.
Once a foreigner enters the United States with permission, if his background is then challenged, he is entitled to a full array of hearings and appeals, as the sheik is now pursuing, which would let the person remain in the country for years, even if the original permission was in error. The F.B.I. has said that it is not seeking to arrest Mr. Abdel Rahman or even to question him.
Since his arrival in the United States, Mr. Abdel Rahman has regularly preached at the Abu Bakr mosque in Brooklyn and the Al-Salaam mosque in Jersey City. But dissension has always followed him.
While his revolutionary interpretation of Islam has won him converts among many poor, young Muslims, many who have recently immigrated to the United States, his radical preaching has alienated many older, more traditional Muslims, who do not consider mosques the appropriate venue for such militant calls for upheaval.
 
Falling Out, and Murder
 When Mr. Abdel Rahman first came to America, he was helped by many other immigrants, among them Mustafa Shalabi, an electrical contractor from Egypt, according to Muslims in Brooklyn. Together, the two men raised money to help the mujahedeen fighters wage war against the Soviet invaders in Afghanistan. Acquaintances in Brooklyn said the two had a falling out. In March 1990, Mr. Shalabi was killed.
After the World Trade Center bombing, the police reopened their investigation into his shooting and stabbing.
The sheik has always refused to talk about Mr. Shalabi. On one occasion, he told an interviewer, "I did not know the man."
In the investigation yesterday, a law-enforcement official said that Federal agents were tracing a number of additional bank accounts, beyond those already reported, linked to one of the men arrested in the bombing, Mohammed A. Salameh. The accounts were said to total thousands of dollars. Officials earlier said that they had identified a joint account that Mr. Salameh kept with a second arrested suspect, Nidal A. Ayyad, and at least two individual accounts kept by Mr. Salameh.
In one of the previously identified individual accounts of Mr. Salameh at a National Westminster Bank in Jersey City, investigators have now traced the source of one deposit of $2,420.87, wired to the account nine days before the Feb. 26 bombing, to a doctor in Germany, the official said. He would not provide further details but said the sender of the money had been traced by German authorities, who then advised the F.B.I.
Mr. Salameh's lawyer, Robert E. Precht, has said that relatives of Mr. Salameh wired him money from Germany, but investigators said they had not yet verified the relationship of the senders to the arrested suspect.
 
Not Sure of Escape Route
 The law-enforcement official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said that the authorities had not yet identified two men who may have accompanied Mahmud Abouhalima, a possible ringleader of the bombing plot, as he fled the United States from Kennedy International Airport shortly after the blast. Mr. Abouhalima is believed to have fled to Pakistan, but the official said investigators were not sure of the route he had taken or whether the two other men accompanied him or went elsewhere.
To aid their investigation of the bombing site in an underground garage, experts are using a duplicate of the yellow Ford Econoline van that Mr. Salameh leased from a Ryder rental dealer, and are trying to match pieces of metal extracted from the wreckage.
No timing device or fuse has yet been found but tons of rubble remain to be sifted, and every time a big truck rumbles by outside, new debris is shaken loose from the crater and rains down on workers.
 
No Bail for Elgabrowny
 In a separate action yesterday, Judge John E. Sprizzo of Federal District Court in Manhattan declined to set bail for Ibraham Elgabrowny, a 42-year-old Egyptian-born civil engineer whose Brooklyn apartment was listed as the address of Mr. Salameh on his application for a New York State driver's license.
Mr. Elgabrowny was indicted on Wednesday on charges of obstructing justice by elbowing investigators who were searching his Brooklyn apartment after the bombing, and possession of fraudulent Nicaraguan passports, birth certificates and drivers licenses in the name of El Sayyid A. Nosair. Mr. Elgabrowny is a relative of Mr. Nosair.
His defense lawyer, William Kunstler, argued that there was no evidence linking Mr. Elgabrowny to the bombing and that the court did not have jurisdiction. He also accused prosecutors of persecuting Mr. Elgabrowny in an effort to fabricate a "a mammoth Islamic conspiracy."
Judge Sprizzo said there was not enough new information to overturn the decision and told Mr. Kunstler to appeal to the Second Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
 
Attacks Media in Media
 In all his interviews yesterday, the sheik used the media to attack the media for making what he called false aspersions about him and Islam. But he reserved his most extensive and nuanced remarks for his interview with Al-Hayat, the Arabic daily, which is owned by a Saudi prince.
Interviewed by Al-Hayat, the sheik supported the spate of attacks on Egypt's security forces, its tourist industry and foreign investment there, and on any civilian, Muslim or Christian, who opposes Islamic principles.
In Cairo yesterday, the Egyptian Government confiscated the estimated 3,000 copies of Al-Hayat that are sold daily in the Egyptian capital.
The Government offered no explanation, but Egyptian officials said privately that they feared that the sheik's remarks would further inflame tensions between the Government and Islamic militants.
Mr. Abdel Rahman told Al-Hayat, according to Mideast Mirror, a London-based news and translation service, that while he did not "accept American laws," he abided by them for two reasons. First, he explained, he obeyed American law because the United States had accepted him as an immigrant. And secondly, he abided by the law because it was practical.
"I need a land from which I can confront the regime," he said, referring to Egypt, his native land. "I would never do anything that might deny me that freedom."
Asked specifically by Al-Hayat whether he condoned the attacks on Egypt's police, Mr. Abdel Rahman answered: "The argument that the police are people following orders and do not deserve to be killed is unacceptable. Every man is responsible for his deeds. The police are one integrated unit, which justifies attacks on any part of that unit."
Mr. Abdel Rahman denied that he led or was a prominent figure in the Islamic Group, or any other Islamic organization in the United States. There is no Islamic Group in the United States nor in Egypt, he asserted. Those who are conducting raids in Egypt, he told Al-Hayat, are simply "young people who value their faith and defend their rights."
In all three interviews, the sheik denied receiving financial support directly or indirectly from Iran, which the United States accuses of supporting international terrorism. Vincent M Cannistraro, a former counterterrorism specialist for the Central Intelligence Agency who left the Government in 1990, said that American officials had "good evidence" that the sheik was getting money from Iran, at least since 1989.
One of the World Trade Center's original tenants, Fiduciary Trust Company, and two currency trading companies -- Eurobank, and Harlow Meyer & Savage -- are the first tenants after Governor Cuomo to start moving office equipment into Tower 2 since the Feb. 26 blast.
Fiduciary started moving office equipment back to the 94th, 95th, 96th and 97th floors of their Twin Tower office spaces at 8 P.M. yesterday. By 6 A.M., three weeks after the explosion, Fiduciary expected to have its office ready to start the day with its full force of over 500 workers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo before leading the first tenants back into Tower Two of the World Trade Center. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: Top Bank in Canada Adds Trustco

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 18

 BODY:
The Royal Bank of Canada, Canada's largest bank, will acquire most of the assets of Royal Trustco Ltd., the nation's second-largest trust company, for $1.65 billion (Canadian), according to an agreement in principle announced today.
If the transaction, which is still subject to approval of stockholders and regulatory agencies, is finally consummated, it would create the fourth-largest bank in North America after Citicorp, the BankAmerica Corporation and the Chemical Banking Corporation. 
 The 101-year-old Royal Trustco is now controlled by the Edper-Bronfman empire, Canada's largest conglomerate, which has recently suffered a series of financial reverses. Today's announcement represents the third major disposal of prized Edper assets within the past two months as the group seeks to redress its position.
In February, Edper sold controlling stakes in John Labatt Ltd., Canada's second-largest brewery after Molson Breweries, and MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., the leading forest products company to raise nearly $2 billion.
 
Real Estate Loan Troubles
 Royal Trustco, which is 47.5 percent owned by the Trilon Financial Corporation, a key Edper holding company, has been hit by sour real estate loans made in Canada, Britain and the United States over the last decade and has been on the auction block for some months.
Royal Trustco today provided some indication of the extent of its own financial problems by announcing a preliminary 1992 loss in the range of $850 million to $900 million (Canadian), compared with net income of $107 million in 1991. A Canadian dollar is worth about 80 American cents.
The Royal Bank is taking on Royal Trustco's stronger assets -- international and Canadian trust subsidiaries, including 146 Royal Trust branches in Canada. Royal Trustco will retain the weaker assets -- $4.3 billion in loans made in Canada, the United States and Britian. The company says 76 percent of those loans are performing.
The trust operations administers $124 billion in client assets, mutal fund assets and other funds. They represent the real payoff for Royal Bank. Financial reform legislation that took effect last June allows banks to take advantage of operations in the lucrative trust business.
Royal Bank is also acquiring $34 billion in deposits, residential and commercial mortgages and credit card loans and $950 million in larger domestic commercial loans and internatinal loans.
 
'Tremendous Opportunities' Seen
 Allan R. Taylor, chairman and chief executive officer of the Royal Bank, said the agreement "creates tremendous opportunities" for his institution and "would place us in a strong leadership position in a number of key businesses with above average, long-term growth and profit potential."
Royal Bank's assets, currently $137 billion (Canadian), would rise another $14 billion, or 10 percent.
James Miller, Royal Trustco president, said his company's depositors and clients "can be assurted that they'll be secure with this transaction. It's joining us with the financial strength of Canada's largest and strongest financial institution."
Royal Bank would pay cash. It expects to raise some of the money through the issuance of non-cumulative preferred shares.
Moody's Investor Service, the New York debt-rating agency, did not see the sale in the same light as the two chief executives. It said today it was placing $2.5 billion of in Royal Bank long-term debt under review for possible downgrade.
The review will entail a look at the risks of the transaction. Moody's said the quality of the bank's loans "continues to be challenged" by tough economic conditions in Canada.
Once the deal is consummated, Royal Trusco will be renamed and will focus on collecting outstanding loans, according to Mr. Miller.

HEADLINE: Fervor for French Rightist Doesn't Show in Polls

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 18

 BODY:
As soon as the first bars of the Slaves' Chorus from Verdi's "Nabucco" boomed out, the 3,000 or so people in the indoor stadium jumped to their feet on cue, turning toward a moving spotlight and wildly cheering the heavily built man who came marching in to address them.
By the time the chorus reached its stirring climax, Jean-Marie Le Pen was on the stage, dressed immaculately in a double-breasted suit, punching the air with his fists and savoring the chants of "Le Pen, President." Behind him, three huge screens showed a televised close-up of his triumphant smile. 
 Mr. Le Pen's meetings are probably as close as French politics ever come to American party conventions, not only because of their orchestrated show-biz atmosphere, but also because the audience is always made up of true believers, in this case supporters of his far-right National Front.
At his final meeting before the parliamentary elections on Sunday, though, there was an unusual tone of defensiveness in his voice. The crowd was as enthusiastic as ever. But for the first time since he raised his anti-immigrant banner in 1974, nationwide support for his party may be flagging.
Having won 14 percent of votes in regional elections one year ago, polls now say National Front candidates will receive only 11 to 12 percent in the first round of balloting on Sunday. And after the runoff election on March 28, the party may control just one seat in the 577-member Parliament. Mr. Le Pen himself is expected to lose in the runoff in his district in Nice.
"People say we're stagnating, but we're going to do better than they think," Mr. Pen, a 64-year-old former army officer, insisted, talking through microphones attached to his jacket as he prowled the stage. "For us the battle won't end this month. It will only end when there is a policy in place to save France."
The threat, he said, echoing his perennial theme, comes from the three million or so third-world immigrants who are slowly "conquering" France. "By the year 2000, the majority of the population of Paris will be foreign!" he shouted, prompting an immediate chant of "France for the French!"
"We see an ethnic conflict in Yugoslavia but we don't see that the same conditions exist here," he went on. "Ethnic cleansing is already taking place in the suburbs where native French are being forced by immigration to take their children out of school, to move out of their neighborhoods."
His party's platform includes 99 measures to combat immigration, to cut welfare for immigrants and to force unemployed foreigners to return home. In his speech, though, Mr. Le Pen focused only on his demand for "national preference" -- that employers give jobs to French before foreigners.
 
Not a Major Campaign Issue
 With three million people unemployed here, this is a view shared by many French. Indeed, with National Front candidates expected to win 25 percent of more of the vote in districts with high concentrations of Arab and African immigrants, it is apparent that immigration continues to stir deep concern.
Yet, to Mr. Le Pen's dismay, it has not been a major issue in the current campaign, partly because France now seems more obsessed by its economic crisis, but also because the conservative coalition favored to sweep the Socialist Government out of office has itself taken a tough line on immigration.
Along with clamping down on clandestine immigration, the Union for France coalition has promised to end family reunification, a program that allows 100,000 wives and children of immigrant men to enter the country each year and that in effect turns "temporary" workers into permanent residents.
Mr. Le Pen can also no longer claim to be the sole defender of France's identity against what he calls "Euro-mondialism." Although he fought against French ratification of a treaty on European union last September, conservative nationalists also did so, successfully stealing the limelight from him.
Further, some political experts believe that the violence against foreigners in Germany may have put some French voters off the National Front, despite its efforts to keep skinheads and the like out of its ranks and to present itself as a respectable "true French" movement.
 
'So Where Can We Go?'
 Yet the well-dressed middle-class crowd that filled the Coubertin Stadium here on Wednesday evening suggested that Mr. Le Pen remains assured of a constituency as long as immigration is seen as a threat, if not to the nation, at least to those living in suburbs with large immigrant populations.
"You should see where we live," said Therese Richmond, a 76-year-old woman who came to hear Mr. Le Pen. "Our building was meant to be reserved for those wounded in the war, but it's now filled with Algerians, Turks, black. So where can we go?"
Young people were also present. "Immigration brings crime, drugs, moral decadence," Sebastian Mercier, an 18-year-old student from the Montreuil suburb of Paris, said. Helene Meurisse, who is 20 years old, added, "I am a bit tired of being the only white person on the bus in the morning."
Brought together more by fear than ideology, then, many in the crowd still seemed ready to embrace Mr. Le Pen as the only man who could save them. "Everything he is accused of is false," Mrs. Richmond said of her hero. "He's not xenophobic, he's not racist. He represents France for us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jean-Marie Le Pen, candidate for the far-right National Front, campaigning in Paris on Wednesday. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Munich Journal;
Free Europe's Entreaty: Don't Tune Us Out Now

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany

 BODY:
News that the Clinton Administration was considering a shutdown of the United States Government-financed Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty stations here in 1995 has set off an avalanche of protest from all over Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
Listeners say they want to know why President Clinton would want to pull the plug on American support for the forces of democracy and free enterprise now, with the struggle in its most intense phase? 
 "I hope there is an opportunity to change your decision or at least postpone it until democracy and stability in Latvia is no longer in doubt," Anatolijs Gorbunovs, the chairman of the Baltic republic's Parliament, wrote to Mr. Clinton on March 5, explaining that he was among the 21 percent of the country's population that listened to Radio Free Europe's Latvian broadcasts.
"I hope the electorate in Latvia does not feel that the United States is no longer concerned whether freedom, democracy and the right to self-determination flourish in this part of the world," Mr. Gorbunovs wrote.
 
A Budget of $211 Million
 Since Mr. Clinton has called for a special summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial democracies to see what more they can do to support democracy and the transition to a market economy in Russia, the station's American managers hope that the Administration will find other, more effective ways to cut the Federal budget deficit than by eliminating the radio services, whose budget last year was $211 million.
"It's a combination of money, a sort of neo-isolationist mood in the United States and a perception that Eastern Europe is now free, so who needs Radio Free Europe?" said Gene Pell, the president of the nonprofit private corporation that runs the radio services under the oversight of the Presidentially appointed Board for International Broadcasting.
With a staff of 1,542, down from 1,809 at the end of 1989, and 57 transmitters in six locations, Mr. Pell said, the broadcasters had closed five Western European bureaus and cut back shortwave transmissions as it became possible to operate more freely inside the countries.
"I believe there are other savings that can be achieved," he said.
Senator Russell Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, has already introduced a bill to consolidate the radio services under the Voice of America, arguing that the stations were never intended to support struggling democracies and that the V.O.A. could do that better if it has to be done at all.
Mr. Pell and his management team hope that support for this argument will wane once legislators and the Administration focus on what the radio services actually do. This, they argue, is helping build the foundations of democracy by broadcasting to the formerly Communist countries in their own languages about what is happening there. They argue that three years after the collapse of Communism, few indigenous Eastern European newspapers or broadcasters are yet able to meet the need.
One of the stations' biggest supporters has been Vaclav Havel, the Czech President, who wrote in January that the kind of reporting Radio Free Europe did on his country was still vital.
"The wide perspective and personality of its editors, even in the future, will help our people free themselves from their own problems, and the useful distance of the reporters will help their objective improvement," he wrote to the stations. "Unfortunately, these attributes are often missing in our domestic media."
Mr. Pell said the oversight board had also proposed to the Administration that Radio Free Europe, which all during the cold war never broadcast to Yugoslavia because it was independent from Moscow, should start doing so now, within existing budget authority, if it got the go-ahead.
"We could bring Serbs and Croats together to talk about how we could end the conflict," he said.
 
'Absolutely Must Listening'
 The assertion that the Voice of America, which broadcasts to the rest of the world about life in the United States, could take over its tasks is vigorously disputed here.
Radio Free Europe was set up in 1951 with clandestine support from the Central Intelligence Agency, as was Radio Liberty, and for years, staffs of emigres from Poland, Hungary, Russia, Ukraine and other Communist countries broadcast to those countries all the news the Communist authorities thought subversive -- dissident activities, news about human rights groups, and the like.
In Moscow and St. Petersburg alone, recent surveys done for the station have shown they have about 178,000 and 103,000 regular listeners each weekday, comparable to the audience for Russian domestic public affairs stations, with 4.4 million to 6.6 million estimated regular listeners throughout its broadcast area.
"There's only one news program that you can depend on, and it's better than anything Russian radio or television can do," said Nikolai S. Portugalov, a former high-ranking official of the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee.
"Radio Liberty has hired all the best political reporters in town," he said. "It's absolutely must listening."
 
They Don't Vote in U.S.
 Coming from a former representative of a Government that for decades denounced Radio Liberty as anti-Soviet propaganda, and did its best to jam it off the airwaves, this was high praise, indeed.
Kevin Klose, a former Moscow correspondent and editor for The Washington Post who became Radio Liberty's director late last year, said that both its Russian staff and its Russian listeners tended to be young.
"The core of the group is Russians in their 20's, kids we started signing on as freelance contributors before the coup," he said of his reporters. "Our committed core audience are the people who, if society is going to be changed and democracy firmly established, are the ones who are going to do it."
But, he lamented, "among our millions of listeners, there is unfortunately nobody who can vote in an American election."

HEADLINE: United Air Gets Tough On Unions

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Playing hardball with labor unions in an attempt to lower costs, the chairman of United Airlines said yesterday that the carrier would not take delivery of at least $2 billion worth of planes from the Boeing Company that had been scheduled for delivery in 1994 and 1995. United may also abandon unprofitable short-haul routes, said the executive, Stephen M. Wolf, leasing the planes used on those to low-cost airlines.
Mr. Wolf said that after August, the airline would not accept delivery of Boeing planes until May 1995, when it would begin to get the 777, a twin-engine jet that it has planned to use on international routes.
 
Pressure Tactic Seen
 The move to pull back in the short-haul markets and possibly to use carriers like Southwest Airlines to feed its major routes would presumably put considerable pressure on United's unions to agree to changes in work rules and make other concessions. 
 Besides the cutback on the 41 new aircraft, Mr. Wolf, in discussing his plans at a meeting with industry analysts at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan, seemed to rub salt into Boeing's wounds. He said that United would continue to take delivery of the Airbus A320, a European-built jet, over the same period, though it would seek to lease most of the new Airbuses to other carriers.
United has long been Boeing's largest and most loyal customer.
 
Longer Hours in the Sky
 Mr. Wolf has asked the airline's three major unions for productivity increases worth a total of about 10 percent, mainly from changes in work rules that would have flight attendants and pilots fly longer hours. He has also asked employees to pay about 5 percent of the cost of their medical benefits.
The flight attendants' and machinists' unions have so far refused to go along, he said, while the pilots' union has said it will study the proposal.
Mr. Wolf made clear that unless the unions come around, United would farm out the short-haul routes.
"It's not brutalizing anybody," he argued. "It's not a management decision; it's a marketplace decision."
All the major airlines have begun to retrench and lay off employees as it becomes evident that the huge systems built in the 1980's are too large and possibly too expensive for current levels of passenger traffic at current fares.
Mr. Wolf said that farming out short-haul routes to other airlines could be done without violating union contracts, as long as United does not own the other carriers.
American Airlines is also considering such a strategy.
Southwest, which has low costs and has been growing rapidly, is the only airline that has stuck to a strategy of low fares and simple service, and in most markets it has entered it has been able to wear down its bigger rivals. The carrier has not built huge hubs, and it has emphasized getting the most out of its workers, stressing measures like quick turnaround time for its aircraft at intermediate stops on a route.
Southwest's financial performance in difficult times has been a reminder to the larger airlines that a low-fare policy can lead to profits even in an adverse economy.
Mr. Wolf said today that United had already had discussions with Southwest about the short-haul routes. "We can tie in through a marketing agreement for these carriers to feed us passengers," he said.
He left unclear whether United would cut back on the 50 Boeing planes due to be delivered this year. Analysts said it was likely that the airline would in fact take delivery of most of them, since it would be difficult to turn them back on such short notice.
Of the Airbus 320's, 5 of which are to be delivered this year and 32 more in the next two years, Mr. Wolf said United would seek lessors. For the carrier to put those planes into service, he said, it would take about $200 million for requirements like flight simulators and crew training.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Clinton Staff Chief Lives Up to Name

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The day after President Clinton delivered a somber and poorly reviewed Oval Office speech calling for individual sacrifice to help the economy, his oldest friend called members of the young White House senior staff into his office. And he scolded them.
Yet the friend, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the courtly chief of staff, never raised his voice. 
 "I don't want to sermonize," he began. He then gave those in the room a five-minute dressing down for suffering from what one person described as the "holier than thou" arrogance of the young.
The President's prime-time appearance on Feb. 15 and the salesmanship that had surrounded it, Mr. McLarty worried, had conveyed the tone of an inflexible leader ordering people to follow rather than asking them to join in a crusade.
 
Sign of Influence
 It is not Mr. McLarty's job to write the President's speeches, but it certainly was his job to discipline the speech writers, who he felt had surrounded the President with an air of hubris.
"McLarty felt there was this attitude among some of the staff that if you weren't for the President's plan, just get out of the way; we'll roll you," said a senior official who had attended the meeting.
Two days after the tongue-lashing, when the President delivered his first major address to a joint session of Congress, references to sacrifice had been deleted, pleas for cooperation had been inserted, and the speech had become a lofty call to arms.
So much for those who say the chief of staff is invisible.
White House officials who work closely with Mr. McLarty say he influences policy by affecting the staff members who set the policy rather than by promoting his own political views.
John H. Sununu, the combative and ultimately deposed chief of staff to President George Bush, controlled policy, politics and personnel from top to bottom. But in the self-consciously egalitarian Clinton White House, that power has been spread far more thinly. What Mr. McLarty does is run the staff.
 
Out of Sight Early On
 Mr. McLarty came to the White House a 46-year-old, Arkansas-born businessman who had made millions in the energy industry, who had known Mr. Clinton since kindergarten and who was universally known as simply Mack. In the Presidential campaign he was almost entirely out of the public view, but he raised significant sums of money for the campaign and remained close to both Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary.
While Mr. McLarty was becoming acclimated to the White House, the "speed bumps" -- as one official described them -- of the first few weeks seemed easily negotiated without him. He worked through his first days while nursing a bout of pneumonia and dropped almost entirely out of sight as candidates for Attorney General rose and fell and as a fight broke out with Congress over allowing homosexuals into the military.
Mr. McLarty's flashes of temper, by all accounts, are few but effective. He spends more of his time, officials said, quietly building a reservoir of support among the White House professionals, who refer to him with almost filial respect, and with members of Congress, whom he has stroked for weeks.
"In the White House every day, there are these buffeting events that could throw you off the path," said Howard Paster, the President's liaison to Congress. "And Mack is sort of steady as she goes."
 
Spreading Responsibilities
 Washington insiders like to draw comparisons with those who have held offices in the past, and most say Mr. McLarty is not the high-profile political handyman that James A. Baker 3d was or the pugnacious overseer that Mr. Sununu was.
Much of the Clinton Administration's press relations, speech writing and political salesmanship is developed in the office of George Stephanopoulos, the communications director. And senior aides like Robert E. Rubin, Mr. Clinton's economic policy adviser, and Bruce Lindsey, the personnel director, have their own routes to the President's office.
"Clearly you've got a lot of issues coming at you in a day," Mr. McLarty said in a recent interview in the pale yellow office he occupies near the President's. "You've got to be able to screen more than one piece at a time. I anticipated that, but you have to really experience it before you appreciate it."
Mr. McLarty's is the gift of understatement. He seldom says more than he intends, corrects himself immediately when he does and is unfailingly polite to the legion of reporters, politicians and lobbyists who have trooped to his West Wing office to acquaint themselves.
His temperament is remarkably unlike the President's. Mr. Clinton's bursts of anger are quickly extinguished but their intentions are clear: to force action. Mr. McLarty is more likely to show displeasure through icy distance or by assuming the demeanor of a disciplinarian.
 
Making the Circuit
 For now, charm is his primary weapon, ladled out, his loyalists say, without ideological bias. Mr. McLarty and his wife, Donna (he calls her "my wonderful partner"), often invite lawmakers to the home they rent in the tony Kalorama section of Washington for supper and a chat.
He has been spotted in the Senate dining room. He received sustained applause when he spoke to the House Democratic Caucus in Baltimore recently. And he soothed conservative Democrats when they grumbled that Mr. Clinton's economic plan spent too much and cut too little.
"A business background is very helpful in Congress," Mr. McLarty said. "I think they view that as very much in keeping with many of the constituencies they represent."
Some who have watched the rise and fall of other Presidential chiefs of staff observe that Mr. McLarty is something of a submarine. It is difficult to attack a target that remains largely submerged.
"I've been impressed by the fact that he has been almost invisible," said Richard Moe, who served as Walter F. Mondale's chief of staff when Mr. Mondale was Vice President. "I think that's positive. Most chiefs of staff who have been very high profile have gotten in trouble."
 
Lessons From Business
 Members of the senior White House staff say Mr. McLarty's daily meetings draw heavily from the management style he developed in nearly 10 years as president of Arkla, a Fortune 500 natural gas company in the South, and a lifetime of dabbling in Arkansas politics.
The Saturday before the President introduced his economic plan, Mr. McLarty met with White House senior staff members in his office and worked his way around the long conference table, demanding that each department head stand and explain how he or she planned to help promote the plan.
"Everyone left that room knowing they had a very clear mission," said Mark D. Gearan, Mr. McLarty's deputy.
But even Mr. McLarty concedes that some of the toughest adjustment has come in learning to fit his schedule to another chief executive's.
"I guess right now I'm kind of splitting my time, probably 50 percent with the President, 30 percent with the Hill, about 30 percent with the press," he said. "I know that adds up to more than 100 percent, but that's kind of how I feel."
In Washington, much of the mystery about powerful new officials comes in determining just how much power they really have. Mr. McLarty is one of several Arkansans in the President's inner circle; others include Mr. Lindsey, Carol H. Rasco, the domestic policy adviser, and Vince Foster, the deputy counsel to the President.
Mr. Lindsey, in particular, is known to be close to Mr. Clinton, having an open door to the Oval Office and a title that belies his broad influence.
"I still tend to think Bruce has more juice with Clinton" than Mr. McLarty does, an aide to a Democratic Senator said. "If we were really furious with someone and had to pick one of the two to call, based on who would understand the politics of it, it would be Lindsey."
 
Challenge for a Nice Guy
 Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, is a longtime Clinton ally who has watched with interest as Mr. McLarty has made his way around Congress.
"You've probably heard the word 'nice' describe him once or twice," Mr. Breaux said. "That's not an overused word here. This is going to be the real test of whether a nice guy can survive in Washington in the arena of national politics."
Mr. Breaux said that even if members of Congress underestimated Mr. McLarty, they should not underestimate Mr. Clinton.
"Even those who think Mack may not cut their knees off know that Mack talks to the President several times a day," the Senator said. "And Bill Clinton knows how to do what has to be done."
This observation touches on a refrain that often comes up in discussions about Mr. McLarty around Washington: The chief of staff, the thinking goes, functions as a mirror of a President's instincts, and because a President is heavily involved in day-to-day White House operations, the person who runs his staff cannot function as a deputy President but only as a staff-level assistant and -- in Mr. McLarty's case -- a friend.
Mr. Clinton, aides say, is likely to walk down the hall to an assistant's office when he has the time rather than call the aide on the telephone. In such an environment, they say, no gatekeeper is needed.
"Even if you wanted to be the ultimate gatekeeper, it's hard to do if the person on the other side doesn't stay in his enclosed area," a senior official said. "They are on the same wavelength."

HEADLINE: Medicaid Cost Jumped 25% In '92 Fiscal Year, U.S. Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Medicaid costs rose by almost $24 billion in the last fiscal year as 3.3 million more Americans joined the health insurance program for the poor, the Government reported this week.
The Federal Government and the states spent $118.2 billion providing the health benefits in the fiscal year 1992, which ended on Sept. 30. That was up 25 percent from the $94.5 billion spent a year earlier. 
 The Federal share of the Medicaid bills was $67.8 billion, or 57 percent. The amount each state contributes varies depending on its per-capita income.
The recession and expanded eligibility for pregnant women and children from low-income families helped swell the Medicaid rolls to 31.6 million from 28.3 million, a record.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The number of Americans applying for state unemployment benefits fell by 10,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, the Government said today, offering more evidence that employers are adding workers to their payrolls.
First-time applicants for state jobless benefits declined for the second straight week, dropping to 351,000, from 361,000 in the week that ended on March 6, the Labor Department reported. It was the lowest level for claims since the week that ended on Feb. 20, when there were also 351,000. 
 The states with the biggest drops were New York, California, Alabama, Illinois and Missouri, partly reflecting fewer layoffs in construction.
 The report supported other recent indicators that suggested the nation's labor market was strengthening. Unemployment fell last month to the lowest level since November 1991, while the number of payroll jobs outside the farm sector surged by 365,000.
But the latest report was not entirely bullish. On a four-week moving average, the number of first-time applicants rose 6,500, to 359,750, the highest level since the week that ended last Nov. 28, when the average was the same.

HEADLINE: Japan's New York Realty Investing Plunges

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
New investment by the Japanese in New York City real estate dropped to $10 million last year from $859 million in 1991 and a peak of $2.8 billion in 1988, according to a report released yesterday by Kenneth Leventhal & Company, the accounting agency.
The report found that the only Japanese investment in New York real estate in 1992 was a $10 million commitment to renovate a midtown office building already owned by a Japanese company. The primary reasons for the decline are Japan's economic crash and, in this country, the continuing repercussions from the overbuilding and steep drop in real estate prices from the mid- to late 80's. 
 The report said Japanese investors spent $807 million on United States real estate last year, down from $5.06 billion in 1991 and a peak of $16.54 billion in 1988. The 1992 figures showed that Japanese spending on real estate in Hawaii accounted for 41 percent of the year's total, with California at 36 percent and New York at 1 percent, down from 17 percent of the 1991 total.
Jack Rodman, director of Leventhal's Pacific Rim practice, said 1993 was not likely to be much better. "I think that next year you'll see an equal amount of money -- less than a billion dollars -- spent to shore up, because we're still so overbuilt," he said. In fact, he said, Japanese investors are likely to start selling properties.
Jennifer Kimball, spokeswoman for the Mayor's Office of Finance and Economic Development, said that foreign real estate purchases were down because of foreign economic turmoil and sinking property values. But over all, including manufacturing and other sources of investment, "the city's share of foreign direct investment is on the rise, and we are confident about that.".
She added that a recent city study found that by 1990, Japanese concerns had become the leading foreign owners of office space in Manhattan, with more than 19 million of the 67 million square feet of space that was foreign owned.
The Leventhal report came two days after the United States Commerce Department released figures showing that there was a net loss in foreign direct investment in the United States in 1992, meaning that foreign investors put less money into the companies in the United States than they took out.
The figures, which reflect a drop in cross-border investment by the British, Japanese and others, showed that foreigners took $3.95 billion more out of American investments than they put in in 1992. In 1991, the Commerce Department said, foreigners put $11.5 billion more into American investments than was taken out. The peak of foreign direct investment came in 1989, when $67.87 billion more was put into American investment than was taken out.

HEADLINE: Housing Authority Plans $139 Million for Security

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
The New York City Housing Authority plans to spend $139 million over the next three years on an array of measures intended to improve security in the authority's 324 housing complexes.
Authority officials said the money would be spent on increasing housing police officers on the beat, more social services for tenants and such safety measures as new locks and intercom systems. Most of the money will come from existing funds in the authority's budget. Agency officials could not immediately say how much the plan would increase the budget or what programs would be cut or altered to provide the extra security. 
 The plan also calls for the hiring of private security guards to supplement the housing police at some complexes for the elderly and some family complexes with stubbornly high crime rates.
Sally Hernandez-Pinero, chairwoman of the authority, and Mayor David N. Dinkins unveiled the details of the security plan yesterday in the packed community center in Red Hook Houses. The sprawling Brooklyn public housing complex is where a popular elementary school principal, Patrick Daly, was shot and killed last December while searching for a student who had missed school. The police say he was caught in a crossfire between drug-dealing gangs in the complex.
 
Plan at Work in Red Hook
 Housing Authority officials, who said the expanded security program was already in the works at the time of the principal's death, said they had choosen the Red Hook Houses as the site for the announcement because parts of the plan were already in operation there. New security hardware is being installed in the Red Hook buildings; so-called vertical foot patrols, with officers walking from top to bottom, have been increased, and the complex is among the 82 Housing Authority projects that are using extra Federal anti-drug money for increased tenant patrols and drug-education programs.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero told the audience of public housing tenants, building managers and officers that the forces of homelessness, increased drug use, the economic downturn and cuts in Federal spending had worsened problems in public housing.
"I am being honest and realistic when I tell you we can not undo in a year what has been done to us in more than a decade," she said. "What is clear is that it can get better."
Most residents and tenant leaders at the meeting who commented praised the authority's initiative, but some said it did not go far enough.
 
'More Than Better Locks'
 "I support some of it," said Ethel Velez, the tenant president in Johnson Houses in Manhattan. "But it will take more than better locks and lighting systems to make people in my complex feel safer. I think that 150 or 200 more cops is just not enough."
Furthermore, the planned hiring of private security guards in some complexes has drawn the ire of police union representatives.
Timothy Nickels, president of the Housing Police Benevolent Association, said private security guards were a poor substitute for patrol officers and a waste of public money.
"The Housing Authority is asking private guards, who have not been trained in police work, to do the jobs police officers should be doing," said Mr. Nickels, who spoke outside the community center. "It is not fair to the residents of public housing."
 
Beat Officers to Double
 Money for the security program will come from the city, the Federal Government and the Housing Authority's existing budget. The city is to put $15.2 million into the program. Another $16.2 million will come from reallocated Housing Authority money, and the remaining $107.4 million will be from existing Federal grants.
The plan calls for a doubling in the number of Housing Authority beat patrol officers, to 400, in the next two years. Part of the expansion will involve putting civilians in jobs currently done by uniformed officers, along with 160 additional Housing Police officers expected under the Mayor's Safe Cities, Safe Streets program.
The Authority will spend $42 million for electromagnetic locks, intercoms and upgraded exterior lighting, another $42 million into refurbishing the authority's recreation centers and $1 million for youth programs. Security, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero commented yesterday, must include social services like these.
In response to tenant complaints about pervasive drug dealing in some public housing projects, the security plan calls for spending $1.5 million to broaden the screening of prospective residents through criminal background checks, references and home visits. The authority currently manages 180,000 apartments in 3,000 buildings. More than half the residents are under 21 years old.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero has stressed the plan's dependence on a successful partnership between tenants, housing police and management. Responding to the critics, she said that she was confident that she had the support to carry out the plan.

HEADLINE: Pratt & Whitney to Eliminate 7,600 Positions by October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., March 18

 BODY:
Pratt & Whitney, one of Connecticut's largest employers, announced today the timetable for its plan to cut 10,600 jobs, saying it would cut 7,600 positions by October.
Officials of the company, which makes jet engines for military and commercial aircraft, also said they would close an unspecified number of its 13 factories. 
 In a state where manufacturers are reeling from the decline in military spending, today's announcement was the kind of bad news that has become all too familiar.
The president, Karl J. Krapek, said in a letter to employees that Pratt & Whitney would reduce its total floor space by as much as five million square feet over the next two years, two million more than previously announced.
Mr. Krapek said Pratt & Whitney will close factories as well as administrative buildings and warehouses, but did not specify where the closings would be.
The company, with about 20,000 employees in Connecticut, has plants in East Hartford, North Haven, Middletown, Southington, Cheshire and Rocky Hill, and in North Berwick, Me.; Columbus, Ga.; West Palm Beach, Fla., and Montreal.
 
No Final Decisions
 A company spokesman, Mark Sullivan, said final decisions on the plant closings have not been made. He said, however, that at least one or two plants will be closed, possibly more.
Mr. Sullivan insisted that today's announcement does not represent an acceleration of previously announced job cuts.
In January, United Technologies, Pratt & Whitney's parent company, announced that it would slash 10,664 jobs from Pratt & Whitney by the end of 1994, reducing total employment at the division to 30,000 employees. Of the jobs to be eliminated, 6,700 were to be from plants in Connecticut.
The company said it expected to finish cutting 3,600 jobs nationwide by the end of this month, to bring its work force down to 37,000. An additional 2,000 jobs will be eliminated by the end of June and another 2,000 by the end of October.
Analysts said the timetable for job cuts is faster than what they expected but is necessary to make Pratt & Whitney more cost-competitive.
 
Closings Expected
 David J. Franus, an aerospace analyst for Forecast International, a private research and consulting concern that specializes in the aerospace and aviation industries, said the decision to close factories has been expected for more than two years.
"It was getting to the point where if you want to be cost-competitive, you can do that to a certain extent by downsizing, but you also have to reduce overhead, and you do that by consolidating and closing plants," Mr. Franus said.
Union officials were angered by the company's announcement because they said they had been told no decision on the restructuring plan would be revealed until next week.
"When we meet with the company on a Wednesday and we ask them point-blank when the announcement is coming out and they tell us it's next week, it's a shock to us," said Andrew D. Romegialli, directing labor representative for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents most of Pratt & Whitney's blue-collar employees.
"The state is hurting real bad," Mr. Romegialli said. "We're going to need a lot more defense money in this state as soon as possible."
Mr. Krapek said Pratt & Whitney's commercial engine business, now a single entity, would be restructured into three stand-alone operations in the Americas, Europe-Middle East-Africa and the Pacific Rim. Each operation will be headed by a manager responsible for sales, service, customer relations and strategic planning.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Will Not Punish Underwithholding

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 18

 BODY:
Connecticut wage-earners who didn't have enough income taxes withheld from their paychecks will get a break from penalties and interest.
The Legislature unanimously passed a measure Wednesday voiding the interest and penalty payments this year, except for cases of fraud. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. promptly signed the measure. 
 The entire process, which normally could have taken weeks, was dispensed with in a matter of hours -- a sign of lingering concerns that legislators have about a backlash of voter anger over the income tax.
"Because this is the first full year of the personal income tax, it makes sense to remove penalties and interest for those taxpayers who -- acting in all good faith -- underwithheld for 1992," Governor Weicker said.
In recent weeks, it had come to light that many taxpayers inadvertently did not have enough money taken out of their paychecks toward the state's 4.5 percent income tax.
In many cases, the underwithholding was because taxpayers had been given a raise during the year, collected a lot of overtime or had employers who failed to correctly calculate the withholding.
If taxpayers owed $200 or more, and if that represented more than 10 percent of their total liability, they faced penalties and interest that could have added 35 percent to the balance owed.
Taxpayers who have already paid penalties and interest will have the money returned in about a month, according to the Department of Revenue Services.
The Legislature's Office of Fiscal Analysis estimated that eliminating the penalties would result in a revenue loss of about $3 million between the rest of this fiscal year and the 1994-95 fiscal year.
But state officials said they did not count on getting that money so it would not affect the state budget.

HEADLINE: U.S. Partners Say President Shows Two Faces on Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
America's trade partners, bracing for the Clinton Administration's first set of trade sanctions, are angry and confused. Which Bill Clinton are they dealing with, they ask: the President whose policy addresses sketch a broad commitment to free trade? Or the confrontational politician whose Administration has repeatedly hit hard?
"Sooner or later, the U.S. will have to clarify its policy," said Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's commissioner for External Affairs. "You cannot use the language of free trade with one voice and engage in damaging pin-pricks with another." 
 Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community's executive commission, held a long-scheduled meeting with President Clinton today but did not head off United States sanctions that are scheduled to take effect on Monday.
President Clinton told reporters during a break in the meeting, "I don't want a trade war with the E.C. and I don't think we'll have one."
Mr. Clinton and his trade officials say there is no inconsistency in the Administration's emerging trade policy. Trade diplomacy can no longer be neatly labeled as free trade, protectionism or managed trade, they contend; what matters are results. "I agree with the President that we should not slavishly adhere to any particular approach," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative.
The immediate cause of Sir Leon's irritation at a news conference in Brussels on Wednesday lies in the Administration's plans to bar European Community companies on Monday from competing for many Federal contracts. The ban would be in retaliation for new government contract rules in Europe that may hurt American companies. Federal purchasing officials have already been warned informally of the coming ban, and an official notice has been prepared for publication in the Federal Register on Monday.
Mr. Delors said after the meeting with the President that he remained concerned about the possibility of a trade war. "I have drawn the attention of the President to the bad consequences of the decision that will be taken next Monday on public procurement," he added.
Few if any trade experts actually anticipate a tit-for-tat trade war that would result in a serious reduction in the volume of trade. But many trade experts are alarmed that the current trade climate is fast deteriorating.
"We cannot have an implosion of trade," said Carla A. Hills, who was the United States trade representative during the Bush Administration. "I worry that you're going to have frictions, from this lobbing of rhetoric across the Atlantic, that will restrict trade."
 
More Disputes Coming
 More trade conflicts are fast approaching. Administration officials will announce as soon as Friday afternoon whether Japan met a target of importing at least 20 percent of its semiconductors. Mr. Kantor is likely to respond vehemently if the figure falls short, as is expected.
The Commerce Department has also imposed steep but temporary import tariffs on steel from 19 countries and must decide within two months whether to make the tariffs permanent. These tariffs have angered foreign trade officials because they replace a more trade-distorting quota system that guaranteed small but automatically profitable shares of the American market to foreign companies.
President Clinton sketched his vision of open international markets at American University on Feb. 26. But he has also flown to Seattle to criticize European aircraft manufacturing subsidies and then gone to Silicon Valley to announce larger Federal subsidies for high technology.
"When the same person is saying different things to different audiences, it is extraordinarily difficult" for trade negotiators, Mrs. Hills said in an interview today.
The Clinton Administration contends that the high-technology subsidies are different from European subsidies because they are aimed at basic research and the earliest stages of product development, whereas the Airbus subsidies have helped the competitiveness of a specific company. But American participants in the main Federal program get to keep the patents for inventions they develop with Federal money.
Clinton Administration officials also say that the differences in emphasis reflect the need for aggressive approaches to what they perceive as unequal trade agreements. For example, the United States puts about $16 billion a year worth of Federal contracts up for international bids under a global free trade code while the European Community has only put about $8 billion worth of annual Government contracts under the same code. No contracts in the code will be affected on Monday.
The World Bank and other independent analysts have found the American market more open than the markets of Europe and Japan. But European officials are quick to point out that the United States has also benefited from nearly half a century of growing international trade that has allowed each country to specialize at what it does best.
They say that Washington is unfairly picking on Europe at a time when America is running a trade surplus with the community and a trade deficit with Japan.
The planned sanctions next week involve banning companies from the 12 European nations from bidding on nearly $50 billion a year in contracts with the United States Government. The move is in retaliation for new European government-contracting rules that the Bush and Clinton Administrations have condemned as protectionist.
Companies from the community have been winning only about $45 million a year worth of these contracts, which mainly consist of local services like supplying cafeterias in government buildings. Unlike certain Federal contracts for merchandise, these contracts are not covered by international free trade rules and the United States is legally free to restrict foreign access to them.
 
Kantor Canceled Meeting
 Mr. Kantor has been aggressive in his handling of the dispute. Last Friday he abruptly canceled a final staff meeting in Brussels, scheduled for Monday and Tuesday. Mr. Kantor contended then that European negotiators had shown so little flexibility that it was not worth the time and expense for his deputies to fly across the Atlantic.
Sir Leon complained in Brussels on Wednesday that, "as the talks were already planned, it served no useful purpose to call them off, especially when we were prepared to commission a joint independent study on the state of the market."
Sir Leon refused to say then whether the community would retaliate if the United States enacted the ban on Monday. But a European official in Brussels said today that retaliation was among the options now being reviewed.
The official added that any decision to retaliate would have to be made by the community's foreign ministers, who are not scheduled to meet until April 1. Mr. Kantor and Sir Leon will have another chance to solve the dispute at a meeting in Brussels scheduled for March 29 and 30.
The community has not threatened any specific retaliation. But a person with a detailed knowledge of the issue said that some European countries were pressing the community's executive commission to tighten its new government contracts regulation, further excluding foreign companies, if the squabble cannot be settled quickly.
The regulation went into effect on Jan. 1 and covers government contracts for telecommunications, electric power generation, mass transit and municipal water supplies. The new rules include two clauses that anger American officials.
One requires that companies from the community's member nations must win a contract unless a company from outside the community underbids them by at least 3 percent. The other clause allows governments to reject bids at any price if less than half of the goods involved are manufactured in the European Community.
The new communitywide rules replaced varying regulations in each of the 12 member countries. Community officials contend that these regulations were generally more restrictive than the new rules.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues in Sharp Price Jump

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices jumped sharply yesterday, raising the question of whether the rally that stalled a week ago could commence again and bring yields on long-term bonds down to new lows.
Coming on the heels of what appeared to be disappointing inflation reports last Friday and Wednesday, the price rises yesterday seemed to show that investors and traders are still comfortable at these lofty levels for price and low levels of yields. 
 The test of whether the rally is on track again could come soon. Yields yesterday fell close to the lows for the year reached at the beginning of the month, and if they now move lower, the rally will look alive.
In trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond rose 12/32 , to 10412/32 , as the yield fell to 6.78 percent, down from 6.86 percent Wednesday and just 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above the 6.72 percent low hit on March 8. That was the lowest yield on the 30-year bond since the Treasury began regular auctions in 1977.
The price of the 10-year note jumped 27/32 as the yield plunged to 5.89 percent, from 6.00 percent the day before and just a few basis points above the 1993 low of 5.82 percent.
The price of the five-year note was up 20/32 as the yield dropped to 5.04 percent, down from 5.18 percent the day before and just 4 basis pojnts above its 1993 low of 5.00 percent.
It is not clear exactly what was pushing the buying yesterday. Some traders said the rally was led by intermediate Treasury securitities -- five- and 10-year notes. This, they argued, was because dealers were buying these Treasury securities as part of the technical trading they do to hedge or lessen the risk of loss from holding corporate bonds and the decline in value of mortgage-backed securities as millions of homeowners refinace at lower rates.
This technical reason for the buying could help power the rally further but could also disappear quickly. J. Gregory Erardi, the managing director at Salomon Brothers in charge of the government trading desk, said he did not see a lot of institutional buying from the funds and portfolio managers that were the big force behind the rally in bond prices this year. Selling by these same money mannagers after the report of the four-tenths of 1 percent jump in the Producer Price Index last Friday knocked prices sharply lower and yields higher.
"If we don't see additional institutional selling, we could resume the move up to higher prices," he said.
Technical Data, a market research firm, said that its recent survey of portfolio managers showed that funds still had a lot of cash to invest.
The other theme yesterday was that people have become more comfortable with the inflation news, in part because other data seem to imply that the economy is growing at a slower pace now.
The perception of the pace of the economy has been shifting all year. Early in the year there was a feeling that it would be slower than the pace at the end of last year. Then there were data that made people think the economy was moving a little faster, a belief that was reinforced by the strong jump in nonfarm payrolls in February.
 
Indications of Slowing Economy
 But since that report in early March, there have been data indicating that the economy may have slowed a little at the end of February. And the recent blizzard along the East Coast has people thinking that data in March may be a little weaker than expected. If this is the case, the price jumps reflected in the producer report Friday and the Consumer Price Index Wednesday are less worrisome because the pace of the increases should not continue with the slowly growing economy.
