HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Lender for Low-Income Areas Gets Boost

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Chicago's two largest banking companies, the First Chicago Corporation and the Continental Bank Corporation, said yesterday that they had bought $4.5 million of stock in Shorebank Corporation, a much smaller Chicago banking company that specializes in lending in low-income neighborhoods.
The investment in nonvoting stock by the large banks will allow Shorebank's South Shore Bank subsidiary to expand its business in several Chicago neighborhoods. It comes at a time when bankers are nervously waiting to see how the Clinton Administration will enforce the Community Reinvestment Act. That 16-year-old act requires banks to do business in their local markets but does not set guidelines for the volume of that business.
 
Ratings Cited
 At the end of 1992, about 10 percent of banks had an "outstanding" rating from regulators for complying with the act, nearly 80 percent were "satisfactory," and more than 10 percent were either "needs improvement" or were in "substantial noncompliance," according to Kenneth H. Thomas, a Miami-based bank consultant. 
 But the top two ratings may become harder to achieve, since bank regulators have been embarrassed over the last two years by Federal reports showing that minority applicants for mortgages have been nearly twice as likely to be rejected as white applicants of similar income.
Continental Bank, which invested $2.5 million in Shorebank, has a C.R.A. rating of satisfactory, as does the American National Bank subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation, which invested $500,000 in Shorebank. The First National Bank of Chicago, a First Chicago unit, with a $1.5 million investment, is rated outstanding.
Deepak Bhargava, legislative director for the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, a group that has often contended that banks do not lend enough in low-income areas, said he expected "serious enforcement of the Community Reinvestment Act for the first time." He said legislators now see support for the act as a politically popular move and a way to help cities without spending much money.
 South Shore Bank is noted in banking circles for its ability to make loans to and earn profits from borrowers that other banks have shunned. Its successful combination of a bank that makes loans at market interest rates with a real estate development corporation and a nonprofit neighborhood development organization is widely regarded as a model for a national network of 100 community development banks that President Clinton has proposed.
South Shore executives helped create the Southern Development Bancorporation in Arkansas with backing from the Arkansas government under Mr. Clinton. Hillary Rodham Clinton was formerly a director of Southern Development.
South Shore grew rapidly last year when it issued $30 million of new loans and assets advanced about 15 percent, to $235 million. The bank expects another $3 million of stock to be bought by other investors, which would allow it to continue growing by raising its total capital to about $24 million from $17 million before the investment by the Chicago banks.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slumps on Concern About Economic Recovery

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against most currencies yesterday, hitting a record low against the yen, as traders expressed concern about the strength of the United States economic recovery.
"There's no reason to buy dollars right now because the U.S. economy isn't recovering as quickly as it once was," Koichi Takenaka, an assistant vice president at the Industrial Bank of Japan in New York, said. 
 The dollar hit a post-World War II low of 115.65 yen late in the New York trading session, breaking the low of 115.85 yen set Feb. 22. The dollar fell almost two pfennigs against the mark, to 1.643 marks in late trading.
 
 
Gold Gains
 Gold for delivery in April jumped $1.50 an ounce, to $331.20, on the Commodity Exchange.
Figures released yesterday showing the trade deficit widened 6 percent in January did the most to damp investors' outlook on the economy, analysts said. Additionally, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its index of economic activity fell in March.
The dollar's late tumble against the yen was exacerbated by big currency funds, which sold the dollar aggressively once the slide started, analysts said.
The dollar fell against the mark earlier in the day after the German central bank cut its key discount rate to 7.5 percent from 8 percent, as many traders and investors expected. The Bundesbank left its Lombard rate unchanged at 9 percent.
"People were looking for a more generous signal from the Bundesbank, and we didn't get it," Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, said.
Lower rates abroad make dollar-deposits more attractive, raising demand for the currency. At half a percentage point, the German cut was not large enough to warrant more dollar purchases, traders said.
The dollar also weakened against the French franc, dropping to 5.603 francs, from 5.658 francs late Wednesday. The dollar slid to 1.508 Swiss francs from 1.5338 francs and slumped to 1,590 Italian lire from 1,608 lire. The dollar weakened against its Canadian counterpart, falling to $1.2473 (Canadian) from $1.2513 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: Canada Trade Surplus

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: OTTAWA, March 18

 BODY:
Canada's trade surplus rose to $1.9 billion (Canadian), or $1.53 billion (United States), in January, the highest level in almost eight years, as exports continued to drive an economic recovery, the Government said today. The trade surplus rose by $900 million, fueled by record exports and falling imports. Exports to the United States hit a record monthly high, while those to Japan and most of the European Community were strong, the Government agency Statistics Canada said.

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Double-Up and Out For No. 1 Courier

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. March 18

 BODY:
Jim Courier, the world's No. 1 player and renowned workaholic, put in a double shift today on the weather-whipped construction site that doubles as the site of the Lipton Championships. He wound up sorry he made the extra effort.
His morning opponent treated him with consummate respect, but his evening opponent -- older, wiser and familiar because of their shared practice sessions in the California desert where they have neighboring condos -- cruelly ambushed him. 
 All systems were go this morning, when Courier dealt Mikael Pernfors a 6-0, 6-3 comeuppance in the third round. But after he punched in again tonight for his fourth-round match with Mark Woodforde, Courier found himself unemployed here.
 
Hadn't Been Worried
 Woodforde exploited Courier's nervousness and advanced to the quarterfinals with a 6-3, 2-6, 6-2 upset that left the No. 1 player chewing ice in an attempt to cool himself down.
Courier hadn't been worried about having to perform twice and called it "no big deal"; after all, the only other time he did this, a year ago in Hong Kong, he segued straight from semifinal to final and won the event.
But tonight's performance by Courier was of an uncharacteristically knock-kneed, flat-footed vintage that, said Woodforde, "only goes to prove that he's normal like the rest of us."
Courier even vented his discomfort on the chair umpire, Dana Loconto, shaking his chair and earning a code violation during a third-set changeover just after dropping his serve to trail 4-1.
"I had a poor performance and he had a poor performance in the chair," said an unrepentant Courier. "It happened in the heat of the moment; I don't regret anything."
Neither did the 27-year-old Woodforde, a veteran on the mend from knee injuries and confidence trouble. He not only advanced to the quarterfinals against 48th-ranked Marcos Ondruska, who eliminated ninth-seed Michael Stich in straight sets, but also climbed into the top 20 for the first time in his career.
After four days of epic gales and downpours that mangled the palm trees, ravaged the beaches, canceled matches and sent Boris Becker packing because of a flu-related pestilence, fine weather struck the Lipton with a vengeance today only to create a mini-disaster along with five significant upsets.
Warmed by the sunshine, the stadium's soggy Laycold hardcourt surface bubbled up like a witch's brew this morning and rendered itself unusable until late afernoon.
Confined to a Court 1 confrontation with the sonic-server Richard Krajicek, eighth-seed Andre Agassi succumbed to the Dutchman's 12th ace at triple match point and was ousted in straight sets, 6-2, 7-5. Germany's Stich, who called Key Biscayne's variable weather fit only for vacations, not tennis business, was next on and met a similar fate.
Krajicek's next opponent, Pete Sampras, has the same kind of serve. Sampras, who ousted Andrei Medvedev, 6-7, 6-3, 6-2, and Krajicek have never played one another.
The tournament director, Butch Buchholz, later described the temporary stadium's floor problems as "cosmetic," and induced the women quarterfinalists to test it. In the first women's quarterfinal, third-seeded Gabriela Sabatini downed Jana Novotna, 6-2, 6-3, and neither complained about the footing. Sabatini confronts her longtime rival, Steffi Graf, in the semifinals Friday.
In the other semifinal, defending champion Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, seeded second, will face Japan's Kimiko Date, who upset fifth-seed Mary Joe Fernandez 7-6 (7-4), 6-3.
 
The Other McEnroe
 Becker's withdrawl advanced 38th-ranked Nicklas Kulti into the fourth-round, but the free ride was halted there, 7-5, 7-6 (7-3), by 18th-ranked MaliVai Washington, who next faces this event's sleeper entry, 180th-ranked Patrick McEnroe.
McEnroe began his Lipton idyll by ousting sixth-seed Goran Ivanisevic, and today he outwitted another of the game's top servers, Olympic champion Marc Rosset, 4-6, 7-6 (7-2), 6-0.
Rosset lost his temper in the third set and blamed -- surprise, surprise -- this besieged tournament site. "I've been able to shut it out until today, but no more," snapped Rosset.

HEADLINE: Stocks Jump 38.90 Points; Rates Cited

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
A German interest rate cut and the ensuing bond market rally in the United States drove stocks sharply higher yesterday, with heavy industries showing the most muscle.
The Dow Jones industrial average shot to within about a point of a record before closing at 3,465.64, up 38.90 points, or 1.1 percent. The broader market averages also ran up, in moderate trading, as the best-known issues stood out. 
 "It's very straightforward," Charles I. Clough Jr., chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, said. "Markets like lower interest rates and recovering economies, and this one's got both. What more do you want?"
 
Medical Issues Lag
 The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.78 percent yesterday after the German central bank lowered its discount rate, for lending to banks, from to 7.5 percent from 8 percent. [Page D12.]
Auto, chemical and energy stocks scored some of yesterday's best gains, with only the medical and secondary issues left behind, as the Nasdaq market was flat.
Traders spotted some foreign buyers, who usually go for the most widely held stocks, and voiced hopes that the German rate cuts would produce more foreign demand for American goods.
"Anything that is going to stimulate the European economies is going to help our multinationals," said Bill Allyn, the director of listed equity trading at Jefferies & Company.
The rally in this country followed a 3 percent gain in Tokyo stocks to the highest level this year.
Lower bond yields have fueled the American stock market's rise, as investors take on the greater risks of stocks in search of higher returns.
The Dow's advance reached 50 points late in the session before settling just 13 points shy of the record of 3,477.26 set last week. Although stocks are already expensive in terms of their earnings and dividends, several strategists look for the rally to continue and broaden.
Elaine M. Garzarelli of Shearson Lehman said that bond yields are low enough to support a rise of about 10 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, which went to 451.88 yesterday, up 3.57. "The market's probably realizing that we're undervalued," she said. "It looks like fun."
Ford had the best time at yesterday's party, rising 2 7/8, to 51 5/8, with some backing from Wall Street analysts and from investors looking for companies with vast sales abroad. General Motors gained a point, to 39 3/4, and Chrysler rose 5/8, to 39 7/8.
Among the Dow industrial heavyweights adding a point or more were 3M, Du Pont, General Electric, Allied Signal and Goodyear Tire. Retailers joined in, with Sears up 1 7/8, to 52 1/2, and Woolworth up 1 1/8, to 31 7/8. The nation's three largest airline holding companies -- Delta, AMR and UAL, also gained more than a point.
Left behind were the medical stocks, which only managed to register narrower losses than earlier this week.
 
Little Nasdaq Action
 Nasdaq stocks also drew little interest, as the Nasdaq composite index gained a mere hundredth of a point to 687.41. While noting the recent enthusiasm for the biggest Big Board issues, Mary C. Farrell, a Paine Webber strategist, said a sluggish domestic economy could favor the rapidly expanding Nasdaq companies. "Growth is going to be increasingly hard to find," she said. "I think we'll play catch-up here."
Yesterday, several Nasdaq medical stocks continued falling. Tokos Medical, which provides home treatment in risky pregnancies, dropped 1 3/4, to 6 3/4, on disappointing earnings, far from the price of 34 1/2 reached last June.
Sci-Med Life Systems dropped 3 3/4, to 38 1/4, after falling 3 points on Wednesday, as a Piper Jaffray analyst downgraded it. The company, which makes equipment used in heart surgery, broke 90 early last year.
The market's more pleasant surprises included Kemper Corporation, up 5 3/8, to 36 5/8, on the company's plan to trade two insurance subsidiaries for 17.4 million shares held by the Lumbermen's Casualty Company.

HEADLINE: The U.S. Trade Deficit Widens

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The United States merchandise trade deficit worsened in January, the Government reported today. Economists said the report reflected in part the flat economies of many of America's overseas trading partners.
"Our trade deficit deteriorated in January because Europe and Japan are in the midst of a winter of severe economic discontent," John M. Albertine, head of a Washington economic forecasting firm, said. 
 The deficit widened to $7.3 billion in January, a 6 percent increase over the $6.89 billion trade gap in December, the Commerce Department reported. The increase nearly wiped out a 6.2 percent improvement a month earlier.
Exports, which reached a record $39.67 billion in December, fell back 6.7 percent in January, to $37.01 billion, the lowest level since $35.8 billion last August. Two-thirds of the decline was in aircraft and automobiles.
Imports also fell, largely due to a drop in United States purchases of foreign cars and other consumer items, and capital goods.
But the 4.8 percent decline, to $44.31 billion, was overshadowed by the decrease in shipments of American goods overseas. Imports also had hit an all-time high in December, $46.56 billion.
Analysts said the deficit, the difference between exports and imports, would worsen this year because the struggling economies in Japan and much of Europe.
Also, the slowly strengthening United States economy would provide Americans with more income and stimulate demand for overseas goods, they said.
The trade gap swelled to $84.3 billion in 1992, from $65.4 billion in 1991, the first deterioration since it peaked at $152.1 billion in 1987.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Moving 'Fortress'
The National Gallery of Art in Washington doesn't want to talk, but that's not stopping the rest of the art world. The news is the gallery's pending purchase of Bellotto's "Fortress of Konigstein," for a reported $9.5 million. The deal hangs on whether the painting will be granted an export license and allowed to leave London. It is considered British property because it has been in a private English collection for the last 150 years.
Painted between 1756 and 1758, Bellotto's landscape is one in a series of five commissioned by the Elector of Saxony, Friedrich Augustus II, for the royal collection in Dresden. The painting is large (52 1/2 by 92 3/4 inches) and is being sold to the National Gallery by Bruno Meissner, a Zurich dealer who bought the work with Konrad Bernheimer, a Munich dealer. It was the centerpiece of Mr. Meissner's booth in October at the International Antique Dealers Show in Manhattan, where it carried a price tag of $14 million. 
 The two dealers bought the picture at Sotheby's in London in December 1991 for about $6 million, and then had it cleaned by the Alte Pinakothek Museum in Munich. At the International Antique Dealers Show, Mr. Meissner said that both the Pinakothek and the National Gallery of Art in London were offered the picture.
Ruth Kaplan, who heads the press office at the National Gallery in Washington, said its purchase money was from the museum's acquisition budget. "The painting is particularly meaningful to the gallery's collection," she said. "While we have two Bellottos from the Samuel Kress collection, we do not have an 18th-century landscape of this quality and size. It is one of the great European masterpieces."
Mr. Meissner said he was optimistic that the painting would be allowed to go to Washington, adding, "No English institution has been able to raise the money to buy it."
 
Lawsuit About a Job
 More troubles at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. When Michael E. Shapiro became the director after Earl A. Powell 3d (now director of the National Gallery in Washington) in October, he was faced with an institution fraught with problems. The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors had cut $2 million from the museum's operating budget, even as the institution suffered a financial setback from declining membership funds and private donations. As a result, there were staff reductions, weekday gallery closings and cancellations of coming traveling exhibitions.
The latest brouhaha erupted on Wednesday, when Maurice Tuchman, who had been the museum's senior curator for 20th-century art for 27 years, filed a lawsuit against Mr. Shapiro and the museum's trustees in Los Angeles County Superior Court, seeking damages and reinstatement in his job.
Mr. Tuchman said he had been essentially demoted, with no warning, when a memo from Mr. Shapiro informed him that his job would be the newly created post of senior curator of 20th-century drawings. Stephanie Barron, a curator in 20th-century art, has been named to Mr. Tuchman's former post.
"We understand the lawsuit has been filed," Mr. Shapiro said yesterday. "But we haven't had an opportunity to review it, therefore it would be inappropriate to comment on it at this time."
 
Bottom Lines
 The year-end figures just released by Sotheby's and Christie's show auction sales crawling out of the recession, one percentage point at a time. Overall profits for both companies, however, are down, at least if measured in American dollars.
Of the two auction houses, Christie's had slightly more encouraging news. Total sales in 1992 were $1.062 billion, up from $1.032 billion in 1991. The company's pre-tax profits amounted to $11.1 million, down from $11.3 million the year before. (In pounds, the company's profits rose to 6.7 million in 1992, from 6.4 million in 1991.)
"We were pleased that we increased our profits a touch, but we have a long way to go," said David Tyler, the group finance director of Christie's International, in a telephone interview from his London office. "We cut our costs by 22 percent over the last two years and that certainly helped."
Sotheby's figures show a small rise in its auction sales, which reached $1.132 billion in 1992, up from $1.104 billion in 1991. But the numbers for the rest of the company's business were grim, with total pre-tax profits for 1992 falling to $6.5 million, way down from 1991 when the company made $21.5 million.
"This certainly wasn't a great year," said Diana D. Brooks, president of Sotheby's in North and South America. The reason for the nose dive in profits, Mrs. Brooks said, is the company's greatly reduced income from Acquavella Modern Art, the subsidiary of the holding company that was formed three years ago by Sotheby's and the Manhattan-based Acquavella Gallery. The holding company paid $143 million for the contents of the Pierre Matisse Gallery in Manhattan, 2,300 works by Miro, Dubuffet, Giacometti, Chagall and other 20th-century masters, and has been selling off works privately. In the last year, Mrs. Brooks said, Sotheby's has not been offering works of art from Acquavella Modern Art for sale, preferring instead to wait until the market goes up.
In the figures Sotheby's released, profits from Acquavella Modern Art are included in a category that also includes sales of art from Sotheby's own inventory. Profits in this category declined drastically, to $1.8 million in 1992 from $15.8 million in 1991 and $31.5 million in 1990.
Another reason for Sotheby's drop in profits, Mrs. Brooks said, was a reduced demand for its financial services. "We also wanted to reduce our portfolio when interest rates went down," she said.
Sotheby's also had several large expenses in 1992, including opening an auction center in Taiwan, buying the Spanish auction house Edmund Peel and installing a worldwide computer program linking all Sotheby's offices.
 
A Letter to the President
 The Whitney Biennial isn't the art world's only source of political statements. A Manhattan dealer, Richard L. Feigen, is speaking out, too, and has gotten many heavy-hitters in the arts world to join him.
In a letter faxed to President Clinton last week, Mr. Feigen suggested that artists, writers, actors, dancers, musicians, photographers and architects should have a voice in the appointment of the next chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. These groups, he wrote, have "felt disenfranchised for 30 years, since the Kennedy Administration."
The letter went on to suggest that the White House consider the actress Jane Alexander for the job, which has been vacant since Anne-Imelda Radice left it after the Presidential election.
Among those who have signed Mr. Feigen's letter are the art dealer Leo Castelli, the artists Frank Stella and Eric Fischl, the writers Norman Mailer and E. L. Doctorow, the actors Michael Douglas, Eli Wallach, Tony Randall and Lily Tomlin; Peter Martins, the artistic director of the New York City Ballet; the dancer Darci Kistler, and the architects Richard Meier and Charles Gwathmey.
"Every day more people call my office wanting their names to be included," Mr. Feigen said. "I'm about to fax the President an additional list."
 
Heading Back to SoHo
 After 10 years on 57th Street, Holly Solomon is moving her gallery back to SoHo. "I was on West Broadway from 1975 to 1983," she said. "Not only is the new space unique, but I think the artists will be more visible there. It's just to hard to create the kind of energy that you find in SoHo."
Ms. Solomon's new gallery, at 174 Mercer Street, on the corner of Houston Street, has 6,000 square feet of space with 20-foot-high ceilings. It once housed the Pineapple Dance Center.
The new gallery opens on April 3 with the work of the Korean-born video artist Nam June Paik. The show is titled "The Rehearsal" because it will feature some work that will be in the German pavilion at the Venice Biennale this summer.

HEADLINE: Films From New Directors Taking Literary License

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
The New Directors/New Films series has existed for 22 years, but it has rarely if ever led off with the literary one-two punch of tonight's opening programs, "Orlando" and "The Music of Chance."
Both films are adapted from the kind of serious novel that Hollywood has traditionally shunned as hopelessly highbrow and uncommercial. "Orlando," the debut of Sally Potter, a 43-year-old English choregrapher turned director, is a cinematic realization of Virginia Woolf's classic 1928 novel. "The Music of Chance," the first fictional feature by the documentary film maker Philip Haas, is an adaptation of a highly regarded metaphysical suspense novel, published in 1990 by the Brooklyn-based author Paul Auster. 
 On the surface, neither book would seem to lend itself readily to translation into a film. Orlando's title character, portrayed by Tilda Swinton, begins the film as a man, then changes sex midway in his/her 400-year journey into the present. Ms. Potter has filmed the novel as a series of highly stylized historical tableaux, each evoking the tyranny of rigidly defined sex roles on an androgynous spirit.
In "The Music of Chance," Mandy Patinkin and James Spader portray a firefighter turned drifter and a lowlife gambler who become unlikely partners and ultimately prisoners on the estate of two eccentric and sinister millionaires.
The two films are the opening features in the 22d edition of the New Directors series, which runs through April 4 in the Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters at the Museum of Modern Art. The series, which is jointly presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the museum's film department, will show 33 films in 22 programs. Twelve of the selections are shorts varying in length from three minutes to just less than an hour.
 
An Independent Spirit
 Like last year's New Directors series, this year's program reflects the continuing boom of the American independent cinema. Ten selections are American independent films. Among those, the boldest, technologically speaking, is Michael Almereyda's 56-minute featurette "Another Girl, Another Planet." The movie, set in an East Village tenement, was shot on a toy video camera. With its air of deadpan comic hipness, it is vaguely similar in tone to the work of Jim Jarmusch.
The series has always cultivated a quality that Richard Pena, program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, described recently as "a certain recklessness."
"The films that seem the most attractive are films that go overboard and take it to the limit beyond what was expected," he said. "It is something one normally associates with youth, and it gives the films, even when they're unsuccessful, a welcome energy."
"In a number of this year's films, there is the sense of constructing narratives by layering," he added. "Instead of the old modernist way, in which telling a story became a problem, here people have almost too many stories to tell, and they keep telling them one on top of another."
Both "Orlando" and "The Music of Chance" evoke a theme that pulses through a surprising number of the other films being shown this year. Adrienne Mancia of the Museum of Modern Art's programming staff described that theme as entrapment.
"A lot of the characters are trapped in situations they have no control over," she observed. "It can be everything from AIDS to living in a Communist society."
 
Forms of Subversion
 Three films that evoke a feeling of being socially trapped are the British film maker Richard Spence's rough-and-tumble "You, Me and Marley," Flora Gomes's "Blues Eyes of Yonta," which is set in Africa, and Goran Markovic's "Tito and Me," from Yugoslavia.
"You, Me and Marley" unfolds on the mean streets of Belfast, where frustrated teen-agers play a death-defying street sport called joy riding, in which they steal cars and ride them to destruction. To these youths, everyone, even the Irish Republican Army, is the enemy.
"The Blue Eyes of Yonta" is set in the troubled capital city of the West African republic of Guinea-Bissau, where the economy is stagnant and the young people daydream about emigrating to Europe. "Tito and Me" is a comically irreverent look back at growing up in Communist Yugoslavia in the 1950's when Jozip Broz Tito ruled like a stern, all-seeing father. The central character is a chubby pubescent boy whose pranks subvert a solemn pilgrimage to Tito's birthplace by a group of students.
In two films, the theme of entrapment extends directly to the human body. Yilmaz Arslan's eerie documentary-style film "Passages" is set in a German rehabilitation center inhabited by troubled teen-agers with severe physical disabilities. The late French film maker Cyril Collard's autobiographical film "Savage Nights" is the story of a bisexual artist who discovers he is H.I.V.-positive and goes on a self-destructive erotic and emotional rampage.
 
Emotional Violence
 Along with "Orlando," "Savage Nights" is likely to be one of the most discussed films in this year's series. This month, the 129-minute film was awarded four Cesars (the French film industry's Oscars), including best film. Four days before the ceremonies, Mr. Collard, who wrote, directed and starred in the film, died of AIDS.
"Savage Nights" is a brutal self-portrait of the film maker, whose cinematic alter ego wreaks destruction, among other sins having unprotected sex with an 18-year-old girl without informing her of his H.I.V. status. As he seesaws between his attraction to the girl and to a 20-year-old rugby player with a streak of sadomasochism, the confusion drives several of the characters nearly haywire. Few films in recent years have been charged with so much emotional violence.
In an interview in "Muses From Chaos and Ash: AIDS, Artists, and Art" (Grove Press, 1993), the film maker talked about the freedom of expression he felt after publicly identifying himself as H.I.V.-positive.
"After an artist says, 'I'm H.I.V.-positive,' he can say anything," Mr. Collard declared. "When that taboo has been swept aside, shame or modesty no longer exists. Pure art, essential art, comes out of situations of extreme repression. And AIDS is a form of nonpolitical repression; it's a psychic repression."
 
Fidelity to Woolf
 "Orlando," although much gentler in tone than the raging erotic rebelliousness of "Savage Nights," expresses a similar sense of liberation.
Or, as Ms. Potter described her motto in a recent telephone interview from London, "empowerment through pleasure."
"I chose 'Orlando' because when I first read the book as a teen-ager, it burned a visual hole in my brain that never went away," she said. "I could see it running in my mind's eye as I read it."
"Although it was written in 1928 and covers 400 years, it is so much about this moment now," she continued. "The idea of being able to transcend normal human life is the ultimate contradiction to the fear of death for nuclear-age babies and AIDS babies."
In adapting the novel, Ms. Potter said she wanted to be "faithful to the spirit of Virginia Woolf's intent but not at all faithful to the letter of the book."
"The story line is the same," she explained. "What I've done is add motivational reasons for certain twists in the story. In the book, the changing of the sex is rather arbitrary. In the film, it comes out of Orlando's being pushed to the very edge of manhood and finding that he cannot or will not be the kind of man society demands he be. Later on, she finds out the same thing."
 
Freedom in Captivity
 If "Orlando" examines issues of freedom and repression from a sexual perspective, "The Music of Chance" takes them a notch higher to a metaphysical plane.
Mr. Haas's previous films have been documentaries of artists, including David Hockney, Richard Long, and the team of Gilbert and George. In a series of four films collectively titled "Magicians of the Earth," he also examined the work of traditional artists, including Australian aboriginal ground painters and Malagasy funerary sculptors.
"The Music of Chance," although a dramatic film, has certain stylistic links to his documentaries. It is especially clear in the scenes where the two prisoners are compelled to build a wall using stones that were once the ruins of an Irish castle.
"My documentary works are pretty formal," Mr. Haas said in a recent interview. "The care I put into making films with visual artists, I tried to translate into 'The Music of Chance,' especially in the wall and how one would film the wall."
This visual formality helps to focus the philosophical paradox that lies at the heart of the film. It is a paradox that echoes in more abstract terms some of the same ideas explored in "Savage Nights" and "Orlando."
"It is the whole issue of freedom and imprisonment," Mr. Haas said. "The central character is in a predicament. Initially he seems to have everything, but he learns that in having everything he perhaps has nothing. It is only when he is confined that he realizes a sense of freedom."
 
Opening Night and After at Film Series

HEADLINE: A Test of Backbone for Democrats

 BODY:
Trent Lott of Mississippi and fellow Senate Republicans are on the verge of attracting enough Democratic votes to scuttle a key component of President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan. The unfortunate coalition opposes raising taxes on wealthier Social Security recipients, which President Clinton proposed as a way to trim a program that accounts for nearly one-fifth of Federal outlays. Sadly, Senate Democratic leaders are gearing up to compromise rather than fight.
There's more at stake here than just the $30 billion the tax hike is expected to raise over five years. If the Democratic leaders flinch on the first challenge to their program by a powerful interest group, the rest of the economic package could come apart at warp speed. 
 Mr. Clinton sold his economic package with the message that the pain would be spread widely. Still, it took courage to take on 30 million of the elderly by asking them to fork over -- even though he asks nothing more from them than their fair share.
The President proposes to raise the percentage of benefits subject to income tax from 50 percent to 85. The poor wouldn't be touched because families with incomes under $32,000 and individuals with incomes less than $25,000, more than three-quarters of retirees, would be exempt. The proposed hike would take away an extra 10 percent of benefits for a family in the 28 percent tax bracket.
The 85 percent figure is not arbitrary. By levying the tax in this manner, retirees would pay tax on benefits in excess of their contributions. That's the same fair principle that applies to taxation of private pensions.
Equity is on the side of Mr. Clinton and the Senate Democratic leadership. But the votes may not be. Running scared, the leaders are reportedly prepared to offer amendments that would either lower the 85 percent figure or raise the income thresholds at which the tax kicks in.
But retreat might easily backfire. It will invite every other interest group to clamor for compromise. The better option is to fight for substantial revenues from families that are rightfully asked to pay more so the President's investment program can go forward.

HEADLINE: Old Alliances, New Asia

 BODY:
North Korea's defiance of the world over nuclear inspections should remind Americans that peace in Asia can't be taken for granted. But while the reckless antics of Pyongyang's time-warp dictatorship are familiar to Washington, newer challenges have crept up on policy makers almost unnoticed. America's cold war era security treaties are inadequate to meet the challenges ahead.
China has doubled its military spending since 1988, using the money to build its first seagoing navy since the Ming Dynasty half a millennium ago. This week it threatened to attack if Taiwan moves toward independence. Japan has stretched the limits of its constitutional ban on overseas military deployment. And smaller powers like Indonesia and Malaysia have embarked on arms-buying sprees. 
 Meanwhile, ideological changes have scrambled Asia's political geography and created new diplomatic alignments -- as demonstrated by Russia's strong stand against North Korea this week.
Washington's system of bilateral mutual security treaties with Japan, South Korea and the Philippines were formulated with a monolithic Communist enemy in mind. Future conflicts are more likely to be nationalistic, potentially pitting one U.S. ally against another. America, as a Pacific power, still needs to play a central role in keeping the Asian peace. But to do so it will need new arrangements, leading toward a collective security system open to all countries prepared to play by its rules.
Unlike the cold-war treaties, collective security aims at maximum inclusion. All participating states agree to basic rules like respecting each other's borders, abiding by arms control agreements and avoiding suspicious troop movements. Participants also agree to cooperate in enforcing these rules against any transgressor.
Asian collective security was anathema to the cautious Bush Administration. But the Clinton hands have proved more receptive. They have already endorsed the regional security discussions held under the auspices of Asean, the six-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
Japan, South Korea, Australia, New Zealand and the U.S. are formal Asean "dialogue partners." But that still leaves East Asian military powers like Russia, China, Vietnam and Taiwan excluded.
China's flouting of proliferation rules and Taiwan's peculiar diplomatic status might argue for proceeding without them, at least initially. But Russia surely belongs in any post-cold-war Asian security system, as its role in the Korean crisis demonstrates. And now that it is cooperating with its neighbors over Cambodia, so might Vietnam.
Asean deserves credit for starting this needed discussion. And the Clinton Administration deserves strong encouragement in taking on a more active, constructive role. The peace of Asia may well hinge on how quickly Washington updates its policies and expands its alliances.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Cutting Aid to Israel

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Israeli economists in Jerusalem are beginning to talk about a brand new problem of aid from the United States -- how and when to bring up the idea of getting not more but less.
That is not yet the policy of the Rabin Government, and may never be. And there will be a lot of back and forth about it, denials maybe, expressions of shock and similar bureaucratic blahblah. 
 But the fact is that it is being discussed in Israel, which is a compliment to the political intelligence of the specialists and officials involved.
Myself, I think it could be one of the best gifts Israel could give itself and the U.S., and the sooner the better.
Cutting back on aid from the U.S. obviously would increase Israel's immediate economic pressures. But provided Israel took the initiative it would have long-term political advantages for both countries.
Israel gets about $3 billion a year from the United States. About $1.8 billion is for loans to buy American weapons essential to Israeli defense. The rest is used to pay interest on past military loans to Israel.
Now that certainly is a nice way to get a loan, with the borrower getting another loan for the interest. But it is not the huge handout that Americans less than enamored of Israel try to make it out.
In fact, it has been a decent bargain for Washington as well as Israel. No U.S. government that did not want Israel utterly destroyed could have gone on selling scores of billions of dollars a year in weapons to the Arabs without keeping up Israeli strength.
And, of course, from the day of its birth to the fall of the Soviet Union Israel was the only dependable American military ally against Moscow in the Mideast.
For years the reality of Israeli strength gave military credibility to the United States' position in the Middle East -- and pause to the Russians.
But Americans and Israelis have to face new realities, mostly political.
The death of the Soviet Union means that the Arab states can no longer look to Moscow for free help. But for Israel that has not removed the military danger. Arab countries are stuffed with new Western arms, clearance-sale tanks from Eastern Europe and late-model Chinese missiles.
Others may forget Iran's nuclear potential for a day or two; Israelis cannot. And the price of fighting terrorism mounts every day.
For an important article on the risks involved in the peace negotiations see the April issue of Commentary. The article is by its editor, Norman Podhoretz. It is one of the few maverick dissenting pieces by pro-Israel Americans about current Israeli strategy to appear in the American press. I would give up my bow ties rather than miss an issue of this sophisticated, essential journal.
The White House, more candid than Israel's Labor Government is in public, said that peace with the Arabs could bring risks that would involve further expenditures and aid -- presumably to build new bases against the loss of the Golan Heights and much of the West Bank.
Anyway, the military loans would have to remain, for the security of both the U.S. and Israel.
But at a time when the U.S. is cutting back on aid to some countries, and facing new costs in the Bosnias and Somalias, it does not seem fitting for Israel and its American friends to insist on the same package.
It hands her enemies in the U.S. a nice new political bat. But the critical reason is for Israel's sake -- its pride, independence and self-confidence.
Mr. Clinton is warm to Israel. But differences may come. There's no sign whatsoever that he will use those differences as did Bushbaker -- to cover the Israeli Government with contempt.
This is exactly the time, when there is no pressure, for Israel to say it needs the military loans but will handle the interest costs itself, perhaps with extra help from individual foreign supporters.
The economic weight will not sink Israel, which is doing pretty well with a growth rate of about 6 percent and the potential $10 billion borrowing power of the U.S.-guaranteed loans.
The extra expense of the $1.2 billion interest might inspire Israel to move away faster from the musty Socialist dogma that has held back Israeli Governments past and present. That alone would be good value for the money.

HEADLINE: U.S. Shouldn't Push Russia Into Chaos

 BODY:
To the Editor:
After acknowledging that President Boris N. Yeltsin's "authoritarian instincts are undeniable" in "The Perfect Gift for Mr. Yeltsin" (editorial, March 10), you endorse him in his conflict with the Russian Congress of People's Deputies. You thus tell Mr. Yeltsin -- and the world -- that you will support him if he carries out his strongly implied threat to use special troops against the legislature.
You justify this on the ground that Mr. Yeltsin faces a Parliament that opposes and thwarts his economic policy. So will President Francois Mitterrand if new elections bring the opposition to power in the French National Assembly, as expected. 
 The conflict comes because the Yeltsin Government -- and the United States -- insist on economic "shock therapy": the fastest possible transition to a free market. But like the effect of sudden change of temperature on the human body, sudden economic change can bring fever or pneumonia. Years of central planning and captive markets make former Soviet industry unequipped to com pete with the world's cheapest, fastest producers. Without patience and substantial investment, Russian industry will simply fail massively, leaving general unemployment.
It will also leave a cash-hungry Russia as a quarry of raw materials and petroleum prospects at fire-sale prices. That vision attracts some investors here -- and draws mounting nationalist anger in Russia.
To win military support for imposing shock therapy, Mr. Yeltsin must buy off a restless army. He -- and we -- find ourselves accepting the very policies for which we blamed his opponents. In "There's No Oil in Bosnia" (Op-Ed, March 10), Dimitri K. Simes warns that the United States cannot take strong action to stop Serbian genocide without hurting Mr. Yeltsin's "democrats." Mr. Yeltsin has asked us for a United Nations mantle to use Russian troops in other former Soviet republics. This arouses their fears of Great Russian imperialism and has led Ukraine to balk at nuclear disarmament commitments.
It is an axiom of United States policy to support Mr. Yeltsin. But which one? President Yeltsin, the democrat who climbed on top of a tank, or Czar Boris, the autocrat who uses one? At times the bully, Mr. Yeltsin has also shown skill in compromise. It is we who have vetoed compromises in economic policy.
We can and should aid Russia -- without attaching intrusive stipulations. It is in everyone's interest that the Russians have the best chance to find their own future. Only a fraction of Mr. Yeltsin's critics favor Stalinism. It is our intervention that makes most likely an extreme reaction in which the vehement few prevail.
Democracy is a process, not a predetermined result. We should make that clear to Mr. Yeltsin -- and respect it ourselves.
 
DAVID KEPPEL
Essex, Conn., March 11, 1993

HEADLINE: The Real Voting Fraud

 BODY:
"Cruel," "sad" and "pathetic." So the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, described Republican obstructionism that prompted his withdrawal of key provisions aimed at increasing voter registration among the poor and unemployed. Unless he had caved in to G.O.P. filibuster threats, he said, the entire "motor voter" bill might have been lost.
But there's still hope that the Republicans can be embarrassed into doing the right thing about broadening the franchise. The bill now goes to a conference committee. If House Democrats stick to the sound standards they have already passed, the bill would bounce back to the Senate, where the G.O.P.'s selfish objections would come under a harsh spotlight. The timid Republican moderates who have been lined up behind the minority leader, Bob Dole, would be forced to face their constituents and their consciences. 
 Three such Republican Senators could tip the balance toward wider participation in democracy: David Durenberger of Minnesota, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Bob Packwood of Oregon.
There can be no glow of principle around the G.O.P. position. Senator Dole wants to limit voting because he fears the new voters will be Democrats -- the same calculation that led President Bush to veto a similar bill last year while arguing that he was merely striking a blow against vote fraud.
The bill would require states to let people register to vote when they obtain or renew a driver's license -- a step that should dramatically increase the number of registered voters, since 90 percent of American adults have driver's licenses. The bill would also require states to permit registration by mail.
Senate Republicans did have one good idea: to make registration available at military recruiting offices. But to obtain the 60 votes needed to halt a Republican filibuster, Democrats also had to accept a handful of other amendments, the most damaging of which removed the requirement that states make registration available at welfare and unemployment offices.
To justify this slap at the poor and unemployed, the G.O.P., true to form, raised the specter of coercion and fraud but produced no evidence that these problems had increased in states that have agency registration programs.
So let House Democrats toss motor voter back to the Senate. The version that returns won't be subject to Republican amendments. That could swing the trio of Durenberger, Specter and Packwood, who have been playing a shady game trying to pose as reformers for the benefit of progressive voters back home while voting with their party to torpedo a worthy bill.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Social Security
Q. If you return to work after receiving Social Security retirement benefits, will your benefits change when you stop working again?
 A. ROSENBLUTH, Manhattan
 
A. Social Security retirement benefits are based on your lifetime average earnings. "If you claim retirement benefits and continue or return to work, the amounts you earn will be credited to your personal lifetime earnings record," said Joseph L. Matthews, author of "Social Security, Medicare and Pensions" (Thorndike Press, $22.95). 
 This means that when your earnings record changes, Social Security automatically recalculates your average earnings. So if the income you earn after having claimed retirement benefits increases your lifetime income average, your retirement benefits will also be recalculated upward.
 
 
 
Commissions on Securities
Q. How are the commissions figured on stock and bond purchases?
 STEPHAN A. LEOPOLD, Manhattan
 
A. Commissions on stock purchases at full-service brokers depend on the number of shares and the total dollar size of the transaction. "They range typically from under 1 percent for 200 shares at $110 to as high as 5.5 percent for 2000 shares at $2," said Madeline I. Noveck, chairman of the Institute of Certified Financial Planners.
Discount brokers offer discounts of 20 to 90 percent from the commissions charged by full-service brokers, although the latter may be negotiable. The Securities and Exchange Commission requires that the exact amount be reported to you on your confirmation slip.
In most cases, there is no separate commission on bonds, which are usually sold to customers from a bond dealer's inventory. And dealers do not disclose their markup on these sales. To find out the difference, or spread, between the buy price and the sell price, get a bid from another dealer, since the selling dealer is unlikely to tell you.

 
 
Savings Bond Interest
Q. I own a large number of E bonds purchased from payroll deductions that date from 1962 through 1974. How long will they continue to earn interest and what is the rate of interest?
 LEONARD RATNER, Manhattan
 
A. Series E United States Savings Bonds issued from 1941 through November 1965 earn interest for 40 years. Bonds issued subsequently earn interest for 30 years.
In November 1982, a program was instituted under which bonds earn either a market-based variable rate if held at least five years or a guaranteed minimum rate -- whichever is higher. Older bonds were grandfathered into this program at the rate prevailing at the time they went into an extension or at the average market-based rate applying to bonds purchased before November 1982, which is 7 3/4 percent.
"All of your bonds are earning that amount for this period because the average is overriding their minimum rates, which are either 4 percent, 6 percent or 7 1/2 percent, depending on the issue date," said Richard J. Schneebeli, deputy executive director of United States Savings Bonds.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Lobbyists Scurry for a Place On the Health-Reform Train

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Politicians love to rail against the entrenched interests who are fighting health-care reform, but nowadays it is hard to find an interest group that does not present itself as a dedicated health-care reformer.
As the lobbyists put it, the train is leaving the station. The Clinton White House is 45 days from producing a comprehensive health-care plan, and the argument is no longer over whether to change the system but how. Nearly all affected interest groups have suggestions, warnings, pleas and competing visions of what the reforms should be. 
 Five big insurance companies, for example, have formed the Alliance for Managed Competition. Managed competition is the Clintons' preferred theory of health care and one that critics say is particularly favorable to big insurance companies. The American Medical Association is running advertisements declaring itself eager for "a new partnership" with the Administration to work toward its plan for "total reform." More than 200 plans for reorganizing the health-care system have been presented to the White House in recent months.
As Jim Jaffe, the press secretary for the House Ways and Means Committee, put it, "Almost everyone has abandoned the Nancy Reagan school of lobbying; rather than just saying no, they're trying to say how."
More than anything, at the moment, the lobbyists want a meeting. At last count, 240 groups -- from nursing home operators to generic drug manufacturers, from insurance agents to advocates for the disabled to supporters of a Canadian-style health system -- have met with Administration officials.
"What we're finding is that some groups want to be met with over and over and over again," said Mike Lux, who heads the White House's public liaison operation for health care.
Some, like A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials, get a private meeting with Hillary Rodham Clinton, who heads the Administration's Task Force on National Health Care Reform. Some, like the Jackson Hole Group that originated the theory of managed competition, get a visit from Ira C. Magaziner, Mrs. Clinton's top aide. Some, like the legislative council of the American Association of Retired Persons, which boasts 34 million members, get a meeting with the President. Others are herded into multi-group "round-table discussions" with Administration officials.
But the normal hierarchical distinctions do not necessarily hold; the more than 500 people in the working groups who are actually developing the plan are in many ways the most sought after. The White House has tried to keep their identities secret, by largely quarantining them in the Old Executive Office Building. But it is hard to keep a secret in Washington, and many of the members have become known.
Mr. Lux said lobbyists had tried to track down some of the working-group members at home. "We're trying to protect our folks from that as much as we can, not because we worry about them being unduly influenced, but because we want them to get their work done," he said. The lobbyists say they are simply trying to convey real-world perspective to a group heavy with academics and theoreticians.
Capitol Hill veterans say this is the struggle's mild phase: Once the Clinton plan reaches Congress in May, a wave of pleading is expected that will make "Gucci Gulch," the hallways near the committee rooms where the tax laws are written, seem subdued.
"There are 750 trade associations specifically connected with health care," said Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, a West Virginia Democrat who has been involved in the issue. "I'm just trying to run through my mind, What happens when this bill hits?"
A bill this big, not surprisingly, involves most of the heavies in the business: the Wexler Group, for example, is representing Johnson & Johnson as well as the Catholic Health Association; Patton, Boggs & Blow is representing Smithkline Beecham, Blue Cross of California and others.
 
Maneuvering by Groups
 But the action at the moment is subtle. "There's a lot of positioning, trying to sound like you're in favor of reform except for this little piece or that little piece; hoping to get your little piece," said Arnold Bennett, a spokesman for Families USA, an advocacy group pushing for universal health insurance. "And if you don't, come out swinging in May."
John Rother, the chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons, said, "There's one overriding strategy right now, and that is to secure a place at the table."
The American Medical Association recently voiced frustration about its lack of access, but in an interview its executive vice president, Dr. James Todd, said the press misunderstood its complaints. "We did not want to sit on the task force or in the working groups; we want exposure to the process," he said. "We want input."
Mr. Magaziner noted last week, "There are 26 other groups who also claim to represent doctors who also want to sit at the table."
What many groups fear is that they might end up the way the drug manufacturers did last month, decidedly on the outside, lambasted by both Clintons for their profits and prices.
There is, in fact, an inside and an outside game going on among the health-care groups: the working groups and the White House are one audience, the public another. Hence the advertising campaigns undertaken by groups like the American Occupational Therapy Association. And hence the grass-roots organizing by groups like Citizen Action, which is hoping to demonstrate overwhelming public support for a single-payer, Canadian-style national health plan.
The Clintons are believed to be committed to a system of managed competition, in which individuals and employers are organized into large cooperatives to buy health care, thus supposedly maximizing their power to get a high-quality plan at the lowest price.
A program with so many moving parts, which will cover one-seventh of the economy and, in one way or another, all 250 million Americans, is riddled with pockets of potential controversy. But most of the action right now centers on two broad areas: What will be in the basic benefits package that will be guaranteed to all Americans? And what kind of controls on costs will be imposed?
 
Issue of Cost Controls
 The retired persons' group, for example, is pressing for a benefits package that covers prescription drugs and, at least down the line, long-term care. Groups like the American Psychological Association are pushing for mental-health benefits.
But the fiercest struggle centers on cost controls. The medical association, for example, is strongly opposed to strict price controls or a national "budget" for health care. So are a range of other industry groups, including some of the big insurers that back managed competition. Most of these groups have carried this message to Mr. Magaziner and any other Administration official who will listen.

HEADLINE: Kenneth Boulding, an Economist, Philosopher and Poet, Dies at 83

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Kenneth Boulding, a much-honored but unorthodox economist, philosopher and poet, died yesterday. He was 83.
His assistant, Vivian Wilson, said Professor Boulding, who had taught at the University of Colorado in Boulder since 1977, died at his home after a long bout with cancer. 
 Nominated at different times for Nobel Prizes in both peace and economics, Professor Boulding was renowned less for a single contribution to economics than for a large number of interesting intellectual and moral insights that both charmed and challenged his fellow social scientists.
In addition to writing three dozen books, three volumes of poetry and 800 articles, Professor Boulding -- whose white mane, stammer and pointed wit made him distinctive -- lectured frequently and entertainingly.
"Ken Boulding is like wine that can't be shipped very far," said Mancur Olson, a professor of economics at the University of Maryland. "His talks, his writing were so full of brilliant asides that no summary does them justice."
 
Early Successes
 The son of a plumber, Kenneth Ewart Boulding was born in grimy Liverpool, England, in 1910. He won a chemistry scholarship to Oxford, said Mark Blaug, professor emeritus at the University of London, but soon switched to economics. In 1931, at age 22, he had his first paper -- a short but brilliant work on economics -- accepted by the Economic Journal, edited by John Maynard Keynes, the British economist.
After fellowships at Harvard University and the University of Chicago and a short spell teaching at the University of Edinburgh in Scotland, Professor Boulding came to the United States for good. He taught at several colleges around the country before settling at the University of Colorado.
Like the American economist Paul Samuelson and the British economist Nicholas Caldor, Professor Boulding initially concentrated on adding his own insights to Keynes's theory that depressions are due to too little private spending and that governments should run deficits to end them.
His first book, "Economic Analysis," was an introductory textbook that over four editions between 1941 and 1966 blended Keynesian and neoclassical economic theory into a coherent synthesis. Professor Blaug said the book was "remarkable in showing how far one can go in economics by using no tool more complicated than that of demand and supply."
Professor Boulding, from a family of deeply religious Methodists, became a Quaker as a young man and remained a passionate if unconventional Christian throughout his life. An ardent pacifist, he opposed Word War II and lost his wartime post as an economist at the League of Nations.
 
Concerns Beyond Economics
 His spiritual and philosophical concerns ultimately led him to look far beyond economics. "Imagine someone who was half Milton Friedman, half Mahatma Ghandi," said Professor Olson, who knew Professor Boulding well and credits him for influencing his own work.
Professor Boulding invented new areas of economics, including the economics of peace, and published a book of that title in 1945. (An Ayer edition is still in print.)
Professor Boulding won the John Bates Clark Medal of the American Economic Association in 1949, a prize given every two years to the economist under age 40 judged to have made a significant contribution to economic thought. The award was recognition that Professor Boulding was one of the best and brightest of his generation of economists. After that, he increasingly wandered from the traditional concerns of economics
"He left economics," said Wassily Leontief, himself a Nobel Prize winner in economics. "He became a universal philosopher."
Though an outsider among modern economists, Professor Boulding was heaped with many honors. He became president of the American Economic Association in 1968 and was awarded dozens of honorary degrees.
Part of his charm was his rare diversity. He wrote rhymed poetry (one of his books was entitled "Beasts, Ballads and Bouldingisms"), sculptured, painted water colors and, friends said, used to sing entire Gilbert and Sullivan musicals from memory and could recite nearly all of Wordsworth.
Professor Boulding is survived by his wife, Dr. Elise M. Boulding, a professor emerita of sociology at Dartmouth College; five children, J. Russell, of Bloomington, Ind., Mark, of Denver, Philip, of Olalla, Wash., William, of Durham, N.C., and Christie Boulding-Graham of Wayland, Mass., and 16 grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kenneth E. Boulding (The New York Times, 1977)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

International
 
A long-looming trade confrontation was unexpectedly defused when U.S. officials announced that the Japanese had met a target for imports of computer chips. Imports accounted for 20.2 percent of the Japanese semiconductor market in the fourth quarter of 1992, exceeding the 20 percent target set in a 1991 agreement. [Page 37.] 
 The U.S. postponed plans to impose trade sanctions on the European Community on Monday over rules that let public utilities favor European companies when making purchasing decisions. The action fended off a trade battle, at least temporarily. [37.]
Economists praised the Bundesbank for lowering its discount rate by half a percentage point. News analysis. [37.]
 
The Economy
 
The collapse of the roof of a computer center has caused the nation's largest disruption of automated teller machines. The consequences of the computer failure, which brought down 5,000 A.T.M.'s, continued to unfold as banks pieced together records and tried to find alternative service for the affected cardholders. [1.]
 
Companies
 
 An F.D.A. advisory committee recommended the approval of a new drug to treat multiple sclerosis. Betaseron, which is made by Chiron and Berlex Labs, is the first drug to show effectiveness against the neurological disease. [1.]
Dow Corning said new studies on lab rats showed that the silicone gel used in breast implants was not inert, and in fact had been found to be a strong irritant of animals' immune systems. [8.]
Makers of speedy RISC processors are finding that software, not hardware, is now the ruling force in computers. And that is hurting RISC's chances of changing the existing order. [37.]
NCR's chairman plans an early retirement. Gilbert P. Williamson will be replaced by Jerre L. Stead, who heads another A.T.&T. unit. [37.] Compaq, in a surprise announcement, said the senior vice president of its personal computer division had quit. [39.]
A feud between Virgin Atlantic and British Airways intensified with the collapse of efforts to settle allegations of "dirty tricks" by British Air. Virgin threatened to take the case to U.S. courts. [39.]
JWP Inc. plans to sell its information services business. The company, once a humble Queens water utility, also estimated that its fourth-quarter losses would be "at least" $265 million. [39.]
Chrysler's introduction of two widely praised luxury sedans stands in contrast with its showing of a new Imperial in 1989. [39.]
 Lewis Galoob Toys intends to acquire Diversified Specialists, a privately held toy maker. [39.]

 Industrial giants continued to march ahead of other stocks. The Dow industrials gained 5.94 for the day and nearly 44 for the week. [38.] Short positions in stocks on the Big Board and the American exchange rose in the period that ended in mid-March. [48.]

Pork prices continued to move higher on news of a low slaughter rate, suggesting a small hog herd. [45.]
 The dollar settled broadly lower in skittish trading. Gold prices rose across the board. [45.]

HEADLINE: Zaire President Reneges on Multiparty Pact

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 19

 BODY:
President Mobutu Sese Seko announced plans today to resurrect his one-party Parliament, effectively tearing up a fragile pact.
He said he would convene the National Assembly "very soon" to debate a draft constitution that would guide Zaire to multiparty democracy. 
 President Mobutu, who says the hard-line opposition to him is in disarray, acted boldly two days after defying key foreign capitals to appoint a new Prime Minister to replace Etienne Tshisekedi.
Parliament, made up entirely of Mr. Mobutu's party, was supposed to be defunct, replaced by the High Council of the Republic, an interim assembly.
The council met today to respond to Mr. Mobutu's initiative, which would reduce it to a marginal role.
The President, who has used guile and force to stay in power since 1965, announced his new strategy in a televised speech closing a "political conclave" he convened on March 9.
He said Zaire's political class had shown in the last 10 days that it was "sufficiently mature and capable to resolve its internal conflicts without foreign interference."
He pledged to cooperate fully with the new Prime Minister chosen by the conclave, Faustin Birindwa, who would be "totally responsible" for economic, financial and administrative policy.
The President has refused pressure from the United States, Belgium and France to reappoint Mr. Tshisekedi.

HEADLINE: Senate Democrats Deflect First G.O.P. Budget Shots

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
With President Clinton's five-year budget plan safely through the House, Democrats turned today to defend the proposal against Republican attacks in the Senate, easily rejecting an attempt to freeze spending on many domestic programs at their current levels.
Congressional aides predicted tougher battles before a final vote on the budget resolution is held late next week. The most difficult may be a Republican attempt to strike the budget's most contentious tax proposal, an increase on the Social Security benefits of better-off retirees. 
 But Democrats appear confident, given the trend of early votes on the budget resolution, that it will survive the Senate intact. "We seem to be weathering the storm," said one Senate Democratic aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, "and the White House is putting a lot of effort into holding the votes" of potential Democratic defectors.
 
Guerrilla Warfare Role
 For their part, Republicans seem resigned to playing the role of guerrilla warriors in this budget battle, harassing the Democratic majority without inflicting any lasting damage to Mr. Clinton's plan on taxes and spending.
"We're going to start shooting real bullets when the package passes and that'll be in the Finance Committee," Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said today.
He was referring to the nitty-gritty of the Federal budget process, the line-by-line writing of tax laws and detailed spending bills. That process will come after next week's probable passage of the broad, deliberately vague budget resolution setting overall spending goals.
Mr. Clinton spent part of his day celebrating the House's passage late Thursday and early today of his budget and a $16.3 billion jobs bill. Both swept through the House on essentially party-line votes, getting Mr. Clinton's budget off to the quickest start of any President since Ronald Reagan submitted his first spending plan in 1981.
The jobs bill was declared to be emergency legislation, a move that allows the money to be spent without violating the letter of legal limits on deficit spending.
Today the President played host to 100 House Democrats, jubilant but still bleary from their bout of wee-hours legislating, at a coffee-and-Danish breakfast at the White House.
 
'Moving to the Future'
 Commending them for acting "with unbelievable dispatch," Mr. Clinton said the House vote proved that Democrats "don't have to spend our time posturing and divided and running for cover instead of moving to the future."
He added: "It is a wonderful beginning. But I think it's important to remember that it's just a beginning; that you have to encourage your colleagues on the other side of the Capitol to act."
Later, in Atlanta to stump for his economic proposals, he asked local business executives to ignore his Republican critics. He called them "guardians of gridlock" whose only pleasure is "to hear the gears squeal."
Many members of Georgia's Democratic Congressional delegation were on hand to meet with Mr. Clinton. Notably absent was Senator Sam Nunn, who was one of five Democrats to side with Republican critics of the President in the one Senate vote of any importance today.
On that vote, the Senate killed an amendment by Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican, that would have imposed a five-year spending freeze on most discretionary domestic programs, like education and agriculture. It would have left untouched spending for the military and such mandatory programs as Medicaid.
Republicans argued that the measure would cut $104 billion from the budget proposal over five years. It was designed to appeal to conservative Democrats, some of whom say the budget plan's stated goal -- to lower the Federal deficit to $200 billion a year from $300 billion a year by 1998 -- is too modest. The conservatives say Mr. Clinton relies too much on new taxes and too little on spending cuts to reach that goal.
While four Democrats joined Mr. Nunn in voting against a motion to kill the amendment, four Republicans deserted Mr. Grassley, giving the Democrats more than enough votes to bury the amendment.
 
Energy Plan Challenged
 The Democrats suffered a slightly greater scare late Thursday when Republicans tried to pull down one of Mr. Clinton budget's pillars, a proposed tax on oil, coal and other forms of energy that would raise $71.4 billion by 1998.
That amendment failed by a narrower margin, 53 to 46. But Republicans and Democrats alike said today that the vote was a bellwether of Senate Democrats' solidarity on the budget, and that not even a fight over the Social Security tax is likely to pry many lawmakers from Mr. Clinton's side.
The House's Democrats drove that point home with a little levity this morning in their meeting with the President. When Mr. Clinton strode into their meeting room, greeting them with a cheery, "Good morning," the Congressmen responded in kind and in unison, like an obedient class of kindergartners.
Then they all burst into guffaws.

Panetta, left, the budget director, talked with Representatives Richard Durbin of Illinois, center, and Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Trade Center Jigsaw Puzzlers Find How Bits Made a Van

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
In a shadowy, makeshift workroom beneath the World Trade Center, yards from where a bomb carried by a Ryder rental van exploded last month, blowing the van to bits, investigators move over an identical yellow van, trying to match parts.
Holding piece after crumpled piece next to corresponding parts of the unscarred van, they are performing a crucial part of the overall investigation, identifying scraps of the original Ford Econoline 350 van that could lead them to new suspects, strengthen ties to those already under arrest and shed light on how the bombing was carried out. 
 "The goal is to piece together as much of the van as we can," said Lieut. Gerald B. Sheehan, commander of the New York City Police Department's Arson Explosion Squad as he stood yesterday in the tiny room, dimly lighted with construction lights that have been strung with wire. "And as we work, we are finding that there are numerous leads coming out of this examination."
Perhaps the most important leads came only two days after the blast, when a team of investigators from the police department's Bomb Squad, the F.B.I. and the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms discovered a piece of mangled chassis bearing a partial vehicle identification number.
That number was traced to a yellow van from a Ryder rental agency in Jersey City, and then to Mohammed A. Salameh, a 25-year-old man who had rented the van and who was later arrested and charged in connection with the bombing.
 
40 Percent of Van Is Found
 The police say the yellow van was used to carry a huge bomb into the center's underground garage, where it exploded on Feb. 26, leaving six people dead and more than 1,000 injured.
Since then, investigators, using the matching technique and comparing identification numbers the manufacturer stamps on car parts, have found bits of what they estimate to be 40 percent to 50 percent of the van.
"Out of the 20 to 30 parts that the guys sifting wreckage bring us each day, we find three or four pieces that are good ones," said Sgt. James Torrens, who runs the Police Department's Auto Crime division and who is working with Federal investigators. "We couldn't work without this van. We'd have to use part numbers alone and it would take much longer. This helps narrow it down."
So far, other investigators say, judging from the areas where they have identified van parts, they have been able to place the van facing west, on the B-2 level near the ramp.
 
How It Was Made and Set Off
 Shapes of the fragments and traces of chemicals found on them, analyzed in police and F.B.I. laboratories, are also helping investigators confirm theories about the bomb's components, and how it was detonated.
"It's a classic approach to solving these crimes and a very good one," said Clayton McManaway, a former State Department counterterrorism official who is now a vice president for the Fairfax Group, a company in Washington specializing in international investigations and security.
"In Pan Am 103 they put 90 percent of the aircraft back together and in the process were able to determine where the bomb was," he said. "That's not as important in the van, but it might tell them what kind of bomb it was and what kind of device was used to set it off."
In the Pan Am bombing, which left 270 people dead in December 1988, Scottish and American forensic experts examined hundreds of thousands of bits of debris combed from an 845-square-mile area where the wreckage fell to earth. That evidence led them to two Libyan intelligence agents, who were later charged.
 
Wires Like Jungle Vines
 The trade center workroom, built from plaster and wood and set up just steps from the yawning crater where steel pipes and wires hang like jungle vines, is hauntingly stark.
On the side of the yellow van, jacked six inches off the ground to let workers slide underneath, investigators have taped a photocopy of the blasted van's Alabama license plate. They also removed the van's grill, front fender and right side panel, and these now sit in a corner of the room, to allow them to compare the charred parts with internal parts of the van.
Otherwise, two wooden tables, covered with flashlights, hardhats and boxes of mangled metal, and six chairs are the workroom's only decor.
And as the weeks have worn on, and workers have cleared rubble down to the bottom of the five-level garage, the discovery of van parts is slowing as well. Many parts may have been blown into undetectable fragments. Investigators have yet to determine the kind of device or fuse that was used to detonate the bomb.
"In the early stages, it was very very exciting because we were finding so much," Lieutenant Sheehan said. "Now we are just putting the pieces of this puzzle together."

HEADLINE: In Busy Day, Blue Chips Outpace Rest of Market

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The lumbering industrial giants continued to march ahead of the rest of the market yesterday, as the Dow stocks advanced slightly but most others lagged.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index lost 1.70 points, to 450.18, and Big Board decliners outnumbered advancing issues, but the Dow Jones industrial average gained 5.94 points, to 3,471.58. As on Thursday, the Dow ventured to within about a point of a record before pulling back. 
 The quarterly expiration of options and futures on stock indexes and options on individual stocks, known as the triple witching hour, was reflected much more in trading volume than in stock prices. The total volume of 339.7 million shares, up from 241.2 million in recent days, was followed by a record 46.6 million in a special after-hours session reserved for trading baskets of 15 or more stocks at once. Until yesterday, the busiest basket session had been on Jan. 14, with 24.4 million shares traded.
 Some of yesterday's better gains came among gold and energy stocks, which have trailed the market but are now seen as good values. The underlying commodities offer some protection against inflation as well.
Among gold issues, Newmont Mining was up 1 1/8, to 44; Homestake Mining was up 3/8, to 13 3/4; Placer Dome was up 5/8, to 14 3/8, and Echo Bay rose 1/4, to 6.
Energy stocks were generally, but not unanimously, up, with Louisiana Land and Exploration gaining 1 5/8, to 44, and Amoco advancing 7/8, to 57 1/8.
Gold and oil prices have moved up only modestly, but the stocks sometimes gain before the commodities.
The Dow's modest advance was paced by Eastman Kodak, up 1, to 56, and International Paper, up 3/8, to 65 1/8.
Health issues continued to be the market's losers, with Abbott Laboratories down 1 5/8, to 23 7/8; Johnson & Johnson down 1, to 39 1/4, and Schering-Plough off 3/4, to 57 3/8. On the Nasdaq, U.S. Healthcare fell 1 3/4, to 41, and Chiron dropped 2 1/4, to 50 1/2.
 As the day went, so went the week, with the Dow up nearly 44 points, or 1.3 percent, but the S.& P. 500 was up less than a point. The Dow reached a high of 3,477.26 on March 10.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 4.69 points yesterday and about 10 points for the week, to 682.72, with consistent weakness among the medical and computer technology stocks.
