HEADLINE: A Railroad Man With the Heart of a Gambler

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
It's 7:15 on a recent morning and the Metro-North train to Manhattan has just departed Chappaqua. A commuter, dozing between pages of his Harry Truman biography, is awakened by the booming voice of a lanky man sprawled across the adjacent seat talking to a companion. "I'm sorry if we've disturbed you," the man says to the sleepy neighbor. "Would you like us to move?"
A scene from one of those Metro-North commercials where real-life conductors plug the tranquillity of their trains? Not quite. But the apologetic man does work for the railroad. In fact, he runs it. 
 He is Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Metro-North's parent agency. And every morning he rides the rails from his home in Westchester County to his office in Manhattan, silently noting torn seats, broken air-conditioners, graffiti-scarred doors and surly service. There is, he insists, less to report on each.
"To the extent you can experience what your customers do is important," Mr. Stangl said. "It's a good system, and it's getting better all the time."
Exuberant, excitable and slightly offbeat -- he once quit a high-level job to shoot pool for 10 months -- Mr. Stangl is a walking, talking advertisement for the $5 billion transportation empire he has led for two years, which includes the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, the Long Island Rail Road, the New York City Transit Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
In the coming weeks, his salesmanship will be severely tested in Albany. The Transit Authority is facing a projected $250 million deficit, and without state help, M.T.A. officials say, bus and subway fares will rise by 25 cents to $1.50 on April 4. Although a fare increase is considered unlikely, Mr. Stangl has another, more ambitious request: $9.6 billion for a five-year program to rebuild stations and replace equipment. And he has asked the Legislature for broad new controls over how the agency spends money.
A tough sell even in good times, Mr. Stangl's program faces a particularly skeptical Legislature this year. For starters, the system is not in the dire shape it was 11 years ago when the Legislature financed the first of two capital plans. And the state has its own projected $3.7 billion deficit.
The political mix has changed as well. The Legislature has lost its most outspoken supporter of mass transit, Jerrold Nadler, to Congress. And the Assembly has had an influx of suburban and upstate Democrats whose concerns about roads and bridges could ally them with the Republican-controlled Senate against New York City Democrats in the tug-of-war for transportation dollars.
For New York City transit riders, Mr. Stangl has emerged as their leading advocate in Albany. But while he has brought a certain flair to the job, his critics and even many supporters express concerns about his ability to win the tough political battles ahead.
"His core concepts are winners," said Gene Russianoff, staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, a riders' group. "The test for Stangl will be whether he hangs in there, whether he keeps pressing even when the issue isn't hot."
With his toothy smile, lean face and hyperactive hands, Mr. Stangl, 51, bears a striking resemblance to a notable Westchester commuter of yesteryear: Rob Petrie of "The Dick Van Dyke Show." Born in Waterbury, Conn., Mr. Stangl put himself through the University of Connecticut by working in a dairy plant and playing poker. After teaching college economics for two years, he joined the administration of New York City Mayor John V. Lindsay in 1970 as a budget analyst and became an expert in transportation issues.
 
Different Smoke-Filled Room
 In 1978, he confounded friends by quitting his job as assistant commissioner for public transportation in New Jersey to shoot pool for 10 months in musty halls from Trenton to 14th Street in Manhattan. He just wanted some time to himself, he said.
"Friends started to think I was crazy, and they worried about my career," he said. "I said, 'It's fun. The career will take care of itself.' "
To some colleagues, the hiatus was typical of what they called Mr. Stangl's noncomformist, irreverent style. "Peter was the guy who never wore a tie, seldom wore a sports coat and often wouldn't wear socks in the summer," said Thomas Downs, the New Jersey Commissioner of Transportation, who worked for the M.T.A. in the late 1980's. "That's just Peter."
In 1980 Mr. Stangl joined the M.T.A., and he become president of Metro-North three years later. In his eight-year tenure, on-time performance improved to 94 percent from 80 percent and ridership increased by 21 percent, according to the M.T.A. Critics of the system were won over by his amiable, open-minded style.
"He accepts criticism from riders," said Jo Ann Katzban of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the M.T.A., a transit riders' group. "Others would say: 'Nothing is wrong' or 'We didn't do it.' Peter says: 'You're right. Bear with us.' "
When he was chosen by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1991 to replace Robert R. Kiley, who was retiring as M.T.A. chairman, Mr. Stangl inherited a system that had already been pulled from the brink of collapse. No longer faced with chronic track fires, derailments and breakdowns, Mr. Stangl set a new goal: to stop cutting service and instead make it more convenient and affordable.
He began by packaging dozens of ideas for improvements -- some new, many old -- under a catchy rubric: "Fare Deal." Announcements would be clearer. Dowdy stations would be spruced up, decrepit ones overhauled. Drivers, conductors and token-booth clerks would become more helpful and courteous.
 
New Deal, Old Hurdles
 The program's centerpiece would be a computerized fare-collection system that would enable the M.T.A. to eliminate dual-fare zones, offer reduced rates to frequent riders and make transfers from commuter lines to subways and buses easier.
Two years into Fare Deal, most of the improvements remain years off, largely because the agency still does not have a multiyear capital plan. Last year, the Legislature financed only a one-year, $1.6 billion plan.
Mr. Stangl says he will not be satisfied if the Legislature only holds down the fare this year -- which, in the midst of a mayoral election, is considered highly likely -- without the multiyear building program.
"I am tired of people coming back from Paris and saying how wonderful that system is," he said. "We have the vision for it, but you've got to continue the investment to make it happen."
Some legislators contend that Mr. Stangl must tighten M.T.A. spending before a major plan is approved. "What we're dealing with here is an agency that's like a fire-eating dinosaur, a relic of another age," said Senator Norman J. Levy, a Nassau County Republican who is chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee. "Only it doesn't eat fire, it eats money."
Mr. Levy, whose support is essential to any M.T.A. plan, said he supports holding the fare at $1.25 for the next two years and financing a $9.6 billion capital plan, although there are questions about how his plan would be financed. But he has also proposed legislation to dramatically increase state regulation of the agency, a plan opposed by Mr. Stangl.
Some critics also say Mr. Stangl needs to take stronger stands against his patron, Mr. Cuomo, who angered mass-transit advocates by calling for a $1 billion cut in the M.T.A.'s capital plan. Some say they think Mr. Stangl is worried that Mr. Cuomo will not ask him to continue in the $150,000 post when his term ends on June 30.
And to some, Mr. Stangl may be too affable to play political hardball. "He's a capable man, a good railroad man, he just hasn't gotten angry enough to fight," said Sonny Hall, president of the Transport Workers Union, the M.T.A.'s largest union. "It's not his style, and that's the problem."
Seasoned gambler that he is, Mr. Stangl does not publicly reveal what he thinks of his critics. Instead, he is quick to praise them and change the subject. "I continue to be frustrated by this we-they mentality," he said. "To me, it's all we."

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Fall in Profit Taking

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Treasury market retreated yesterday as profit taking and fears of inflation eroded Thursday's surge in prices.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond, which jumped 12/32 on Thursday, was off 5/16 point yesterday, or $3.13 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield rose to 6.81 percent, from 6.78 percent late Thursday. 
 Market participants said Treasury prices began to lose ground after Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, said that the economy might be in better shape than had been believed.
He said the economy was "closer to full employment than we might expect." A healthy economy could aggravate inflation and decrease the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates.
And the selloff was driven by profit taking after Thursday's rally.
Also hurting bonds was a continued rise in the daily Commodity Research Bureau price index, which is considered a barometer of inflation.
By afternoon, volume thinned as traders hesitated to take large positions before the weekend.
"Even though there's been a lot of up-and-down movement in the market, it's not going anywhere," said Kevin Logan, chief United States economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Medium-term Treasury notes led yesterday's decline. Short-term maturities were off between 3/16 and 9/32 , and intermediate maturities were off between 1/2 and 17/32 , the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 4.44, to 1,295.91.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.01 percent, as the discount rose three-tenths of a percentage point, to 2.96 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 3.15 percent, as the discount added half a percentage point, to 3.07 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 3.30 percent, as the discount rose six-tenths of a percentage point, to 3.19 percent.
Prices of tax-exempt municipal bonds ended slightly higher, although there were concerns over higher inflation and an oversupply of new and already issued securities. Towns and cities plan to sell more than $7 billion in new bonds next week.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Campaign to Stress Control of the Schools

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that his re-election campaign would be a crusade to give the mayor control over the Board of Education, which he said had become "sidetracked and politicized."
By focusing on who would control the schools, Mr. Dinkins appeared to stake his political fortune on his belief that most New Yorkers support the initiatives begun by the outgoing Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, whose proposals ignited a backlash among conservative board members that led to his ouster. 
 In a speech to the Citizens Budget Commission that laid out themes Mr. Dinkins expects to use in his campaign, the Mayor sought to blame the board for the school system's problems.
"That's why, this fall, I will wage an all-out campaign within a campaign to change our system of school governance, to give the mayor the majority of appointees to the Board of Education, to make the mayor more accountable for performance in our schools," Mr. Dinkins said.
"I want this fall's election to be a referendum on school governance," he said.
The school board ousted Mr. Fernandez in a 4-to-3 vote because, among other things, he imposed a grade-school curriculum that teaches respect for homosexuals.
Some political strategists have predicted that the movement to remove Mr. Fernandez would also damage Mr. Dinkins politically, since the Mayor supported the curriculum. By campaigning against the school board, the Mayor appears to be trying to divert the anger over the plight of the schools away from himself.
Mr. Dinkins's thrust at the school board comes while the teachers' union, whose contract talks are mired in an impasse over wages, has been attacking him in television commercials, depicting him as a Mayor who cares little about education. The union, which supported Mr. Dinkins in 1989, opposes the Mayor's proposal to give himself control over the board but is willing to consider changes in the size of the board.
Bill Lynch Jr., the Mayor's campaign manager, said yesterday that the two main themes of Mr. Dinkins's campaign would be improving schools and creating jobs, just as he ran in 1989 on a promise to be "the toughest mayor on crime."
Mr. Dinkins's political rivals said he had underestimated the breadth of unhappiness among voters over the rainbow curriculum and the discontent over the state of public education. The school board's vote reflected a groundswell against using the schools to advance socially liberal philosophies and in favor of a return to basic education, they said.
"At this point in the debate it would be a mistake for David Dinkins to argue for more power for himself," Rudolph W. Giuliani, the expected Republican candidate, said. "After all, what just happened was his approach and his agenda was rejected. I believe one of the things we should have learned from the dispute is that the local governments are asking for more discretion and the ability to shape the system."
But Mr. Dinkins argues that because his hands have been tied by the structure of the school board he cannot be held responsible for the quality of education. The mayor appoints two members to the board and each borough president appoints one.
"It's real simple," he said. "A fourth of our budget goes to education. They look to the mayor to raise the money for it, and many people hold the mayor responsible for the condition of the schools. I say then give me the authority."
One reason Mr. Dinkins is seeking to move the battleground to education is that he believes that the city's declining crime rates during the last two years prove he has succeeded on that front. During his speech yesterday at the Inter-Continental Hotel, Mr. Dinkins asserted that while people may still perceive crime as rampant, the statistics prove that his hiring of 3,000 police officers has reduced violence.
"Without suggesting we are satisfied, people need to know that crime is in fact down," he said. "The fact is there is not a crime wave and crime is down and we have got to some way or another make that point."
Mr. Dinkins's speech signaled that decisions about the schools will be an important arena for the contestants this fall. Mr. Giuliani, who has criticized the rainbow curriculum because it introduces homosexuality as a topic at a young age, has said he will push for policies that give local communities more control over curriculum rather than less.
On the Democratic side, Mr. Dinkins's challenger, Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, favors the rainbow curriculum. But he has sharply criticized the Mayor for reducing the education budget and failing to reach a contract with the teachers.
"Who's he kidding?" said Phil Friedman, a political consultant to Mr. Stein. "For him to make education a main theme is like Richard Nixon to make honesty in government a main theme."

HEADLINE: Trade Confrontations Averted on Two Fronts;
Washington Says Japan Meets Goal On Chip Imports

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
A trade confrontation that had been looming for years was unexpectedly defused today when American officials announced that the Japanese had met a target for imports of computer chips.
Imports accounted for 20.2 percent of the Japanese semiconductor market during the fourth quarter of last year, exceeding the 20 percent target set in a 1991 trade agreement, said Donald H. Phillips, the assistant United States trade representative for industry. 
 The American semiconductor industry, which accounts for 85 percent of Japan's computer chip imports, has fought for seven years for the 20 percent overall foreign share, enlisting the aid of the Reagan, Bush and Clinton Administrations. The issue had become the most sensitive point in the tense trade relations between the world's two largest economies.
 
Only 15.9% in 3d Quarter
 The foreign share of the nearly $20 billion Japanese market had reached only 15.9 percent by the third quarter of last year. Until Thursday night, when the final calculations were done, Government and industry officials assumed that the fourth-quarter figures would also fall short, leading to speculation that the Clinton Administration might impose sanctions against Japanese exports to the United States.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said today that the abrupt increase in the fourth quarter reflected a significant contraction of the overall Japanese semiconductor market while sales by American companies continued their long, slow climb.
"There was more shrinkage than anyone expected, and more growth," he said at a news conference this afternoon.
The American semiconductor industry welcomed the improvement.
"It marks a level of openness in the Japanese market that numerous people in the American and Japanese Governments and industries have been working very hard to reach since the mid-80's," said James Norling, the chairman of The Semiconductor Industry Association, which represents American producers and is based in San Jose, Calif.
Non-Japanese companies held only 14.3 percent of the market in 1991, when the current agreement was negotiated, and less than 9 percent in 1986, when a pact was reached calling for a 20 percent share by 1991. Both agreements were aimed at reducing formal and informal trade barriers and used market shares as an indicator of whether this was being accomplished.
The 20 percent figure became the American target in 1986 as a compromise between the American industry's estimate that it would hold 25 to 35 percent of the Japanese market without trade barriers, while Japanese officials did not want a target at all.
In addition to the United States, the European Community and South Korea have small shares of the Japanese semiconductor market.
Mr. Phillips said that total sales of semiconductors in Japan for all of last year were $19.4 billion, but he declined to provide figures for the fourth quarter for either the entire market or the American share.
Mr. Kantor said that the fourth-quarter import increase appeared to be sustainable, and that he had seen no indications that it might have been the result of stockpiling by Japanese semiconductor users seeking to reach the 20 percent target.
But semiconductor industry officials have also noted that computer chip prices in recent months have been higher in the United States, where personal computer production is booming, than in Japan, where the economy is stagnant. As a result, there has been an incentive for Japanese companies to send as much of their production as possible to the United States, leaving room for foreign companies to sell more chips in Japan.
Stanton Anderson, a longtime Washington lawyer for the Electronic Industries Association of Japan, which represents semiconductor users and producers there, said that future market share figures were hard to predict.
"Obviously we're pleased by this, but it doesn't mean that this number is going to stay there as the Japanese economy comes back," he said. "I'm sure it's sustainable in the long term -- whether it's sustainable on a quarter-by-quarter basis, I just can't tell."
Mr. Anderson repeated the contention of Japanese officials that their semiconductor market was open and not subject to Government controls, so that market shares might fluctuate unpredictably.
Japanese officials in Tokyo and Washington have stated repeatedly in recent days their dismay at the attention focused on the 20 percent figure. They have vowed to resist any American efforts to set any target for future sales of semiconductors or any other product.
A Presidential advisory committee on trade, composed of the heads of three dozen multinationals as well as academics and labor leaders, recommended earlier this year that fixed import targets be used more often with Japan.
Mr. Kantor avoided answering questions today about whether the United States would try to set a new target for semiconductor or other industries. He pointed out that the 1991 agreement lasts for three more years and that it calls for "gradual and steady improvement" in the non-Japanese market share.
"The implication is that 20 percent would be the average we would achieve," and that the United States market share will continue to climb, he said.
Mr. Norling of the semiconductor association made a similar point in a statement today.
"The steady improvement over 20 percent foreign share will be evidence that the Japan market is increasingly open," said Mr. Norling, who is also the head of Motorola's semiconductor division.
Japanese officials and their American lawyers have argued that the 20 percent figure should not be paramount. Mr. Anderson said that market share figures were a poor indication of overall access.
And Seiichiro Noboru, the economics minister at the Japanese Embassy in Washington, was quick to point out that the agreement called for steady overall improvement in foreign access to the Japanese market, and did not refer specifically to the 20 percent figure.
"The purpose of the agreement is not only market share -- equally important is the industry-to-industry cooperation," he said. "Progress does not only mean change of the figure."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler Gets Serious About Luxury Cars

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RUTHERFORD, Calif., March 19

 BODY:
Auto makers stake their reputations on luxury cars, their flagships. In 1989, when the Chrysler Corporation introduced a new Imperial, the boxy, stretched version of the outdated K-car seemed to embody the company's condition, which appeared critical at the time. In contrast, Chrysler's introduction here this week of its New Yorker and LHS sedans is being greeted as a return to the promised land.
The Imperial, decorated with vinyl on its vinyl and plastic froufrou, prompted sneers and giggles from cogniscenti, who deemed it unworthy of comparison with Lexus, Mercedes, Cadillac or Lincoln. Similarly, the New Yorker and LHS are essentially longer versions of Chrysler's new midsize sedans: the Dodge Intrepid, Chrysler Concorde and Eagle Vision. 
 But automotive analysts and critics say that Chrysler has seemed to learn its lesson from the Imperial. For its latest luxury offerings, the auto maker did not scrimp on the styling, creature comforts and engineering attributes that luxury buyers expect; it priced the New Yorker and LHS from $25,000 to about $30,000, a range that should make it highly competitive with domestic and imported luxury brands.
Reviewers from enthusiast magazines and the Wall Street analysts and portfolio managers who gathered here to compare the new cars with other luxury brands were impressed. "The Mercedes was the only car I thought was better," said Ronald A. Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco. "For my taste, it's a better car for less money."
Kathy Hamilton, senior editor of Automobile magazine, said, "Road noise was a little strong for a luxury car," but added, "The styling is striking, handling is good and there's not much out there that's good and fun to drive for $30,000."
A critical question is whether the models will have enough prestige. "These are cars for 50-year-olds who listened to Joan Baez when they were growing up," Mr. Glantz said. "They owned Beetles. Now they want nicer cars, but a Lexus is too much."
For most of the 1980's, the Chrysler name came to signify, for many consumers, second-rate, working-class cars. (The company did win over more affluent buyers with mini-vans and Jeeps.) The new midsize sedans, introduced last summer, are off to a fast start. But luxury buyers, who are fewer in number, are notoriously picky.
The New Yorker, styled for an older buyer who might also consider domestic models like the Buick Park Avenue or Lincoln Continental, "is on the mark for a person seeking traditional luxury," said Susan Jacobs, an automotive marketing consultant based in Little Falls, N.J.
But the LHS model, styled to appeal to a younger buyer who might be considering an Acura Legend or Lexus ES 300, "isn't styled in a way that will appeal to those who like European cars," Ms. Jacobs said. "and secondly, the brand doesn't have enough prestige. It may take a couple of years before the brand can tap into these buyers."
The positive reception for the so-called L/H midsize cars has made Chrysler executives quite optimistic about the prospects for the New Yorker and LHS. The company's stock has performed strongly in recent months, perhaps in part because the economics of a successful luxury car are quite compelling; the gross profit margin of each New Yorker or LHS could amount to $9,000 or $10,000, several analysts said, compared with half that amount or less for the L/H midsize sedans.
Thus, if Chrysler sells out the 65,000 or so luxury sedans it expects to build this year at plants in Bramalea, Ontario, and Newark, Del., that could mean $500 million to $600 million extra in gross profit -- provided that rebates are not necessary to sell the cars.
Even without this additional profit, Wall Street suddenly regards the No. 3 producer as the most reliable money maker among the Big Three, after several years in which Chrysler was on the brink of financial collapse.
Jerry G. Paul, automotive analyst of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York, estimates that Chrysler now earns much more for a vehicle than the Ford Motor Company, which had been the most profitable company in the 1980's. The reason: Although Ford is a more efficient manufacturer, Chrysler with its mini-vans, Jeeps and now its L/H cars is snagging more well-heeled customers than Ford.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Lower; Gold Has Gains Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled broadly lower yesterday in skittish trading on the world's currency markets.
Gold prices rose across the board. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $331.90 an ounce, up $1.10 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold gained $1.25, to a late price of $331.50. 
 Currency traders said the market activity was largely technical. The dollar continued the downward trend that began when Germany's central bank cut a key lending rate on Thursday. The German move had been anticipated, and some traders were disappointed that the Bundesbank did not take further action.
Lisa Pazer, an analyst with MMS International, said the dollar's decline was based on technical factors. "The market has been searching for direction, and for the past few weeks has been tightly range bound," she said.
While the dollar could test lower levels, traders said the underlying tone was relatively bullish, given the improving American economy. Trading was cautious and relatively light.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 116.10 yen, down 0.87 yen from the Thursday close but up from an opening of 115.80. That had been the dollar's lowest opening in Tokyo since the modern exchange rate system was established in the late 1940's.
Later in London, the dollar fell to 115.90 yen. In New York, the dollar rebounded to settle at 116.10 yen, up from 115.65 on Thursday.
Reported comments by Japanese officials, who were said to have complained about the yen's rise, and fears of intervention helped the dollar gain against the yen in American trading.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4895, from $1.4750 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.4915 to buy 1, up from Thursday's $1.4860.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
There Are Those Who Say

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
Some say the most delicious recent metaphor-mangling in Washington came from the lips of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, who gained fame as televised balcony-mate of Hillary Rodham Clinton during her husband's economic address to Congress. The Greenspan pledge: "to break the back of the credit crunch."
The some that led the preceding paragraph is an example of phantom attribution -- a way of making a statement by pretending to report it as the assertion of others. Whenever a speech writer uses the "some say" construction, a speech reader knows that he's safe to agree with, or sternly dissociate himself from, whatever "some" are saying. 
 Some say is neutral; for really stupid or wrongheaded statements, phantom attribution is made to there are those who say; you can bank on those who being straw men. Others say  something far out; others live in a whole other world.
In this regard, we present the first effluvia -- beyond mere metaphoria -- from Foggy Bottom in the Clinton Era. It comes from the "Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense, Public Affairs," which means that the letter does not come from the Assistant Secretary, but from his office, which is commanded by a desk that writes memos from the desk of.
For as long as I can remember, I have been getting great gobs of unsolicited mail in bulky manila envelopes -- occasionally pretty useful -- from Les Aspin, who was a hard-working Congressman and is a nice guy. Today, in comes this missive from the Directorate for Public Communication (the K.G.B. loved directorates; what else has the Pentagon stolen from Moscow Central?), addressed to "Dear Sir or Madam."
"When Secretary Aspin was Chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, you had expressed an interest in receiving information from him on national security issues." (Maybe I put a check mark on a postcard when I was sleepy or drunk.) "Now that he is the Secretary of Defense," writes Harold Heilsnis, director for public communication -- presumably bucking for Chief of the Sixth Directorate of Public Communication and Interactive Relationships -- "some  [italics mine] have asked to continue receiving material from him on these issues."
Ah, some have asked. Who? Close relatives? Old flames? His lips are sealed in his own version of a back-breaking credit crunch. So, is the press agent going to keep sending me the stuff? "We are evaluating the possibility of providing such mailings." (He means "making similar mailings" or "providing such information"; you do not provide a mailing as if it were humanitarian relief dropped from the sky.)
"If you wish to receive such materials from Secretary Aspin, please complete the enclosed form," and he attaches one of those Government forms that require not only my signature (which I suspect would trigger a full field investigation, tax audit and wiretap warrant) but also demand in capitalized boldface that I return the address label from the envelope I threw away.
In the old days, Les's flack would have dropped me a note asking, "You want to stay on the mailing list?" Gone, gone are the days of plain English, as genuine communication is sucked into the black hole of directorates. I'm afraid those snappy salutes are getting to that old gang of Clinton's.
 
KUBLA'S COMEBACK
 "IN XANADU," WROTE the poet Coleridge, transcribing an interrupted dream, "did Kubla Khan/ A stately pleasure dome decree."
Pleasure used to be a powerful word. Rooted in the Old French plaisir, it came into English and developed that sensual zh sound in the middle, similar to the pleasing azure, favorite of romantic poets. As a verb, it means "to give sexual satisfaction to"; as a noun, it is not so lively as delight or gladness, not so rapturous as joy, bliss or ecstasy, and not so amusing as delectation. Pleasure is an emotion that suffuses one who has been gratified or stroked; it's a good feeling, whether physical or intellectual.
It is also a semantically endangered species. Kathie Wellde, the Washington lecture agent who heads Speakers of the Times, sends in this disturbing heads up: "Instead of saying Have a nice day, people are ending their conversations with My pleasure."
Come to think of it, I've noticed that, too, especially at high-class hotels: the phrase is used not merely to mean "I'd be glad to," or even "It's a thrill just to be asked," but with the added sense of "O.K. and so long." Example: "I'll be checking out at noon." "My pleasure."
Where is this coming from? European responses to thanks range from the French je vous en prie, using "I pray of you" to mean "you're welcome," to the German bitteschon, literally a combination of "please" and "beautiful," and the Spanish de nada, "for nothing." In Chinese, the Mandarin dialect response is bu keqi (pronounced boo KUH-chee), and is used for "Don't mention it." But the impetus in our vocabulary has to come from closer to home.
Ellie Peters at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in New York informs me that Horst Schulze, president of the chain of 28 hotels, distributed a credo as part of the employee orientation that includes this as Point 12: "Maintain positive eye contact. Use the proper vocabulary with our guests. Use words like . . . 'I'll be happy to' and 'My pleasure.' "
I don't hear too many I'll be happy tos in the Phoenix Ritz-Carlton, but My pleasure has grabbed hold at Laguna Niguel and Naples. And the fond farewell is in vogue not just in hotels; as Ms. Wellde reports, the soothing phrase is spreading like wildfire. (Like most urban Americans, I have never seen wildfire with my own eyes, but presume it to be a conflagration that spreads quickly.)
Some people (along with others, joined by the dopey those who) hate to see a lush word like pleasure made part of a routine parting or a cheery telephone operator's sign-off, but it beats Have a nice day, originally a happy thought but now one very tired phrase. A more exasperated conversation concluder is Get a life!, the origin of which lexicographers are eagerly seeking; early citations will be accepted gratefully here.
At this point, a with-it sign-off comes all too readily to mind.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2455 words

HEADLINE: STAGE VIEW;
Opening a Window at a Theater Gone Stale

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
When a dying Joseph Papp turned over the artistic directorship of the New York Shakespeare Festival to JoAnne Akalaitis in the summer of 1991, he kept a title for himself: producer. A little more than two months later, Papp was dead, and the role of producer at the festival, like the title, was buried with him. Ms. Akalaitis, it soon became clear, simply did not know enough about what it means to be a producer, and the consequences of that ignorance were severe.
In the mere 20 months she presided as artistic director, the company that Papp built over three decades became an empty shell, a ragtag fairway for theatrical sideshows rather than main events. The institution that had once been a role model for nonprofit theaters nationwide and a leader in New York City arts advocacy found its own long-term survival thrown into jeopardy. Last week the festival's board stepped in and dismissed Ms. Akalaitis, replacing her with George C. Wolfe. In a typically theatrical gesture, the 38-year-old Mr. Wolfe made it known that he would not be the festival's artistic director. He took instead the title of producer. 
 Somewhere, Papp may be smiling, or at least breathing a sigh of relief. Certainly anyone who cares about the future of the New York theater is. If anyone can save the festival, it may well be Mr. Wolfe, who has heretofore not been known as a producer but as a playwright and director, lately of "Jelly's Last Jam" on Broadway, though earlier of such fine pieces as "The Colored Museum" and "Spunk," both of which were produced at the Public Theater by Papp. Though Mr. Wolfe is untried as a producer and an administrator, he actually produced unofficially the only thrilling new work to appear at the Public during Ms. Akalaitis's tenure, Anna Deavere Smith's "Fires in the Mirror," which had its premiere as part of a mini-festival he organized.
Like Papp, who nurtured his early career, Mr. Wolfe has a flair for talent scouting, show business and self-promotion. He also has an artistic range whose broad sweep has more in common with Papp's inclusivity than Ms. Akalaitis's narrow, academic vision. The Wolfe canon to date has crossed over from the American to the African, from drama to satire to musical theater, from verbal elegance to visual dash. He is one to try anything rather than take no for an answer.
As for Ms. Akalaitis's record on Lafayette Street, it would be nice simply to forget about it, and get on with tomorrow. That's the theater's sentimental way. And certainly any objective observer can see that she was in part a victim of bad luck. A smart director, she was not only miscast as the Public's leader but was also asked to take over an organization already in turmoil during a major recession. But there are important lessons to be drawn from her failure, and they have import beyond her career and the institution she served so inadequately.
Both the nonprofit and commercial American theater are at a crucial juncture in their history, beset by a leadership that is aging and frequently out of touch, severe economic cutbacks, racial divisions and a shortage of new producers. Even as Ms. Akalaitis resigned, board-room squabbles broke out at another major New York company, Playwrights Horizons, prompting the departure of the theater's longtime executive director, Paul Daniels. Other institutional theaters, most prominently La Mama E.T.C. and Circle in the Square, have been on the financial ropes, and more may soon join them. Still other major resident theaters around the country, from Arena Stage in Washington to the Yale Repertory Theater, are in the process of artistic transition following the retirement of visionary leaders of the Papp generation.
If the theater at large is to benefit from the Public's sad tale, it should look carefully not only at what Ms. Akalaitis did and did not do during her tenure there, but also at how the theater community itself responded to her short-lived regime.
Ms. Akalaitis's failures at the festival have little to do with her gifts as an artist. She has been and will continue to be a talented director, especially of edgy European plays (notably those of Jean Genet and of the German playwright Franz Xaver Kroetz) and of darker classics. Though her work as a director during the months she doubled as the festival's chief executive was erratic, ranging from the inspired (" 'Tis Pity She's a Whore") to the dreadful ("Woyzeck"), she would still have failed at her bigger job even if each of her productions had been a triumph.
To be a true leader of a theater with six stages at its disposal -- five at the Public, one in Central Park -- Ms. Akalaitis had to see beyond her own occasional productions as a director. She had to be a producer, whether or not she called or considered herself one. And while being a producer means many things, it means first of all the very basic chore of putting productions onstage. The festival's stages were all too frequently dark during Ms. Akalaitis's term. When they were occupied, the fare was often solo turns by mainstream performance artists (Reno, Ann Magnuson), readings, special events (a puppetry festival) or plays by writers on Ms. Akalaitis's short list of Drama 101 modernists (Beckett, Garcia Lorca, Brecht) or their imitators (Steve Tesich, whose recent "On the Open Road" was a pastiche of "Mother Courage" and "Waiting for Godot.")
All of these theatrical endeavors might well have been produced by Papp, and all are certainly legitimate parts of the Public's bill of fare. But Papp would have combined them with other, more substantial offerings, such as a steady diet of original new American plays and musicals, not to mention frequent mountings of Shakespeare. Ms. Akalaitis's agenda for the festival consisted mainly of theatrical snacks, with very few feasts that might contribute to the Public's allure in the competitive New York performing-arts scene and perhaps even attract audiences to the smaller, more eccentric presentations.
When the Public did offer an occasional new American play or musical (the current "Wings"), it generally did not originate them. Rather than produce plays that might reflect her own creative passions, Ms. Akalaitis usually booked plays produced by others into the Public because they were hits in their originating theaters outside New York.
Booking is what cautious commercial theater owners do; it is not supposed to be the principal calling of artistic directors of leading institutional theaters. Yet Ms. Akalaitis seemed unwilling to gamble her prestige or larger production budgets on playwrights and directors who might give birth to exciting new works in her theater; she became a co-sponsor of new American plays like Tony Kushner's "Angels in America" and Jose Rivera's forthcoming "Marisol" only after other theaters had developed them or given them their imprimatur. At Ms. Akalaitis's Public, there was only one theatrical artist who consistently received the time, money and space necessary to do elaborate new productions -- Ms. Akalaitis. Indeed, her "Woyzeck" was the only major home-grown production to be seen on any Public Theater stage this entire season.
Given how little activity there was at the Public, and how little of it was fresh or substantial, it is no wonder that the festival seemed to fall off the map of many theatergoers. Even so, Ms. Akalaitis sometimes went out of her way to antagonize a public that might otherwise have been patient. She persistently announced that she would stage a theater piece about the Palestinians, possibly a daring one that might stir up some valuable controversy, but never actually bothered to do it. In widely quoted (and published) remarks, she even attacked her theater's most loyal customers: speaking of the festival's subscription audiences at a symposium, she said "they didn't understand the work . . . were essentially dull people [and] did not appreciate especially what we might call more adventurous theater . . . ."
On Ms. Akalaitis's behalf, it can be said that no successor could hope to compete with the Papp record, that in tough economic times co-productions with other theaters can cut fiscal risks, and that she did not have enough time to get her act together. While there is real validity to all these points, there was little evidence to suggest that Ms. Akalaitis had any plan for expanding the Public's scale of play production in the near future. The problem was not that her producing record was inferior to Papp's but that it was virtually nonexistent. (Even the co-production ventures she chose tended to be limited, often to a single company, the Goodman Theater of Chicago, that frequently hired her as a director.) It was not clear, either, that she had any exceptional skill for two essential, if thankless, aspects of the producer's calling -- fund raising and promotion.
Since Ms. Akalaitis was an ailing Joseph Papp's own choice for artistic director, it would have been both unethical and unseemly for the festival's board to jettison her immediately. The board, which acted with unanimity, should be applauded for ending the misery with relative promptness, at the end of two poor seasons and when a successor of Mr. Wolfe's caliber was available.
But what if the board had not acted? One of the saddest aspects of the New York Shakespeare Festival's recent history is how little the theater community stirred itself either to help the fading theater or to call attention to its plight.
Do the art or dance communities stand idly by when comparable institutions like the Whitney Museum or American Ballet Theater are in a crisis? Most official organs of the theater, from the Dramatists Guild to the League of American Theater Owners and Producers (the organization of commercial producers) to the Theater Communications Group (the organization of nonprofit theaters), are so committed to industry boosterism that they spoke only in whispers, if that, about the artistic and financial collapse at what once was the most influential theatrical institution in the country. (The playwright Larry Kramer, author of the longest-running play of the Papp years, "The Normal Heart," and the polemical Papp's spiritual heir if ever there was one, was a conspicuous exception, attacking Ms. Akalaitis's leadership in the same terms he aims at government officials about AIDS.) Would the theater community have maintained its conspiracy of silence until Papp's theater had shriveled to the point of closing its doors, or threatening to? By then, it would have been too late to save the festival, but, oh, the crocodile tears that would have been shed!
Perhaps the theatrical artists and administrators who remained mute about the decline at the Public could argue that they legitimately and genuinely had to stay quiet until Ms. Akalaitis had more time to prove herself. Fair enough, but, if so, why didn't they then support Ms. Akalaitis with actions, by giving her their own time and their creative projects? Despite an admirable but vaguely conceived Artistic Associates program, many major playwrights, directors and actors shunned the festival, thereby executing a pocket veto on the new regime. Yet some of these artists hypocritically implied support for Ms. Akalaitis by either remaining silent or praising her to the press.
As the Akalaitis fiasco dramatizes the timid everyone-for-himself mentality that now seems to drive the theater community, so it also calls attention to another crisis in the American theater: the inability of most of its institutions to plan for an orderly succession. If Papp had not waited to the difficult final months of his battle with cancer to decide the fate of his theater, if he had groomed a successor over a few years when he was in robust health, perhaps a lot of the ensuing waste of his company's artistic capital could have been avoided. But he's hardly unique. Very few of the prominent American theaters with retirement-age leaders have an obvious heir apparent or one of exciting promise. The same is true of the dominant commercial theater companies, the Shubert and Nederlander organizations. Must the leader of every American theatrical organization feel compelled to play King Lear and leave his empire behind in ruins?
By appointing Mr. Wolfe, the festival's board does offer hope, at least about this one institution. Aside from his talents, he is a link to the new generation of audiences and artists on which the future of the American theater depends. Mr. Wolfe is almost two decades younger than the 55-year-old Ms. Akalaitis, who was frequently labeled avant-garde but whose unsurprising tastes were often reminiscent of the avant-garde of the 1960's and 1970's. (The cafe she set up in the Public's lobby looked like a sentimental homage to the bohemian heyday of San Francisco's City Lights bookstore.) Though Mr. Wolfe is grounded in a cultural past, from Brecht to Zora Neale Hurston to Jelly Roll Morton, he is well connected to the theatrical future, whether it is Anna Deavere Smith or Tony Kushner, whose "Angels in America" he is now directing for Broadway.
Mr. Wolfe also happens to be black, at a moment when there is a great deal of African-American talent in the theater but relatively little minority representation in the management of major nonprofit and commercial theater companies and professional organizations. Mr. Wolfe, who is as outspoken about social issues as Papp was, may yet play a role in confronting the Marge Schotts of the American theater world, for surely it is only a matter of time before the theater's top artistic players demand management that reflects their own increased diversity.
For the time being, Mr. Wolfe will have his hands full just getting the Public active again, and it's doubly good news that Kevin Kline, another energetic force in the final Papp decade, will join him in the fight to revive this troubled institution. Whatever mistakes they make, and they will make them, they are unlikely to repeat Ms. Akalaitis's fatal error of simply refusing to take the gutsy chances and to chase the big dreams that are the essence of producing.
The festival's close escape from calamity has at least served one constructive purpose by dramatizing gaping voids throughout the theatrical establishment: of courage, long-term planning and entrepreneurial talent. Perhaps no one can replace Joseph Papp, the last old-time producer of the American theater. But with George Wolfe, the New York Shakespeare Festival has found, and not a moment too soon, a leader with the real promise to reinvent the role of producer for the new generation now banging at the theater's door.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
The Fine Art Of Complaining

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
COMPLAINING has become a subspecies of travel literature, to judge by the daily mail. But a close reading of the copies of complaints that readers send to hotels, cruise lines and tour companies shows that most have not been effective: They are already in round 2 or 3 and have not got what they want. In fact, they often have not specified what they want, which is a major mistake.
To recast the line about how crucial location is in real estate, the three most important aspects of complaining are timing, timing and timing. A complaint must be lodged while something can be done to make things right because, as one tour executive put it, money does not replace lost vacation time. A letter sent a month after a traveler returns from a trip is less likely to get results than a phone call made on the spot, saying, for example, that a hotel does not correspond to the description in the brochure. When the issue is services not provided, delay may make it impossible for management to track down who did not do what for whom. 
 Setting aside problems with airlines -- a whole separate issue -- complaints about hotels, resorts, tours and cruises can be effective and, in a slow economy, can produce more results than you might guess. Among the compensation options are free nights, a change of hotels, points on frequent-stay programs and vouchers for visits to higher-priced places. Those in the business of selling travel want repeat customers.
Here is guidance on getting results, based on the advice of the experts who must cope with the complaints.
To start with, if whatever you are presented does not look right, don't eat it, sleep in it or stay with it, if you can avoid it. Once you have eaten the meal, complaints get a dubious response. If the desk clerk or the tour escort cannot get you a room with a view of something other than the dumpster, try the manager. A scene is not called for, but persist. Call your travel agent collect or failing that, call the tour operator, also collect, and explain that the hotel does not offer the features -- pool, beachfront, air-conditioning, whatever -- listed in the brochure.
 
Room Without a View
 Amy Stainman, an advertising executive in Philadelphia, bought a four-day, three-night Gogo Tours trip, called Miami on Your Own, last month. She and her sister together paid $894 for air fares, hotel and a rental car. They wanted to stay in the city's Art Deco district, relax and swim. Having looked at the brochure, they asked for the Cardozo Hotel, but could not get it and were assigned to another hotel on Ocean Drive.
When they got there, Ms. Stainman said, the hotel was not what they wanted. The view from the room was dismal, the hotel did not seem clean, and their rental car would have to be parked at an expensive meter, she said.
"I said to my sister, 'What are we going to do that will make us happy now?' and we decided to leave," Ms. Stainman said. They went to a Howard Johnson, which was just under $100 a night for a double room. When they got home, Ms. Stainman sent a letter and the motel bill to her travel agent, who will take it up with Gogo Tours. Though the resolution of Ms. Stainman's complaint is still pending, her question was the right one: What will salvage the vacation now? She might have done better if she had called her travel agent from the hotel, possibly getting a place more in the Art Deco mode than a Howard Johnson.
Richard Ellis, senior vice president for marketing at Gogo, said that his company also accepted collect calls from people faced with an unsatisfactory hotel. In this case, it would not have been a big surprise. Mr. Ellis said demand for South Miami Beach rose unexpectedly over Christmas and in February. Kathy Wiltshire, head of Florida marketing for Gogo, said that the company was no longer booking the hotel to which Ms. Stainman was assigned nor a few others, which are in renovation.
Mr. Ellis offers advice. "Separate emotion from reality," he said. "Propose a solution. No operator, no hotel, no cruise is going to deliver 100 percent of the time, so avoid saying you will never visit so-and-so again. State what you want."
But most of all, he said, try to get the problem fixed while you are on the spot. He acknowledges it is less expensive for the tour operator to get an upgraded room for a client than to give a cash refund. "But my real goal is not to lose a customer," he said.
Complaint letters should be as brief as possible, but with names, times and dates, and should be businesslike and not surly in tone. Suggest a remedy: an apology, a refund, a guarantee for the room you want next time. Josephine Kling of Landry & Kling of Coral Gables, Fla., a cruise specialist, said that a pleasant tone was likewise important in making an initial complaint: "An ugly scene turns everyone off," she said.
 
Problem Solving
 Hotel and motel chains, scrambling for customers, have set up guarantee systems to try to satisfy unhappy customers and keep track of what goes wrong where. These systems give top priority to solving the problem on the spot.
Holiday Inn's Hospitality Promise program, which is more than 10 years old, is also in effect at the limited-service Holiday Inn Express motels. If a difficulty is not resolved by checkout time, the brochures in rooms say, the customer need not pay for the part of the stay that caused the problem. Steve Jacobs, vice president for reservations and guest relations, said this meant that the room would be free, for example, if the complimentary breakfast buffet was unsatisfactory. Most complaints, Mr. Jacobs said, pertain to bills: guests are charged for the wrong meal or for a movie they did not rent. If the complaint is not resolved with personnel at the hotel, the guest can call (800) 621-0555, where employees are authorized to negotiate a solution. Even complaints that do not reach the 800 number are logged by guest, hotel and problem, Mr. Jacobs said, and training teams are sent to places with persistent problems.
Efforts to please the customer whose problem was not resolved range from a voucher for another visit, possibly to the premium-brand Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza, to points on a Holiday Inn Priority Club account, to a refund in cash.
Mr. Jacobs said that less than 2 percent of the chain's room nights brought complaints. Of these, he said, less than 1 percent came from chronic complainers, who are eventually flagged and get no more free nights.
Hampton Inn also has a satisfaction guarantee for its 300 limited-service motels, as does its sister brand, Homewood Suites, both owned by the Promus Companies. The Hampton guarantee was begun in 1989, and Reg Mallamo, vice president of marketing, said that the number of people who invoked the guarantee was "nominal." All employees are authorized to give the guest a free night if the problem cannot be otherwise solved.
On the assumption that motels not now offering such guarantees are still concerned about guest satisfaction, it's probably worthwhile to ask what can be done about the room bill if the reading lamp was never fixed or the graduation party destroyed a night's sleep. If you get no results, write your complaint soon.

HEADLINE: Lead Paint Moves Up as Housing Issue

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
THE first time Marlene Zarfes ever worried seriously about lead-based paint was in February when officials of the New York City Department of Health called. They told her that her pediatrician had found a dangerously high level of lead in the blood of her 15-month-old son, Adam.
They also told her that they were coming to inspect her co-op apartment in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn for the source of her son's lead poisoning, probably chips or dust particles of lead paint. 
 "I was in shock," said Ms. Zarfes, who moved into her 106-year-old apartment building nine years ago.
Lead-based paint, like asbestos and radon in the 80's, is fast becoming a leading environmental issue affecting residential real estate in the 90's.
Homeowners, landlords and tenants, particularly those with children under the age of 7, are raising a multitude of questions: Does my home have lead paint? What are dangerously high levels of lead? What are the laws regarding lead testing and abatement? Who pays to have the lead removed? Is it tax deductible? Is it covered by my insurance?
"The problem has always existed, but the concern is growing and regulations are coming," said Roellen Garito, an administrative assistant with ACA Environmental Testing of Yonkers, which removes lead paint from homes.
In Ms. Zarfes's case, health officials tested her two-bedroom apartment and found elevated levels of lead in the paint used in the molding around the windows and doors. "The city told me it was off the meter," she said.
Ms. Zarfes, a lawyer, and her husband, Michael Durand, a public relations executive, then agreed to remove the lead paint; if they hadn't they would have been ordered to do so. They hired ACA Environmental Testing. "We spent over $4,000," she said.
ADAM'S lead levels are expected to return to normal, and none of the health problems associated with lead poisoning -- learning disorders being perhaps the most common -- are expected to develop. Other potential illnesses linked to lead poisoning are stomach and kidney ailments and anemia. It is not known conclusively whether the lead came from eating chips of lead paint or inhaling lead dust. Since Ms. Zarfes has minimal levels of lead in her blood it is not thought that Adam contracted the lead during his mother's preganancy.
"It's the kind of thing you think happens to -- I don't know how to say this -- but to people with less money," said Ms. Zarfes, whose oldest child, Matthew, 5, had slightly elevated amounts of lead in his blood two years ago. (Upon retesting, though, it fell to normal levels.)
In New York, about 650 children a year are found to have lead poisoning. That number, though, is expected to increase significantly after April 1 when a new state law goes into effect mandating annual testing for all children under 7. (Mandatory testing is not required in New Jersey or Connecticut.)
The number of cases is also expected to rise as more local jurisdictions adopt the new guideline of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the maximum permissible level of lead in the blood. The level, adopted by the centers in 1991, has dropped to 10 micrograms per deciliter of blood, down from 25.
"The number of lead poisonings is projected to increase to between 6,000 and 10,000 a year in New York," said Vincent M. Coluccio of the Mayor's Lead Paint Advisory Committee and vice president of ATC Environmental, a consulting firm in Manhattan. "We are the lead poisoning capital of the country."
The lower Federal guideline is currently not used as a legal level that triggers an inspection of a New York, New Jersey or Connecticut house or apartment. Rather, if a child under 7 has a blood lead level of 20 micrograms per deciliter or higher, the state or local Department of Health must inspect the child's home. The level for Ms. Zarfes's son, Adam, for example, was 27 micrograms.
 Exposure to lead comes from various sources, including paint, fuel, factory emissions, drinking water, contaminated soil and plumbing joined with lead solder. Children are usually exposed to lead-based paint and paint-contaminated dust and soil. About 74 percent of the homes in the United States built before 1980 contain lead paint. New York City banned lead paint in 1960 for residential use. Under Federal law, it was banned in 1977.
A doctor should test the blood of any children who are regularly in a house built before 1978 that has flaking paint, especially around windows. Surfaces suspected of having lead should be cleaned by wet-wiping rather than sweeping or vacuuming. Children should also be tested if their drinking water moves through the original plumbing in an older home.
During a Health Department inspection, if paint is found to have a lead concentration higher than 0.5 percent, using a chemical laboratory test, or 1.0 milligrams per square centimeter, using an XRF, an x-ray fluoroscopic meter, the removal or covering of the lead will be ordered. Homeowners getting such notices have been hiring lead abatement companies at a cost, typically, of $1,000 to $8,000.
Extreme care should be taken in removing lead paint, as well as in the subsequent clean-up. The work can create high levels of lead dust that can remain in the air and on surfaces for long periods. Indeed, abatement done by untrained people can create a health hazard more serious than if the lead paint were left in place. Generally, the safest approach is to cover walls with sheetrock or paneling and replace, rather than strip, window frames, doors and baseboards.
Though health departments often provide lists of experienced lead-abatement companies, no regulations exist for how the lead must be removed or who can do it.
"Anyone can hang out a shingle," said Mr. Coluccio, the environmental consultant. "There is no training or certification. We need to have good training and certification standards for people doing this work."
Daniel J. Sitomer, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in environmental issues, cautioned owners not to overreact to the potential danger.
"In the beginning of the asbestos issue, there was an over-reaction to it," he said, "and it caused building owners to quickly retain contractors who proved not to be qualified to perform asbestos abatement work properly, and as a result building owners faced additional problems causes by negligence.
"There needs to be a partnership with government and real estate and building owners to move slowly to develop a process whereby consultants and contractors can be properly trained to perform this kind of work professionally. At the same time, it is important to move slowly in requiring this type of work to be done to allow those contractors and consultants the necessary training to perform the work properly.
"Lead management can be implemented in such a way as to protect building inhabitants yet not force wholesale lead abatement, which could cause more problems than leaving the material in place."
Lead paint was used extensively when fashionable limestone or brownstone town houses were built in the early 20th century in such Brooklyn neighborhoods as Bedford-Stuyvesant, East New York and Fort Greene. The chances of extensive renovation with nonlead paint in subsequent years are more remote they are in wealthier locations.
"We call that 'the Lead Belt' and it goes right on up through Queens and Upper Manhattan and the Bronx," Mr. Coluccio said. "It is an economically depressed strip of land where 50 percent of the new cases of lead-poisoned children come from."
IN New York City regulations call for officials with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development to issue a citation and order corrective steps if, in an inspection for any alleged violation, chipped or peeling paint or dust from paint is seen in a building built before 1960.
A bill that would establish a new regulatory system and a grants-and-loans program for rental housing with lead hazards was introduced by Mayor David N. Dinkins last year but has been stalled in the City Council.
Some critics have complained that the city should seek stronger legislation, such as the removal or covering of all apartment elements that have been coated with lead paint, regardless of whether a surface has been damaged or a child made ill.
The city's proposed legislation states that remediation would have to be undertaken only if, after an insepction, lead is found to be deteriorating and a child under 7 lives in the housing. The form of the remediation would depend on the extent of the lead present.
"We certainly have hopes that the Council will act on this or some other alternative proposal," said Harold M. Shultz, a deputy commissioner with the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
For public housing regulations are already in place.Under Federal law, all public housing units must be tested for lead levels by December 1994 and if the level exceeds 0.5 percent in the chemical test, or 1.0 with the XRF, abatement must be ordered.
"It is the first attempt to have a proactive rather than reactive set of regulations," Mr. Coluccio said. "Until now we have been using children as lead detectors to tell us that there have been problems with lead."
About 10 percent of the public housing units in the city have been done thus far. Bids are now going out for the rest. "Thus far, anecdotally, the results are surprisingly low," Mr. Coluccio said. "People didn't tend to use lead paint in situations like public housing, where they were trying to economize in housing materials."
PERHAPS the most sweeping new law pertaining to lead and the real estate market is a new Federal regulation taking effect in October 1994 that will require property owners to identify potential lead paint hazards before selling housing. The law will apply to all housing built before 1978. Specifically, owners must provide the buyer or renter with a lead hazard information pamphlet, inform the buyer or renter of any known lead hazard evaluation report available, let the buyer or renter inspect the property over a 10-day period to determine lead paint hazards and insert a lead warning statement in the contract of sale.
In addition to the seller or landlord, several other parties, including real estate agents and management companies, could also be held liable. Violations of the disclosure law call for civil liability of triple damages of up to $10,000 for each violation.
As for who pays for the abatement, generally, it is a homeowner's or landlord's responsibility or, in the case of most co-ops and condominiums, the individual unit owners. "Virtually all offering plans provide that the unit owners buy on an 'as is' basis," said Marc Luxemburg, a Manhattan real estate lawyer.
As to whether lead abatement is covered by homeowners' insurance policies, it depends largely on whether the policy has a pollution exclusion.
"Different insurance companies have different positions regarding lead and whether they include it in their pollution exclusion and therefore offer no coverage," Mr. Sitomer said.
Perhaps the only bright financial note for homeowners who have to remove lead-paint is that the cost can be deducted from Federal income taxes under medical expenses if it is being done to prevent a child who has or has had lead poisoning from eating the paint. The surfaces must be peeling or cracking and within the child's reach. Repainting is not deductible as a medical expense, although covering the area with paneling or wall board could be deducted as a capital expense.

HEADLINE: Dangers of Predicting Children's Destinies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The article, "State's Case Links Poverty to Students' Performance" (New York Times, Feb. 28), reveals a severe prejudice which has prevailed in Connecticut, despite the popularity of politically correct attitudes. Instead of attributing deficiencies in students' academic performances to racial or ethnic inequalities, witnesses in the desegregation trial in West Hartford have reported that children's potential in school can be determined by their family's social and economic status.
One expert witness, Prof. David Armor of George Mason University, was paraphrased in The Times as testifying that mastery test scores in Hartford and its suburbs can be predicted almost entirely by looking at the income, college education and number of single parents in each community. He is wrong. 
 Our society does great damage to children by predicting their destinies according to the socio-economic status of the children's families. Great damage. We are replacing one harmful misconception -- that of genetic limitations due to race -- with another stigma -- that of academic inferiority due to one's family. In both myths, a child who is born into a supposedly inferior situation is doomed to mediocrity or failure in school, unless he heroically overcomes the odds.
Unfortunately, educators who maintain this view of children inadvertently create a self-fulfilling prophecy. They track children -- from kindergarten reading groups through high school honors programs -- according to their perceptions of the pupils' potential. Despite the fact that children develop skills in bursts, plateaus and everything in between, students rarely move out of the tracks established in the primary grades. Groupings quickly become based on the child's experience, instead of his or her aptitude.
Educators cannot predict students' test scores according to the family's socio-economic status. The factors which help students persevere to learn are not matters of income, but of opportunity; not college education, but respect for and dedication to learning; not single parents, but the accessibility of deeply caring adult guidance.
Would desegregation, then, promote the academic development of youngsters in the lower socio-economic classes of Hartford? If it increases the opportunities for inner-city students to attend well-equipped, attractive, academically challenging schools, then the answer is yes, desegregation would help. However, we will not serve the needs of these youngsters by moving them to a new school, and then putting them into segregated tracks. We will not meet their needs by ignoring them as individuals and anticipating that they shall fail. If we want to successfully desegregate schools, we must accept responsibility for integrating youngsters into the finest opportunities in their new alma maters.
The complex problem of educating all students in our diverse society cannot be solved by desegregation alone, or even by schools alone. Improving education requires the concerted effort of parents, educators and other members of the community to support children in their academic growth.
 
DIANE BARDES FAY
Riverside

Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Connecticut Weekly, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

HEADLINE: Another Bridgeport Emerges As a Leader With a Past

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
WHEN the leaders of eight Connecticut cities met last month for what was described as a summit on violence, it seemed appropriate that Bridgeport was the site. It has the highest per capita homicide rate in the state.
But forgetting the violence, which in Bridgeport is hard to do because of the unending series of crimes involving drugs and guns, particularly on its grimy East Side, the city has a terrible image. It has evolved with such public embarrassments as its huge illegal dump known as Mount Trashmore, the attempt by a former mayor to throw the municipality into bankruptcy, and the furor that resulted when an arm of the Unification Church, led by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, bailed out the university that bears the city's name.
 
Neighborhood Pride
 Despite all that, there is another Bridgeport. 
 The "other" Bridgeport is made up of homeowners who fight to keep their neighborhoods safe and clean and who take pride in the state's biggest city (population about 142,000) and its history and architectural legacy. In fact, in one category Bridgeport has emerged in recent months as the leader of the state. The city now has more local historic districts -- five -- than any other community in the state. In contrast, New Haven has two districts; Hartford has none.
Bridgeport became the leader in historic districts, an event rather lost to media attention because of the stream of bad news coming from the city, in the latter half of 1992. Four separate districts were voted by residents, to add to the single district, Black Rock Harbor, that had been created a decade and a half earlier.
 
A Hopeful Omen
 The new districts are Stratfield, a section of 280 homes, mostly stately affairs built in the latter part of the 19th century and the first part of this century; Barnum-Palliser, 42 modest homes built by the legendary P. T. Barnum and an architectural firm for working-class families in the 1880's; Pembroke City, 266 homes dating back to a planned residential development of the middle of the last century that was the brainchild of the energetic Barnum, and Marina Park, a turn-of-the-century seaside enclave of 14 mansions or near-mansions built for Bridgeport's industrial elite of the time.
Preservationists are hailing the creation of the four new districts as a hopeful omen for the future of the city. "I'm so heartened," said Laura Weir Clarke, director of Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation. "It shows the city has stability. The vote shows concern for the community and its neighborhoods."
John W. Shannahan, director of the Connecticut Historical Commission, said Bridgeport neighborhood groups that were successful in obtaining the historical districts should be commended. "To achieve this in a large city is a real accomplishment," he said. "A two-thirds vote is hard to get."
The two-thirds vote of a prospective district is the latest magic figure in the sometimes turbulent story of historical districts in Connecticut.
The move for such districts grew out of the fear in the early 1960's that towns and cities would lose their identities in an era of massive urban renewal and highway construction. The General Assembly responded with a law enabling residents of areas considered historically significant to set up commissions to regulate exterior alterations on existing buildings and also control the design of new buildings.
From the beginning, the districts were controversial in a state that has traditionally valued individual freedom. Opponents said they reduced freedom of homeowners to do with their properties what they wished. Proponents said old neighborhoods would disintegrate without them, or become so homogenized that they would lose their identities.
The law survived an effort to vote it out shortly after it had been voted in; it has been amended several times. In 1987, the number of affected property owners needed to vote in a historic district was reduced to two-thirds from 75 percent.
 
Half the Proposals Fail
 Even with the reduction, one out of every two proposals to establish historic districts fails because of lack of voter support, Mr. Shannahan noted. The addition of the four new districts in Bridgeport brings to 103 the total spread out among the state's 169 communities.
The most interesting aspect of Bridgeport's districts is that they are not reflective of the Colonial period, as are most of the other historical districts of the state. Instead, they are reminders of Bridgeport's role as a leading industrial city in the 19th and 20th centuries and the part P. T. Barnum played as civic booster, entrepreneur and Mayor.
The man most identified with the new historic districts, and who did the paperwork necessary for them, is Charles W. Brilvitch, city historian and unabashed fan of Barnum.
"He was a pioneer in city planning." said Mr. Brilvitch of Barnum. "The setback requirements for houses, that was his idea. And rural cemeteries, that was his, too." By rural cemeteries, he referred to spacious Victorian-era city cemeteries, adorned with exotic trees and shrubbery and monuments that are high art in themselves.
Barnum's most enduring gesture to the city that he loved is Mountain Grove Cemetery, where he now rests under a massive monument. Nearby is an obelisk with a tiny stone figure on top. This is the burial place of Charles S. Stratton, the Bridgeport midget made famous by Barnum as General Tom Thumb, the world's smallest man.
 
Glory Days
 A trip around Bridgeport with Mr. Brilvitch is a quick education in the glory that was Bridgeport. It is spiced with comments about how stupid he believes city leaders can be when they ignore the heritage of their domains.
"That's the William Hall house," he said, driving by a formidable frame house in the Black Rock district. "I call it steamboat Gothic." William Hall, he explained, was a builder of clipper ships known all over the world. Establishment of the Black Rock Historic District saved the house. "They were going to tear it down," he said.
Driving though Pembroke Park, he supplied a little tidbit about Barnum's requirements for people who bought houses there: "They couldn't drink, they couldn't smoke and they couldn't keep a pig."
Mr. Brilvitch is not a bookish historian. He is a tall, gangling man of 39, with hair hanging far enough down in back to cover a collar, if he wore a collar. Mostly, it's a sweater and jeans. He is a native of Bridgeport, went to Ohio to get a degree from Case Western Reserve University in urban and environmental studies and came back to his home city after trying the Washington scene for a time.
 
'A Dirty Word'
 Actually, being city historian is only part of his job. He is also the city's environmental officer but only on matters involving Federal money. He works out of the city planning office at City Hall. "I'm the only one in the office without a tie," he will say as a means of identification. He volunteers the information that he is not the most popular person in the building.
"Preservation is a dirty word here," he said. "We never would have gotten any restoration done if the city had anything to do with it. The homeowners were responsible, not the city."
Michael W. Freimuth, the city's director of planning and economic development, denies that he was against the four new historic districts but admits that he and Mr. Brilvitch do occasionally have differences about what is best for Bridgeport. "I needle him and he needles me," he said.
Of one thing, there is no question. The votes to create the new historic zones took everyone by surprise, certainly Mr. Brilvitch. "Before they took the votes, I had no idea how they would come out," he said. "It was overwhelming." The vote in the two bigger districts, Stratfield and Pembroke City, was nearly 90 percent in favor. In the two smaller districts, Barnum-Palliser and Marine Park, it was 100 percent.
A homeowner in the Stratfield district and a leader in the move for historic districts, Nancy R. Savin, credited Mr. Brilvitch for much of its success. "He's the lone person at City Hall who seems to have vision," she said.
Flushed with the new historical status, she and others are talking of conducting a house and garden tour. She admits that it may seem a bit strange for Bridgeport, noting, "No one can remember when one of those was held here."
