HEADLINE: Ties That Bind Poverty's Children

DATELINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
IN the last 10 years, admissions to juvenile detention centers in Connecticut have risen by 65 percent, the State Judicial Department says. Last year more than 13,000 cases were added to the department's caseload.
Michael F., 14, is one of those statistics. 
 On the run from the police last month, he said, he spent his time wandering the streets of New Haven until about midnight, then slept over at the home of a relative or friend. He would wake at about 11 A.M., dress and play video games or else find a prime corner where he could act as a "backup for my boys," meaning a lookout for drug dealers. He said he earned about $600 a week.
But late one night the police picked him up as he walked away from a 1987 Chevy on Congress Avenue that had been broken into. He was charged with attempted car theft and violation of parole.
 
Hard to Break Out of Cycle
 The charges were among 25 he had accumulated since August. Others included assault, possession of cocaine, conspiracy, burglary and larceny. The day before he was picked up, his mother said, he stole $70 from her pocketbook. Late last month a juvenile court judge in New Haven placed the boy under the custody of the Department of Children and Youth Services for 18 months.
But marred by the disintegration of his family through poverty, drugs and violence, Michael may never break out of his cycle of destructive behavior. Often the lives of such youngsters evolve into a whirlwind of assaults, thefts, truancies, vandalism and other crimes, child behavior specialists say. Their actions frequently become part of a lifelong pattern.
A recent study by child behavior specialists at Yale University found that 80 percent of chronically troubled youngsters grow up to become adults with high rates of imprisonment, unemployment, failed marriages, alcoholism and other psychiatric disorders. The problem behavior is often passed from generation to generation.
"This is probably the most costly mental health problem we face in the United States," said Dr. Alan E. Kazdin, one of the study's authors. "Not only in terms of dollars but also in terms of human suffering."
The major risk factors in developing behavior problems, he said, include family violence, a parent with a criminal background, depression in the mother and learning disabilities. The study is one of dozens over the last decade that have focused on how poverty and the absence of parental skills form the basis for disturbed families and the behavior problems that occur in children as a result. Children in urban areas like New Haven are especially afflicted.
"Every kid that comes through our doors has a chronic dysfunction somewhere," said Melsetta McFadden, a probation officer for the state Juvenile Probation Department in New Haven. "We're dealing with severely dysfunctional families, and dysfunctional neighborhoods. And if we're going to try and fix one we've got to fix everything."
Raised in a poor, drug-infested neighborhood in the Hill section of New Haven, Michael began being suspended from school for fighting and verbally assaulting his teachers two years ago. Gun violence in the neighborhood escalated at the time and two close friends were shot and killed, one in a drive-by shooting. Soon after, his mother was accidentally shot by another son, who is 17 and now serving his second prison term for gun and drug violations. Earlier the boy's father had served a prison term for assault.
 
'Want to Be Somebody'
 After a long period of marital discord that included violence, the boy's parents recently separated. His mother is severely depressed about the separation and from the multiple disabilities that have resulted from the gunshot wound, she said.
While staying at his mother's on a 24-hour furlough from the Juvenile Detention Center in New Haven in December, Michael said he was excited about an education program offered by the Juvenile Probation Services. "I just want to be somebody," he said.
He wore baggy designer jeans that hung below his hips and a new red sweatshirt. His mother described him as angelic. An hour before the boy was due back at the detention center on Whalley Avenue, he ran away.
For the next three weeks, his mother said, she had nightmares about the boy's possible whereabouts. Every time she heard about another shooting death in New Haven, she said she was certain it was her son.
"I'd just have this feeling that I'd be burying my boy in 1993," she said.
When a police officer appeared at her door to say her son had been arrested, she said she cried in relief. She has applied to the Yale Child Conduct Study Center for counseling for herself and for her 9-year-old son in hopes of deterring him from following the same path as her two older children.
Dr. Kazdin estimated that up to 3.8 million schoolchildren in the United States exhibit chronic-behavior disorders. For the most part, counseling or medicating the youngsters has been ineffective, he said. In the Yale study, he found that treatment worked far better when parents were also taught constructive ways to discipline their children and help them practice new social skills.
"But this type of therapy is far from a cure," he said, "because this disorder appears to be a lifelong condition, especially when you've had a parent with the same problem."
The New Haven Family Alliance applies a similar family-oriented approach. The agency, which receives Federal and private financing, works with 150 families a year, who have been referred to them by the court system, schools or the Department of Children and Youth Services. Some 10 caseworkers work with 12 to 15 families each for a year to 18 months. Both children and parents receive individual and group counseling on a range of personal issues to help them build self-respect and find constructive ways to resolve conflicts. The agency also staffs neighborhood support centers that offer residents tutoring, drug counseling, parental workshops and support for grandparents who are raising their children's children.
 
Overcoming Mistrust
 Mustafa Abdul-Salaam, the agency's executive director, said that although the caseworkers had been able to stabilize about half of the families they see, winning trust was difficult because many poor families had developed a keen mistrust for social service agencies.
"We have made an entire welfare industry out of people's miseries," he said. "That leaves us with clients who have suffered years of abuse from a system that encourages dependency and discourages families to stay intact. Their level of hopelessness and mistrust goes very, very, very deep."
He added that about 80 percent of the agency's clients were affected by drug or alcohol abuse and that most of the families had also undergone generations of physical and sexual abuse, a possible predictor of behavior problems in adolescence.
In a study by the National Institute of Justice last year, researchers found that child abuse increased the odds of future delinquency and adult criminal behavior by 40 percent. Being neglected or abused as a child increased the likelihood of being arrested as a juvenile by 53 percent and as an adult by 38 percent.
Chris M., a 40-year-old mother of a 15-year-old boy, said she was trying to steer him away from a life of criminal actions. After he was suspended from school several times, juvenile officials put her in contact with the New Haven Family Alliance for family counseling. Like many parents who use the agency's services, she came from a troubled background. Sexually abused by her father at the age of 3, she said she was later pressed into having sex with her brother when she was 11. At 16, she attempted suicide, she said. After the birth of her son, she became sexually and emotionally involved with a woman, whom she has since lived with for 14 years. They have raised their children together, she said.
 
Lives of Pain and Inconsistency
 Last year, her son got angry at her for dealing drugs, she said, which prompted her to stop. Nevertheless, she said, the boy's anger continued to grow to the point where he became dangerous. In August, she said, he physically attacked her, forcing her companion to break them apart. The boy now lives with his aunt. She said she had joined a peer group for parents offered by the agency and received individual counseling to help her work through the emotional turmoil of her life and become an effective parent.
Another member of the group was a 27-year-old mother whose husband was imprisoned on rape charges. She had recently completed a drug-rehabilitation program after she discovered that her 3-year-old daughter had ingested cocaine. Her 7-year-old son was sexually molested by a cousin last year, she said. She said she was afraid of the long-term impact her neglect would have on her children's future.
Toni Sands, a caseworker, said that most parents who sought help through the agency had never received professional counseling or openly discussed their problems.
"These are people who are dealing with a billion scary issues," she said. "It's so hard for them to be consistent and firm with their kids when their lives have been filled with so much pain and inconsistency."
 
Goal: Stay Alive
 For many of the youngsters of these parents, life beyond the front door is equally precarious. Eddie Aybar counsels 40 to 50 juveniles a week at Project More, a social service agency for former offenders. He estimates that 60 percent of the youngsters he sees will repeat their criminal behaviors. Many arrive at their appointments terrified because they are being followed by armed gang members, he said.
"Even if their home life is intact, their neighborhood environment is so bad that it's bound to catch up with them."
One 17-year-old that Mr. Aybar was counseling one recent day told of the horror and venality of street life and the fear he shares with many of his friends that he will die young.
"Selling drugs, hanging out and trying to stay alive," he said, summarizing his generation. "That's what the youth of America is all about."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Westchester;
3 Megastores Proposed by Home Depot

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
A PROPOSAL by Home Depot, the home-improvement discount giant, to build three megastores in southern Westchester County has encountered some opposition, particularly in Yonkers, where an organization was formed just last month to block its plans.
But Robert Morris, chief executive officer of the Morris Companies, of Secaucus, N.J., which would develop a 100-acre complex anchored by Home Depot in Yonkers, called Westchester "the perfect site" for such projects. 
 He noted that Yonkers was an "area with older housing stock and a dense population," where every day more people are doing their own home improvements."
In addition to Home Depot, the $60 million project would include Costco, a wholesale club, and another store, "probably Kmart," Mr. Morris said, plus a multiscreen cinema.
The three-building complex, with more than 450,000 square feet, will be near Austin Avenue, in the north central part of the city, right off the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.
"It will really be a regional center," said Mr. Morris. "It will draw people from as far north as the Tappan Zee Bridge and as far south as the Bronx."
A similar project anchored by Home Depot has been proposed for New Rochelle. A third Home Depot is proposed for Port Chester.
A key opponent of Home Depot plans is Herbert Lockwood, president of the Citzens, Business & Labor for Proper Planning in Westchester, a group of business and residents formed last month to oppose the Home Depot projects.
Mr. Lockwood, who is president of Lockwood Lumber in Yonkers, calls the proposals for three megastores a "2,000-pound gorilla trying to fit into one shoe."
The group contends that Home Depot comes into a community seeking tax abatements and other favors that negate any benefits it might bring.
"The company saturates an area with stores, puts the competition out of business in order to gain total market dominance," said George Drapeau, spokesman for the opposition group. "Eventually one of the three stores is bound to fail, and one of these communities will be left holding the bag with a shell of a building."
The group maintains that that is what happened in Fairfield County, Conn., where several lumber companes did go out of business after Home Depot stores opened in Fairfield and Danbury.
Home Depot counters that there are economic reasons for the failure of those businesses.
"Lumber companies have also closed in Westchester," said Mark Bander, real estate manager for the Atlanta-based company, "and we're not even there yet."
Furthermore, Mr. Bander said, Home Depot meets a market need unserved by any other store. "For the first time, the do-it-yourselfer can afford to do the kinds of projects he's always wanted to do but couldn't finance before," he said.
At a crowded hearing on the project on March 9 before the Yonkers City Council, concerns were voiced about the traffic and noise that would be generated by the project. Many also opposed rezoning a part of the site to permit retail development. It is now zoned for office parks only.
Opponents say that such rezoning could set a dangerous precedent that would enable other retail development on sites not currently zoned for it.
The City Council is now split, 3 to 3, on the project, with Councilman Thomas Dickerson, a Republican, holding the swing vote. He said he had asked both sides to come up with more detailed information.
A COST analysis by Ernst & Young, a Manhattan accounting firm, that was commissioned by the developer was "superficial," said Mr. Dickerson. Among other things, the report estimates that the project would generate $5.7 million in recurring annual tax revenues for the city and bring in 950 new jobs. "I also want to know how many businesses will be hurt, how many unemployed and what taxes will be lost because of this," Mr. Dickerson said.
Nevertheless, Mr. Dickerson calls the proposal "the single most important revenue- generating project we've seen in this city in 30 years," adding that Home Depot and Costco would "be a big plus for consumers."
Home Depot currently has no stores in Westchester, but has opened outlets in Fairfield County, Bergen and Middlesex Counties in New Jersey and on Long Island.
In Westchester, other large discount centers have built stores, such as Tops Appliance City, an electronic and appliance retailer in Hawthorne, and Pace Membership Warehouse, a general merchandise store, in Elmsford.
The 26-acre New Rochelle site will include the $20 million, 165,000-square-foot Home Depot, BJ's Warehouse, Price Club and Costco.
"We expect the biggest tax benefit to be in sales tax," said Joseph Madonna, the city's development commissioner. He said that conservative estimates put total yearly sales volume for Home Depot alone at $60 million, "which would generate $900,000 for us" and create 150 to 200 jobs. Home Depot will develop its site. The remaining 13 acres will be developed jointly by Halpern Development Corporation of Tarrytown and G & S Investors of Farmingdale, L.I.
The little local opposition, Mr. Madonna said, came mostly from merchants. "I can understand their concerns, he said, "but I think the overall benefit to the city is going to be incredible. Without it we can't succeed."
The Port Chester project seems to have even more support, according to Mayor Peter Iasillo, who is retiring on April 5.
Some village residents fear that a 101,467-square-foot store on Midland Avenue bordering Rye would create traffic snarls and parking problems, a concern of Rye residents, who note that they will get none of the revenue benefits.
"They will be impacted," Mr. Iasillo said of the Rye residents, "but we've also been impacted by their projects and we're going to do what's best for Port Chester."
To accommodate an expected larger crowd, the Yonkers City Council meets again on the Home Depot complex tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at Saunders Technical and Trades High School at 183 Palmer Road near the Saw Mill River Parkway.
"This is a big deal," Mr. Dickerson said. "It will take time to look at all the issues involved, not to mention what else might be brought up at the next hearing."

HEADLINE: The Global Village In the Classroom

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
MARSHALL McLUHAN'S vision of the world as a global village is becoming a reality in New Jersey high schools.
All across the state, more and more students are taking courses like Russian, advanced-placement economics and world geography from teachers who are hundreds or thousands of miles away, through a satellite hookup. So far, 45 schools have signed on, and 32 more are expected to join in next year. The system also provides training for the schools' teachers. 
 At the same time, 15 high schools and two colleges in Bergen County have been connected by fiber-optic cable, making it possible to share hundreds of hours of classroom instruction a week. And last month the Morris County Board of Freeholders approved financing for a similar system that will link 28 of the county's school districts and tie into the Bergen County network.
 
Interaction With Teacher
 Under the satellite system, far-distant teachers appear in New Jersey classrooms on television monitors. Speakerphones enable students to interact with the teacher, asking and answering questions, and to talk with fellow students from other states. Homework and exams are often passed along by computer key pad and modem.
School officials say the satellite system makes it possible for a school to offer courses it could not otherwise provide either because of limited student interest or an inability to find a certified teacher. Generally, only a handful of students are enrolled in each class.
"The thing that sold us was high interest and low numbers," said Paul Galusha, educational resources coordinator for Cedar Grove High School. "To be able to say that you took Russian, Latin and Japanese in a small school like Cedar Grove is really something."
Before it became one of the first schools in the state to embark on satellite learning four years ago, Cedar Grove, a 400-student high school, offered language courses in only Italian and Spanish.
But not all the subscribing schools are small. Pennsauken High School, with 1,300 students, receives nine different courses throughout the school day. The $14,000 the district pays in total tuition for the more than 25 students taking the courses represents a substantial saving over hiring even one teacher at an average salary of $42,000, said John Ritchie, the principal.
 
Hearing 'Distress' in a Voice
 Though the satellite teachers cannot see their students, the two-way speakerphone system makes up for that, teachers say.
"I can hear when they're asking a question they already know the answer to, or the distress in their voices when they have panicked and really need help," said Pam Winders, who teaches advanced-placement economics from Columbia, S.C., to more than 200 students from 18 states, including 56 in New Jersey.
She likens the experience to being blind and having one's hearing take over. "Before, I would have seen that by the look on their faces," she said. "Now, I hear it in their voices."
Ms. Winders said that, in the course of her teaching, many interstate friendships had developed among her students and at least one transcontinental romance had blossomed. And when the subject of a gasoline tax came up recently, students in South Carolina were surprised to learn from their classmates in New Jersey that self-service gasoline is illegal here.
"They find out about things they never could in a traditional classroom," she said. "But they are also 16, 17 or 18 years old, and they discover they're pretty much the same."
Ms. Winders said her students tend to perform at least as well as the national average on the advanced placement economics examination.
As high-tech as high school satellite learning seems, it is already being replaced by more advanced systems of telecommunications. While satellites allow for only one-way video transmission, the network of underground fiber-optic cables in Bergen County is providing two-way video transmission, enabling teachers and students in remote locations to both see and hear each other. Three high school classes can be linked with the teacher's classroom at any one time.
Susan Mullins, director of program development for Bergen County technical schools, said the county was just beginning to explore the potential of its fiber-optics system. She said, for example, that someday students in small high schools would have access to the same library information that a college student at a major university has.
"It's like using the basement and first floor of the Empire State Building and having the whole rest of the building to expand into," Ms. Mullins said. "This job is about 5 percent technology and 95 percent getting people to work together."
 
A Nonprofit Partnership
 The satellite system that New Jersey high schools are using, called the Satellite Educational Resources Consortium, is a nonprofit partnership between public broadcasters and 23 state departments of education. The cost to individual school districts runs about $3,000 for installation of a satellite dish and tuition of about $500 a student for each course. A teacher, who is usually excused from some other duty during the day, monitors each class and mails in assignments if they are not transmitted electronically.
For students who have been weaned on "Sesame Street" and MTV, staring at a television screen can be a familiar and enjoyable format.
"You pay more attention to the TV because there are a lot of pictures in the background that keep you entertained," said Kurt Long, a senior at North Plainfield High School who took probability and statistics last semester by satellite and is enrolled in a course in discrete mathematics this semester.
Kurt's teacher, Tom Graviss of Lexington, Ky., is not above receiving a pie in the face on camera to illustrate a mathematical point and keep students interested. A recipient of a Presidential Award for Excellence in Teaching Mathematics, Mr. Graviss, addressed by his students as Tom, ended his course on probability and statistics last semester with an animated video and rap song that summed up the subject.
 
Popularity of Japanese
 One of the most popular satellite courses is Japanese, with an enrollment of 176 students in New Jersey and 1,800 students nationwide. Yoshiko Hirano, a second-year Japanese teacher who broadcasts from Lincoln, Neb., said the biggest drawback to distance learning was her inability to stop a lesson if a student was having difficulty.
"I can't tell him to please come and see me," she said.
Ms. Hirano teaches three times a week for 50 minutes. During each class she interacts with about 20 students while the rest of her 500 students listen, which means that most of her pupils will have direct contact with her six times a year. Her students must also call in to telephone tutors twice weekly, who reinforce concepts and correct errors.
 
Problems Experienced
 Satellite instruction is not without its problems. There are occasional equipment breakdowns, and concentrating on a television set rarely equals the intensity and excitement that a gifted teacher can bring to a classroom. There are also scheduling problems since broadcasting starts in August before school opens in New Jersey and ends in early June, and the daily transmission hours are often at odds with a school's own class schedules.
Teachers worry, too, that they may one day become as obsolete as the one-room schoolhouse if distance learning really takes off. But that fear is unfounded, said Paula Keiser, coordinator of distance learning for New Jersey Network.
"If there is enough interest to hire a teacher, this is not the way to go," Ms. Keiser said. "It's not in any danger of replacing any teacher."
In addition to expanding curricular offerings, many districts are using satellites to transmit special programs throughout the year. When the Berlin wall was being torn down, students of German at Watchung Hills Regional High School watched the action live. Recently, 600 Cedar Grove students of all ages gathered at the high school for a teleconference with a NASA astronaut to discuss his trip to the moon.
"When one of your kids is talking to an astronaut, you get chills up and down your spine," Mr. Galusha said.
 
Training for Teachers
 Satellites are also being used to help train staff members and are drawing on the expertise of educators around the state. Among the programs for teachers have been a workshop on computers in the high school math curriculum that was produced by the Stevens Institute of Technology, a series on elementary science teaching from the New Jersey Institute of Technology and there have been teleconferences with the Thomas Kean State Aquarium and the New Jersey Department of Education.
Despite the relative economy of satellite learning, it still costs too much for some financially strapped districts. After beaming in Japanese, Russian and world geography for a few years, Boonton High School had to drop out of the system last year.
"It's all to do with finances, and nothing to do with the program," said Robert Kane, principal at Boonton High School. "If the financial picture improves, we'll come right back on line."
In Irvington, there is no classroom space to increase offerings beyond Japanese.
"There are no free classrooms anywhere, anytime," said Dennis Rumme, director of media services at Frank H. Morrell High School there, noting that Japanese was made possible only because an extended lunch hour had freed up a room.

HEADLINE: Westchester Guide

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

GERMAN PRINTS
An exhibition of German prints opens today at the Katonah Museum and continues through May 9. The show is on a national tour from its point of origin at the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago. 
 Titled "The German Print Portfolio 1890-1930: Serials for a Private Sphere," it contains works by 10 German and Austrian artists, all internationally known and expert at producing powerful, often disturbing, images. They are Max Klinger, Erich Heckel, Oskar Kokoschka, Lovis Corinth, Max Pechstein, Max Beckmann, George Grosz, Rafaello Busoni, Otto Dix and Ernst Barlach.
War, religion, politics, illicit love affairs, social issues, the chaos of World War I and its humiliating aftermath, and upheavals under the Weimar Republic supplied the artists with a wealth of subject matter expressed in etchings, engravings, lithographs and woodcuts.
The museum, on Route 22 at Jay Street in Katonah, is open free of charge Tuesday through Friday and Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M., Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Its phone number is 232-9555.
 
LECTURE ON BULGARIA
 Bulgaria is not one of the former Soviet bloc countries that confront us almost daily with bad news, but it is in the throes of adjusting to a non-Communist form of government and a free-market economy. A glimpse of present-day Bulgaria will be provided in a slide presentation and lecture by Marguerita Z. Herman today at 2:30 P.M. in the Desmond-Fish Library in Garrison.
Ms. Herman was born in Sophia, Bulgaria's capital, but fled with her family in 1942 when she was 1 year old. She said that her first and only pilgrimage back to her native land last September was an unsettling experience.
"I went back to see about some family property that had been confiscated by the Communists and is now being returned," she said. She stayed with family members in Sophia and traveled to Blagoevgard, where the property is situated, trying to absorb a culture whose language she speaks fluently but whose day-to-day activities are quite alien.
"The pollution is unbelievable, and the difficulties in creating a free market are overwhelming," she said. "People are doing things like turning their garages into cafes." One of her cousins, who lives in Sophia, told her that it was doubtful her generation would make the transition but that she hoped her children would.
A coalition of parties, which made up the parliament while Ms. Herman was there, collapsed in October. "Now the Communists are back," she said, "calling themselves Socialists, but they seem to understand that they cannot return the country to Communism." Admission to the lecture is free.
 
CHILDREN'S CONCERT
 A musical program for children, enhanced with puppets and audience participation, begins today at 2 P.M. at the Bronxville Public School, 177 Pondfield Road. The Fine Arts Symphony will be joined by Barbara Pollitt and her puppets in a performance of "Peter and the Wolf," narrated by Karen Bevan.
Ms. Pollitt designed the puppets and masks for "Jelly's Last Jam" on Broadway, and she has performed at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, the Royal Court Theater in London and the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Today's program also includes Sousa's "Stars and Stripes Forever" and "Four Musicians of Bremen" by Louis F. Simon, director of the Fine Arts Symphony. Tickets are $8 at the door; the number to call for reservations or more information is 368-2300.
 
NAVAJO PAINTER
 Mark Silversmith's father and grandfather were Navajo silversmiths in New Mexico, and Mark has followed his family's artistic tradition but as a painter working in watercolor, pastel, acrylics and prints. He will have a three-day show at Steve's Trading Post in Scarsdale Friday through Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., when he will be on hand to demonstrate his painting techniques.
Approximately 50 pieces of his work will be on display. Most are realistic scenes of the Navajos and the countryside they inhabit in New Mexico. The pictures are sensitively colored and meticulously drawn, melting into misty backgrounds that evoke the Indians' views on earth and the elements.
The Trading Post is at 75 Garth Road; the phone number for more information is 472-8094.

HEADLINE: HOW JACK KEMP LOST THE WAR ON POVERTY

 BODY:
A major criticism leveled against the Bush Administration was that its members were apathetic and out of touch with the day-to-day problems faced by average Americans. In light of that, DeParle's article was particularly ironic. Jack Kemp defied traditional Republican conservative ideology by fiercely advocating the cause of America's poor and downtrodden. It's a tribute to Kemp that his ideals have been embraced by members of all political persuasions and that he continues to be a favorite among conservatives. To portray Kemp's efforts in any other way is patently unfair. Even staunch supporters of the Bush Administration recognize that housing issues were low on the budgetary priority list. It is a credit to Kemp that he continued to battle for what he believed was right despite constant opposition. Perhaps the new administration will be more responsive to the nation's housing crisis. If not, in four more years Jack Kemp may be given a real opportunity to empower America.
 
SHARON WEINGARTEN
Middle Island, N.Y.

HEADLINE: America's Newest Industrial Belt

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: CHIHUAHUA, Mexico

 BODY:
WALK down the long rows of huge machines, newly installed in the freshly painted Ford Motor Company factory. Stop to examine the futuristic control panels that will run this automated factory. Watch Mexican engineers fine-tuning the new machines. And it becomes easy to imagine -- except for the Spanish and the low salaries -- that this most modern of engine plants is really in Dearborn, Mich., and not here on an arid plateau in northern Mexico.
Staffing the plant are people like Eleazor Faudoa, a 32-year-old technician equal in skill and motivation to the best in Dearborn, but earning only $1,000 a month, one-fourth the wage of an American counterpart. Currently, Mr. Faudoa heads a team completing the installation of machines that will grind the connecting rods for a new four-cylinder, multi-valve engine. Illustrating the sort of initiative often sought from American workers, Mr. Faudoa had a say in the machinery's design. "The manufacturers agreed to incorporate some of our suggestions," he said, "like those for a simpler electrical system and for easier access for maintenance." 
 The Ford engine plant is just one example of the rise of advanced manufacturing in northern Mexico, mainly to make products for export to the United States. A.T.& T. is making telephone answering machines; the Big Three, cars and engines; Zenith, television sets; Whirlpool, washing machines. The list goes on, deep into the roster of Fortune Magazine's 500 largest manufacturing companies. They are joined by other foreign giants, like Nissan and Sony, and a handful of Mexican manufacturers. Having invested millions, the Mexicans are exporting paper, tiles, glass and other products to America.
Northern Mexico -- not just the border towns but a strip more than 300 miles deep -- is rapidly becoming the newest American industrial belt. By most accounts, nearly 600,000 jobs have been located in Mexico that in the past might have been in the United States. Most are at maquiladoras, the simple assembly plants that pioneered the migration in the 1970's. But the maquiladoras are increasingly being automated, making them harder to tell apart from Midwestern factories.
 
The 51st State
 "The technological superiority that retained the most advanced production in the United States is disappearing, so that northern Mexico is now almost a 51st state in terms of production," said Harley Shaiken, a labor economist at the University of California at San Diego, who has written on Mexico's industrial transformation. "Boeing might still have a hard time making jet airliners in Mexico, but Mexican workers can match the skills of 70 percent of the labor force in the United States."
The rise of modern manufacturing techniques in northern Mexico seems certain to draw much more American industry to this country, hurting the American work force while amounting to only a mixed blessing for Mexican workers.
For Americans, it may no longer be true that a factory in the United States can be made more profitable than one in Mexico, even if a factory owner in America automates and retrains workers. Ford and others are discovering that semi-automation in Mexico -- with equally skilled and trainable, but lower-paid workers -- can be cheaper than full automation in the United States.
Many American executives argue that if they did not relocate to Mexico, they would be moving operations to low-wage countries in the Far East. Because Mexico is so close, the factories here at least buy their machinery in the United States, along with most of the parts that go into the products. That creates jobs in the United States. But a Mexican manufacturing belt increasingly capable of matching American production seems to guarantee a continuing shift of jobs to the south.
"That is going to create a political problem in the United States that is not likely to surface for two or three more years," Professor Shaiken said. "And when it does surface, it will be difficult to undo. The North American Free Trade Agreement will have locked in the open border arrangement that makes the job shifting possible."
For Mexicans, there is a gain as more companies hire people like Mr. Faudoa, creating a new class of factory managers and professionals. But the automation is also prompting factories to shrink the number of production workers. Partly for this reason, manufacturing employment in Mexico failed to grow last year.
Finally, to maintain the low wages that draw American companies to Mexico, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has gotten commitments from business and union leaders to limit raises. It could be years before the gap with American wages narrows significantly, said John Pearlman, chairman of the Zenith Electronic Corporation, which has 20,000 employees in Mexico.
 
A Coming of Age
 The transformation of Mexican manufacturing is only gradually becoming evident. Until now, the American presence had been most noticeable in the border towns, like Ciudad Juarez. The image there was of unskilled people earning very little to perform simple, repetitive assembly.
But farther from the Rio Grande, major cities like Hermosillo, Monterrey and Chihuahua are becoming more representative of northern Mexico's coming of age in manufacturing. The shipments north from these cities are contributing mightily to Mexico's merchandise exports, which reached $16.7 billion last year from a meager $10 billion in 1986.
The lure for the owners of Mexico's new factories is still low pay. But in the 1980's, corporate America realized that low wages could attract not only unskilled people, but also educated applicants in cities like Chihuahua that boast many graduates from public universities and technical schools.
"Without this pool of skilled people, we could not have put a high-tech factory in Chihuahua," said Lyle Raymond, manager of the Ford engine plant. The plant, which has made engines since 1984 for cars sold in the United States, is about to reopen after retooling to make the new four-cylinder engine.
Chihuahua, located on a mountain plain 230 miles south of El Paso, is a birthplace of this process. Now, more than 40,000 people, nearly one-third of the city's workers, are employed in the pastel-colored factories that are spreading across the plain, appearing from a distance like tiny spots of fresh paint against a backdrop of steeply rising mountains.
The Ford engine plant's employees are a cross section of the new work force. One hundred are licensed engineers -- earning $1,400 a month on average and often functioning as foremen, a task that American engineers consider beneath their skills. The 700 production workers are high school or technical school graduates, hired for the assembly line at $1.55 an hour and trained by Ford to work up to electrician, machinery repair, computer programmer or mechanic. The top pay for such specialties is $3 an hour. Mr. Faudoa is a graduate of these ranks, having risen through endless training to be a supervisor of foremen.
The Ford pay, slightly above the norm for Mexico, is deeply below American levels, where a manufacturing worker's average wage is $11 an hour and an engineer newly out of school commands $25,000 to $30,000 a year as a starting salary. By comparison, Esquiel De Luna, a 20-year-old sophomore in electronic engineering at the Institute of Technology here, expects to earn $400 a month -- $4,800 a year -- at one of the factories upon graduation, and work up to $12,000 annually in three or four years. "I would not take a first job as an engineer for less than $400," he said.
 
The Shrinking Payroll
 Seeking to maintain the low-wage lure, President Salinas got business and labor to agree to hold annual wage increases to less than 10 percent this year, in a nation that had 12 percent inflation last year. But he is losing ground on another front: he has promised Mexicans thousands of new jobs, many from American companies here. Now, factory modernization is undercutting this goal.
Just as companies in the United States have automated and shrunk their staffs, automation is limiting job growth in Mexico. The automation here, however, is meant not to save wages, but to improve quality.
"Sixty percent of what we once did by hand is now done by machinery," said Elio Bacich, director of a maquiladora here owned by Zenith that produces circuit boards and TV coders. Employment at the plant has fallen to 2,400, from 3,300, in recent years.
The trend is very visible in Chihuahua, a city of nearly 600,000 with striking combinations of new homes near squatter neighborhoods and shiny malls a few blocks from rundown stores. The population has tripled since the 1970's, and as people migrated here from rural areas, jobs grew at an 8 percent annual rate -- until the 1990's, when job growth halted, at 140,000 employees.
"I would say that the unemployment rate in the city has risen to 8 percent or more, double what it was three years ago," Mayor Patricio Martinez said. "This does not include housewives who worked and now don't. We don't count them as unemployed."
The growing automation is chipping away at a widely held economic theory. That theory states that Mexico and other low-wage countries should be centers of labor-intensive operations while the industrial nations should remain home for the best manufacturing technologies. But some American companies are finding the arithmetic of partial automation in Mexico persuasive. Given their low wages, five Mexicans operating a partly automated assembly line here cost less than one or two Americans on a fully automated line in the Midwest.
Nothing illustrates the trend more clearly than Ford's decision to switch the manufacture of dashboard gauges from a factory in Saline, Mich., to a Ford-owned maquiladora in Chihuahua named Altec. Altec employs 3,000 people to produce radios and other car components. It is assigning 700 people to the production of dashboard gauges, replacing 400 workers in Michigan by 1995. The alternative would be to automate in Michigan.
"When you automate, you get rid of direct labor, but you add indirect labor costs for very skilled people to maintain the more complicated equipment," said Thomas E. Davis, Altec's controller. Mario M. Okubo, Altec's manager, put it more simply. "We brought the production here and saved the business," he said.
 
Getting the Skills
 The pressure to be more skilled also touches young women like Magdalena Munoz, a 19-year-old operator in an automated assembly process at the Zenith plant, which like most of the 60 maquiladoras in Chihuahua is evolving into a higher-tech factory.
Young women seated at long tables in one area of the warehouse-like building still function in traditional maquiladora fashion, repetitively placing plastic and wire prongs into slots. These are the larger parts of a circuit board, and the labor-intensive work that these women do, for $1 an hour, originally prompted Zenith to shift production to Chihuahua from factories in the Midwest.
But technology has miniaturized other circuit board components, so that many tasks can no longer be done with precision by hand. And not far from the women seated at their tables, Zenith has installed computer-controlled machines to stamp or glue these tiny parts onto circuit boards. Ms. Munoz has been trained to operate one of these machines.
As the boards emerge, she scans a computerized readout to make certain the parts have been properly placed; if they haven't, she adjusts the machine or tries to fix the problem by hand. If she can't, she calls over a technician or engineer.
Ms. Munoz's pay is 137 pesos, or $45, for a 45-hour week, the same as the wage for the women assigned to hand assembly. A dollar an hour is the standard factory wage in Chihuahua, although the most modern factories -- like the Ford engine plant -- start production employees higher, at $1.25 or $1.50 an hour. These factories employ mostly young men, while the maquiladoras hire mostly young women.
Ms. Munoz's wage might rise with more training, if she stays. Worker turnover at maquiladoras is often more than 20 percent a year. That is a new problem for companies increasingly in need of retaining experienced workers to operate automated machinery. Rather than raises, other incentives are offered to try to keep people like Ms. Munoz.
A company bus takes her, free of charge, from her parents' home outside the city, a 90-minute trip, and returns her at day's end. She gets two free meals on the job. There is a free health clinic and some factories, like Altec, have ball fields, gymnasiums, adult education courses and social halls that workers can use for family weddings and parties.
But Ms. Munoz's day lasts from the time she rises before dawn until she returns home after dark from her long commute. She had kept a similar schedule for a year at another maquiladora, and then took a year off. Will she stay this time, and go through more training to master the complex equipment that Zenith is installing?
A partial answer comes from Graciela Ramos, who directs a center for working women. "These women see themselves as subjected to intense work and, increasingly, skilled work," Ms. Ramos said. "They know that what they do is worth much more in the United States. They don't discuss this even among themselves. The turnover is their resistance; when they can't take it anymore, they quit. But they take jobs again. Despite everything, the work gives them a sense of self-respect that women don't get at home."
Gerald Gonzalez, 22, is a notch or two above Ms. Munoz in Mexico's work force hierarchy. He was among 125 young men hired recently by Grupo Ponderosa to operate its new paper mill. For years, the Mexican company has manufactured pulp at a plant outside Chihuahua, and now it has opened a paper mill alongside the pulp factory, investing $230 million in the project.
Rather than just sell pulp to Mexican companies, the struggle now is to compete across an open border against American companies that also produce white paper for writing and for copying machines. Mr. Gonzalez and his mates, having survived the hiring tests, are being trained to operate the complicated machinery, made in Finland.
"If this group can learn all the tasks and have a vision of the whole paper-making process, including how to maintain the equipment and repair it, these young men will be more valuable, even though most of their work will be repetitive," said Hector M. Raynal, the plant's director.
That is two years of training, at the end of which Mr. Gonzalez is to earn 250 pesos -- $83 -- for a 48-hour week, or $1.73 an hour. He now earns 165 pesos a week, or $1.15 an hour.
Grupo Ponderosa has recruited its new paper mill workers not from Chihuahua, but from two smaller communities nearer the paper mill, where 165 pesos a week seems like a lot. Furthermore, "For only 17 pesos a month," Mr. Gonzalez said, "I live with my wife and baby in a bungalow on the plant grounds."
Grupo Ponderosa has managed to add the paper mill to the pulp operation without increasing the work force. Having installed a partly automated mill and having upgraded the pulp operation, the company is operating the complex with 400 people -- the same number that once staffed only the pulp plant.
 
Weighing the Costs
 That sort of labor savings is helping to fuel a debate over whether Mexico's low wages still justify shifting production to this country -- since even here the labor content of a given product is declining. For example, George Baker, an Oakland, Calif., economic consultant whose specialty is Mexico, argues that Mexican production is burdened by other costs, not present in the United States, that offset the savings in wages. These include poor transportation, power outages and an absence of nearby suppliers.
Mr. Pearlman of Zenith disagrees. "When I factor in other nonlabor costs -- less heat, cheaper land and cheaper construction -- there is no question that Mexico's lower labor costs are decisive," he said.
So are Mexico's markedly nonmilitant unions. And nonlabor costs are falling as the infrastructure improves. Until its engine plant closed for retooling in 1991, Ford had been shipping engines north to El Paso by railroad. Now, tractor-trailers will haul the engines in half the time on a recently opened high-speed toll road.
The plant here and a Ford engine plant in Dearborn had competed to be the manufacturer of the new four-cylinder engine. The final decision, depriving Dearborn of 500 jobs, involved factors that went beyond labor costs, Ford officials said.
Ford originally put the engine plant here to satisfy Mexican export requirements for doing business in this country, and those requirements won't disappear completely during the first decade of the free trade agreement. Then, too, Ford sells more than 100,000 cars a year in Mexico, and the bad publicity from shifting Chihuahua's production back to the United States could have hurt Mexican sales, Mr. Raymond, the plant manager, said.
Finally, retooling the Dearborn plant would have required an extra $20 million investment -- $420 million versus $400 million here -- for enough automation to reduce the labor force.
Thus companies drawn by low wages find other reasons to stay, entrenching northern Mexico as an American industrial belt.

 
 
FOR MEXICAN COMPANIES, OPPORTUNITY AND PERIL
 The integration of northern Mexico into the United States industrial base is bringing opportunity to some Mexican companies and peril to many others.
Among those prospering in Chihuahua is the Almeida family, which has multiplied a grandfather's brick factory into a modern manufacturer of household and commercial tiles, employing new Italian technology.
Nearby clay deposits, owned by the Almeidas, give their company, Interceramic, an important advantage. So does the recently installed automated machinery that carries out most of the production process. The company's largest bank lender, Banamex, is also a big shareholder, and an American partner, Armstrong World Industries, helps with marketing in the United States, where 20 percent of Interceramic's output is sold.
"If you put the same plants here and in the United States," said Victor D. Almeida, Interceramic's chief executive, "with people of similar skills earning similar wages, the cost here would still be 5 to 10 percent less."
Maybe. Grupo Ponderosa, owner of a pulp factory and a new paper mill here, has not been so lucky. It is going against an American industry more powerful than American tilemakers. With Mexican tariffs slashed, American paper companies raised sales here by 64 percent in 1992, endangering Mexican paper companies that buy Ponderosa's pulp.
In building a paper mill, Ponderosa hoped to compete against the Americans, not only in Mexico but in the nearby Southwestern United States. So far, the strategy has not worked; the company has lost money and recently renegotiated $200 million in debts.
"The United States industry is very competitive," said Irene W. Meister, a vice president of the American Forest and Paper Association. She added that American paper makers had an advantage in technology, chemicals and wood supplies -- advantages the new free trade agreement will strengthen.
And then there is Arnulfo Solis D'Santiago, president of Chihuahua's Association of Small Manufacturers and himself the owner of a company that makes truck bodies and trailers. His work force is down to 52, from 76, and production has fallen to 400 units a year, from 1,500.
Second-hand American trucks, driven south in growing numbers, are cutting into the business, Mr. Solis said, and now that quotas have been lifted on new truck imports, he is expecting to be hurt from that quarter, too. "All our members have the same problem," he said. "We lack the economies of scale, the technology and the marketing to compete."
And Mr. Solis's solution? Well, he is trying to ally with a Minnesota company that makes hydraulic dump truck lifts. Mr. Solis would sell the lifts in Mexico and the American company would sell his dump truck bodies in the United States.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Bond That Only a Gambler Would Consider

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
FIFTEEN percent.
In this age of 5 percent Treasuries and 3 percent bank rates, doesn't that number make you nostalgic? Wouldn't you love an investment that promised that kind of return? 
 If so, Donald Trump and Merrill Lynch have a deal for you. The price talk on the new issue of $50 million in Trump Plaza Holding Associates bonds is a lip-smacking 15 percent. Add in a sweetener -- buyers get additional bonds, absolutely free, after three years -- and the promised yield is over 16 percent.
Those bonds are secured, sort of, by a majority stake in Trump Plaza, one of Mr. Trump's three Atlantic City casinos. A couple of years ago, that casino could not pay its bills and had to restructure its debts, but results have picked up recently, and this $50 million bond issue is to be sold in April. The new bonds rank below every other obligation, and they won't pay out any cash for eight years. Until then, interest will be paid by issuing more bonds.
If you're interested in collateral, these bonds are probably not for you. There isn't much of it, which is why Max Holmes, a Salomon Brothers bond analyst, calls them "fluff bonds." The prospectus devotes a lot of space to listing classes of people and investors with prior claims to the casino's cash flow. Mr. Trump does not guarantee payment, but his personal guarantee is a bit devalued anyway. Some of the proceeds from the bonds will go to pay his bank debts at 50 cents on the dollar.
If this bond issue sells, and Mr. Holmes says he believes there are enough "yield hogs" in mutual-fund land that it will, a new peak in junk will have been reached. In the most speculative days of the 1980's, even the most outrageous junk issues promised to begin cash payments within five years. But in underwriting this deal, Merrill has to delay the cash for eight years, simply because earlier cash flows are already reserved for others.
A buyer is betting that the casino's profits will continue to improve for the next decade, that competition will not get too severe despite the trend to allow casinos in more states, and that by the next century it will be possible for the casino to borrow enough money from others to pay off these bonds. If that bet fails, the bondholders will have a claim to a majority stake in a highly leveraged casino. But the casino's intricate management structure assures that even after default the bondholders would have no say in operating the casino, and no influence over whether the casino paid money to them.
After the junk bond market collapsed in 1990, the words "never again" were heard from investors and fund managers. As it has revived -- Securities Data reports that more junk bonds have been sold in 1993 than in 1990 and 1991 combined -- there have been frequent reassurances that the new issues are of much higher quality than the old ones. That has been true. But if this issue is any indication, the deterioration in credit quality is proceeding apace.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A British Star Called Telecom

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
FEW companies have remade themselves so completely as British Telecommunications P.L.C., the state-owned phone company that was privatized in 1984. Since privatization, it has ruthlessly cut costs, shed its slow-moving bureaucratic methods and claimed a place as a dominant force in the worldwide telecommunications industry. In the process, its stock, which trades on both the London and New York Stock Exchanges, has become a favorite among analysts.
"I follow everything in the industry, and within the universe of telecom stocks, B. T. is clearly at the most attractive end of the spectrum," said Jack Grubman, an analyst at PaineWebber Inc. in New York. 
 Analysts said the company, which holds about 90 percent of the domestic and international telephone market in Britain, has done an admirable job of paring costs to prepare for ever-increasing competition. In the last year alone, British Telecom has cut 38,000 jobs, reducing employment to 170,000, and it plans to shed an additional 15,000 positions in each of the next two years.
Over the last 20 years, analysts note, there has been a close relationship between the strength of the economy and the volume of phone calls. British Telecom's lower operating costs -- the job reductions are projected to save as much as $1.5 billion a year by 1997, although expenses related to the cuts are biting into current profits -- will bring it even more benefit than it would otherwise get from an economic rebound.
After three years of deep recession, the economy here is showing tentative signs of life, and according to Government estimates should grow 1.25 percent this year after shrinking by 0.5 percent in 1992.
"If and when the U.K. economy begins to recover, the leverage to the earnings of B.T. is tremendous," Mr. Grubman said. "They will be exiting the recession with 80,000 fewer people than when they entered."
Analysts said the improving earnings could bring dividend growth and lift the stock price. The stock closed on Friday in London at 423 pence, up 38.7 percent over its 1992-93 low. In New York, the American Depositary Receipts closed Friday at 63 3/8, up 3/4, but 10.3 percent below their 52-week high, primarily reflecting the dollar's 25 percent rise against the pound since September.
Analysts view the stock as already attractive to investors because it offers a relatively high dividend yield -- nearly 5 percent -- with low risk. "Relative to the market, it's still offering a good yield," said Stephen Owen, an analyst here at James Capel & Company. "And it's not like the average U.K. utility, which offers good yield but doesn't have much upside in a recovery."
British Telecom is by no means without problems or challenges. From an investment perspective, some analysts are worried that the British Government's plan to sell all or some of its remaining 21.8 percent stake in the company this year will dilute demand and hold down any rise in share prices.
From a technological perspective, like all phone companies, it faces competition in the long run from satellite-based personal communications systems that would largely bypass traditional phone lines.
In the short term, it faces growing competition in its home market, where it gets more than 90 percent of its revenues. Its main rival in Britain, Mercury Communications, continues to make inroads by underpricing British Telecom, particularly on international calls. Cable television companies, some of which have teamed up with telephone companies from the United States, including US West Inc., are starting to offer telephone service.
The British Government, determined to foster competition, continues to license new telephone carriers. So far, however, most of them are small and unlikely to pose a major near-term threat to British Telecom.
The company is pressing ahead with an international strategy to offset the restrictions on growth in Britain, even though it has had several false starts internationally. It is selling its 20 percent stake in McCaw Cellular Communications of the United States to American Telephone and Telegraph.
The British company's current emphasis is on developing ways to serve multinational companies that need international voice and data communications. With relatively little debt and a growing cash pile, analysts said, it has the flexibility to expand abroad.
One of its thrusts is in the United States, where this month it asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to operate telephone service. The ability to send calls from the United States would be crucial to its plans to offer "one-stop shopping" to big corporations around the world. But the plan is certain to encounter opposition from the American telecommunications industry unless American companies are given reciprocal permission to move into Britain.
British Telecom has also held talks about purchasing or taking a stake in EDS, the data-management company founded by H. Ross Perot that is now owned by the General Motors Corporation.
Its other big opportunity is in Europe, where the European Community is moving hesitantly toward opening highly protected national markets to competition.
"There is going to be only a small handful of companies that will be centers that offer true global services," Mr. Grubman said. "A.T.& T. will be one, and B. T. will be another. Along with A.T.& T., it's the only company that has the resources and the balance sheet to go around the world and forge alliances."

HEADLINE: The Dangers of Declaring War on Doctors

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
WILL Washington soon be in the business of telling doctors and hospitals how much they can charge? Hillary Rodham Clinton & Company aren't saying, but you don't need trifocals to read the handwriting on this wall: The only way to expand access to health care without tapping new sources of revenue is to regulate prices.
While what Administration insiders term "interim cost containment measures" can be accomplished in other ways, the President will most likely extend the elaborate system used by the Government to limit reimbursement of doctors and hospitals for care of the elderly and disabled. 
 The prospect is generating no outrage from free-market economists because it is widely understood that the prices of medical services bear little relation to cost. But economists are extremely skeptical that price controls will do more good than harm. They worry that the immediate financial gains from squeezing health care providers could be more than offset by the additional worthless procedures and bad will elicited in treating physicians and hospitals as the enemy.
The point has not been lost on the medical lobbies. "Price controls are a simple quick fix that will alienate the medical profession," said Dr. James Todd, senior vice president of the American Medical Association.
As important, economists fear that the focus on prices will distract from the core issue driving medical inflation: the failure to ration ever more expensive technology. "Once you have controls, you won't be able to muster political support for tough structural changes," argued Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
For a project so prominent, the Clinton reform effort has been remarkably successful in keeping its own counsel. But the President has not cloaked his desire to wring savings through price controls.
Mr. Clinton's apparent method for cutting costs is an outright abandonment of competitive market principles -- and not worth mourning, suggested Peter Diamond of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, because there never was a competitive market to lose. Consumers of medical services barely understand what they are buying in the best of times. And the bulk of services are consumed in the worst of times, when people are hardly capable of rational choices about who should dissect their innards or how much they should pay.
Consumers barely understand what they are buying. And even if patients were up to the task of comparison shopping, they rarely would have the incentive because most bills are paid by insurance companies or the Government.
The distortions created by these "third party payments" are probably large. A classic experiment run by the Rand Corporation in the 1970's showed that requiring patients to write checks when they went to the doctor sharply reduced the demand for routine health care. It should not be surprising, then, that Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution thinks the fees currently paid by private insurers "are essentially arbitrary" -- virtually unrelated to actual costs.
If President Clinton (and Congress) does decide on controls, there are a number of options. The simplest is a freeze, with prices locked in place on the date of announcement. But "even 30 to 60 days is a long time" for a freeze, said John Dunlop, the Harvard economist who administered the general price controls imposed in 1971 by President Nixon.
At some point, Washington would have to allow providers to pass through increased costs, a process that could quickly become unworkable unless the Government was also prepared to dictate wages, employment levels and capital spending. Such micromanagement of medical-care providers would not be very different from nationalization.
This is what happened during the Nixon era. Wage increases were limited economywide to 5.5 percent and price increases to 2.5 percent. If a company -- or, in this case, a hospital -- wanted more, it had to justify each item in its budget to the regulators.
THIS task was never easy for services, like medical care, where there is no clear measure of total output and therefore no straightforward way to measure cost per unit of output. And Mr. Bosworth noted that the difficult became close to impossible after the big jump in oil prices cascaded through the economy through a million different routes. To the relief of almost everybody, the system was phased out in 1974.
"Administered price controls sound tempting," said Mr. Bosworth, who worked on the price regulators' staff. "But the details drive you nuts."
Uwe Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton University, is not even tempted: "It's like lending the car to teen-agers and telling them not to make love: How do you police it?"
The most likely alternative, insiders agree, is one that builds on efforts to curb the costs of Government insurance for the elderly.
Washington, struggling to contain double-digit cost increases in Medicare since the early 1970's, came up with a comprehensive program for hospitals in 1983. Since then hospitals have been required to classify each Medicare patient's illness into one of 487 Diagnosis-Related Groups, or D.R.G.'s in the alphabet soup of health care. They are paid a flat fee for each D.R.G. admission, which is calculated to cover the average cost of treatment -- provided the hospitals are running efficiently.
A parallel system is now being phased in for physicians. Called the Resource-Based Relative Value Scale (R.B.R.V.S.), it divides Medicare treatment into some 7,000 procedures graded according to the time and expertise needed. For example, a colonoscopy rates as 8.43 times as valuable as an ordinary office visit for an established patient, so Medicare will pay 8.43 times as much for it. (See chart.)
The idea would be to extend the D.R.G. and R.B.R.V.S. scales to the treatment of all patients, not just those insured by the Government. Adjustments might be made to reflect lower rents and wages in, say, Alabama than in California.
Would it work? Care providers have beaten the Medicare caps by shifting overhead expenses to bills paid by unregulated private insurers. Medicare now covers just 90 percent of the average cost of care, while private patients pay more than 120 percent. But if all payments were regulated, there would be no place to shift.
Well, not quite. Economists worry about what health planners euphemistically refer to as the "behavioral response."
"The services provided by doctors are infinitely expandable" as they struggle to make up income lost to price controls, said Dr. Jack Resnick, the president of Managed Care Inc., a health maintenance organization on Long Island. Physicians and hospitals could also fight back by "upcoding" (billing for procedures that receive higher reimbursement rates) and by "unbundling" (billing for one procedure as two or three parts that cost more than the whole). Indeed, these practices are apparently so acceptable to the medical community that software makers sell programs to help physicians and hospitals maximize Medicare billing.
Today, Medicare administrators assume that every dollar saved by binding fee limits is offset by a 50-cent increase through volume, upcoding and unbundling.
ONE solution is to put a cap on total payments -- what the cognoscenti call global budgeting. Insurers might, for example, hold back a portion of the payments due physicians and hospitals, and then cut reimbursements by the proportion that total bills exceeded the allotted expenditure for the group insured.
This is guaranteed to work, if the philosopher-kings in charge of budgeting are resolute. But it might not work in a way that satisfied patients or providers.
For one thing, global budgeting is an accounting exercise, not a way to determine how much medical care is enough. It would not, for example, address which new procedures would be covered, and at what rates. This is no small matter: Joseph Newhouse, an economist at Harvard, estimates that half of the increase in the national bill for medical care now goes to pay for new technology.
For another, it would give physicians a strong incentive to order every test and procedure they could. The alternative would be to order only necessary treatments and lose income to less scrupulous practitioners.
Then there is the issue of regional equity. Alabamans spend less per medical procedure and undergo fewer procedures than Californians. Would global budgets lock these differences in place, or would they be used to equalize the quality of care? If the latter, would Californians be asked, in effect, to sacrifice to make Alabama a healthier place to live?
Kenneth Raske, the president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, points out that this issue is further complicated by the fact that some states have already begun to squeeze hospitals. In New York City, regulated reimbursement rates for private insurers kept hospital operating margins to 0.3 percent in 1991, compared with the national average of 3.9 percent. Curbs on capital spending pushed occupancy rates to 88 percent, compared with 66 percent nationally. Would states that have already pared the quantity and, by most accounts, the quality of hospital care be asked to cut back proportionately?
EXPERTS are divided about the merits of price controls and global budgeting. What comes through loud and clear, however, is that tough regulation aimed at saving money during the transition to universal care would carry heavy penalties.
Mr. Reinhardt of Princeton points out that countries that have arguably done a better job at containing medical costs while delivering high-quality care -- notably Germany and Canada -- have managed it by emphasizing cooperation with providers. The prospects for creating such a social contract here are bound to be diminished by a declaration of war on the industry.
Mr. Bosworth worries that controls could undermine what comes after. The experience of the Nixon controls, he says, suggests that an effective squeeze on medical bills would generate a burst of inflation when controls were lifted. And hardly anything could do more to discredit reforms in health care.
 
DRUG MAKERS' FIRST-STRIKE STRATEGY
EAGER to soften the punch of price regulation, drug makers have staged a pre-emptive strike: the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association has told President Clinton that the industry will voluntarily limit price increases to the cost of living.
That offer is not likely to satisfy industry critics because it would not prevent manufacturers from introducing new drugs at prices of their choosing. Nor would the proposal touch problems outlined last month by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment: high marketing expenditures, discrimination against domestic consumers and the proliferation of drugs that add nothing to the therapeutic arsenal. But it could save face for President Clinton, who may think twice before plunging into this regulatory quagmire.
Prescription drugs absorb just a nickel of the American health care dollar, a smaller fraction than in any other advanced country save Britain. Moreover, pharmaceuticals are often part of the solution rather than the problem: modern ulcer drugs, for example, are substitutes for surgery 20 times as expensive.
But there are a few clouds raining on this technological Eden. Drug makers spend one-fifth of their revenue on marketing -- a mighty $10 billion. And they charge less per dose in countries where governments negotiate drug purchases. Then, too, the Office of Technology Assessment frets that manufacturers invest excessively in drugs that duplicate competitors': between 1975 and 1989, 58 percent of new drugs fell into this "me too" category.
That said, it is hard to find an economist who believes regulators would know how to keep the innovative muscle and get rid of the fat. The best hope, suggested Joseph Newhouse of Harvard, is that health care reforms will give consumers the collective muscle and expertise to bargain for the best prices -- and maybe even push drug makers toward the most productive research.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Investing as the Rules Change

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
WITH President Clinton's economic package now on the table, and higher taxes for many at the core of it, some fine tuning of fund portfolios may be in order.
The Administration is proposing higher tax rates, a wider gap between the top rates on income and capital gains and policies that favor some market sectors over others. But advisers stress that only small adjustments, if any, should be made in light of these proposals, and those only with an eye to the long term and a firm grasp of the basics. Uncertain times, they counsel, call for exceptional discipline. 
 "Investment strategies should never be tax-driven," said Robert Clarfeld, president of Clarfeld & Company, a New York City accounting and financial planning firm. Long-term investing, he said, "should be based only on the fundamentals."
Still, planners note several things for investors to consider.
The Clinton plan would raise the top Federal income tax rate to 36 percent for couples with taxable incomes of $140,000 or more ($115,000 for singles) and 39.6 percent for the wealthiest. The top capital gains rates would remain fixed at 28 percent. This growing disparity is producing "more interest in equities because of the appreciation potential, built up on a tax-free basis, and because of the tax breaks" on sales, said William G. Brennan, who heads the Washington financial planning practice for Ernst & Young.
In particular, the proposals favor small-capitalization stocks by offering tax credits and other incentives to small firms, while large companies stand to be harder hit by limits on deductions. From a tax standpoint, smaller firms, which produce few if any dividends but have a larger potential for capital appreciation, make good sense now.
That's a lucky coincidence for investors because small-company stock funds appear to be good bets at the moment. Large-capitalization stocks dominated the list of winners during most of the 1980's, but the relative performance of big and small stocks has tended to move in cycles and small firms have just begun to take the lead.
As a result, advisers recommend that most long-term investors keep at least part of their portfolios in small-stock funds during the 90's. Look for those investing in companies with median market capitalizations below $250 million -- or mid-cap funds, at $500 million to $5 billion, advisers say.
The spread between the top rates on income and capital gains also means that fund investors who must sell shares should consider holding them for more than a year, when the favorable capital gains rate kicks in.
Funds that buy and sell securities quickly (chart) become less attractive because investors owe taxes on any gains, even if the money is reinvested in more fund shares. One strategy is to segregate high turnover funds in tax-deferred accounts like Individual Retirement Accounts or Keogh plans.
Overall, given an economy growing at 2 percent or 3 percent a year, equities are best, said Michael Stolper, who publishes the Mutual Fund Monthly in San Diego. For people who can part with their money for 10 to 15 years, he likes a mix of growth-driven stock funds, among them Pasadena Growth, Strong Discovery and Nicholas II.
On the bond side, tax-free funds become a relatively better investment if tax rates rise. Yet because most municipal bond funds own long-term issues, which are vulnerable to price drops if interest rates rise, many advisers recommend the shorter-term muni funds.
James F. Lynch, who edits the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, an investment newsletter in New York, recommends a package of three tax-free funds to diversify and blend management styles and fix the average maturity to satisfy volatility concerns. They are the T. Rowe Price Tax-Free Short-Intermediate Fund, Stein Roe Intermediate Municipals and Fidelity Limited-Term Municipals.
Investors in high-tax states like New York and California where the combined Federal/ state tax rate can run more than 45 percent, might want to investigate municipal bond or money market funds for their state alone, whose income is free from Federal, state and local taxes.
A caveat: retirees should not overload on tax-free funds because half their Social Security becomes taxable when the half, plus tax-free income and modified adjusted gross income, exceeds $32,000 for married couples, $25,000 for singles. The half could become 85 percent under the Clinton plan.
Balanced funds, which own a mix of stocks and bonds, provide income plus low volatility, but most own taxable bonds. Sheldon Jacobs, editor of The No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., suggests that top-bracket taxpayers sell balanced-fund shares and divide the proceeds between conservative equity funds and muni funds. For example, investors in Vanguard's Wellington or Wellesley Income funds might switch to Vanguard Equity-Income plus a Vanguard municipal fund bond.
Because of increased confidence in the economy, Harold R. Evensky, a financial planner in Coral Gables, Fla., has been moving his clients' money from government into corporate bond funds. One of his favorites is the Pimco Total Return Fund.
