SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1544 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/March 14-19

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
A House Cheer for the Budget Plan; Next: The Messy Part
 
So far, so good for the Clinton vision of the economic future. In a ringing show of unity, nearly all the House Democrats came into line behind their President last week, as the House passed his broad deficit-cutting plan with a solid majority. With Senate action expected this week, final passage is possible before lawmakers break for Easter. With a goal of cutting the $300 billion deficit to below $200 billion in four years, the resolution would set firm limits on total spending and taxes. In a sense, though, this is the easy part. A family might calmly decide to put a firm limit on, say, spending for food, but then find it a lot harder to pass by the steak counter and head for the rice and beans. Individual committees must soon climb into the ring to wrestle this beast, trying to translate a sweeping, faceless mandate into a nasty spending cut here, a biting tax increase there. "The real budget work will be done in the trenches," said Representative Robert Michel. Will unity last?
 
Taking a High-Tech Look at Meat 

The Government has inspected meat pretty much the same way for 87 years, even though its system -- relying on visual inspection -- misses many new dangers. In short, it doesn't work: in the last decade, 150 people have died and 150,000 made seriously ill by tainted meat, making it the top edible health threat. But recent poisoning deaths got the Administration's attention, and last week it proposed a high-tech overhaul. It should meet little resistance: seeing its damaged reputation, the $80 billion meat industry is ready to go along.
 
A Fair Price for the Airwaves
 
Who should rule the airwaves? Those with deep pockets? Many have long said no -- that fairness dictates allocating frequencies on merit, or by lottery. But where's the fairness if a lucky lottery winner resells, at a fat profit, this slice of nature's dowry? The Administration saw this reality and called for wide use of auctions, saying it would bring in $4.4 billion. Existing radio and television stations would not be affected -- they've got their slots. The true impact would be on those trappings of high-tech commerce-to-go: the pocket phones, the pagers, the laptops whose existence inflicts untold guilt on grim-faced executives who dare to read spy novels on the train.
 
Insurer Lament: Enough Already!
 
The insurance industry had something powerful in common with East Coast residents last week: That storm was the last thing it needed just now. Two huge hurricanes in recent years have cost insurers billions. So as everyone was struggling with snow shovels -- or, in the South, wishing they had such things -- the insurers tried to guess at losses. The industry's first, rough estimate: $800 million. What next? In coastal areas, premiums are bound to rise -- if people can get insurance at all.
 
Prices Up. Or Worse. Maybe Not.
 
Statistics are wonderful. For every number, it seems, there's a "but." Jobless rate up? Yes, but Santa did lay off half his elves. Widget output down? Yes, but hemlines are up. And so to last week's consumer price data: February's rise clocked in at 0.3 percent. Not bad. But wait: "core" inflation (no food or energy) was 0.5 percent. More worrisome; bond prices fall. But wait again: apparel, it turns out, accounted for much of the gain; bond prices rise. Bottom line: Inflation has stopped falling, but won't rise much. Or, as one economist (afflicted by that other malady, verb inflation) put it: "We've troughed out."
 
Toward Health Care's Future
 
The nation does seem to be inching toward a new era in health care. Candidate Clinton said Oregon should be allowed to try its innovative rationing system, so it was no surprise last week to find that he plans to approve the proposal. The President will impose certain conditions and try to limit Federal costs. But he clearly applauds the basics of the Oregon plan, which in many ways resembles the blueprint his team is drafting.
 
One member of that secretive team emerged into the daylight -- but not in triumph: Thomas O. Pyle was expelled from the inner circle for conflicts of interest. Mr. Pyle, who had headed one panel, was demoted because of his ties to health care companies.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Germany Cries Uncle on Rates
 
Terrified that inflation could wash in if it opened the credit floodgates, Germany has kept interest rates far above world levels. But reality is forcing the Bundesbank to change its tune. Essentially admitting the severity of its recession, Germany last week lowered a key rate and signaled that it would keep cutting. These days, no European economy is an island, and that must have been on the Bundesbank's mind: lower German rates allow other nations to try to get their economies going, too.
 
A Gift, and a Fist, for British Air
 
Global airline deals are clearly a sticky issue. United States airlines need foreign cash desperately, but if a foreign carrier gets a foothold here without returning the favor, the playing field tilts. What's a new Administration to do? Transportation Secretary Federico Pena tried it both ways. Even as he approved British Airways' $300 million investment in USAir, he warned British Air that that was the limit unless United States airlines got more access to Britain.
 
Hong Kong: Calm Amid a Storm
 
Hong Kong's mighty economy has its own momentum, unruffled by a surreal political backdrop. As 1997 inches closer, the tennis game is heating up: China denounced Hong Kong's plan to broaden democracy and vowed to set up a shadow government now. A nasty mess, and surely a recipe for business chaos. But no: After some gyrations, Hong Kong stocks steadied, as investors bet both sides had too much to lose not to compromise.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
United Airlines Shrinks to Fit
 
In the airline industry, one reality hits home regularly: a system that made sense in the overblown 1980's is wildly out of scale for the 1990's. United's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, was quick to use that argument last week as he brought word of the latest shrinkage. "It's not a management decision," he said. "It's a marketplace decision." United's decision: not to take delivery of $2 billion worth of Boeing planes (but, in a slap at Boeing, to continue to take Airbus A320's). He also said United may abandon some unprofitable short-haul routes. Part of his motive was clearly to put pressure on unions to accept cost cuts.
 
'Drooling' Abe, Weeping Alex
 
It's really an existential dilemma: Does one buy newsprint so that a bunch of people who detest you can, in nearly inch-high type on that very newsprint, call you a "drooling old fool" and then vilify you for not buying the newsprint sooner? I am ridiculed, therefore I am? Absurdist farce? No, just the latest act of the Abe Hirschfeld Follies at The New York Post. Gov. Mario Cuomo is not laughing; he does not want the nation's oldest paper to die. Last week, casting about for a workable solution, he cobbled together another group of investors to look into buying The Post. But the latest round went to Mr. Hirschfeld, as a judge upheld his control.
 
Lopez Is Here! There! He's Gone!
 
Finally it can be told: Ignacio Lopez does walk on water. Now those of you who are totally confused by Mr. Lopez's personal revolving door will understand why both General Motors and Volkswagen gave every impression that they believed the lean and stingy Spaniard was the only human in the known universe who could save them from oblivion. Of course a corporate Superman's resume should include decisiveness, too, and Mr. Lopez has been making decisions with lightning speed: in the blink of an eye, he quit G.M., came dashing back as the No. 2 man, then left a red-faced Jack Smith standing at the altar alone, wilted bouquet in hand.
 
One Tower, Back in Business
 
It takes most people longer to get around to dusting the piano or washing the kitchen floor. But most people don't have 2,700 workers cleaning full tilt. Last week, nearly two weeks ahead of schedule, Gov. Mario Cuomo led the first group of tenants back into one World Trade Center tower. But this is no instant, fairy-tale return to normalcy. Workers will be trickling back to the site of last month's smoky nightmare. Dean Witter, the largest tenant, at first moved just 100 of 4,500 employees back. And it will be a different place: new communications, backup generators. And the garage? That may never reopen.
 
80's 'Barbarians,' 90's Sitcom
 
In a world where fame lasts but 15 seconds, events of five years back are as dusty as ancient history. Last week's history lesson: HBO's "Barbarians at the Gate." It tells of a time, children, when giants of business strode the planet, brushing gold dust off their pristine lapels. Just feel the earth shudder at the sound of the names: Ross Johnson, Henry Kravis, James Robinson -- all tossing billions about in the battle for RJR Nabisco. Well, the Takeover Age is dead, the stars humbled -- but survivors of the era turned out in force for a New York screening. Ah, for greed gone by!

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
Pushing the Frontiers of the Electronic Age

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
MITCHELL D. KAPOR is best known as the founder of the Lotus Development Corporation, maker of the Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet, perhaps the single most widely used personal computer application of all time.
He is less well known as a former disk jockey in Connecticut, a stand-up comic and an instructor in transcendental meditation, a trade he plied in Cambridge, Mass., and Fairfield, Iowa. ("I quit because I knew people couldn't fly," he said.) His wardrobe favors Hawaiian shirts. 
 He left Lotus in 1987 and co-founded, with John Perry Barlow, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, based in Cambridge. The E.F.F. explores public policy issues related to the future of computing. Mr. Kapor lives in Brookline, Mass., with his wife and two children.
Question: What is the electronic frontier?
Answer: The construction of the transcontinental railroad was an enabling technology for the economic development of America in the 19th century. In the 20th century, we saw infrastructure development of highways and freeways and ultimately the interstate highway system for the automobile. It had a huge impact on commerce and life style.
In the next century, the development of the digital infrastructure, some connection of digital networks that link all homes and offices and schools, is going to be an enabling technology for, uh, whatever it is that comes. But we're certainly going to be doing commerce and entertainment and education increasingly over these kinds of networks.
Q: Why a foundation?
A: The E.F.F. believes very strongly in freedom, openness and diversity in both the technical architecture of these networks and the public policy regimes under which they operate. We believe the interests of the free enterprise system and the people who are interested in free expression really coincide.
Q: How real is the threat the new technology poses to privacy?
A: If you've seen any of these stories about cellular telephone eavesdropping, you know it's totally real.
Q: Poor Prince Charles.
A: Well, yeah, poor Prince Charles, but the latest thing is that there are clubs of people who get together to listen to the Hollywood stars cutting deals with their agents. Yeah, it's pretty serious. And there was a story about how some hackers reverse-engineered the read-only memory inside the Oki cellular phone, to do all sorts of nasty things including finding out whenever a particular subscriber was making a call, wherever they were, and taping all the calls of that particular subscriber, with code that is just sitting inside the ROM. Yes, there is a real threat to privacy in all these devices.
Q: What was your personal reason for becoming involved with E.F.F. issues?
A: It was an emotional identification with some of the kids who had gotten caught up in the Secret Service raids on the so-called hackers. My gut told me that some of these kids were innocent, no different than I was at age 18, at worst engaged in some mischief, and they were being pilloried, called the villains, the bad guys. I got really mad and said, "This is not right." There is not sufficient understanding in law enforcement of the issues involved here and of the real threat to the constitutionally protected liberties as they apply to computers. A lot of people are scared of technology.
And then it sort of generalized. As John Barlow and I were talking, we realized that we're just ill-prepared as a society to move into this future. We started E.F.F. as a way to understand the impact of that digital stuff, and it broadened in terms of its mission to try to understand the impact of all this digital stuff on society.
Over the last couple of years, we have broadened the agenda to be involved with the infrastructure issues, privacy and all that.
 
 
 
MITCHELL D. KAPOR

 
 Born: Nov. 1, 1950, Brooklyn.
 
 Education: B.A. in cybernetics, Yale; M.A. in humanistic psychology, Campus Free College (later Beacon College); graduate work at M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Business.
 
 Noncomputer reading: "The Miracle of Mindfulness," by Thich Nhat Hanh.
 
 Drives: A bicycle, and a six-year-old Mercedes 560.
 
 Frequent-flier miles: "Zero. I own a jet."
 
 Ideal escape: Beijing.
 
 Hobby: Spending time with his family.

HEADLINE: How to Tell the Debt From the Deficit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Perot Continues His Campaign on Capitol Hill" (front page, March 3), you once again mix up the debt and the deficit, referring to Ross Perot's pounding away at the evil of the $4 trillion Federal deficit. 
 It is the total Federal debt that is about $4 trillion, although even that figure, however often cited, is misleading. What is relevant to the economy is the debt owed outside of the Government itself, about $3 trillion.
The deficit is the excess of spending over revenues, usually financed by borrowing. The debt is what is owed at some point, the sum of all past net borrowings. The deficit in any year is hence the amount by which the debt increases.
The deficit is running at an annual rate of around $300 billion. It will thus increase the debt by that figure over the current year, to about $3.3 trillion.
To be fair, you are one among many in this confusion. Network news programs have erred repeatedly. President Clinton himself mis-spoke in his Inaugural Address and on many other occasions, talking of reducing the debt. This is certainly not part of his program nor, I might add, should it be.
For Mr. Clinton to achieve his goal of reducing the deficit will simply mean to reduce the rate at which the debt grows. His proposed reductions in the deficit would then keep the debt, over the long run, from outgrowing income, which is a sensible rule of thumb for individuals and businesses, and for governments.
Almost everyone is talking about the deficit, or is it the debt? Does anyone, literally, know what he is talking about?
 
ROBERT EISNER
Evanston, Ill., March 3, 1993
 
The writer, a former American Economic Association president, is professor of economics, Northwestern U.

HEADLINE: Rhodes to Rhodes: On the Inside Looking In

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Forget The New Republic. In Washington, this week's hot book may be the privately circulated quarterly published by the Association of American Rhodes Scholars.
Where but in the pages of The American Oxonian might the Secretary of Labor submit a chatty letter reporting on the doings of his classmate the President? Where else might the Ambassador at Large for Russia advise his former roommate to "keep your sense of humor" in the White House? 
 In the pages of the Oxonian, Bill Clinton is still quaintly identified by his home state and Oxford college: Arkansas and University '68. In the corridors of his Government, though, that form of identification is becoming more familiar.
"They seem to be everywhere," said Senator John H. Chafee, the Rhode Island Republican, who at a recent confirmation hearing found himself staring down at a witness table lined with nothing but Rhodes Scholars.
To a fraternity whose members also include six United States Senators and two Supreme Court Justices, prominence is nothing new. But the willingness of the first Rhodes Scholar President to enlist so many like-credentialed deputies has given new possibility to Cecil Rhodes's injunction that the scholarships he endowed at Oxford University be used to "fight the world's fight."
In addition to the lawyers, professors, bankers and reporters, including this one, who are its usual recipients, the latest Oxonian landed this week in the mailboxes of new officials at the White House, the State Department, the Central Intelligence Agency, the Department of Health and Human Services and other departments.
It indeed reflects the confidence of a group that always knew its time would come. "Bill notes that in early November he was elected President of the United States," reports Robert Reich, secretary to the Rhodes class of 1968, and now also the Labor Secretary. "Be excellent," adds Strobe Talbott, offering advice to the classmate who plucked him from Time magazine to take charge of the State Department's Russian affairs.
Even for those a step removed from power, the journal provides the chance to underline their near-proximity. "I recently caught up with Geoff in the halls of the Presidential transition office," reports David Frederick, the 1983 class secretary, who like his classmate is thought to be a candidate for an Administration job.
In addition to a red-bordered announcement of Mr. Clinton's election, a poem called "The Man from Hope," and Mr. Reich's tongue-in-cheek advice ("Be especially careful of any economic advice you receive from short people"), the journal includes a report of two letters received from Carl Albert, elected a Rhodes Scholar in 1931. Having first complained of his deteriorating health, the former Speaker of the House was said to have dispatched a post-election update that showed the therapeutic value of electoral success.
"Now Bill Clinton has made it," the class secretary writes, "and Carl is overflowing with euphoria."
Apart from Mr. Clinton, no fewer than six Rhodes Scholars are on the White House staff, including George Stephanopoulos, the communications director; Ira Magaziner, a top health care adviser; Bruce Reed, a domestic policy adviser, and Sylvia Matthews, an aide to the National Economic Council. At Labor, Mr. Reich tapped his classmate Thomas Williamson as the department's chief counsel. The new Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey, put a fellow Rhodes, Joseph Nye, in charge of the National Intelligence Council.
And at the Department of Health and Human Services, a younger cadre has begun to fill the ranks, including Kevin Thurm, the chief of staff, and Daniel Porterfield, a speech writer -- who like Mr. Stephanopoulos are members of the class of 1984 -- and Atul Kawande, an even younger health care specialist.
By mere arithmetic, the representation of Rhodes Scholars is not exactly overwhelming; their total within the Administration now stands at 15. But the numbers are swelling so quickly that even Mr. Stephanopoulos said he was losing count.
In some circles, this has created an element of presumption. One White House official who is a Rhodes Scholar tells of receiving a letter from a long-lost classmate who wondered about job prospects. Another outside the Administration describes calculated schmoozemanship by classmates in which "everybody's trying to angle the connection."
The new Oxonian even includes a cartoon character typing a letter: "Dear Bill: You will no doubt consider yourself fortunate that I, a fellow Rhodes scholar, am prepared to join your innermost circle of advisers. . . ."
Mr. Clinton is expected at a North American reunion this spring that shows signs of becoming a political occasion. While 800 people signed up before an October deadline, another 500 expressed interest only after Election Day, organizers have noted. A similar surge of interest is expected for an Oxford and Cambridge dinner to be held here next month at which Mr. Stephanopoulos is to deliver the ritual "toast to the Queen."
In his role as Mr. Clinton's chief spokesman, Mr. Stephanopoulos at first contended that Oxford credentialism had played little role in his boss's choices. "There's his personal network of friends who are Rhodes Scholars, and then there are the young people, and it's not necessarily because they're Rhodeses.
"At least I don't think so," he quickly added. "Well, I'm not really sure, to tell you the truth."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
China Is Making Asia's Goods, and the U.S. Is Buying

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
For 150 years Westerners have dreamed of cracking the Chinese consumer market, ever since the British calculated that if each Chinese added just one inch to his shirttail, the mills of Lancashire could be kept busy for a generation.
Nobody bothered to look at it the other way around: If each American and European began buying Chinese-made shirts, the mills of Lancashire might be idled for a generation. Yet these days, trade statistics suggest that may be a more likely prospect. 
 The United States Commerce Department reported last month that the American trade deficit with China in 1992 was $18.3 billion, the second-highest after the deficit with Japan. But while the deficit with Japan is down from its peak in 1987, the trade deficit with China has risen more than 500 percent in that period.
Last year alone, the deficit with China rose 43 percent, and that was not a fluke. Since 1985, the gap has doubled, on average, every two years.
"It's going up, up and up," said Nicholas Lardy, a specialist on the Chinese economy at the University of Washington. Like others interviewed, Professor Lardy believes that the deficit may continue to grow, although probably at a slower pace than in the past.
Already, trade is joining human rights as a major source of friction between China and the West. China is vulnerable to criticism because it still has far higher duties and many more restrictions on imports than Japan and other industrialized countries.
The bright side of the picture is that American exports to China are also rising rapidly, though not as quickly as imports. Under pressure, China is opening up its market to foreigners, and that may create more sales opportunities for American airplane manufacturers, grain farmers, chemical makers -- even for Madonna, whose music is popular in China.
"There was a significant increase in American exports the last couple of months of last year," said a Western diplomat. "If American companies are able to take advantage of the market opportunities, if American exports increase as much as I think there's a potential to, that could help a lot."
In any case, there is a crucial reason why some diplomats and economists believe that China is not so much of a trade threat to the United States as are Japan and Europe. They note that the tennis shoes, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, fishing rods and neckties that are pouring into the United States from China are not costing a lot of American jobs. Rather, they are mostly displacing jobs in Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea.
How's that?
Take Hong Kong, which used to be a major toy-making center, producing Cabbage Patch dolls and other products that sent little hearts leaping in the United States. These exports gave Hong Kong a $5.6. billion trade surplus with the United States as recently as 1987.
Over the last five years, however, Hong Kong's toy manufacturers found that local wages were too high. They moved their factories a few dozen miles to the north, to Guangdong Province in southern China. The Hong Kong company still designs the toys, manages the manufacturing, packages the dolls and ships them abroad -- usually via Hong Kong -- but now they count as an export from China rather than Hong Kong. As a result, Hong Kong's trade surplus with the United States plummeted to just $700 million last year.
 
Importing Factories
 Hong Kong has become like a company's corporate headquarters, housing the bosses, the accountants and the planners. China has become the factory site.
The same process is under way in Taiwan, which is gradually being transformed from mainland China's bitterest rival to its greatest economic partner. While political relations between Taiwan and the mainland remain tense, most of Taiwan's shoe-making industry has already moved its assembly lines to the mainland. Garment makers and sports equipment manufacturers are also relocating factories.
South Korea is just starting the same journey, just beginning to shift production of labor-intensive manufacturing to factories in China.
"Taiwan and Hong Kong are offloading their trade problem onto China," Professor Lardy said. "As they move their labor-intensive industry there, it shows up in the trade deficit with China rather than with Hong Kong or Taiwan."
One indication of this pattern of shifting production is that the United States' trade deficit with "Greater China" -- China, Hong Kong and Taiwan combined -- has risen relatively slowly. Since 1986, the joint deficit with these countries has ranged between $20 billion and $30 billion.
As a result, the wave of exports from China may not be as politically sensitive as exports from Japan. There are many fewer American toy-makers and purse-makers to be upset by Chinese imports than there are American auto workers to complain about competition from Japanese cars. Most jobs making cheap toys and purses were already lost a decade ago to Taiwan and Hong Kong, and in any case those were jobs not much valued in the United States.
First indications are that the Clinton Administration is going to take a tough line on trade with China. After a negotiating session a few weeks ago, the United States outraged the Chinese by playing down their chances of entering the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade anytime soon. China is extremely eager to join, partly because that would symbolize its membership in the international community of trading nations.
The Administration's policy is expected to become clearer by June, when it must decide whether to add conditions to an extension of China's low-tariff access to the American market, or most-favored-nation status.
There are other trade complications, like copyright and trademark abuses. President Bush's autobiography, for example, was published in China in at least four different pirated editions.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Reckoning May Be Due For British Landlords

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Pity poor Gerald Cavendish Grosvenor, otherwise known as the sixth Duke of Westminster. He had the foresight to have as a forebear one Thomas Grosvenor who in 1677, trying to recoup losses incurred by choosing the wrong side in the civil war, married 12-year-old Mary Davies. Her dowry was a water-logged cabbage farm called Ebury Manor. To cut the story short: the family held onto the farm, London grew around it.
Today the Duke is one of the two or three richest people in Britain, owning 300 acres in posh Mayfair and Belgravia that could fetch a cool $5 billion. The plot contains, among other things, Claridge's, the Connaught Hotel, the United States Embassy, Belgrave Square and the shops and homes of about 4,000 leaseholding tenants, many of whom live in dark brick townhouses trimmed with cream-colored wood and lined up as neat as chocolates in Thorntons' window. 
 The 41-year-old Duke's position has been summed up by an anecdote, perhaps apocryphal. Speaking at a charity dinner, he exhorted his listeners to empathize with "those less fortunate than ourselves," at which point a guest at one table was heard to mutter: "Gerald, everyone's less fortunate than yourself."
But now all that might very well change, at least somewhat. Under a Jacobin piece of legislation masquerading under the innocuous title of the housing and urban development bill, wealthy landowners in England and Wales could be forced to sell apartments and high-priced houses to people who occupy them under long-term purchased leases. The bill, which could affect as many as 750,000 households, would effectively spell the end of the peculiarly British leasehold system in which tenants pay substantial sums for the right to occupy a property for a certain time, generally 99 years. At the end the property, including improvements made by the tenant, reverts to the landlord, or freeholder. Among other anomalies, the system means that the leaseholder's investment loses value drastically as the lease wears on -- a wasting asset if there ever was one.
 
A Traitor to His Class
 The system of long leasehold tenure, with roots in the 17th century when the crown showered its favored few with tracts of land, took hold as the norm in mid-Victorian London. Those fighting to overturn it, like Joan South, who founded the Leasehold Enfranchisement Association two years ago, argue that it is archaic and discredited and responsible for poor maintenance and the breaking up of neighborhoods. As leases approach the expiration date, lease-holders panic and sell for whatever they can get. "We got fed up seeing people being virtually forced out of their homes and moving away," she said. "That was the glory of London -- its residential heart."
On the other side, the argument is largely the sanctity of contracts and the inviolability of private property."With this as a precedent," asked Jane Sanders, marketing and communications director for the Grosvenor Estate, "what's to stop another government from interfering in other ways -- say, by making people who bought shares in private companies give them to the government?"
The bill is the extension of a "right to buy" principle embodied in a 1967 law, the Leasehold Reform Act, which contributed to a rise of 13 percent in the number of owner-occupiers between 1979 and 1990. But that law excluded apartments and certain very expensive houses, an omission this bill seeks to rectify. It is riddled with provisions and qualifications: leaseholders must buy the freehold of the apartments collectively; their leases must be 21 years or longer when granted, and they must meet a "low rent" test to ensure that they are not simply renters. The sale price is set by a complicated mechanism that both sides object to -- one says it's too low, the other too high. Crown lands are exempt.
Still, it represents a revolution of sorts. And for the scions of the landed gentry, like 79-year-old Lord Cadogan, the possessor of 100 acres in Chelsea worth $600 million, or 59-year-old Lord Portman, whose 150 acres around Marylebone could go for about the same, the unkindest cut is that the bill comes not from Marxist- mumbling Laborites but from their own Tory party, the bastion of property-owning aristocrats. The person pushing the bill is none other than Sir George Young, a gawky housing minister who fights for the poor and homeless in that traitor-to-his-class spirit and is lately lampooned by The Spectator as "the Che Guevara of the leaseholders."
The bill sailed through the House of Commons last month but ran into a predictable storm last week in the House of Lords, where there was much harrumphing and where the debate, noted The Economist, was peppered with "references to expropriation, sequestration, nationalization, socialism and theft." Opponents thundered that it made a mockery of the rule of law, and there were one or two hints that it might make it easier for foreigners to buy up London properties. One defender, Lord Hailsham, a former Lord Chancellor, said it was "no more confiscatory than the liberation of slaves." The various amendments that would have scuttled the bill were voted down. It is in committee and could still change.
Of course, the debate mirrored the changes taking place in British politics and especially among the Conservatives of John Major, himself the son of a carnival worker. The Tories are the party of the middle class now, and the middle class packs clout. As Lord Harris of High Cross put it, in condemning the bill as pandering to populism: "If you take 100 from one man and give 1 each to 100 men, you make one enemy and 100 friends. There are more tenants than landlords."
Perhaps then it was no surprise that the Duke of Westminster quit the Tory party in a fit of pique. And rubbing salt in the wounds, The Sunday Times's list of the richest people in Britain, expected out next month, is rumored to predict that if the bill becomes law and he is forced to sell most of his holdings, the Duke will drop from the second position all the way to the seventh.
Pity poor Gerald Cavendish Grosvenor.

GRAPHIC: Photos: An urban development bill under consideration in Britain would force wealthy landowners to sell apartments and high-priced houses, like those at Eaton Place, above, and Eaton Mews North, left, both in the Belgravia section of London, to people who occupy them under long-term purchased leases. (Photographs by Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: All Aboard;
Clinton's Plan Gets Moving

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Democrats have been saying for four months that Government gridlock is over, now that they control both the White House and Congress. Last week they proved it, at least tentatively. "Lawmaker," a word reporters use casually when seeking a synonym for a member of Congress, may at last be literally applicable at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue.
Friday morning, after staying in session for nearly 14 hours, the House of Representatives passed President Clinton's deficit-boosting $16.3 billion economic stimulus bill. A few hours earlier it voted for his $500 billion deficit-cutting budget plan. In the meantime Democrats in the Senate were successfully defending the plan against Republican attacks there. 
 And although that fight is not over, these early victories on the economic issues that got Mr. Clinton elected marked the end of his awkward transition to the Presidency. This was his legislation, not just something Congress passes every year like family leave. Every issue he faces will be different, but success breeds success. And Mr. Clinton had license to claim that the votes showed ordinary Americans "that we don't have to be mired in gridlock, that we don't have to spend all of our time posturing and dividing and running for cover."
The party discipline in the House was remarkable. Congressional Democrats have been promising to deliver, insisting they would not repeat their mistakes of the Carter Presidency. Old Washington hands took that with a grain of salt, saying Congress could not save itself from dissidence and pride of turf.
But the results speak for the Democrats. In 1992, they never got more than 83 percent of their members to vote with the party on a budget or tax measure. Last week, 96 percent backed the budget resolution and 91 percent supported the spending bill. On that vote, 22 Democrats sided with the Republicans, half as many as did so on their most unified budget vote last year, when there were 13 more Democrats in the House.
There are several important reasons for this success. One is concentration. "When they focus all their energies, they have the votes," said Representative Newt Gingrich, the Georgia Republican whip who is as unabashed an admirer of Mr. Clinton's tactical talent as he is a critic of his policies.
Mr. Gingrich claimed surprise at the effort Democrats had to put into passing a spending bill, but credited the President and his staff with skillfully tamping down incipient rebellion. And while Jimmy Carter spoiled his own good start with Congress by irritating Capitol Hill with efforts to kill patronage-type dams and reservoirs, Mr. Clinton is not pressing Congress on any issue other than his economic plan, and certainly not inviting irritation by demanding action on sensitive matters like campaign finance.
Another reason is the strength of a basic Democratic desire not to see their first President in many years fail. Burdett Loomis, professor of political science at the University of Kansas, recalled that even those Republicans who were not convinced of Ronald Reagan's policies in 1981 voted for them. Mr. Reagan's Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., steered them to passage and called them a "riverboat gamble." A similar commitment to Mr. Clinton's succeeding, and hard lobbying, won votes from previously unhappy Democrats like Representative Tim Penny of Minnesota.
And there is a change in the House Democratic caucus itself. Nelson W. Polsby, professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley, said the rise of Southern Republicans and the thinning ranks of very conservative Democrats gave Mr. Clinton a rare opportunity. He said Mr. Clinton was the first Democrat in many years with the option of using a "straight Democratic strategy," with no need "for bargaining or compromising with Republicans," at least in the House. The Democratic caucus is a little smaller this year, but it may have more Democratic votes in it.
But is this unity likely to be fleeting, like one of those frequent flyer awards that is valid only for a few months? Are these votes somehow special and irrelevant to the challenges ahead? And, anyhow, isn't the Senate different?
 
Waiting for the Tax Votes
 Republicans like Mr. Gingrich and Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, hope for Democratic failures on taxes. Their hope is that, later this summer, real votes for real taxes will prove much more painful to Democrats than spring votes for budget resolutions that direct committees to raise more tax revenue but in reality leave it up to committees to decide which tax to impose or raise.
Democrats worry less about unity on issues foreshadowed by the budget resolutions than about some other issues. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, argues that members will find no comfort in inconsistency, and cutting the deficit will continue to be a political defense for a vote for higher taxes. "I think people will be willing to stand by their votes on the budget," he said.
If there is one political minefield ahead that everyone knows about, it is the North American Free Trade Agreement. The jobs it will cost are held by real voters who know how their representatives and senators vote. The jobs it will produce are not held by anyone yet, and that makes a difficult political tradeoff.
Social issues like homosexuals in the armed forces and abortion present another set of threats to unity. Mr. Clinton's mandate, and that of most freshman representatives (60 of the 63 voted for the spending bill and 62 voted for the budget), is economic change. Touchy issues outside that area can hardly claim the same sort of authority.
 
Like a Laser
 That may irritate abortion rights advocates, just as delay on campaign finance irritates other reformers, but there was an effective single-mindedness to the Clinton legislative program that last week, at least, paid off.
The Senate presents different problems. It is possible to steamroller the House (if Republican cries of "tyranny" don't bother you even when they have a case), but not the Senate. As George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said, "the rules of the Senate really do lend themselves to delay and obstruction."
The Senate is different in another way, too. Under shrewd leadership, determined Republicans do have the ability to block action. That power, and their experience as the majority from 1981 to 1987, also makes lawmakers of them. House Republicans are shut out -- through their own obstreperous inclination and because Democrats squelch them whenever possible -- but many in the Senate minority want to be part of the action.
Health care is the issue that may test the Administration's legislative flexibility. In the House, it will probably have to count on Democrats alone, and Mr. Gephardt and his allies will try to use the 1992 election as reason to pass it. "On all these economic issues, including health care, there is a mandate," Mr. Gephardt said.
But in the Senate, cooperation and compromise will almost certainly be necessary. Republicans say they cannot tell if the Administration really wants to deal with them or is just pretending. Certainly nothing that has leaked out about Hillary Rodham Clinton's deliberations on health care suggests that political conciliation is as yet a part of the planning.
Mr. Mitchell said he had urged the Administration to stay in touch with Republicans and not to be put off by occasional disagreements. "These people have been active in writing legislation," Mr. Mitchell said. "I don't think they view themselves as obstructionists."
There is one outside force that Mr. Clinton and his Congressional allies count on, and that is public impatience with Washington and its reputation for inaction. House Republicans winced when one of their crankier members, Representative Dan Burton of Indiana, stalled the House for an hour and 34 minutes out of personal pique Thursday.
Mr. Gephardt argues Democrats can pass tough bills that would have had no chance a couple of years ago because the public wants change and believes Mr. Clinton has a plan. Even if "they're not sure of it," he said, "they want him to be given a chance."

HEADLINE: YELTSIN, DEFYING CONGRESS, CLAIMS EMERGENCY POWERS; CALLS APRIL 25 REFERENDUM;
Rivals Resist Move

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 20

 BODY:
Declaring it his duty "as a citizen, as a patriot and as a decent man," President Boris N. Yeltsin today assumed virtually unlimited powers and ordered national balloting to decide how and by whom Russia is to be governed.
Mr. Yeltsin's dramatic appeal to the nation in a televised address plunged the country into an immediate crisis. 
 Within an hour of his address, Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, an Afghanistan War veteran who is popular with the military, and the head of the Constitutional Court, Valery D. Zorkin, repudiated the President before the leadership of the sitting parliament, the Supreme Soviet, and declared his actions unconstitutional.
That raised the prospect of impeachment proceedings and an all-out conflict of the legislative and executive branches. One of the measures put in force by the Congress of People's Deputies, the full Parliament, last week declared that the President would automatically lose his powers if he moved to suspend the Constitution.
 
Emergency Session Today
 The Speaker of the Parliament and Mr. Yeltsin's main rival, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, broke off a tour of former Soviet republics and rushed back from Kazakhstan, and the deputies were summoned to an emergency session at 4 P.M. Sunday.
There were no immediate signs of activity by security forces, and the streets remained calm and empty after the late-evening address. In his speech, Mr. Yeltsin said that as supreme commander he had issued an order to the Defense Ministry "not to use the army for political purposes." He also called for a nationwide vote of confidence in him and Mr. Rutskoi on April 25.
The Deputy Chairman of the Parliament, Yuri M. Voronin, said he had contacted the Ministers of Interior, Security and Defense and was assured that they would "act within the framework of the Constitution." What that meant in the current crisis was not clear, but Mr. Voronin took it to mean that Mr. Yeltsin would be blocked.
In Washington, President Clinton gave strong support to Mr. Yeltsin and said he would meet the Russian leader as scheduled next month. [Page 13]
 
Showdown Has Been Building
 Mr. Yeltsin specifically declared that he was not dissolving the Congress of People's Deputies, which is the full Parliament, or the Supreme Soviet, though he declared that any action they might attempt to block his decrees or orders had "no juridical force."
Since it seemed obvious that the Supreme Soviet would do just that on Sunday, Mr. Yeltsin's speech drew the lines for a showdown that has been building virtually since Russia emerged from the ruins of the Soviet Union. It pits a nationally elected President committed to Russia's profound transformation against laws and legislators inherited from the Communist state.
It is a showdown that Mr. Yeltsin either avoided or was denied in the past. Now the question is whether it is coming too late, whether the coalition of the elected legislature, the Constitutional Court and the Vice President is too entrenched and legitimate for Mr. Yeltsin to overcome.
There is no telling, either, whether a nation badly drained by unending political and economic crisis will once again rise to Mr. Yeltsin's summons. Above all, there is no telling what the military will do if the confrontation reaches a stalemate and all Government is paralyzed. Unsure, too, if the tide of political battle turns against Mr. Yeltsin, is the fate of the summit meeting he has scheduled with President Clinton next month.
The core of Mr. Yeltsin's proposal was the proclamation of a period of "special rule" during which neither his nor his Government's decrees could be challenged by any other organ of power.
 
Vote on New Constitution
 In the same balloting on the vote of confidence, Russians would be asked to vote on the draft of a new Constitution and a draft law on elections to a national Parliament. These would come into effect if the President won the vote of confidence. Then, in line with the Constitution so adopted, elections would be held to the new Parliament.
This would not be a Congress, Mr. Yeltsin stressed, but a new Russian Parliament. Under the Soviet Constitution, the Congress was the highest legal authority, capable of changing the Constitution virtually at will.
Mr. Yeltsin gave no details of the new Constitution or the distribution of powers it envisioned, but it was certain to embody the principles of a strong presidency and a distinct separation of powers that the existing arrangement lacked.
Mr. Yeltsin also announced that he had ordered the Government of Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin to formulate measures to push economic reforms forward, including a law on private ownership of land. The Congress has repeatedly stalled on questions of private property.
 
Circumventing Constitution
 In calling for "balloting," Mr. Yeltsin was evidently trying to get around the Constitutional strictures against his calling for an election or a referendum. In many other portions of his address, Mr. Yeltsin seemed to be trying to build a legal foundation for his action, based essentially on the fact that he had been elected by the entire nation and entrusted with Russia's welfare.
But with the Constitutional Court already ranged against him and the Supreme Soviet armed with broad legislative powers, legality was obviously Mr. Yeltsin's weak spot.
In his address to the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, Mr. Rutskoi declared that Mr. Yeltsin's order violated the Constitution 18 ways. Mr. Zorkin of the Constitutional Court said he had addressed a letter to the President warning that the President's measures would only lead to destabilization and disintegration, and discredit him as President.
But in Russia the law has always been more a tool of rulers, Communist or czarist, than their master. The question is not whether Mr. Yeltsin is acting legally, but whether he can muster sufficient legitimacy from the people to withstand the inevitable counterattack and to prevent violence.
Mr. Yeltsin's move had been anticipated all week after the Congress of People's Deputies scrapped a deal reached with the President at its last session in December to hold a referendum and to abstain from any power struggles.
Already well in advance of the Congress, aware that the cards were stacked against him, Mr. Yeltsin had offered a broad variety of compromises. He also warned repeatedly of "extreme measures" if the deputies rejected his every overture -- as it finally did.
But as the week wore on, the likelihood of a dramatic counterattack seemed to wane, and Mr. Yeltsin seemed to be withdrawing into the shell of the Kremlin. Once he began to speak, however, he was once again the powerful maverick who defied the Communist Party of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who stood atop a tank during the Communist putsch of August 1991, whose broad shoulders shielded a team of academic reformers when they launched the program of painful economic reforms.
Sitting under a Russian flag, his eyes narrowed and his mouth set in a grim scowl, Mr. Yeltsin declared that his election in June 1991 marked a choice of President and a choice of course. "The choice was extremely acute and responsible: either to slide as before into the Communist dead-end, or to begin profound reforms, to take the road of progress on which all civilized humanity has embarked."
The problem now facing the country, he said, is not a conflict between two branches of government, but a conflict between the nation and the "former Bolshevist anti-national system which has not yet fully disintegrated and which is seeking today to recapture its lost control over Russia."
The last Congress, he declared, "was in fact a dress rehearsal of revenge-taking by the former party nomenklatura." With its powers virtually unchecked by the Constitution or the Constitutional Court, the Congress "allowed the leadership of the Supreme Soviet to virtually set loose the flywheel of an anti-constitutional coup."
"The Congress declined to heed the voice of the country," Mr. Yeltsin declared. "It rejected the opinion of the overwhelming majority of voters. But the Congress is not yet a state itself; the Congress does not mean Russia."
But even as Mr. Yeltsin spoke, his adversaries were gathering force. Shortly after midnight, Mr. Rutskoi, Mr. Zorkin, Mr. Voronin and the prosecutor-general, Valentin G. Stepankov, took their turn on national television to denounce Mr. Yeltsin's actions.
Mr. Rutskoi said he had refused to co-sign the order on "special rule." Instead, he said, he addressed a letter to Mr. Yeltsin appealing to him to cancel his statement and warning that it could lead to the use of force and bloodshed. He urged the nation to stay calm.
 
Rutskoi Appeals to Citizens
 "As we say, what happened has happened," said Mr. Rutskoi, a former Air Force pilot. "I find it necessary now to appeal to the citizens of Russia, to law-enforcement agencies, to the Ministries of the Interior, Security and Defense not to give in to provocations, not to dramatize the situation. I also wish to appeal to social movements and parties not to dramatize the situation and not to create provocations."
Mr. Zorkin, who cut short a trip to the United States when reports of Mr. Yeltsin's actions began to surface, addressed his comments to the President.
"Boris Nikolayevich, I sincerely pity you," he said. "You have lost the chance to become the savior of Russia, to be a Russian Roosevelt, a Russian de Gaulle. You tried to regain absolute power. You have put yourself outside the Constitution. Come back to it."
But the die is cast, and it is hard to see how Mr. Yeltsin could backtrack now. Much will depend on the immediate reaction of the public, of security officials and of regional leaders.
Though public-opinion polls showed a distinct public preference for Mr. Yeltsin, there is also a profound fatigue with chaos and a loss of faith in economic reforms that, for now, offered mostly poverty and crime.
The army is likely to do its best to stay out of the fray. But there is always the threat of actions by separate units, like the large security forces controlled by the Parliament.

HEADLINE: New View Calls Environmental Policy Misguided

SERIES: What Price Cleanup?/First article of a series.

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
A generation after the United States responded to poisoned streams and filthy air with the world's first comprehensive strategy to protect the environment, many scientists, economists and Government officials have reached the dismaying conclusion that much of America's environmental program has gone seriously awry.
These experts say that in the last 15 years environmental policy has too often evolved largely in reaction to popular panics, not in response to sound scientific analyses of which environmental hazards present the greatest risks. 
 As a result, many scientists and public health specialists say, billions of dollars are wasted each year in battling problems that are no longer considered especially dangerous, leaving little money for others that cause far more harm.
 
At First, Clear Benefits
 In the first wave of the modern environmental movement, starting about 30 years ago, the focus was on broad efforts to eliminate the most visible pollution pouring from smokestacks and sewer pipes -- programs with clear goals that had obvious benefits.
But a second wave began in the late 1970's, with a new strategy intended to limit visible pollution further -- and to begin attacking invisible threats from toxic substances.
To that end, states and the Federal Government began writing sweeping environmental laws, some of which included strict regulations to insure that certain toxic compounds were not present in air, water or the ground at levels that did not exceed a few parts per billion, concentrations that could be measured with only the most sophisticated equipment.
The result was a tangle of regulations that the Environmental Protection Agency estimates cost more than $140 billion a year, roughly $100 billion spent by industry and $40 billion by Government.
But what is now becoming apparent, some scientists and public health specialists say, is that some of these laws -- written in reaction to popular concerns about toxic waste dumps or asbestos in the schools, as examples -- were based on little if any sound research about the true nature of the threat. Since 1980, for instance, thousands of regulations were written to restrict compounds that had caused cancer in rats or mice, even though these animal studies often fail to predict how the compounds might affect humans.
And with rare exceptions, Congress approved new laws without subjecting them to even rudimentary cost-benefit analyses. One reason was that during the 1980's, when the economy seemed healthier, there was far less pressure on Congress to consider the cost of environmental policy.
 
Overpriced and Misguided?
 Now a new Administration intent on strengthening environmental policy is settling into office when competition for scarce financial resources is keen. At the same time, a wealth of new research shows that some of the nation's environmental protection efforts are excessively costly -- though no one knows how much of this money is misspent -- and devoted to the wrong problems.
This view is the vanguard of a new, third wave of environmentalism that is sweeping across America. It began in the late 1980's among farmers, homeowners and others who were upset largely by the growing cost of regulations that didn't appear to bring any measurable benefits. Corporate executives had long been making similar arguments but had gone unheeded, even during 12 years of Republican rule, because often they were seen as interested only in saving money.
Richard J. Mahoney, chairman and chief executive of Monsanto, the chemical company, said the nation may start listening to industry now.
"People want to know, even with the environment, what we are getting for our money," he said. "The most positive thing since the election is that we are beginning to recognize that we do have finite resources, and one must make choices."
But leaders of the nation's conservation organizations believe the new view is misguided.
"We don't need a new paradigm," said David D. Doniger, a senior lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "For 35 years, the policy of the Government has been that when there is uncertainty about a threat it is better to be safe than sorry. When you are operating at the limits of what science knows, the big mistake would be to underestimate the real danger and leave people unprotected."
Still, in the last few years the wave has moved into universities, city halls, state capitols and even to the highest levels of the E.P.A., whose Science Advisory Board in 1990 concluded that environmental laws "are more reflective of public perceptions of risk than of scientific understanding of risk."
 
Law Follows Panic
 William K. Reilly, the E.P.A. Administrator at the time, agreed. And in a recent interview, he argued: "People have a right to expect that public officials are making the right choices for the right reasons. We need to develop a new system for taking action on the environment that isn't based on responding to the nightly news.
"We're misallocating large amounts of money," added Mr. Reilly, who is now a senior fellow at of the World Wildlife Fund. "What we have had in the United States is environmental agenda-setting by episodic panic. We've had Love Canal, Valley of the Drums, the Exxon Valdez and with virtually every case of a new environmental crisis, there is a new legislative priority and a new budget allocation. That has created a mix of programs that don't respect the biggest risks to health and ecology."
Richard D. Morgenstern, the acting administrator for policy planning and evaluation at the E.P.A., explains the problem this way: "Our society is very reactive, and when concerns are raised people want action. The problem in a democracy is you can't easily sit idly back and tell people it would be better to learn more."
The result, he added, is that "we're now in the position of saying in quite a few of our programs, 'Oops, we made a mistake.' "
President Clinton is clearly aware of this view. As Governor of Arkansas, he continually complained as a Federal toxic waste cleanup project in Jacksonville devoured $25 million in state, Federal and private money. State officials said nearly a decade of work has produced little more than piles of technical documents, exorbitant legal bills and public discord.
 
Greater Consequences
 To be sure, some of the $140 billion the nation is spending this year pays for environmental programs that are indisputably useful. As an example, few experts question the value of spending roughly $3 billion each year on new sewage treatment plants. Many experts, however, question the wisdom of spending billions of dollars to protect people from traces of toxic compounds.
The new school of thought has blossomed as policy makers confront planetary threats like global warming, ozone depletion and deforestation in which the consequences of wrong action are much greater. Unless the nation rethinks its approach to environmental protection, some experts say, the United States could repeat its mistakes.
"The President is aware of this dilemma, and there is leadership in this Administration for trying to change the way we do business in every aspect of governing, including environmental protection," said Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "We have to allow for change to occur as new information becomes available. This is not an area where a solution will fit forever."
 
Policy Now
Costly Solutions Seeking Problems

Almost everyone involved, including community and local environmental groups, agrees that the toxic waste program stands as the most wasteful effort of all. It began 15 years ago when the nation rose in revulsion over the discovery of seeping chemicals at Love Canal in New York. Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes.
In response, Congress passed two laws: the Superfund law of 1980 and amendments to the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act in 1984. A decade later, those laws have driven the Government to spend almost $2 billion a year for the Superfund, which cleans up toxic waste sites, and more than $8 billion more a year on similar programs in other agencies, even though many of the sites pose little if any danger.
The Superfund law, which is a foundation for the Government's toxic cleanup policy, established a formula for ranking the potential hazards of toxic sites, and then devised a rigid recipe for cleaning them up.
 
'Throwing Money at a Problem'
 "Does it make sense to spend millions of dollars cleaning up a site that only has a tenth of an ounce of contamination?" asked Dr. Richard Goodwin, a private environmental engineer in Upper Saddle River, N.J., who has overseen more than 20 toxic waste cleanups. "I say no. All we're doing in most cases is throwing money at a problem without improving public health or the environment."
Hugh B. Kaufman, a hazardous waste specialist at the E.P.A. who helped uncover the problem at Love Canal, said that in the few cases in which a site is near populated areas, "the best thing we can do is evacuate people if they want, then put up a fence and a flag that says 'Stay Away.' "
Mr. Kaufman said he knows that his idea represents a marked change in the traditional view of how the nation should care for its land. But he and other experts says it does not make sense to clean up these wastes at costs that frequently exceed $10 million an acre.
Even a principal author of the Superfund law, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, who was chairman of a House environmental subcommittee in the 1970's, now argues that inflexible rules mean that Superfund resources are too often devoted to making sites pristine.
"It doesn't make any sense to clean up a rail yard in downtown Newark so it can be a drinking water reservoir," he said, speaking rhetorically.
Toxic waste cleanups are one example of a program gone awry. Here are others:
*Early in the 1980's, Government scientists argued that exposure to asbestos could cause thousands of cancer deaths. Since asbestos was used as insulation in schools and public buildings, parents reacted with alarm. So in 1985 Congress approved a sweeping law that led cities and states to spend between $15 billion and $20 billion to remove asbestos from public buildings. But three years ago, the E.P.A. completed research that prompted officials to admit that ripping out the asbestos had been an expensive mistake; the removal often sent tiny asbestos fibers into the air. Now, except in cases when the asbestos is damaged or crumbling, the Government's official advice is: Don't touch it.
* In 1982, high concentrations of dioxin were discovered in the dirt roads of Times Beach, Mo., near St. Louis. Residents were alarmed; the Government had designated dioxin as one of the most toxic substances known. The furor came in the middle of a scandal at the E.P.A.; the agency's chief, Anne Gorsuch Burford, was accused of not enforcing environmental law and being too close to industry. And as that scandal dominated the news, the Reagan Administration decided to evacuate all 2,240 residents of Times Beach, a project that cost the Government $37 million. But new research indicates that dioxin may not be so dangerous after all. None of the former residents of Times Beach have been found to have been harmed by dioxin, and two years ago, Dr. Vernon N. Houk, the Federal official who urged the evacuation, declared that he had made a mistake.
Yet even as enormous sums of money were being spent on these problems, Washington was doing little about others. Here are two:
*Mercury, a highly toxic metal, has contaminated thousands of lakes across the nation, poisoning wildlife and threatening human health, state environmental officials say. Twenty states, including New York, have warned consumers not to eat lake fish because they are tainted by mercury, which can cause nervous system disorders. During debate on the Clean Air Act, in 1990, Congress considered limiting mercury emissions from coal-burning electric plants, but lawmakers decided not to act because they believed utilities had already been asked to spend enough to control acid rain, Senate and House leaders said.
*In the last two years, several Federal agencies have called exposure to lead the largest environmental threat to the nation's children. Although some scientists dispute that, several studies have shown that lead poisoning in children leads to reduced intelligence, learning disabilities and hyperactivity. The problem is that most houses built before the 1970's could have some lead-based paint, and the fear is that children are eating paint chips or inhaling lead-laden dust. Some experts have said removing the lead paint will cost at least $200 billion. This year, the Government will spend $234 million on the problem, far less than it spends on cleaning up toxic wastes.
 
The Path to Policy
When Politics Mixes With Fear

Even the advocates of change acknowledge that as science evolves, experts may change their views again on the dangers posed by these and other substances. But at the least, "sound science should be our compass," as Mr. Reilly put it two years ago.
After all, it was politics, misinterpreted or inaccurate scientific findings and a newly influential national environmental movement that combined to set America down its present path.
During the 1970's, the United States had successfully dealt with many obvious environmental problems. When the Cuyahoga River in Cleveland caught fire in 1969, as an example, Congress passed the Clean Water Act. About the same time came the Clean Air Act, the Endangered Species Act and other landmark environmental statutes -- laws that are now widely acclaimed.
 
Partisan Battles
 By the late 1970's, many Democrats in Congress believed the public wanted even stricter environmental law. But when Ronald Reagan was elected in 1980, he promised to reduce regulation. While the White House and Congress battled over this, the national environmental movement, with help from the news media, took on the job of warning the public about new threats and enlisting popular support for new regulations. They were spectacularly effective at this, and Congress passed two dozen bills that laid down mandates.
In the 1970's, environmental statutes rarely ran more than 50 pages. In the 1980's, these bills seldom numbered fewer than 500 pages. The reason was that Congress wanted to mandate safety limits so specific that the Administration could not ignore or evade them. Mr. Reilly, the former E.P.A. chief, said he was largely unable to change the Government's thinking, despite his strong opinion that environmental policy was on the wrong course, because "this represented a pretty significant change of direction."
 
Legitimizing Pollution?
 At the leading environmental groups, staff members dispute the developing view that environmental policy is off track.
"It's an effort to legitimize pollution," said Daniel F. Becker, director of the Global Warming and Energy Program at the Sierra Club. "There are powerful forces who have an economic stake in de-emphasizing environmental damage."
But others who analyze environmental issues said these groups are in danger of becoming the green equivalent of the military lobby, more interested in sowing fear and protecting wasteful programs than in devising a new course.
"We are in danger of losing credibility and thus losing public support if we don't modify the whole way we go about protecting public health and the environment," said Dr. Devra Lee Davis, a senior research fellow at the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences.
 
A Case Study
Making Dirt Safe Enough to Eat

Perhaps no environmental program has come under more criticism than the Superfund and its progeny. The Federal programs to clear toxic or radioactive wastes will consume more than one-quarter of the roughly $38 billion that the Federal Government spends for environmental protection this year. Experts in and out of the Government assert, though, that the justification for these expenditures is often questionable.
Consider the case of Columbia, Miss. The E.P.A. is overseeing the last phases of a $20 million Superfund cleanup project there. Like many others around the country, this one was guided by the Government's assumption that children will eat dirt. Lots of it. And from that dirt, the Government theorized that they could develop cancer.
Some evidence suggested that this was an exaggerated concern. In 1981, a study for the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, which has been endorsed by the National Cancer Institute, found that only 1 to 3 percent of all cancers in people are caused by exposure to toxic chemicals in the environment. This finding, however, has had little influence on Federal policy.
The problem in Columbia was an 81-acre site that over its long life had been home to a lumber mill, a naval turpentine and pine tar plant and a chemical manufacturer.
Soil tests taken in 1986 showed traces of compounds the Government defines as hazardous. The concentrations rarely exceeded 50 parts per million, or about two ounces of chemicals mixed in a ton of soil. But that level exceeded the Federal limit, and the E.P.A. placed the land on its list of dangerous toxic waste sites.
Some experts told the E.P.A. that such tiny amounts of contamination were harmless. They said the safest and most economical way to solve the problem would be to spread a layer of cleaner soil and call it a day. The cost: about $1 million.
 
Most Expensive Solution
 But two years ago, the E.P.A. settled on the most expensive possible solution. The Government ordered Reichhold Chemical, the plant's former owner, to dig up more than 12,500 tons of soil and haul most of it to a commercial dump in Louisiana -- 450 dump truck loads, each one costing $7,500.
E.P.A. officials said they wanted to make the site safe enough to be used for any purpose, including houses -- though no one was proposing to build anything there. With that as the goal, the agency wanted to make sure children could play in the dirt, even eat it, without risk. And since a chemical in the dirt had been shown to cause cancer in rats, the agency set a limit low enough that a child could eat half a teaspoon of dirt every month for 70 years and not get cancer.
Last month, the E.P.A. officials acknowledged that at least half of the $14 billion the nation has spent on Superfund cleanups was used to comply with similar "dirt-eating rules," as they call them.
"I don't think any way you look at this it could be seen as a practical solution," said W. Scott Phillips, an engineer with Malcolm Pirnie, an environmental planning company that manages the cleanup. "It's a lot of money to spend moving dirt."
