HEADLINE: Inside White House: Long Days, Late Nights

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
It's not as if they've replaced the oil portrait of George Washington in the Cabinet Room with a velvet rendering of Elvis. And President Clinton was only joking the other night when he said, "We expect our own McDonald's to be completed by fall."
But he did invite an Elvis impersonator into the Oval Office last weekend. (Actually, it was Mark Alan Stamaty, creator of "Washingtoon," who turned up his collar, fluffed out his hair and broke out in an a cappella rendition of "All Shook Up" during a meeting for cartoonists.) 
 And though they have not had Big Macs yet in the White House mess, the President's minions have ordered that the kitchen stay open after hours to accommodate the work habits of Mr. Clinton and his equally compulsive aides.
After two months, the character of the Clinton White House is becoming clearer. In ways large and small, it reflects the character of Bill Clinton. If Richard M. Nixon's White House took on an air that sometimes approached paranoia and George Bush's was properly preppy, Mr. Clinton's White House is a mix of pure policy with controlled pandemonium.
It is a loose place, where doors are flung open and top aides wander fairly freely into the Oval Office. (One boasted this week that he had caught the President stepping out of the bathroom.)
Spontaneity is rampant. After Mr. Stamaty's recent performance, for instance, the President dispatched an aide to his living quarters to retrieve an autographed Elvis tie from his collection, which he then presented to the cartoonist.
 
Imposing Discipline
 Yet the White House has imposed some discipline on a rather undisciplined man. After all, Mr. Clinton lives right upstairs, so he's not as late for appointments as he was during the campaign and usually makes it to the Oval Office by 8:30 A.M., an hour after his senior aides start their staff meeting. He goes upstairs for dinner between 6:30 and 8 P.M., but often drifts back for more work. (Hillary Rodham Clinton has such a feverish schedule that she is rarely spotted with her spouse.)
Mr. Clinton still operates on little sleep, often not more than five hours a night. His pace has prompted some friends and close aides to warn Mr. Clinton to slow down, saying he does not need to be so deeply involved in every nugget of policy. But it is advice that he clearly has not taken.
Perhaps that is how he manages to read four books a week, always including a mystery novel. He rarely tunes into television news during the day but can play the Washington insider at night, watching Congress on C-Span. And though the President doesn't snack between meals (he sips constantly on decaffeinated cola and coffee and often chews on a fat unlit cigar), his hearty appetite for fried foods has not diminished.
Though there is no truth to the rumor that Mr. Clinton wanders through the West Wing at all hours, it is not uncommon for guests to roam the halls. On Wednesday, Ted Turner and his wife, Jane Fonda, had an appointment with Mr. Clinton.
"He's so smart," Ms. Fonda said of Mr. Clinton after looking into the office of a startled Howard Paster, the deputy for Congressional relations.
Even in the Oval Office, the scene can get pretty wild. There was the day that one of his advisers stood before the President's desk and came close to pulling his pants down after briefing Mr. Clinton for a speech. Paul Begala, a top strategist in the campaign who is a Texas native, mentioned to the President and Vice President Gore that he was wearing his burnt orange Texas longhorn boxer shorts to commemorate Texas Independence Day.
"Gore said: 'Come on, show him your underwear, anything goes! This is the Clinton Administration,' " Mr. Begala recalled. "So I showed the President my underwear in the Oval Office. I was standing in front of the President's desk. I did not drop my trousers. I sort of hiked my shorts up over the belt."
 
Well-Rounded Diet
 He may jog a few days a week and order highbrow dishes on forays to trendy restaurants (like the grilled San Pietro, a Mediterranean fish, at Galileo's on Monday), but don't think Mr. Clinton has adopted a watch-your-heart diet.
True, he usually eats a plain, untoasted cinnamon-raisin bagel at his morning briefings and often orders a tuna sandwich for lunch. But at times he cannot resist something more artery clogging, like French fries.
Once a steward returned from the White House mess to the President's private dining room with trays for Mr. Clinton and his more svelte Vice President. One had baked swordfish, a dried out baked potato and green beans. The other had the special du jour: the Mexican Fiesta Platter, loaded with tacos, enchiladas, rice and beans.
Mr. Clinton's aides laughed, certain about who ordered what. But the President had the last laugh.
"The truth was that Clinton ate the swordfish," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "I was as surprised as anyone."
 
How Time Flies
 For those whose job it is to make the President's day run on time, the little black box is the bearer of bad news.
In an office in the White House basement, a box behind the desk of Marcia Hale, the director of scheduling, tracks the comings and goings of her boss, known in White House jargon as "POTUS," President of the United States.
Green letters on a digital readout show where the President is at any moment and what time he got there. Often, it shows, he got there late.
His aides still find that he cannot quite stop from talking to people beyond the time allotted. They have done what they can, like scheduling 15 minutes of leeway into meetings.
"There's no such thing as a quick meeting with President Clinton," Ms. Hale said. "You wouldn't schedule even a phone call for five minutes because that's just not who he is. It just won't happen. He will engage and he will ask more questions."
His aides try to structure his days by giving him a briefing book each night that accounts for nearly every minute of the next day. It includes a summary of all his meetings, drafts of his speeches (which he almost never delivers word for word) and related background. No detail is too small.
"You depart shaking hands along the ropeline," Mr. Clinton is told in advance of a meeting with Treasury officials on Wednesday.
Knowing that they can push a President only so hard, aides are resigned to the boss's tardiness.
But a President gets a grace period mere citizens don't. As the commander of the U.S.S. Theodore Roosevelt was waiting for the President's helicopter to land on board recently, he looked at his watch and fretted that Mr. Clinton was more than a half-hour late. Then he stopped and said: "Hey, he's the commanding officer of the armed forces. He's never late."
 
Hunger for Details
 When she first worked for Governor Clinton in Arkansas, Carol H. Rasco, the White House domestic policy adviser, was taken aback when he would routinely call her as late as midnight to chat about policy. "My mother had taught me it was bad manners to call that late," recalled Ms. Rasco, a genteel Southerner of polished manners.
Eventually, Ms. Rasco got accustomed to the calls, which still persist. Many top aides, in fact, now know that when the phone rings between 9 P.M. and midnight, it is likely to be a call from the President. If they aren't home, their beepers will go off, with the message, "Pres US calling. Call WH operator." He'll call them to chat about minute policy details, or to keep abreast of the news. He called Mr. Stephanopoulos at 10:30 the other night to check on Defense Secretary Les Aspin, who was in the hospital.
But Mr. Clinton's true love of detail comes across best in the memos he scribbles to aides in his trademark wavy, indecipherable handwriting. Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, recently sent the President a memo specifying how the summer jobs money in the stimulus package would be allocated. It was full of details, but not enough for Mr. Clinton. He wrote, "I'd like to know which cities, how many jobs next year and projected for this year."
For Mr. Clinton's aides, the problem often is not carrying out his orders but understanding them.
"He has absolutely terribly handwriting," said John Podesta, Mr. Clinton's staff secretary, who handles the 300 or so pieces of paper that go to the President daily. "One of the people from the N.S.C. came in sheepishly the other day, asking us to decipher something. That happens all the time."
 
Reading List
 When he is not reading briefing papers, newspapers and letters, the President reads books -- a chapter here or there when he has time.
Stacked on the small table behind his desk in the Oval Office are the books he is reading this week.
*"Pandaemonium. Ethnicity in International Politics." A new book by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York.
*"A Testament of Hope: The Essential Writings of Martin Luther King Jr." A collection edited by James Melvin Washington.
*"The Search for Temperance Moon," a mystery by Douglas C. Jones set in Fort Smith, Ark., in 1892.
*"Preparing for the Twenty-First Century," a new book on global challenges by Paul Kennedy.
 
Back to Reality
 It may sometimes resemble a college dormitory full of zany overachievers, but it is the White House. And every once in a while, aides are reminded of the weight of the office.
Ask Heather Beckel, Mr. Stephanopoulos's assistant. The President, looking for an article by the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the ousted Haitian President, called Mr. Stephanopoulos, but he wasn't at his desk and Ms. Beckel picked up the phone, not noticing it was the long ring that means it's from the Oval Office.
"Hi, Heather, this is the President," Mr. Clinton said, nearly causing Ms. Beckel to freeze in place.
During the campaign, Ms. Beckel said she did not have such fears. "He used to just call and say, 'Hi, Heather, this is Bill.' "

HEADLINE: Called to Disturbance, Officers Slay Man

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
Police officers shot an unemployed doorman to death early yesterday morning after he pulled a gun on two uniformed officers as they investigated a disturbance at a 24-hour diner in Manhattan, the authorities said.
The man, Bekim Ahmeti, 20, of 83 Continental Place in the Mariners Harbor section of Staten Island, died at 8:15 A.M at St. Vincent's Hospital with four gunshot wounds to the chest and abdomen, said Sgt. Anthony Barlanti, a spokesman for the New York City Police Department. 
 The shooting occurred at 5 A.M. when several officers responded to a radio call about gunshots being fired in a large fight at the Moonstruck Diner, at 400 West 23d Street, at Ninth Avenue, in Chelsea, Sergeant Barlanti said. When the officers arrived, he said, they found about 20 people standing outside the diner. The fighting had stopped, but the smell of gunpowder lingered, he said.
As the officers tried to find out what happened, Mr. Ahmeti started to run, said Officer Scott Bloch, a police spokesman. Lieut. Michael Herer, 37, and Officer Joseph Dalton, 32, of the 10th Precinct, called out that they were police officers and ordered Mr. Ahmeti to stop, he said. Mr. Ahmeti stopped, pulled out a .38-caliber revolver, turned and aimed it at the officers, Sergeant Barlanti said. Before he could shoot, the officers fired six shots, striking him in the torso, the sergeant said. The lieutenant fired two shots from his .38-caliber revolver and the officer fired four shots from his 9-millimeter Smith & Wesson semi-automatic pistol, Officer Bloch said.
 
Father Disputes Account
 While the police said that Mr. Ahmeti was struck in the chest and abdomen, his father, Arif, said that his son had been shot in the back.
"Even if my son did pull a gun on the officers, they should have shot him in the legs to stop him from running," the father said. "They should not have shot him to kill him."
The father, who said he emigrated to New York from Albania 21 years ago, said he had not known that his son carried a gun. He said friends who were with his son at the diner said that he might have tried to run because he did not want to be arrested for carrying an unlicensed gun. He said that two months ago his son had been shot in the back and right hand in a drive-by shooting.
The father, who works as a doorman on Riverside Drive, said his son, the youngest of four children, had told him that he was taking the car to pick up his brother, Gazmend, also a doorman, near 84th Street and Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. He said his son apparently stopped at the diner to get something to eat before his brother got off work at 7 A.M. The younger Mr. Ahmeti had been unemployed for about a year, his father said.
Another man was arrested, the police said, and it was unclear if he was with Mr. Ahmeti. Ray McElroy of 609 West 189th Street in Manhattan was arrested and charged with possession of a weapon, a 38-caliber revolver. Investigators said Mr. McElroy was wearing a bullet-proof vest under his coat.
Lieutenant Herer, a night platoon commander in the 10th Precinct, and Officer Dalton have been placed on desk duty pending the outcome of an investigation, Officer Bloch said, which is routinely done in such cases. The incident is being reviewed by detectives in the 10th Precinct, the Manhattan District Attorney's office, the firearms and tactics review board and the Internal Affairs Bureau.

HEADLINE: Park Cutbacks Over the Years Cause Distress

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Just a few yards from the edge of the manicured Long Meadow in Brooklyn's Prospect Park -- where the New York Philharmonic plays each summer -- are pathways so trampled that they now have deep holes. Nearby trees are diseased and dying. An ornate archway, recently refurbished, is besmeared with graffiti and many of the catch basins are clogged, destroying the park's intricate drainage system.
After three years of cuts that have whittled the Parks and Recreation Department's budget and work force by 20 percent, the problems in Prospect Park are indicative of the distress that New Yorkers can expect to find in the city's vast network of parks as the warmer weather of spring begins to bring people back outdoors. And officials say that a decline in personnel and maintenance will make the job of restoring the parks a costly and difficult challenge. 
 Following the budget crisis of the mid-1970's and the deterioration of the parks that followed, the city spent about $1 billion in the 1980's to refurbish and restore the park system to its best condition in years. But the recent budget cuts and slump in maintenance threaten that progress, department officials and advocates for the parks maintain.
 
A Vulnerable Department
 For the Dinkins administration -- as it was for its predecessors -- there is the thorny issue of how to balance the desire for graceful and brilliant parks with the growing, more palpable demands like housing the city's burgeoning homeless population and improving public safety. Indeed, most city agencies have seen their budgets trimmed since the recession gripped the city. And cutting money from the parks' budget seems more acceptable to the public, if not a universally popular means of enabling the city to hire more police officers or provide more services for poorer families.
But the cuts affecting the parks have been among the most severe. "The parks took the deepest cuts because, when you have to cut, you can't cut positions where your staff earns money for the city," said Barbara J. Fife, Deputy Mayor for planning and development. "You have mandated spending like environmental positions, jobs in water systems that can't be cut. So when you're being pressed everywhere to get your staff down, this is one agency where it is possible."
Of course, the grass in the parks is still being cut, and the trash is still being collected, making many parks appear at first glance relatively unaffected by the decline in maintenance. But the parks are nonetheless becoming frayed, with so much erosion in service and maintenance that some officials argue that many will soon need drastic and costly overhaul.
"There are countless examples of maintenance that has been deferred," said Julius Spiegel, the parks commissioner in Brooklyn. "Ninety percent of our time now is spent picking up garbage, and little time is spent maintaining our buildings, our sewers, our infrastructure," he said. "The public doesn't see it all the time, but the parks are suffering."
While the conditions vary from one site to another, the more than 1,500 parks share a common plight. Much structural repair work is being left undone, and the number of workers has thinned too severely to keep up with the litter and debris. A great deal of patrolling by rangers was abandoned long ago, decrepit buildings are unattended, thousands of trees stand rotting and scores of public toilets have been closed because of neglected plumbing or structural decline.
"There just hasn't been enough money spent on the kind of maintenance the parks need," said Linda Davidoff, executive director of the Parks Council, an advocacy group. "No matter how much capital expenditure there has been in the past, if you don't continue the maintenance, the pristine condition of the park will not last long."
Despite receiving the most attention and having full-time workers devoted to maintenance, long-term planning and supervision, the city's large flagship parks are suffering along with the smaller ones. Besides Prospect Park, Central and Riverside parks in Manhattan, Van Cortlandt and Pelham Bay parks in the Bronx, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens and the Greenbelt in Staten Island, among others, show signs of the cutbacks.
In Pelham Bay Park, the city's largest, trees felled by last December's storm are still sitting on the ground. "A few years ago we could have taken care of that sort of thing quickly," said Cordell Schachter, an administrative manager with the Parks Department in the Bronx. And throughout the system, the snowstorm last weekend has added to the burden.
In Prospect Park, the lakes are being invaded by a tall, unsightly wild grass called phragmites -- there is no money to scour and reline the lake -- and graffiti has begun to resurface on buildings. The number of workers at Prospect Park stands at 42, down from 60 three years ago.
One of the biggest problems, park officials lament, is the near absence of nighttime security. "Because of the drop in security at night, we have seen a dramatic rise in vandalism, theft and break-ins in the park buildings at night," said Tupper W. Thomas, the administrator of Prospect Park. She added that nearly every building in the park needs substantial repairs, including in many cases repair of leaking roofs.
Today, 32 full-time workers maintain not only the vast Van Cortlandt Park, but also the dozen playgrounds and parks in the adjacent community board area. Three years ago, that job was performed by more than 50 workers.
In addition there are dozens of smaller parks -- like Julius Richman Park in the Bronx and the McDonald Playground in Brooklyn -- where daily maintenance has become a thing of the past. A decade ago most of these smaller neighborhood parks had at least one staff member who performed daily maintenance from sunup to sundown.
Now maintenance crews share responsibility for as many as a dozen sites and can visit each park only two or three times a week.
"We just can't do the kind of maintenance job we used to," said Frank Wright, a parks service worker, standing amid broken glass and litter in Julius Richman Park in the South Bronx. "And when you don't have the maintenance and people working in the park, that encourages the addicts and troublemakers to come into the park."
 
Cuts and Wounds
 Since 1990, the number of workers at city parks has dropped by more than 1,400, from 4,667 to the current 3,261. Long-term plans call for further reductions to about 2,600 in 1997. Meanwhile, the parks' budget has shrunk to $156.7 million for the current fiscal year, from $195 million in 1990. And plans for the next fiscal year call for the parks budget to drop a little more, by more than $1 million.
The decline is evident in other ways. In 1990 the Parks Department rated about two-thirds of the parks as being in acceptable condition; last summer the figure was about half. In the summer of 1989, 17 percent of the park's drinking fountains were inoperable. By last summer, 30 percent were broken. Also, the number of defective pieces of playground equipment had doubled between 1990 and last summer.
Despite the cuts in the annual maintenance, the Parks Department still has a capital budget of $100 million to finance long-term projects, such as reconstructing buildings, buying new playground equipment, purchasing new lighting systems or restoring park paths. But officials worry that without regular maintenance, the capital budget will be less effective.
"The effect of the cuts is that, 15 years ago, a park renovation would have lasted 15 years, if the park was properly maintained," said Kuo Ming Tsu, the park system's assistant commissioner for capital budgets. "But now, that time may now be cut by two-thirds."
Still, the involvement of some community groups has helped offset some of the cuts in maintenance. Also, there are the large, nonprofit civic organizations, which in the last two years have raised $54 million to finance projects ranging from restoring baseball fields and bridges in Central Park to restoring a carousel and planting new trees in Prospect Park. But some other community groups complain that these groups respond to the needs of just a handful of the city's most visible parks and maintain that many smaller, neighborhood parks are located in areas where residents don't have the financial resources to pay for refurbishing.
 
More Efficiency Sought
 Another way of compensating for the budget cuts is improving efficiency of the parks' maintenance workers. Betsy Gotbaum, the city's Parks Commissioner, said workers have begun developing more efficient work procedures. Mobile crews, for example, have started staggering their schedules of refueling, a process that often left drivers standing in city-operated gas lines.
And some classes provided by recreation centers -- such as aerobics or fencing -- are now provided for a small enrollment fee, rather than being financed by the city.
Still, many workers and parks officials say that, even with increased efficiency, they feel they are unable to keep up with the demands of maintaining the parks. "Our people are working harder than ever, and we have learned to do more with less," said Leroy Knowles, deputy chief of operations for the Bronx. "It's tough, but we're still trying to make it."

HEADLINE: Clinton and Aides Plan Strategy for High Court Nomination

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
President Clinton met with top advisers today to plot a strategy for choosing a new Supreme Court Justice, a process that aides said could take until the end of the Court term early this summer.
White House officials said no names were mentioned at the hourlong meeting. Nor did they discuss requirements for a Justice. Instead, they said, the talk centered on timing and mechanics. Participants included Vice President Al Gore, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff; Bruce Lindsey, the personnel director; Vince Foster, the deputy Presidential counsel, and Ronald Klain, associate counsel and a former law clerk to retiring Justice Byron R. White. 
 "They concluded that this can be a timely decision," said Mark D. Gearan, the deputy chief of staff, "but that we're not in a position of having to make an immediate decision. Justice White's timetable in terms of sitting through June allows for an opportunity to have a process that's deliberative and complete."
Though they want to be thorough, White House officials also said they did not want to linger so long as to cause weeks of speculation in the press over who would be nominated. Officials said they hoped Mr. Clinton would make his choice by the end of the current term in late June or early July, when Justice White said he would retire.
The 75-year-old conservative, the only sitting Justice appointed by a Democratic President, announced Friday that he would retire. While Mr. Clinton cited judgment, intelligence and experience as qualifications for a Justice, Mr. Clinton's advisers said that political considerations could not but help be a factor.
 
Mention of a Political Reward
 One close adviser to Mr. Clinton speculated, for example, that rather than a legal scholar, the President would pick a political figure from the battleground states of Illinois, Michigan or Ohio, which all went solidly for Mr. Clinton in last year's election. The adviser noted that the President had not given those states any reward for their support, which would be crucial for his re-election.
While they said names were not discussed at the meeting, White House officials said that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, the only person Mr. Clinton ever mentioned during the campaign as a prospective Justice, would certainly be under consideration.
In an interview today, Mr. Cuomo insisted that he did not want to discuss his possible candidacy, except to say: "I've talked enough about it. The last thing I'm going to do is have another go round like I did on the Presidency. It wasted everybody's time."
Officials of both the White House and the Senate Judiciary Committee said they were researching whether they would be restricted from picking a successor and seeking his confirmation before Justice White actually leaves the bench. Even if a new Justice cannot be confirmed by the end of the term, White House officials said they hoped the process could be in motion with a nominee selected. That way, the confirmation could be completed in the summer, giving the new Justice time to read petitions and briefs before the start of the fall term.
 
Giving Weight to Diversity
 White House officials also said the President would give weight to candidates of ethnic and sexual diversity, prompting an assortment of interest groups to begin pressing for particular candidates. In a reversal among lobbying groups not seen in years, liberal groups were positioning themselves for a large role in advising the Administration, while conservatives prepared to oppose a nominee that might not be to their liking.
Nan Aron, executive director of the Alliance for Justice, a liberal group, said, "We urge the President to look beyond the traditional settings of lawyering and make racial, ethnic and gender diversity one of the principal factors in his selection of the next Supreme Court Justice."
But conservatives urged moderation. "As to philosophy," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who serves on the Judiciary Committee, "I can only hope that President Clinton will, as did Presidents Reagan and Bush, avoid ideological litmus tests."
Mr. Clinton did not speak publicly today about the search for a Justice, but not knowing his remarks were being broadcast to reporters, he bantered about the process with friends and aides in the Oval Office before beginning his radio address this morning.
He joked about selecting the comedian Jay Leno for the Court. Then he teasingly mentioned James Carville, his colorful strategist during the campaign. "Carville's a lawyer," Mr. Clinton said. "I think that would be interesting, you know. Then we'd have our, the things that he and I say to each other like, 'Squeal like a pig under a gate' would be in a Supreme Court opinion."
After getting the one-minute cue for his address on the economy, Mr. Clinton put on a serious Presidential voice and said: "Good morning. Today I have decided to appoint James Carville to the United States Supreme Court. He has plans to get our country moving again."
Then, seconds before the radio broadcast, Mr. Clinton said, "I'm terrified I'm going to say something like that without thinking about it."

HEADLINE: Port Authority Crisis Is Over, but Problems Persist

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Three weeks after the bombing of the World Trade Center, the managers of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are caught in a paradoxical mood.
Despite the shock and disruption of the attack, agency officials are exhilarated at what they see as a successful all-out effort to restore the buildings and are confident that the bombing will not permanently damage the authority's operations. But beneath the can-do zeal that the agency has brought to the current crisis is a more sober assessment of long-range problems that have nothing to do with the Feb. 26 attack. 
 The managers are cheered because the first tenants temporarily evacuated from the stricken towers began moving back in last week, and others show little sign of wanting to leave permanently. Meanwhile, the rebuilding of the underground garage is going smoothly and the arrests of suspects in the attack have helped to quell the feeling of defeat that can arise from unpunished crimes.
 
Problems Persist
 But longer-range problems, rooted in economics and demographics, persist for the nation's biggest and richest public developer.
For one thing, the authority's books are lopsided, with some parts of its $1.9 billion in annual operations making buckets of money and others, notably mass transit, losing ever larger sums. While the Port Authority is still rich in cash and assets, growth in its profitable ventures is flat, while the losses are rising. Moreover, agency officials say, the New York-New Jersey metropolitan region is economically mature, with its greatest growth behind it and its population moving away from the authority's core waterfront area of operation.
These trends leave the agency with diminishing room to maneuver, when political leaders are looking to the Port Authority to take the lead in stimulating growth in employment and investment.
 
Tolls, Fees and Rents
 The Port Authority, created in 1921 to develop transportation and other development projects for New York and New Jersey, is a largely independent public agency run by a board appointed by the governors of the two states. Most of the agency's nearly $2 billion in annual income comes from Hudson River bridge and tunnel tolls, airport fees and rents in the World Trade Center, but it also operates the PATH system, several industrial development districts and -- its original mission -- the New York harbor shipping ports.
In the short term, the management of this vast operation may feel entitled to take some muted satisfaction from the aftermath of the bombing, despite the deaths of six people in the attack and the still-unreckoned costs of restoring the buildings.
 
Going to Funerals
 "There are two things going on here," said Richard C. Leone, chairman of the Port Authority Board of Commissioners, in a recent interview. "One is the emotion and sadness that was really draining for the top people who went from funeral to funeral after the bombing.
"But the opposite of that is the exhilaration many of us feel in seeing this group of literally hundreds of dedicated people working a sort of fighting-Sea Bees way to overcome and recover from this. I honestly think if you could bottle whatever we have here we would all stop worrying about American competitiveness."
Mr. Leone and the Port Authority's executive director, Stanley Brezenoff, stress the agency's determination to come out of the bombing with new vigor.
The $500 million renovation of the aging World Trade Center, begun two years ago, will resume once bomb-damage repairs are made, as will plans to link the region's three airports by rail to Queens and Manhattan. In the distance is the prospect of a second span over the Arthur Kill to Staten Island, paralleling the overburdened Goethals Bridge, at a cost of a half-billion dollars.
 
Failed to See Danger
 Insurance will cover most of the $5 million a week in lost rentals at the trade center, as well as the lawsuits that are sure to result from the bombing, officials say. But the agency must still deal with criticism that it failed to take adequate precautions against terrorism. Several times in recent years, Port Authority officials drew up antiterrorism plans that specifically noted the vulnerability of the World Trade Center garages.
"I don't want to minimize the human tragedy," Mr. Leone said. "I don't want to trivialize the lawsuits and the hearings and the entanglements that lie ahead. It will be open season on us all. But on the other hand I think we will come out of this with a renewed sense that it is worth having an institution such as this."
 
Long-Term Positive Effect
 Mitchell I. Moss, a New York University professor of urban affairs who has often charged the Port Authority with a lack of vision, suggested that the long-term effect of the blast might even be positive.
"Is this a Chernobyl for them?" he said. "No. I think people could argue that they are going to be safer at the World Trade Center than in other buildings after this, because the Port Authority is going to be more aware of the dangers. The real question is, is the Port Authority going to see this as an opportunity to rebuild their reputation and to take a leadership role in this region, or are they just going to go back to business as usual?"
But it is clear, people in and out of the Port Authority acknowledge, that the huge agency does not have the scope and breadth that it once did to reshape the very skyline of the country's biggest metropolis. Its most recent plan to rebuild Kennedy International Airport nearly from the ground up faltered after at least $100 million in wasted costs in 1989 as the recession bit deeper and the airlines balked at paying any additional costs. A year later, the agency lost $25 million building a commercial fish port in Brooklyn that failed to draw any fishing boats.
Long-promised plans for new industrial development sites and the Hunters Point housing project in Queens are still nowhere in sight, while in 1990, Los Angeles overtook New York in what was once the Port Authority's core business, ocean shipping.
 
Winter Storm Woes
 In December, meanwhile, a winter storm flooded several PATH tunnels under the Hudson river, adding to the costs of a service that is already the Port Authority's biggest single money-loser. And last weekend's blizzard added to the agency's woes by shutting down all four of its airports -- Kennedy, Newark International, La Guardia and Teterboro, N.J., the little suburban airport -- for 24 hours.
The Port Authority separates its operations into five categories: interstate transportation, air terminals, marine operations, world trade and regional development. Of those, only two, air terminals and world trade, made money last year. In interstate transportation, the bridges and tunnels were all immensely profitable, but the money disappears into the $230 million mass transit loss for PATH and Port Authority Bus Terminal operations.
Those losses are likely to increase at the rate of inflation, at least, said Barry Weintrob, chief financial officer, while the bridges and tunnels that subsidize them are nearing capacity, and income from them is projected to rise at only 1 percent per year.
 
No Toll Increases
 Mr. Brezenoff has committed the Port Authority to avoiding toll increases on the Hudson River crossings through next year. But with the agency's losses from unprofitable operations rising and profits from the money-makers essentially flat, officials on both sides of the Hudson expect that a new round of toll increases is inevitable, and likely to ignite a fight with New Jersey officials on behalf of the state's commuters, who pay the bulk of the tolls.
Mr. Leone and Mr. Brezenoff refused to concede the eventual need for higher tolls, but Mr. Leone granted that the authority has entered a period of austerity and retrenchment.
"Everybody has had to pull back," he said. "Some of our businesses are more mature. Aviation is not going to grow, real estate is not going to show the same meteoric rise in incomes, so we are not going to see the resources that we had when some of our riskier projects were started. Instead, a lot of our activities are going to be associated with improving our existing facilities."
The bold airport rail links will not depend on tolls. Assuming approval by the Federal Aviation Administration, the Port Authority's tax of $3 per departing passenger at the three main airports, imposed last year, will be extended to pay the estimated $2 billion that linking the airports with Manhattan will cost.
Before the bombing the Port Authority spoke of the air-link projects as tentative. But its leaders now describe the system with certainty, with the final stages due for completion after the turn of the century -- as if to underscore that the agency is still up to its old role as master builder.
"Those systems will be built," Mr. Brezenoff said.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
In Wake of Crises, Cuomo Makes Lemonade

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 19

 BODY:
After watching his poll ratings slide while struggling with the state's budget crisis, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo seems to have discovered that a different kind of crisis can sometimes work to his advantage.
In the past three weeks, the bombing of the World Trade Center, the crippling weekend blizzard and the struggle to save The New York Post have provided Mr. Cuomo with opportunities to cast himself in every politician's favorite roles -- general, dealmaker and hometown booster -- all of which play better on television than sparring with the Legislature. 
 "When the people see him now, they realize why they elected him," said John A. Marino, the state Democratic Party chairman and a top political aide to the Governor. "It's the personal Cuomo, the familial Cuomo, the father figure. And with budget negotiations and other things going on, that's not the way Cuomo has been coming out."
Now Mr. Cuomo is likely to receive another public relations boost in the form of speculation about whether he will be nominated to fill the Supreme Court seat being vacated by Justice Byron R. White.
 
A Welcome Diversion
 Political strategists believe the Governor's approval rating in New York improved each time he encouraged speculation about his Presidential ambitions. They assume the same thing will happen now, if only because attention will be diverted from the bad news of cutting budgets and raising taxes.
If Mr. Cuomo does not find himself on the Court, he is expected to run in 1994 for a fourth four-year term. Toward that end, he has been trying to burnish his popularity, a process that his aides realize must be incremental.
They know that the timely passage of balanced budgets will help, as will holding the line on tax increases. And they know they must take advantage of unexpected events that offer positive moments in the spotlight.
Mr. Cuomo's responses to the various crises have not by any means been exclusively self-promotional. To a large extent, he has done what leaders are expected to do at such times -- calm the public, restore morale and direct what Mr. Cuomo calls a "return to normalcy."
 
'Back Front and Center'
 But the crises gave Mr. Cuomo innumerable opportunities to appear in charge. He has been busy declaring emergencies, calling out the National Guard, monitoring rescue and cleanup efforts, rounding up newspaper investors and, as he has mentioned in almost every interview, conferring with President Clinton.
He also has been talking about his efforts in a stream of media interviews and news conferences. When not talking to Larry King or Charlie Rose, he was appearing on CNN's "Newsmaker Sunday," NBC's "Today" show, ABC's "Good Morning America" and a variety of local television and radio shows.
His presence in New York City has seemed almost more mayoral than gubernatorial, a perception that was exaggerated by the fact that Mayor David N. Dinkins was in Japan on the day the trade center was bombed.
"There's no doubt that Cuomo has been making the circuit," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion. "This has been a rare time when he's back front and center."
On occasion, Mr. Cuomo has shown a flair for the flamboyant, including Thursday's MacArthuresque return to his offices on the 57th floor of the World Trade Center, fulfilling a pledge to become the first tenant to reoccupy the building.
 
A Stress on Survival
 The Governor also claimed at a news conference several weeks ago that in the long run the bombing would be good for New York City because the city's calm response might soften the image created in recent years by disturbances in Crown Heights and the rape of a jogger in Central Park.
The trade center bombing and the snowstorm gave Mr. Cuomo new opportunities to reiterate a favorite political theme, that New York, and by implication its governor, have long been victims of outside forces.
"This is New York," he said on the Today show on March 1. "We'll survive this. We survived depressions, recessions, presidents who sent vice presidents here to make fun of us. After what we've been through over the last three or four years, this one we'll do with one hand."
And like Ronald Reagan, he has made effective use of anecdotes to personify the spirit of his state.
After the trade center blast, he spoke about Kevin Shea, a firefighter who was seriously injured while searching for survivors. This week, he has been telling the story of Karen Woodcock, a Saratoga County woman who gave birth to "a brand new New Yorker" after a state snowplow cleared her driveway, enabling an ambulance to take her to the hospital.
 
A Double-Edged Post
 Whether Mr. Cuomo will benefit politically from his role with The Post is more ambiguous. He is at least partly responsible for the emergence of Steven Hoffenberg as a potential owner for the paper, and by extension, for Mr. Hoffenberg's onetime ally, Abraham Hirschfeld, who despite an open rebellion last week from the paper's staff now seems to be the leading bidder for the troubled paper.
At the end of last week, Mr. Cuomo was trying to line up new investors to replace Mr. Hirschfeld.
Mr. Cuomo has portrayed his involvement with the paper as the ultimate act of political selflessness. His goal, he has said, is to save jobs and preserve an alternative editorial voice, even though that voice often has railed against him.
"In the end they're going to beat me up anyway, whoever owns the thing," he said on WNYW-TV's "Good Day New York" on Monday.
Even Mr. Cuomo's political opponents agree that he has helped himself in recent weeks. But some pollsters believe the public's image of Mr. Cuomo will be hard to change after a decade in office, and Republican leaders question whether the events of March 1993 will be remembered in November 1994.
"Three weeks in 10 years doesn't make a man," said the state Republican Party chairman, William D. Powers. "And it doesn't make a governor."

HEADLINE: Casino Issue Divides Mohawk Reservation in New York

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. REGIS MOHAWK RESERVATION, N.Y.

 BODY:
There is a postcard quality to the winter scene outside Dave George's door, where birch forests and snow-swept wheat fields meet the St. Lawrence River. But to many Mohawk Indians, it is a landscape of bad memories, the scene of a divisive, unsolved crime.
In May 1990, two Indians died near here in a gun battle between rival Mohawk groups. The shooting, for which no one has been arrested, was ostensibly over casino gambling on the reservation, but Mohawk leaders say it was rooted in more elemental conflicts over moral values, tribal traditions, money and power. 
 Today the casinos are shuttered and the guns silent, but the underlying tensions remain. And amid talk of reopening the gambling halls, Mr. George and others are keeping their rifles clean and close at hand, awaiting the spark that could reignite their simmering feud.
"Sure, there will be trouble again," said Mr. George, a broad-shouldered, 47-year-old fisherman who opposes gambling. "People are going to make a stand. It's going to be like the Civil War, North against South."
In the coming weeks, negotiators for the Mohawks and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo are expected to complete an agreement that once signed by Mr. Cuomo and the United States Secretary of the Interior, would allow casino games like roulette, blackjack and craps on the 14,000-acre Mohawk reservation. Some Mohawks say they can have a casino operating by summer.
 
Wariness, Not Open Arms
 The Oneida Indians of central New York State, who have been more united than the Mohawks in supporting gambling, have already reached a tentative agreement with Mr. Cuomo's office and are awaiting his signature to open a $10 million casino near Syracuse. It would be the first high-stakes casino in the state.
While for-profit casino gambling has been welcomed on scores of impoverished Indian reservations nationwide as a financial boon, many Mohawks in this border region are deeply wary of the immense wealth casinos are sure to attract.
Some Indians fear an invasion of disruptive neon-lit businesses and organized crime. Others say gambling engenders a fast-money mentality at odds with traditional Mohawk values. Still others contend casinos will infringe Mohawk sovereignty by opening the reservation to state police officers, gambling inspectors and possibly Federal tax collectors.
But for most, the strongest memories are of 1990, when anti-gambling Mohawks blocked roads, attacked businesses and virtually closed the reservation for five weeks in protests against eight casinos that had opened without state approval. When pro-gambling Mohawks tried to tear down the roadblocks, the conflict escalated first into fistfights and then into firefights, culminating in the two fatal shootings and the closing of the casinos.
 
Time Has Healed Little
 Time has done little to heal the wounds. Families have been riven by the dispute. Anti-gambling Mohawks refuse to patronize stores owned by pro-gambling Mohawks. Racketeering suits have been filed against state officials and pro-gambling Mohawks blaming them for the violence. Former friends and allies now accuse each other of links to organized crime. One pro-gambling chief has even accused another pro-gambling chief of accepting a bribe from a potential casino operator.
"What you have here is a community in dysfunction," said Harold L. Oakes, a Mohawk who is part of a group trying to mediate between rival factions. "A lot of it has to do with 1990. A lot of it has to do with blood feuds. A lot of it has to do with different religions. Gambling will just bring all the tensions to the surface."
The Mohawk dispute has also reverberated in the state capital. Some legislators say casino gambling could revive tourism in places like Niagara Falls and the Catskills, and they see gambling on Indian reservations as a first step toward allowing casinos elsewhere. Gambling opponents have called for Mr. Cuomo to reject the Mohawk and Oneida compacts to prevent casinos from spreading across the state.
 
Anything Charities Can Do
 But there is little Mr. Cuomo, who opposes casino gambling, or the Legislature can do to derail Indian gambling. Under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988, states are required to allow Indians to operate, for profit, any gambling game that charities and other nonprofit groups are allowed to run. In New York State that means most casino-style card and dice games, though not slot machines.
Mr. Cuomo can negotiate for state regulation of games, as he did with the Oneidas. But if he refuses to sign a gambling agreement, the tribes can ask a Federal judge to impose one.
Since the law was passed, 58 tribes in 18 states -- about one third of all the tribes outside of Alaska -- have signed compacts. According to industry estimates, Indian casinos generated $6 billion in revenues last year. The Oneidas have predicted that their casino could earn over $50 million in its first year, drawing mostly from Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse.
Although a casino is scheduled to open in Quebec Province this year, the Mohawks say their casino can still attract a large clientele from Montreal and Ottawa, which are each a 90-minute drive away.
 
A Bitter Power Struggle
 Like advocates of Indian gambling elsewhere, pro-gambling Mohawks say casinos would create thousands of new jobs and provide money for a host of beneficial programs, from small business loans to college scholarships to housing for the elderly.
But unlike many other tribes, the Mohawks have been racked by bitter rivalries among factions divided by geography, religion and politics.
"It has been a power struggle over who is going to govern the reservation," said Chief John S. Loran, one of three members of the Mohawk tribal council, the elected governing body, which would run the casino under the state compact. "Gaming is just a vehicle some people have used to split the community."
The son of an ironworker and founder of a construction company, Mr. Loran, 34, represents a budding Mohawk business community, which has experienced robust growth in recent years from the sale of tax-free gasoline and cigarettes to non-Indians, many from Canada.
 
Christians and Non-Christians
 "Casino revenues will trickle down to help everyone," he said, estimating that earnings could top $100 million next year. "We'll have new restaurants, motels and shops."
But many Mohawks -- a third or more, by some estimates -- consider the tribal council part of the United States Government and will not participate in annual elections. These Indians are mostly non-Christians who consider themselves less assimilated than pro-gambling Mohawks, many of whom are baptized Christians. They have their own clan leaders, who deride gambling as a get-rich-quick scheme for an elite and consider it an offense to Mohawk values.
"We look at Las Vegas and everything is centered around money," said Charlie Patton, a member of the traditional, or longhouse, council. "Do we want to be a nation of Cadillac owners or a people who live in peace?"
Many Mohawks also fear that the tribe will fall prey to organized crime. One tribal council chief, L. David Jacobs, has accused Mr. Loran of accepting a bribe from a potential casino operator. Mr. Loran denied the accusation, calling Mr. Jacobs "a paranoid schizophrenic."
 
Warrior Society in Shadows
 A wild card in the gambling debate is a shadowy group known as the Warrior Society. Its members, whose numbers are not publicly known, promote a militant brand of nationalism that advocates reclaiming Mohawk land and opposes government intervention on the reservation, which they call Akwesasne. They have supported gambling as a means of giving Mohawks economic power.
But what role they will play in the current dispute is unclear. In 1990, Warrior members wearing bandanas across their faces and brandishing automatic weapons provided security for illegal casinos. Now, however, Warrior members say they oppose the proposed compact because it would allow state police and inspectors onto the reservation.
"When we want to open a casino, it will be on our terms," said Mark Montour, the Cornell-educated proprietor of "Smoke Cignals," a cigarette shop, who is an active supporter of the Warriors. "The way they want us to do it is like running Off Track Betting."
Geography has also played a role in the conflict. Akwesasne, the traditional name for the Mohawk land that straddles the border, has about 7,500 residents, about equally divided between the United States and Canada. Each side is governed by a separate council. The Canadian council strongly opposes gambling, which has been proposed only for the American side, and that stand has caused the American council to accuse it of interfering in the American side's affairs.
 
A Way Station for Smuggling
 The reservation's border location has made it a way station for smuggling drugs, weapons, cigarettes and people to and from Canada, law enforcement officials say. Opponents of gambling say casinos will only fuel such illegal activities by attracting criminal groups to the reservation.
The result, they say, will be violence, Mohawk against Mohawk, in a battle for the tribe's future.
"Gambling breaks down our cultural values," said Chief Jake Swamp, a leading opponent of gambling. "And what I hear from people is that they are not going to take it any longer."

HEADLINE: Neither Malthus Nor a Luddite Be

 BODY:
To the Editor:
George Sai-Halasz's commentary on "Stanching the Loss of Good Jobs" ("Count In the Computer Effect," Letters, Feb. 28) puts the blame for rising unemployment on computers. He asserts that as the cost of computers decreases and the tasks that they can do multiply, "the vast majority of the population, through no fault of its own, has no economic justification for drawing a sustenance." 
 Malthus would be proud of this. For Malthus, "a man who is born into a world already possessed . . . has no claim of right to the smallest portion of food." Malthus, too, never considered redistribution of income or wealth as a possibility.
Blaming tools, such as computers, for unemployment is the same as blaming the poor for the existence of poverty. If computers double our productivity, we can cut our working day in half, without a decrease in wages. What is so sacrosanct about the eight-hour day? It was a 16-hour day 200 years ago.
I agree with Mr. Sai-Halasz that the major problem of our society is the tremendous disparity in the distribution of wealth. However, until we correct this inequality, we will be constantly exorted by neo-Malthusian and neo-Luddite arguments to control populations or destroy machines.
 
A. T. PAPATHANASIS
New Britain, Conn., March 1
 
The author is an associate professor of economics at Central Connecticut University.

HEADLINE: Cost of Heart Revival Put at $150,000 per Survivor

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., March 20

 BODY:
A hospital's practice of reviving patients whose hearts stop beating costs more than $150,000 for each survivor, a study has found.
The study found that most of those given cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, in hospital wards never regain the ability to breathe on their own. Instead, they spend their final days on respirators in intensive-care units, often running up high bills. 
 The study was conducted by doctors from Duke University, who followed 146 patients given CPR after suffering cardiac arrest in general medical and surgical wards from 1988 to 1991. Eighty-four patients, or 58 percent, were revived, but only seven patients, or 5 percent, got well enough to leave the hospital.
The researchers found that the total costs of saving the lives of the 84 patients was $1.1 million. But when the cost was measured in terms of those who went on to lead meaningful lives for a period, it was $150,000 for each of the seven. Nationally, CPR is tried on about one-third of all patients who die in hospitals. Many are elderly and terminally ill from heart ailments, cancer and other diseases.
After the patients are revived, their medical bills rise sharply because most are transferred to intensive care and put on expensive life-support systems.
"It's a medical avalanche," said Dr. Christopher O'Connor, one of the Duke researchers. "You trigger everything."
Dr. O'Connor and Dr. Mark Thel presented the findings on Tuesday at a meeting of the American College of Cardiology.
Dr. O'Connor said CPR first gained routine use during operations, when it often worked well. But it has since been used on patients in all parts of hospitals with little thought given to the cost of interrupting death.
Dr. O'Connor urged doctors to ask their patients how they would like to be treated if their hearts stopped beating. While hospitals are required to ask such questions, it is usually done by clerks rather than doctors.
 
Guidelines on Counseling
 And when doctors bring up the subject, he said, they should keep the price in mind. "We feel that the cost of CPR should be considered when the doctor counsels patients about whether they should get it," he said.
The researchers said doctors should be reluctant to recommend CPR to people who are gravely ill.
Typically, hospitals try to revive all patients after cardiac arrest unless a specific "do not resuscitate" order has been given by the patient.
"When you look at the way we treat patients at the extremes of life, it's plain there is no reason why we doctors can't allow people to die with dignity," Dr. Adolph Hutter of Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston said in an interview at the meeting.
The cost of caring for patients in the last months of life has become a matter of concern, especially as health economists look for ways to restrain costs.
In a similar study of life-prolonging treatment for critically ill cancer patients, published last month in The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers found that very expensive care usually brought little added survival. Among the 150 patients in the study, those who spent any time in intensive care for reasons other than post-surgical recovery ran up subsequent hospital bills of $82,845 to $189,339 for each year of life gained.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Plants Said to Be Vulnerable to Bombings

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The bombing of the World Trade Center and the ease with which an intruder invaded the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in February suggest that nuclear power plants may be far more vulnerable to terrorist attacks than previously assumed, experts told a Senate subcommittee today.
The two incidents underscored a suddenly worrisome gap in current regulations, they said: plant owners are prepared for attacks by well-trained commandoes, but they are not required to safeguard against car bombs. 
 The experts are becoming increasingly concerned as details emerge about the World Trade Center bombing on Feb. 26 and an incident on Feb. 7 in which a former mental patient sped past the guard shack at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near Harrisburg, Pa., crashed his station wagon through a metal door and drove 60 feet inside the turbine hall.
The man, although unarmed, was loose in the plant for four hours.
Ivan Selin, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, told the subcommittee that the two events had prompted his agency to rethink its security regulations.
Mr. Selin, who acknowledged that his agency's assessment was based on "one part hard data and several parts judgment," said the commission thought that a nuclear plant was not an attractive target because destroying one would not gain sympathy or support for the perpetrators. He also said that the driver of a truck bomb would be on a suicide mission.
Others disputed him on both points.
Mr. Selin said that even if a big bomb was set off in a turbine hall, a radiation release was unlikely, but that a big enough blast could hurt safety systems and leave the plant "skating on thin ice."
Bruce Hoffman, a terrorism expert at the Rand Corporation, said of the World Trade Center blast, "If amateurs using ordinary, commercially available materials can fashion a simple bomb and cause so much damage and destruction, one shudders to think what international terrorism's genuine professionals could accomplish.
 
'A Warning Earthquake'
 "One similarly shudders to think what professional terrorists, well-armed and trained in combat skills, driving something more formidable than a Plymouth station wagon, could accomplish should they decide that the defenses and security measures at this country's commercial nuclear power plants were permeable," he told the subcommittee on Clean Air and Nuclear Regulation of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works.
The subcommittee chairman, Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, said, "The break-in at Three Mile Island in February was a warning bell, and what happened a month later in New York was a warning earthquake."
At the hearing, Phillip Clark, president of GPU Nuclear Corporation, which owns Three Mile Island, showed a videotape of the route the intruder was believed to have taken, first by car and then on foot. Senator Lieberman observed that the plant "looked like a soft target."
Eldon V. C. Greenberg, representing two watchdog groups, the Nuclear Control Institute, which is concerned with weapons proliferation, and the Committee to Bridge the Gap, a safety group, said that for years the commission had assumed that truck bombs were not credible and that if they became credible, there would be warning. "In a span of less than three weeks, both those pillars have been demolished," he said.
But Harry B. Brandon 3d, the deputy assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said, "Our current assessment is that the threat is very low." There is no intelligence indicating a trend from either the Three Mile Island incident or the World Trade Center bombing, he said.
Mr. Selin told the subcommittee that regulations were designed not to prevent an attack but to assure that no radioactive material would be released. But utility executives said that if they thought bombs were likely they would invest in protective measures to protect many millions of dollars worth of nonnuclear equipment.

HEADLINE: A Bitter Storm Leaves Winners and Losers

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOMERSET, N.J., March 19

 BODY:
Last Friday, before the weekend blizzard blew in, Frank Santangelo Jr. had 46 tons of ice-melting rock salt piled in the lumber yard of his store, Franks Hardware, here. On Monday night, it was all sold, along with most of his snow shovels. Count him as one of the winners in the storm.
Also on Friday, Charles Peterson of Peterson's Nursery in Princeton had row upon row of daffodils, crocuses and mums carefully timed to bloom for what was supposed to be the first big weekend of the spring gardening season. As the snow fell and shoppers stayed home, the flowers bloomed and drooped. Count him as one who lost. 
 Throughout the New York metropolitan region, the Blizzard of '93 dispensed profit and penalty with magisterial symmetry. It liberated schoolchildren from classes but sent parents hunting for scarce baby sitters. It crushed roofs under the weight of snow and ice, and left roofers with more work than they could handle. To the familiar term "snowbound" it added a modern cognate, "plow-bound," for the thousands of driveways that became barricaded behind iced-over drifts heaped up by municipal plows, awaiting exhausted but happy private plow operators like Jim Zappi of Ossining, N.Y.
"What a storm!" Mr. Zappi cheered. "I wish we could have another one."
A final tally of what the storm cost can never be known, since the drifts were fought and prices paid in as many ways as there are households, and there are about 7.6 million of them, in the region. The three states have already begun asking Washington for help paying for state and municipal snow removal costs, which have amounted to an estimated $129 million for New York State, $30 million in New Jersey and $5.9 million in Connecticut.
 
'What Killed Us'
 Those numbers mean that for a lot of municipalities, annual snow removal budgets are already depleted for the year, with next fall's storms still ahead, not to mention any surprises that the spring may bring.
"What killed us was the ice on top of the snow," said Clifford Steele, head of administration for Paramus, N.J. "A normal storm would have cost us about eight grand in overtime, but with the ice, it just about doubled it. After the snow we've already had, that doesn't leave much left for the rest of the year."
President Clinton last week gave the states approval to apply for emergency snow removal reimbursements, which are based on a portion of the costs of clearing certain roads for emergency access. Because the emergency aid covers the cost of plowing only one lane on certain roads, the final level of aid will be far less than the total state and local plowing bill.
State governments are also trying to reckon the costs of wind and water damage, and early estimates suggest that because the storm moved inland and winds shifted offshore the next day, the harm done was far less than the heavy winds and high tides that struck before Christmas and again on March 4.
"We don't have a damage assessment yet," said Jon Shure, the spokesman for Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey. But, he said, "I don't think it will amount to enough to justify applying for Federal disaster relief."
 
Many Calls for Jobs
 The second big storm of the season, on March 4, lifted the shingles from Laura Lovgren's Monmouth Beach, N.J., home. The gaps were covered only with tarp, awaiting the roofer, when the snow and wind came a week later. Now she has a partially bare roof again and water damage to boot. Three storms in three months have made her and her husband, Thomas, second-guess their decision to move to the Jersey Shore community in 1991, doubts that may be harder to quell with each new storm.
Nancy Rumph, who helps her husband, Ben, operate Ben's Roofing in Monmouth, said she had fielded 300 phone calls seeking repairs for the storms. "We haven't caught up with work from the first storm," she said, "and the second storm caused work from the first one to blow away."
Mr. Zappi, the plow operator, who is president of John Dos Anjos Landscaping in Ossining, worked all weekend with his four employees, his dump trucks and loaders clearing parking lots in Westchester County and in Fairfield County, Conn. He gave up all but about seven hours sleep, he said, between Saturday morning and Monday morning, but made about $25,000 from the work.
But Richard McKnight, head of Manpower Temporary Services in Stamford, found that not all able-bodied workers were willing to spend a weekend of shoveling, even if it did pay $10 to $12 per hour.
"We got some requests for snow shovelers and we could find them, but not like we used to be able to," he said. "Snow shoveling has historically been a young people's job and a bottom-of-the-economic-barrel type of job, and it's getting tough finding people who are willing to do that kind of work."
 
Weekend Hibernation
 And home is where the people stayed, said Lou Funk, manager of the Davidson's supermarket in Princeton, N.J.
"Every time there's a storm forecast, it's madness around here," he said. "Everyone comes in for milk, bread and a dozen eggs. The only difference is that this time they also picked up about seven videos each."
Mr. Peterson, the Princeton nurseryman, figured that the storm cost cost him $10,000 in sales, and this weekend, with snow still heavy on the ground, would be little better.
Beyond money made or lost to the storm, Steven Montello of Mont Management, a Stamford, Conn., apartment management firm, counted the more intangible benefits of neighborliness as one of the storm's dividends.
"People in condos tend to stick to themselves and leave the snow removal to the management company, so I was just overwhelmed by the number of people who were just happy to be outside and pitching in," Mr. Montello said. "People were out in their parking lots all day, helping each other, and it was a great feeling."

HEADLINE: Wilbur Daniels, 70, Garment Union Official, Dies

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Wilbur Daniels, a former top officer of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and a civic leader, died yesterday at home in Manhattan at the age of 70.
The cause was a heart ailment, his family said. 
 Mr. Daniels served the union for 44 years, starting as a researcher fresh out of college at the age of 19. Originally trained in economics, he shifted to the union's legal staff after earning a law degree in night classes at New York University. He was the assistant to the union's president, David Dubinsky, and became a vice president in 1969 and executive vice president in 1973.
His work included negotiating major contracts, revising the union constitution, developing programs for immigrant members, lobbying to protect American jobs and handling other legal and legislative duties.
 
Organized Ad Campaign
 The "look for the union label" commercial, with a chorus of union members singing the jingle, was a project he helped organize. In 1981 he opposed new government rules allowing manufacturing at home, saying: "Lifting this ban simply will bring the sweatshop back into the home. It's something we thought we got rid of 40 years ago."
Mr. Daniels was the chairman of the State Advisory Council on Employment and Unemployment Insurance and was the vice chairman of the State Job Development Authority. He was also a former executive director of the National Board of the Coat and Suit Industry.
Since leaving the union in 1987 he worked as the executive director of the S. H. and Helen R. Scheuer Foundation, which promotes the arts and Jewish life and education.
He was the Metropolitan Opera's executive committee chairman and was also instrumental in finding the Roundabout Theater a new home in a former union auditorium. He also served on the boards of the Lincoln Center, United Housing Foundation, New York Urban Coalition and American Arbitration Association.
Born in Detroit, Mr. Daniels grew up in New York City.
His survivors include his wife of 29 years, the former Patricia Heyman; a daughter, Ann, of Oakland, Calif., and a granddaughter.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
A St. Patrick's Day Call From the White House

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
St. Patrick's Day was a political challenge for Mayor David N. Dinkins, who had sided with homosexuals in their unsuccessful effort to march openly under their own banner in the annual parade.
Mr. Dinkins's support of an inclusive parade -- and his refusal to march in the traditional affair put on by the Order of Ancient Hibernians -- no doubt will hurt him among some Irish-American voters this fall. But, because it was also the Mayor's lawyers who obtained a court order last week preventing the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organization from staging its own march on Fifth Avenue before the parade, several advocates for gay and lesbian causes said that Mr. Dinkins might have lost support among some homosexual voters as well. 
 So touchy was the political balancing act on St. Patrick's Day that in midafternoon, mayoral aides suddenly announced that Mr. Dinkins would rush to an unscheduled meeting at the White House at 7 that evening. A request came about noon, the aides said, to meet with Robert E. Rubin, the chairman of President Clinton's National Economic Council. The subject: a Presidential task force on the "urban core" that was to hold its first session the following day.
The Mayor's shift in schedule required the cancellation of his planned appearance at a dinner with the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick here in New York. Skeptical reporters asked Mr. Dinkins if he was rushing off to Washington to avoid a potential confrontation with conservative Irish-Americans angry with the Mayor over the parade.
"I've been called to the White House by Bob Rubin," Mr. Dinkins said. "I think that is pretty important."
The Mayor noted that he hosted a St. Patrick's Day breakfast that morning at Gracie Mansion and that he had attended two other celebratory breakfasts. "I've been around," he said. "I've seen most of the players. I'm not avoiding anyone."
But a political adviser to the Mayor, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that while Mr. Rubin's request had in fact come at the last minute, Mr. Dinkins's political strategists had also encouraged him not to attend the dinner out of concern that there might be a confrontation.
 
Unfair Political Advantage?
 It is an election year in New Jersey, and legislators are turning their hands to the task of eliminating what they say is an unfair advantage enjoyed by certain candidates. Just who those candidates are, of course, is very much in the eye of the beholder.
The Republican-controlled Legislature is pondering legislation that would forbid a sitting governor running for re-election from appearing in broadcast commercials promoting the state. Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, has been on the airwaves of late in public interest radio spots -- with the mother of the pop singer Whitney Houston urging prospective mothers to get prenatal care, with the Consumer Affairs Director, Emma Byrne, warning of telephone scams, and in promotions for "Jersey Fresh" agricultural products, among other things.
The man who made that kind of promotional technique famous, of course, was not Mr. Florio, but his predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, a Republican, who gained political and personal stardom with his tourism ads, "New Jersey and You -- Perfect Together."
That, of course, was different, the Republicans say.
 
Time With the President
 After 15 years as a New York City elected official, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, does not often gush effusively about a fellow politician. But after a chance private encounter with President Clinton during a trip to Washington earlier this month, Ms. Messinger was downright euphoric. "Extraordinary" and "impressive" were among the barrage of adjectives she used to describe the experience.
The Borough President, it seems, was sitting in the second row of a hotel ballroom at a meeting of the National League of Cities, preparing along with about 3,000 other people to listen to the President discuss his economic plan. Scanning the audience before the speech, Mr. Clinton recognized Ms. Messinger -- whom he had met late in 1991 during the Presidential primary campaign and who became a strong supporter. The President waved and yelled hello.
A few minutes later, as Mr. Clinton began speaking, an aide invited Ms. Messinger to join the President's staff backstage. That led to an invitation from the President, at the conclusion of his speech, to walk with him to a nearby room for a photo session, which in turn led to a ride with Mr. Clinton back to the White House.
Before Ms. Messinger knew it, she was greeting Hillary Rodham Clinton in the White House and talking with the President about everything from the new art on the office walls to New York City's response to the World Trade Center bombing. And when the conversation moved to children, the Borough President said she took out the latest photographs of her 5-month-old granddaughter.
"It was a wild, wonderful afternoon," Ms. Messinger said. "I have not ever spent a better hour in public service."

HEADLINE: Man Admits Lie About Dog Attack on Son

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dog that seriously wounded a 2-year-old boy in Brooklyn last week was not a stray but was adopted the previous day by the boy's father.
The father, Anthony Calvacca, 24, admitted on Friday that he had lied to the authorities. 
 "I didn't want no one to know, that people would think it was my fault what happened to my son," he said.
The dog, which was part pit bull, was killed at an animal shelter Friday afternoon for tests, said Joan Paylo, a spokeswoman for the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The tests determined that it did not have rabies.
Mr. Calvacca, an unemployed deli clerk, and his son, Anthony Jr., were attacked by the dog Thursday afternoon in their apartment in Williamsburg, the police said.
The boy suffered "a very severe mutilating injury to his lip, cheek and face, near his eye, which required more than 50 sutures to repair," said Dr. Howard Langstein, a plastic surgeon at Bellevue Hospital.
Mr. Calvacca said in a telephone interview Friday that he was carrying his son inside his apartment building when a stray dog chased after his collie, running up the stairs and into his first-floor apartment.
