HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Next Crisis

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
North Korea's decision to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and bar international inspectors from its soil is revealing a historic shift in attitudes here. For 40 years South Koreans worried about whether the U.S. would be tough enough in combating threats from the North. Now they're worried that Washington will be too tough.
The truth is that South Koreans were wrong to doubt American resolve in the past, and are right in sensing that the U.S. is likely to be tougher than they in the present crisis. 
 President Clinton is not going to run off half-cocked and force a showdown with Pyongyang. Nor is President Kim Young Sam, the newly installed leader in Seoul -- perhaps the first truly democratically elected one in this peninsula's history -- going to lie down and play dead.
But South Korean and American officials realize that just below their surface unity sits a fundamental clash in perspective. Diplomats on both sides will devote a great deal of energy in coming weeks to denying the breach. But they know it's there, and they know it will weaken their shared hand unless they face their differences honestly and work out a creative common strategy.
In a nutshell, this is the clash: Seoul, understandably frightened about war on its soil, will go very far to avoid a confrontation with the North, perhaps even to the point of living with a North Korean bomb, or at least with some ambiguity about whether or not the North has the bomb. Washington, with its global commitment to preventing the spread of nuclear arms, will be prepared to push Pyongyang harder and take greater risks to eliminate the nuclear threat.
President Kim seems alert to the problem and eager to massage it. He told me he would be "firm" in dealing with the crisis and wanted to "thank the U.S. for its firmness."
But in official circles generally, there is a gnawing anxiety about Washington and about war. Many leaders here fear that President Clinton will see North Korea as his Iraq and President Kim Il Sung as his Saddam Hussein, and start a war to prove he's tough.
"If you corner a rat, he will turn around and bite," mused one leader. "Then," he said, pointing out the window at the panorama of the city, "30 years' hard work will be destroyed in a blizzard of missiles from North Korea."
South Koreans, of course, can't produce a shred of evidence that Mr. Clinton will act with such haste or abandon. So far, he has been every bit as cautious and patient in trying to resolve the crisis as the South Koreans themselves. But the wildness of their speculations betrays the dimensions of their fears.
Though they hate the North's leaders, officials here will go out of their way to tell you about the North Koreans' poverty, insecurities and isolation, and warn about driving them toward irrational acts. Though they profoundly mistrust Pyongyang, they search for relatively benign excuses to explain the current crisis.
Seoul officials say Kim Jong Il, the son of Kim Il Sung and his heir apparent, started it to show his military how tough he is or to blackmail the West for more economic goodies or to claim he thwarted an imminent U.S. attack or to frighten the West into lowering its nuclear inspection standards.
In fact, most officials here will offer almost any explanation but the one right in front of their noses. Pyongyang wants the bomb and either wants or already has chemical and biological arms, and it is quite ready to precipitate a crisis to protect the facilities that make them.
Perhaps the two Northern Kims, bad guys like Saddam, really believe they need the bomb to stay in power and fulfill their ambitions. Perhaps the lesson they learned from the Persian Gulf war was that Saddam made the mistake of attacking Kuwait before he had the bomb. Perhaps they think that if Saddam had waited until he had it, the U.S. might have given in to his demands.
If that is Pyongyang's game -- as I believe it is -- the U.S., South Korea and every other sane nation will have to be careful and tough and, above all, united. If North Korea gets the bomb, others -- Japan, Taiwan and South Korea itself, to name a few -- will not be far behind. This new crisis with Pyongyang is nowhere near a diplomatic settlement, as some here like to pretend. It is just beginning.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Like U.S., State Governments Look to Affluent to Pay More Tax

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
In the 1980's, one state after another followed the Federal Government's lead in cutting top income tax rates and eliminating loopholes. Lately, however, states have made a U-turn. More and more of them are raising taxes on their more affluent citizens -- or thinking about it.
Since 1990, when Congress raised the top Federal income tax rate to about 33 percent from 28 percent, a dozen states have increased their taxes on the more affluent. Promises by conservatives like Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts to cut taxes have been shelved. 
 And in at least half a dozen states, including New York, politicians are considering proposals to raise the top tax rate or replace flat rates with progressive ones.
 
Higher Income, Higher Taxes
 "It's something that's percolating, and it's the direction toward which states are going to move," said Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute.
What is clear is that the more affluent could face a double whammy. Forty-one states now have income taxes and rely on them for about one-third of their revenue.
President Clinton's proposal would push the top tax rates, or marginal rates, into the high 30-percent and 40-percent range for taxpayers with incomes of at least $140,000.
At present, states have marginal tax rates of up to 11 percent.
"You start to look at some brutal situations in terms of marginal rate," said Kevin Phillips, a political consultant in Washington.
 
An Emphasis on 'Fairness'
 During the Reagan era, the gospel around state capitals was that a tax system characterized by low rates and a broad definition of taxable income -- that is, few loopholes -- not only pulled in the most revenue, but also did the least possible economic damage.
But that view has been modified by budget strains, disappointments with the 1980's tax changes and a new emphasis on "fairness," which generally means the return to a more progressive tax system.
 
West Virginia's Proposal
 West Virginia is a case in point. Back in 1987, the state slashed its top income tax rate to 6.5 percent from 13 percent while eliminating a number of tax loopholes. But Gov. Gaston Caperton, a Democrat, recently introduced a bill to push the rate back up to 7.5 percent for people with taxable incomes of more than 100,000. The bill, intended to raise an additional $10 million a year, would affect more than 8,000 taxpayers.
Proposals to raise taxes on higher earners are under consideration in several other states. Experts say that they stand the best chance of adoption -- though not necessarily this year -- in Connecticut, Massachusetts, Nebraska, Missouri, Indiana, Wisconsin and Minnesota.
In New York, the Speaker of the State Assembly, Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, has introduced a proposal to raise the top rate on high-income taxpayers to nearly 9 percent from 7.88 percent. The bill is opposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, recently vetoed a bill to raise income tax rates on the top taxpayers.
Both Governors indicated they were concerned that the higher taxes would discourage companies from locating in their states.
In West Virginia, legislative assistants say Governor Caperton's proposal to raise the marginal tax rate faces a tough fight.
But in Nebraska, the prospects appeared brighter for a tax increase proposed by Gov. Bob Nelson, a Democrat. Eric Byrd, a budget analyst at the Legislative Fiscal Office in Lincoln, said: "This is fulfilling one of the Governor's campaign promises. We pushed hard last year. It's probably going to happen this year."
 
A Late-Session Phenomenon
 Harley Duncan, executive director of the Federation of Tax Administrators in Washington, said: "In my experience, these things often arise late in sessions. As people start to focus on spending, they realize more revenue is necessary, and the income-tax-rate increases tend to serve as a balancing element in those sorts of packages."
The move to raise personal tax rates seems to be continuing even as states are beginning to see tax collections from sales and services revive along with the economy. Many states have already raised, or are considering raising, taxes on cigarettes, soft drinks or alcohol. If Congress adopts the President's plan to raise tax rates, that would automatically result in tax increases in three states -- North Dakota, Vermont and Rhode Island -- whose rates are directly linked to Federal rates.
Currently, a two-income couple with two children and a gross income of at least $200,000 pays about $40,808 in Federal taxes, according to a new study by the Minnesota Department of Revenue. In New York, a similar family paid another $13,309 in state taxes. New Jersey's top rate is 7 percent, but in Connecticut, where the income tax is relatively new, the top rate is 4.5 percent.
 
Problems Go Beyond Recession
 The strains on state and city budgets go beyond the recent recession. Medicaid, education and prisons eat up ever-larger portions of state and local spending. And business tax revenue stopped growing even before the recession started.
In addition, some states -- Alabama, Missouri and Oregon among them -- face imminent court decisions on school financing that may result in more mandated spending.
"What's driving the trend is frustration with the inability to fund state services," said James Papke, director of the Center for Tax Policy Studies at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind. "In the Midwest taxes are still a bad word. But in many cases the budget situation is so severe that they're going to have to look on the tax side."
In Indiana, where Gov. Evan Bayh, a Democrat, recently proposed deep cuts in Medicaid, some legislators have talked about introducing a new 5 percent tax rate as an alternative to the cuts or to an increase in the state sales tax.
Another reason for raising state taxes is the growing sense among voters that the affluent should pick up a bigger share of the tax burden.
"People used to talk about economic growth and efficiency in taxation," said Professor Papke. "Now people don't just look at the effect on business or the economy but on the burden on the poor and middle class."
 
Disappointment With Changes
 Finally, there is a feeling that the tax changes of the 1980's produced disappointing results. The Reagan Administration's notion that lower tax rates would increase savings and investment was not borne out, and now the thinking is drifting back toward employing special preferences, or loopholes, to influence saving and investment decisions.
"In the 1980's, economic development strategy was to reduce taxes on the wealthy and the upper-middle class," said Ronald Snell at the National Conference of State Legislatures. "That assumption may be in question, and if it is, it makes it easier to raise incomes."
Nonetheless, economists point out, several forces are likely to inhibit states, preventing a return to the super-high rates that prevailed in the late 1970's. For one thing, unlike Washington, states have to worry about becoming uncompetitive vis-a-vis their neighbors.
"When you get too far out of line you have to be concerned about the impact of taxes on decisions about where to locate," said Robert Cline, director of Tax Research at the Minnesota Department of Revenue.
More important, the affluent are likely to fight back.
"They have lobbies," said Mr. Phillips, the political consultant. "The politicians in legislatures are going to hear from these people. They know they're a target, and they will fight these packages at a state level."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 6, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on March 21 with an article about changes in state taxes for affluent people omitted the year on which the data were based. It was 1991. Thus the chart only partly reflected the effect of the 4.5 percent income tax phased in by Connecticut in 1991. In later years, a typical Connecticut couple earning $200,000 a year would owe $9,000 -- not $3,000 -- in state and local taxes, close to what similar couples pay in Georgia, Kentucky and Virginia.

HEADLINE: The Gospel of the Marketplace . . .

BYLINE: By Kenneth L. Woodward; Kenneth L. Woodward is a senior writer at Newsweek and the author, most recently, of "Making Saints: How the Catholic Church Determines Who Becomes a Saint, Who Doesn't, and Why."

 BODY:

THE CATHOLIC ETHIC AND THE SPIRIT OF CAPITALISM
By Michael Novak.
334 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95. 
 ELEVEN years ago, Michael Novak set out in "The Spirit of Democratic Capitalism" to prove that capitalism "rightly understood" is compatible with Roman Catholic social doctrine. This was no small achievement, given the modern papacy's century-old suspicion of capitalism as the invention of Protestant individualism, and Mr. Novak, once a self-declared "social democrat," found himself something of a pariah among American Catholicism's liberal intelligentsia. Never mind that Catholic higher education in the United States, led by the Jesuits' urban universities, pioneered the creation of undergraduate schools of commerce in order to facilitate the passage of immigrant Catholics into business. Never mind that by the 1980's Catholics were as likely as Protestants to be heads of major corporations, or to vote for Republicans. Mr. Novak's sin, if sin it be, was to bring a convert's enthusiasm to capitalism's entrepreneurial spirit, and to confer a lay theologian's blessings on it. Worse, in his critics' eyes, he did all this from the sheltered confines of the American Enterprise Institute, a not-for-profit Washington think tank financed by captains of industry.
In essence, Mr. Novak argued that democratic capitalism is morally superior to socialism: that the triangular nexus of a market economy, a democratic polity and a pluralistic culture not only produces a higher standard of living but is also more consonant with Christian values than the command economies and socialistic policies of Eastern Europe. What he couldn't do was square his conclusions with the received wisdom of his own religious tradition. Paul VI, Pope from 1963 to 1978, was no friend of American capitalism or of multinational corporations, and John Paul II, at that point, was advocating (with his Polish homeland very much in mind) a modified form of socialism: workers sharing in the ownership of productive means while state planners insure a just distribution of goods and services. Rome, Mr. Novak concluded, still had much to learn from the American experience in political economy.
Socialism is now history in Eastern Europe, and John Paul II himself has embraced market economics with an ardor that signals a new departure in papal social thought. Mr. Novak's hour has come round at last: his earlier book has become not only a primer for Poland's post-Communist intellectuals but also a major influence on John Paul II, a fellow Slav with whom Mr. Novak has been known to dine at the Vatican and to whom he dedicates this book.
In his latest volume, "The Catholic Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism," Mr. Novak reiterates the substance of his previous arguments, but angles them in new directions. Now that the Pope (in his 1991 encyclical "Centesimus Annus") agrees with his way of thinking, Mr. Novak wants to set the historical record straight. Max Weber was wrong, he writes, to suppose that capitalism depends for moral legitimation on the ascetic Protestant spirit. In any case, it is now Catholicism's turn to provide the necessary ethics for grounding and applying capitalism's wealth-producing magic, especially in the heavily Catholic countries of Eastern Europe and Latin America.
In Mr. Novak's view, Catholic ethics brings two dowries to its betrothal to capitalism: an appreciation for "social dimensions of the free economy" and a rich understanding of human inventiveness and creativity, which he celebrates as "the spirit of capitalism."
By the first, he means businesses and other voluntary associations that capitalism necessarily brings into existence in order to produce goods, services and profits. In calling attention to these associations, Mr. Novak hopes to show that capitalism is inherently social, not individualistic; that by nourishing the development of institutions and the personal virtues (of thrift, honesty and practical wisdom) necessary to sustain them, capitalism enriches the social and moral life of its constituents.
By the second, Mr. Novak means that capitalism is fundamentally as much an exercise in human creativity as are literature, science and the arts. Imagination, it should be said, has long been a central concern in Mr. Novak's writings on theology, philosophy, education, literature and sports. But now that John Paul II has declared that all workers are called to be "co-creators" with God, Mr. Novak is moved to declare that "in fact, the true moral strength of capitalism lies in its promotion of human creativity," and that a democratic capitalist society, however imperfect, is "perhaps the most responsive to the social implications of the Gospels yet developed by the human race."
This is theological cheerleading of the baldest type. Mr. Novak has never worked in the milieu he romanticizes. His book says nothing about the disruptions to family life demanded of ambitious executives; of the ruthless dispatch of colleagues by competitors on the way up the corporate ladder; of American workers displaced by companies in search of cheaper, foreign labor; of the get-rich-quick ethics of Wall Street; of the blindness of the marketplace to values that transcend its own. Like John Paul II himself, Mr. Novak glamorizes work at the expense of leisure; surely much of what passes for a career, in professions no less than in business, is high-paid toil of dubious personal or social value. To be sure, Mr. Novak insists that the capitalist spirit must be chastened by a culture informed by higher values. And now that capitalism is the only game in town, that might be his most important message. Certainly he is right in declaring that the church has a special obligation to help inspire private enterprise in the emerging economies of Eastern Europe and in the submerged economies of Latin America. But as he himself argues, capitalism is mother of its own inventions; in biblical language, its spirit bloweth where it will. In the past, the popes may indeed have been blind to capitalism's considerable merits. But they did well to insist that this modern genie be tethered once it is outside its bottle.

HEADLINE: At Tilles, It's Come to the Cabaret

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
HOW to describe the experience of cabaret performing?
To Craig Carnelia it is an innermost thing, "a journey through a life." 
 Andrea Marcovicci describes it as "the most personal expression of a performer's heart and soul and accumulated knowledge."
"It's what I always wanted to do," Mary Cleere Haran said, "sing and talk about movie songs of the 30's and 40's to a roomful of people as obsessed with great songs as I am."
Ms. Marcovicci sings old and new songs, including Mr. Carnelia's, and has an array of acts at the ready, all "tailor-made to the occasion."
Mr. Carnelia sings his own songs, which concentrate on character and context and have lately become more personal in their explorations of emotions, delicate imagery and musical structure.
 
Renaissance in Recital Hall
 With their distinct styles, the three performers are at the forefront of a flourishing cabaret renaissance in Manhattan. All are scheduled to appear in the second half of Club T, a concept and not a hot spot, in the Hillwood Recital Hall at Tilles Center on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville.
Mr. Carnelia will perform on Friday, Ms. Marcovicci in a Jerome Kern evening on April 17 and Ms. Haran on May 15. The shows begin at 8:30 and 10:30 P.M.
The concept, of course, is cabaret, "an art form onto itself," Ms. Marcovicci said. It is also an adventurous one, for it is a new subscription series for audiences accustomed to classical concerts and recitals. Yet starting with Club T's first show, in November, a Gershwin revue with seven Broadway performers, cabaret has been a hit. All 8:30 shows have been sold out by subscription.
Given the luster of the first two soloists in the series of six events -- Karen Akers in January and Julie Wilson last month -- it is clear that top-of-the-line cabaret is the newest form of entertainment to make an impact on the Island, where year-round professional Actors Equity playhouses have all but vanished. Thus, cabaret becomes a viable alternative to theater, especially in a theater without the clutter of ice cubes and dishes.
"Taking the cabaret artists out of the clubs and putting them into the theater" is precisely the mission of the American Cabaret Theater, an organization in Manhattan devoted to promoting cabaret as an art form. "It's still too new to the general public," said Peter Ligeti, who founded the group 14 months ago. Mr. Ligeti has produced cabaret shows at the John Drew Theater in East Hampton, the latest featuring Mr. Carnelia.
It took five years for cabaret to arrive on the Island with such a classy lineup. After a 20th-anniversary production of "Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris," which starred Ms. Akers in January 1988, the 491-seat Hillwood, usually used for student activities, was given over to chamber music, children's theater and now-and-then performances, one by Elly Stone and another by Betty Comden and Adolph Green.
Last fall John Aulbach, then the production manager of Tilles, thought up the term "Club T." "And it caught on," said the director of the center, Elliott Sroka. "We had to add 10:30 shows, and they are attracting mostly single-ticket buyers who might not come here otherwise. They're generally a younger audience."
 
'It's a Special World'
 He added that cabaret "creates the atmosphere of sophistication and drama without layers, without extra stuff, without redundant spectacle, without barriers."
"It's focused on human reality -- direct feelings, ideas, contact," Mr. Sroka said. "It's a special world. And it's about virtuosity, technique and excellent musicianship. So it's natural for audiences used to classical music to cross over to cabaret."
Mr. Carnelia, who was born in Floral Park, added: "Now that it's been introduced on the Island, cabaret needs to be defined not in a Las Vegas vein. It is theater at its most intimate and intense, when it really cooks. Then it's nothing except a song and a singer, and that singer can take you on a trip, invite you in if he or she is truly in the song. But when it's bad, it can be like someone putting on a show in a garage."
Jack Globenfelt of Garden City, who is producing Club T and owns two record labels, Cabaret and Elba, said: "Cabaret demands that you sit there and listen, and this is the time for it on Long Island. People don't want to traipse into Manhattan to see performers they hear about."
"The revues like the Gershwin are more costly, complex and require more rehearsals and space, but bringing the best cabaret artists to the Island has to be continued," Mr. Sroka said. "This is a new culture otherwise unavailable. But can we come up with another series as powerful as this one? We have to be careful and selective, but we know this is a major art form of the 90's and it has to continue. Our sponsor, Banfi Vintners of Old Brookville, has confirmed that it will. We don't have to worry about economics based on food and drink. With two shows playing back to back, it can be self-sustaining."
No doubt about it. Island audiences who want to go to the professional theater can come to the cabaret. As theater.

HEADLINE: Parking Lots, Reborn as Beauty Spots

BYLINE: By ARTHUR Z. KAMIN

DATELINE: FREEHOLD

 BODY:
PARKING lots do not have to look like parking lots. They can be bathed in greenery. They can be havens for bicycle riders. They can have pedestrian walkways, shops and museums.
Passers-by may even have to look twice to see the cars in a parking lot. And when the vehicles are gone, a lot can take on another role, as a park or marketplace. 
It's all possible, and that was the message the Monmouth County Planning Board wanted to get across with its 32-page booklet called "Not for Cars Only -- A Guide to Innovative Parking Lot Design," published in October. It's turned out to be something of a smash.
Most of the 500 copies printed were gone by December, snapped up at $6 a copy, mainly by municipal officials, planners and developers, and the demand for more has led the county planners to order a second printing.
"Little did we realize we had a best seller on our hands," said Harriet Strickler, a senior planner for the county, who compiled the guide with Louise Allen, head of the board's general planning section.
The booklet was based largely on "Carscape," a 1988 parking handbook published by the Irwin-Sweeney-Miller Foundation in Columbus, Ind., that contains ideas generated by a competition sponsored by the National Endowment for the Arts.
"Designers have typically been allowed to plan unattractive parking lots, which stand in striking contrast to the well-designed structures they serve," Ms. Strickler said. "Generally, ordinances require a few feet of grass along the lot's perimeter and little or no greenery inside the lot."
The Monmouth booklet began modestly and with little fanfare, intended to help governing bodies and planners in the county's 53 municipalities, who had asked for help in making their towns more attractive.
Starting with a historical perspective -- Julius Caesar's solution to parking problems was to ban chariots from Rome's central business district -- the guide defines today's problems, noting that parking lots tend to be crowded eyesores. It suggests solutions including hiding parking lots behind facades of buildings and trees and dividing large lots into smaller, more attractive pieces.
Demand for the guide was stimulated when it won two important awards -- from the New Jersey Chapter of the American Planning Association and the New Jersey Planning Officials, a group of planning and zoning board members. Both awards praised the project's contributions to the planning process.
 
Vine-Covered Parking
 The booklet is filled with illustrations of landscaping options. In one, a canopy of vines forms a leafy roof over an entire parking lot. Another shows a vine-covered trellis enclosure surrounding a lot.
Requests for the booklet have been received from all over the state. "I'm ordering 30 copies," said Robert E. Rosa, a professional planner and a landscape architect in Woodbridge, Middlesex County, and a consultant to the Planning Board and Zoning Board of Adjustment in Rahway, which is working to revitalize its downtown business district.
"Good parking is going to be a key element of this project," Mr. Rosa said. "I want everyone on the task force to see the parking lot guide. I think it can help us in Rahway."
Mr. Rosa said he was enthusiastic about landscaping in and around parking lots.
"I think the trees, the flowers, the shrubbery and the landscaping give people peace of mind," he said. "It's like when people go for a walk in the woods. For a few minutes they are taken out of the city." He does not see a security problem in landscaped parking lots, he added.
Anton Nelessen, an associate professor in the department of urban planning and policy development at Rutgers University in New Brunswick and a private planner in Princeton, served as a consultant in the booklet's preparation. He said he was happy to learn that the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which operates the Meadowlands Sports Complex in East Rutherford, had requested several copies.
"That's one of the worst-looking parking lots in the state of New Jersey," he said. "A sea of asphalt sameness. They've got a lot of work to do there." He cited Disney World in Orlando, Fla., as an example of what parking lots should look like at a large entertainment complex.
John Samerjan, the sports authority's director of public affairs, said that "looks are not the important thing" in the Meadowlands lots, which can handle 25,000 vehicles but sometimes must cope with 30,000 for Giants games.
"We want our lots to be safe, and we want them to function well," he said, noting that as a public agency, the authority might not be able to afford landscaping for its lots.
But he added that the sports complex was "in the business of hosting guests," and that the Monmouth parking booklet could contain some tips for the Meadowlands planners.
Mr. Nelessen, who has been at Rutgers for 19 years and has been a consultant to design projects throughout the nation and in Europe, including the redevelopment of whole downtown business districts, said: "A parking lot is very often the first thing you see in a town. It should create a positive image."
 
Company's Design Praised
 He gives high marks to the parking design at Johnson & Johnson's headquarters in New Brunswick, saying the company "solves potential parking problems with generous landscaping." He said the lots were totally screened from view, including one parking deck that had been incorporated into an old stone wall.
Noting that surface parking covers as much as 30 percent of the downtown area in some towns, Ms. Strickler and Mrs. Allen said that improving the lots was critical. They wrote in the guide that "the solutions presented can be used to humanize the scale and eliminate the visual monotony generally associated with parking lot design."
Lighting, signs and security are covered in the booklet, along with examples of local parking ordinances that show how to encourage improvements.
But not everybody is so enthusiastic about these new frontiers in parking. Harold Gottesman, chief executive of the Edison Parking Corporation, based in Newark, said he had not seen the guide and wasn't sure he wanted to.
 
Shrubbery as 'Wasted Space'
 "From a business point of view, all that shrubbery is wasted space," said Mr. Gottesman, whose company owns and manages 175 parking complexes nationwide, including about 25 surface lots in downtown Newark. "It's not productive. Space is at a premium -- especially in cities. Our customers want fast and safe service. That's what we try to give them."
Mr. Gottesman said attempts to beautify Newark parking lots had not been successful. "Urban settings don't always provide the best growing environment," he said. "And it's tough to maintain all those plants."
The guide received good marks from Mel Israel, president of an architectural and planning concern in Tinton Falls, where he is president of the local Business and Professional Association.
"It's time many municipalities came to grips with parking design concept in the 1990's," said Mr. Israel, who is also chairman of the Economic Development Commission in Highlands, also in Monmouth County. "We build parking lots for the Christmas shopping season. The rest of the time most of the lots are empty."
He also said many local ordinances required individual parking spaces that were too big. "Many towns want 10 feet by 20 feet," he said. "Nine feet by 18 feet would do -- and even 8 feet by 17 feet. Everyone doesn't drive a Lincoln."
Further praise for the guide came from Richard Cramer, a planner with T & M Associates, a planning and engineering firm in Middletown, Monmouth County, that serves municipalities throughout the state.
"Parking lots have gone out of control," he said. "They have become a big no man's land -- uninviting and unattractive."
He said he applauded any attempt to encourage more landscaping and to beautify the lots. "In the long run, developers will be saving money," he said. "Believe me, some shrubs and trees and landscaping won't make or break a project. Some of the better developers realize this."
Ms. Strickler and Mrs. Allen may begin to see the fruits of their labor soon, as they look out of their Planning Department offices in Freehold, the Monmouth County seat. Working with Guy Leighton, a planner and landscape architect in the county transportation section, they are providing free advice to the borough's downtown revitalization effort, being coordinated by the Freehold Partnership, which includes residents, businesses and local and county government.
 
Taking Ideas from Guide
 William J. Mehr, a Freehold lawyer and partnership president, said one parking lot in Freehold, across from the County Hall of Records, would include some of the concepts from the guide.
Plans also are being drawn for the Market Yard parking lot, in the central business district, which would harmonize with a series of promenades and sidewalk cafes.
"We want our parking lots to be user-friendly, to have an abundance of green areas and to blend right in with and link up with the community," Mr. Mehr said. "We want friendly parking lots -- the gateway to our business district."

LENGTH: 1132 words

HEADLINE: New Venture Delivers Success (and Dinner)

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: RYE

 BODY:
RAIN, snow and gloom of night are the elements most prized by the owners of Cuisine on Call here, a company that has built a business by delivering restaurant meals to homes and offices.
"The worse the weather, the better for our business," said Sheryl B. Lutsky, who started the business in October with her partner, Deena S. Grotto. "But what's most important is the repeat business we're getting that has nothing to do with weather, so we feel we've found a niche for ourselves." 
 Cuisine on Call takes orders and delivers for 36 restaurants in the Sound Shore area. "In giving them a delivery service, we're able to do something that would be too expensive and take too much time for the individual restaurants to do successfully on their own," Mrs. Lutsky said.
Customers receive a dining guide containing menus from the restaurants. "The variety is tremendous, 14 different cuisines including French, Mexican and Indian," Mrs. Grotto said. She added that the idea for the business grew from the partners' own desires for delivered meals beyond pizza and Chinese food.
Mrs. Grotto's husband, Robert, a former textile executive and now a consultant to Cuisine on Call, devised the company's business plan.
"Deena and I had the idea in mind when we moved here from Chicago 14 years ago," he said. "In Chicago there are restaurants of all sorts that deliver, but when we moved to Tarrytown and the kitchen in the house we bought was out of commission for about two weeks, we found when we started calling restaurants we could not find any in the area that delivered. I remembered thinking, 'Here's a good business opportunity for someone.' But we never did anything about it. I was running a textile company, and Deena was teaching a special-education class."
 
'We Missed That Convenience'
 But the idea arose again last summer, Mr. Grotto said.
"We were spending the weekend with friends in Great Neck, L.I., and they were raving about a new restaurant service out there called Eatin' In," he said. "They called, and half an hour later we were eating really good Mexican food on their patio. That did it. We got back home, and Deena called Sheryl, and she and her husband, Ira, who are friends and neighbors of ours in Rye Brook, kicked around the idea."
Mrs. Lutsky, who says she has always been interested in food and caters parties as favors for friends, was enthusiastic.
"We used to live in Manhattan, where you can get everything delivered, and we missed that convenience," she said. "So Deena and I, with our husbands supporting the idea, started a market-research program consisting of going to restaurants. It was very pleasurable. We knew if our business was to be successful, we had to have good restaurants."
Ten pounds later, "we had eaten very well, and we had developed a solid business plan," Mrs. Lutsky said. "We were encouraged by the reception we got from some of the best restaurants in the county. They thought enough of our idea to sign six-month contracts with us."
 
Start-Up Costs Underestimated
 Cuisine on Call opened officially on Halloween 1992.
"All things considered, the launch went pretty smoothly," Mr. Grotto said. "As with most entrepreneurial enterprises, the start-up costs were more than anticipated. Originally, we thought we could swing it on an investment of $15,000, but we ended up investing $40,000 -- half from us and the other half from the Lutskys." Most of the start-up money went for printing a dining guide and for computers to process orders, he said.
Customers can get sushi from Noda's Japanese Steak House and Sushi Bar in White Plains, spending approximately $25 for two, or a 14-ounce fillet mignon with baked potato or rice from the Willet House in Port Chester, spending approximately $50 for two, delivered hot in insulated bags by a driver-waiter in a tuxedo shirt.
"For someone who was computer illiterate when we began this operation, I've become very proficient in processing orders," Mrs. Lutsky said. When a customer calls, the order is entered into a custom-designed computer program that sends the order to the restaurant by fax. "A dispatcher of ours, using two-way radio, coordinates the order with one of our drivers with the restaurant for the pickup and delivery," she said.
 
Drivers Are an Essential Factor
 Customers pay the driver either by credit card or cash, and the prices are the same as at the restaurants, plus a $3 delivery charge, "not per meal but per restaurant," Mrs. Grotto said. "The driver also unpacks the food and puts it on the table."
Good drivers, who know their way around Westchester's streets, are essential to the success of the business, she said.
"That was a big headache, trying to find the right ones," she recalled. "I remember the first ad we ran for drivers brought us more than 100 replies from out-of-work executives, former real estate brokers, even bankers -- and they were all looking for work, which I think says something about the economy. But this is essentially a part-time job, and through trial and error we found the best people suited to our hours were college students.
"We now have a cadre of 20 of them, from SUNY, Westchester Community College, Iona and Marymount, and they are all independent contractors who use their own cars to make deliveries. The restaurants pack the food in their own insulated containers, which are sealed tight until they are opened in front of the customer."
 
Where's the House Number?
 Because of Westchester's haphazard system of numbering houses, difficulties can arise. "Drivers are told, 'It's the large white house halfway down the block,' or, 'You will find our name on the tree,' " Mrs. Lutsky said. "But even with the obstacles, deliveries are made within the hour. You quickly get to know customers on a first-name basis, especially the regulars who will ask: 'What's good for dinner? What do you suggest?' just as if they were in a restaurant."
The company makes between 50 and 80 deliveries a day.
The partners said they hoped to develop more corporate business -- delivering to individuals at offices and catering parties.
"We catered an Around the World luncheon for 55 people last week at Seagram's Conference Center on Corporate Drive in White Plains," Mrs. Grotto said. "The food came from six different restaurants, including Indian, Mexican and Chinese. We supplied the plates and the utensils and set up the food in chafing dishes. This type of volume business is very desirable for us, and we'd like to generate more of it."
The partners said they had not yet drawn salaries.
"We are expanding, but we have not had to add to our original investment, which we think is good," Mrs. Lutsky said. "The money that we make is going right back into growing the company."

HEADLINE: When Being An Old Hand Becomes A Handicap

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
BRACING himself against a wintry blast that whipped across the platform at Greystone Station here one recent morning, Roy Podorson waited with the throngs of commuters for the next express train to Manhattan. The silver-haired advertising executive, who has been out of work for seven months, was continuing to make the rounds -- sending out resumes, phoning prospective employers and scheduling interviews.
Mr. Podorson -- 52 and vying with many aggressive younger workers -- said he was undaunted by a stiffly competitive job market and an economy that is, at best, merely crawling out of the recession. 
 Although his spirits sometimes flag, Mr. Podorson -- who swims seven miles a week -- said his stamina continues to be like that of a much younger man. "Some days I don't know how I keep going, but I do," he said. "I'm like an Energizer battery."
As an art director, Mr. Podorson designed the block-long Camel cigarette sign in Times Square and handled accounts for Sony, Volvo and Perdue chickens, among others. And he believes that his creativity, honed by years of experience, will eventually prevail over job seekers many years his junior, who often come with a lower price tag.
To the north, in Somers, Thomas R. Thyne -- an engineer with New York Telephone in Valhalla for 24 years -- is also out of work. Like Mr. Podorson, he is finding the business of looking for a new job frustrating, and at times, disheartening. In his field, too, younger workers appear to have an advantage, he said.
Mr. Thyne, who is 46, said he felt betrayed four months ago when he learned that his services with the phone company were no longer needed. "I planned to be there for life," he said. "And then I found myself sitting across from a 25-year-old supervisor who was telling me that I didn't have a job anymore."
Mr. Thyne has joined a long list of plaintiffs who are suing New York Telephone and its parent, the Nynex Corporation, for job discrimination. The former workers are charging that the companies terminated their employment in violation of the Federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act and the New York Human Rights Law.
 
'I Was Not a Bad Employee'
 "What I want most," said Mr. Thyne, who is divorced and raising two teen-age children, "is an acknowledgement that they wronged me; I was not a bad employee."
The suit claims that New York Telephone discharged Mr. Thyne and hundreds of other employees last Dec. 11 as a result of a reduction-in-force plan that discriminated against workers 40 years or older because of "a corporate culture disfavoring older employees."
Judith P. Vladeck, a lawyer with Vladeck, Waldman, Elias & Engelhard, a Manhattan firm handling the class-action suit, said: "This whole youth cult thing is a dreadful mistake. And, unfortunately, with corporate restructurings we are going to be seeing more and more older workers who are scrapped."
The American Association of Retired Persons, in Washington, reported that it has seen an increasing number of complaints from older workers as companies cut back.
Examples of age bias, said Sally Dunaway, a staff lawyer for the association's worker equity department, include an older worker who traditionally received high job-performance ratings, then begins to get "fair" or "poor" evaluations and finally is discharged, a long-time employee who is no longer invited to staff meetings, the worker who has responsibilities taken away, or an older employee who is transferred to a division where there are likely to be layoffs.
Telephone company spokesmen denied that employees' ages influenced who was laid off last year. Henry Gomez, staff director for media relations at Nynex, said no one group had been singled out during the recent cutbacks, in accordance with a strict company policy forbidding that.
"It is important to our bottom line that we have a diverse work force to reflect our diverse customer base," Mr. Gomez said. "That's just smart business policy."
But experts in the human resources field, many of whom are working with older employees who have lost their jobs, said that despite what companies say publicly, they are motivated by economic reasons to shed older workers who often command larger salaries and are in line for expensive retirement packages.
 
Incentives Not Based on Age
 "The 40-to-60-year-olds are especially vulnerable when it comes to layoffs," said Joan D. Learn, president of the Greenwich Group, a Connecticut-based consulting company specializing in outplacement services for corporations in Westchester and Fairfield Counties. "Let's face it: they cost more."
Like Mr. Gomez at Nynex, other spokesmen at large corporations in the county denied that age discrimination was a factor in layoffs or that it influenced who was offered early retirement packages.
At the International Business Machines Corporation, for example, John Boudreaux said his company's efforts to reduce its work force by offering incentive packages had little to do with age.
"I can't speak for corporate America in general, but our packages are for all ages and all skills, for people who may wish to leave the company for a variety of reasons," the I.B.M. spokesman said. "To describe them as early retirement packages only or packages for just older workers would be innacurate."
 
'An Enormously Difficult Adjustment'
 But he added that it was "only natural" that such packages appealed to older workers, because a 30-year-old employee, for example, would not have accrued enough time on the job to earn substantial retirement benefits.
William J. Adock, a 48-year-old former director of finance and planning at I.B.M., recently took advantage of an incentive package that left him with a year's salary and lifetime benefits. "After 23 years with the company, I felt there would be more opportunity out there for challenge," said the Pound Ridge resident, who was earning "in the low six figures" before he left.
Even if age discrimination is not a factor, and whatever the reasons for leaving a job -- layoffs or enticements -- finding new employment has been a difficult business for many older workers.
"It's traumatic, an enormously difficult adjustment," said David B. Opton, executive director of Exec-U-Net, a Weston-based job search and career management information network.
"If you lose a job at 30, so what?" Mr. Opton said. "But with two kids in college, it's a different ball game altogether."
 
Dropping Out of the Work Force
 For Mr. Adock, whose children are grown but who is still paying off the mortgage on a large house on 9.5 acres, life outside I.B.M. has not been as easy as he thought it would be. Like Mr. Podorson and Mr. Thyne, the former I.B.M. executive said he was finding the job market "very, very slow."
Michael Simon, president of Michael Simon Associates, a career transition and outplacement firm in Valhalla, said, "There are declining curves in hiring all over, but for older workers, it's even worse."
At the State Labor Department, a regional economist, Frank M. Surdey, reported that many older workers were simply dropping out of the work force. "These are the discouraged workers," he said, "those who believe there are no jobs available for them."
Although the national average unemployment rate in 1992 for workers in the 45-to-54-year-old bracket was lower than for all workers -- 5.1 percent compared with 7.4 percent -- the figures do not reflect the number of workers who are no longer looking for work, Mr. Surdey said.
Mr. Simon in Valhalla recommended that older workers upgrade their skills for what has become an increasingly technological workplace.
 
Looking at Other Options
 "Age won't matter much if a worker keeps developing skills of value," he said. "It is not just a matter of a youth cult. People have to keep up with the times."
At the Greenwich Group, Ms. Learn said she was counseling older workers, especially former executives and managers, to begin looking at other options.
Some older workers, she said, are taking jobs with smaller companies that are looking for experienced leaders.
Others, like Mr. Thyne and Mr. Adock, are considering the possibility of starting their own businesses.
"I had to ask myself, 'Do I really want to go back to corporate America?' " said Mr. Thyne, who recently decided to use his severance package, including nine months' pay, to open a restaurant. "Maybe it's time to use other talents and seek fame and fortune in a different way," he said.
 
An Eye Toward Modeling
 For Mr. Adock, who uses the secretarial, networking, counseling and other outplacement services of the Greenwich Group, the solution, he said, may be purchasing a small manufacturing company.
And for Mr. Podorson, the alternative may be a career in modeling. Although he said that his first choice is to land a job as a senior art director again, he has also registered with model agencies in several cities. In a recent project completed for a computer graphics course that he took to upgrade his skills, he designed a book jacket that read, "The Hilarious Story of Roy Podorson, Art Director for Over 20 Years Turned Model."
"All of this is pretty serious business," he said. "But you still have to keep your sense of humor, or at least develop one if you didn't have it before. Laughter definitely is the best medicine."
Those interested in the Association of Retired Persons' free pamphlet "Age Discrimination on the Job" should write to A.A.R.P.-Fulfillment, 601 E Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20049.
The Westchester County Office for the Aging runs two programs for low- and middle-income workers to help place them in jobs in government and business. For more information, the number to call is 682-3000.

HEADLINE: Roosevelt Unbound

BYLINE: By Robert Dallek; Robert Dallek is the author of "Franklin D. Roosevelt and American Foreign Policy, 1932-1945" and, most recently, "Lone Star Rising: Lyndon Johnson and His Times, 1908-1960."

 BODY:

FDR
Into the Storm 1937-1940: A History.
By Kenneth S. Davis.
691 pp. New York:
Random House. $35. 
 TWO hundred and seventeen years after our declaration of independence from royal rule, America's preoccupation with its Presidents, their wives and their children suggests a longing for a royal family that can bring us together and promote national well-being. At the same time, as good egalitarians in an age of anything-goes journalism, we enjoy hearing the intimate details of our leaders' lives -- and the more sensational the better. A dignified former high official I recently interviewed for a biography of Lyndon B. Johnson began our conversation with a bit of what he called "human-interest detail that biographers crave." Did I know, he asked, that Johnson had never been circumcised? "No," I muttered, wondering what possible use he thought I could make of this "revelation" in a volume on Johnson's Presidential years.
To Kenneth S. Davis's credit, his fourth and penultimate volume on Franklin D. Roosevelt spares us excursions into the 32d President's sex life. Not that he shuns the private man; he has plenty to say about Roosevelt's moods and health and about his relationships with Eleanor, his children, and his associates and friends, but all with an eye to explaining the frustrations, agonies and occasional triumphs of Roosevelt's second term. Besides, as Mr. Davis says in a note about his sources, this study "is concerned less with the discovery and presentation of hitherto hidden facts about Franklin Roosevelt and his years than it is with comprehending in interpretive ways, and from a clearly defined point of view, factual information that has long been at hand in vast bulk."
Yet what makes "FDR: Into the Storm 1937-1940" distinctive is not the interpretations or the "clearly defined point of view," which seem all too familiar, but rather the mass of detail on all the major and many minor events of Roosevelt's second term. Here, in a richer recounting than we have ever had before, are the domestic struggles to sustain and expand the New Deal, the effort to pack the Supreme Court, the attempted purge of conservative Democrats, the successful battles over the wages-and-hours, farm tenancy and housing bills, and the victorious 1940 re-election campaign against Wendell Willkie. Nor does Mr. Davis slight foreign affairs; he recounts in even greater detail American responses to the crises in Spain, China and Czechoslovakia, and later throughout Europe with the outbreak of World War II.
There is an almost encyclopedic quality to Mr. Davis's narrative that will fascinate scholars and aficionados of Roosevelt, but will probably be more than any general reader, even one keenly interested in Presidential biography, will care to read. If Mr. Davis had confined himself to reconstructing in voluminous detail Roosevelt's maneuvering through the various political, economic and international crises of these years, his biography might have been more palatable than it is. But the lengthy background descriptions of the Spanish Civil War, the Munich crisis of 1938 and the development of atomic physics, to give just three examples, are more distracting than enthralling. No one wants the life without the times, but there are degrees and degrees.
Mr. Davis's affinity for the big picture, for all the background detail, might have made more sense if he saw it as essential to explaining Roosevelt's many difficulties. But that is not so. Mr. Davis's Roosevelt in the years 1937-40 is not a man plagued by uncontrollable events at home and abroad, but a stumbling political leader who miscalculated in domestic affairs and exercised excessive caution in foreign ones.
The analysis of the fight over the Supreme Court in 1937 illustrates the point. Roosevelt's landslide victory in the 1936 election, Mr. Davis asserts, encouraged in him "an egotistical mood, a sense of omnipotence, that was far less conducive to sober thought than it was to a willful assertiveness, a reckless disregard of opposition."
"Corrupted by a heady sense of limitless power," Mr. Davis says, the President at the start of his second term moved to overcome the Supreme Court's anti-New Deal, pro-business decisions of the previous two years. Roosevelt's method was a subterfuge: he proposed adding up to six justices to the Supreme Court as a means, he explained, not to rescue and expand the New Deal but to make the Court more efficient. Historians generally agree that Roosevelt was too clever by half, and that he miscalculated badly in assuming that he had the political muscle to alter the size of the Court. But to see him as carried away by excessive egotism, as Mr. Davis does, diminishes the importance of his intense concern with salvaging the New Deal and advancing the cause of those who were "ill housed, ill clad and ill nourished."
Similarly, Mr. Davis sees the failure of the United States to lead or join a collective security action against Japan in 1937, after its renewed aggression in China, as due principally to Roosevelt's inadequate leadership. More specifically, Mr. Davis believes that Roosevelt had the opportunity to press the case for a renewed internationalism after the public's strong positive reaction to his "quarantine the aggressors" speech in October 1937. In Mr. Davis's view the President could have "worked against the disastrous 'appeasement' policy of the British and French, while preparing and easing the way of the democracies toward the kind of collective action that was ultimately required for the survival of Western civilization." But Mr. Davis finds that a lack of "requisite resolve, nerve, energy and clarity of mind" combined with Roosevelt's "isolationist sentiments" to deter him from leading the nation onto a new path in foreign affairs.
YET Mr. Davis concedes that the favorable response to the President's speech largely centered on his denunciation of aggressor nations, and that only a distinct minority in the United States wanted a more active policy. He thinks that Roosevelt missed a chance to use the influential leaders of this minority to convert a majority of Americans to collective security. But given the bitter and lengthy struggle Roosevelt had to make in the more perilous conditions of 1939-41 to drag the country toward involvement in the war, the author's conclusion seems dubious at best.
Mr. Davis's opinion of Roosevelt as a poor leader extends to his actions on everything from the recession of 1937-38 to the Nazi threat of 1939-40. No one familiar with Roosevelt's performance in these years would argue that he was without serious shortcomings. But Mr. Davis's picture of a cautious, ineffective leader is overdrawn, giving too little weight to the restraints on Roosevelt's powers and the limited but striking gains of his second term. The Farm Security Administration, the Fair Labor Standards Act and the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act stand along with the President's success in aiding Britain's fight against Hitler in 1939-40 as achievements any President would be proud to claim.
Mr. Davis's massive biography, despite its many questionable judgments, will take its place in the Roosevelt literature as a standard against which other, more sympathetic historians will have to argue. More important, it will be an enduring tribute to the significance of Franklin D. Roosevelt in the history of the 20th century. For as Mr. Davis himself says, we cannot understand the contemporary United States and the world without reference to Roosevelt's decisions "during the 12 crisis years in which he, as President of the United States, occupied a pivotal position in world affairs."

HEADLINE: St. Ferghana Preserve Us!

BYLINE: By Andrew Bergman; Andrew Bergman, who wrote and directed the film "Honeymoon in Vegas," is the author of the mystery novels "The Big Kiss-Off of 1944" and "Hollywood and LeVine."

 BODY:

DON'T ASK
By Donald E. Westlake.
327 pp. New York:
The Mysterious Press. $18.95. 
 DONALD E. WESTLAKE has written his eighth novel featuring the ingenious and larcenous John Dortmunder and his familiar gang of thieves -- the picklock Andy Kelp, the driver Stan Murch and the mammoth Tiny Bulcher. Together they occupy an almost fairy tale world of New York crime in which genuine evil seems to have no place. It is small potatoes, small beer, crime as operetta -- with blundering forces matching wits and half-wits for minuscule economic gain. In this era of thrillers about serial killers and child molesters, Mr. Westlake's psychology-free capers are balm for the nerves. "Don't Ask" is one of his best.
This latest Dortmunder adventure has a particularly outlandish and lighthearted plot that revolves around the competing efforts of two rival and newly misbegotten Eastern European nations, Tsergovia and Votskojek, to gain admittance to the United Nations. There is literally a bone of contention, the 800-year-old femur of the martyred St. Ferghana, a medieval slut turned saint who was murdered and eaten by her cannibalistic peers in the 13th century. This sacred relic, claimed by both Tsergovia and Votskojek, has great political significance: the country with the actual bone will gain admission to the United Nations, the authenticity of said bone to be determined by the august and senile Archbishop Minkokus.
The Tsergovian forces, who occupy a Second Avenue storefront embassy recently occupied by a dry cleaner, hire Dortmunder and his companions to recover the bone from the floating "embassy" of Votskojek, the Pride of Votskojek, a boat whose principal occupant, Hradec Kralowc, is his tiny nation's Ambassador to the United States. Kralowc's principal duties appear to consist of escorting showgirls on and off the boat, and protecting the bone, aided by the deranged Dr. Karver Zorn. Complications further ensue, involving the purloined art collection of the New York hotel magnate Harry Hochman, who is lobbying to build his Happy Hour Inns throughout Eastern Europe, dreaming of the slogan, "From the Rockies to the Urals, a Hochman pillow will rest your head."
If the plot is of no great concern, it is the effortlessness, wit, and sheer good-heartedness of the telling that make "Don't Ask" such a consistent delight. Mr. Westlake's prose is as deft as ever -- he describes the Queens side of the East River as a "Dickensian warren of riverside grunge," and his characterizations ("this woman was about the size and shape of a mailbox") are models of brevity. His affection for his characters is infectious, and because the stakes are so low, the book has the unhurried pace of the best of the shaggy dog stories; the pleasure is all in the journey rather than the destination.
There is also something Joycean in Mr. Westlake's love not only of New York's pettiest crooks, but also of its very geography. The descriptive handle "stately, plump Joe Mulligan," echoing the opening of "Ulysses," resonates because Mr. Westlake's affection for the details of New York resembles Joyce's encyclopedic knowledge of Dublin. Murch's explanations of his driving routes -- "with the construction on the Bruckner, I think I'll stay on the Henry Hudson. It's a toll across Spuyten Duyvil, but it's worth it" -- are a kind of music to any New Yorker's ears. One does not simply drive around New York; one devises strategies out of Clausewitz simply to go from Manhattan to the Bronx. Dortmunder and his gang are fish out of water once they leave the boroughs; a trip to Vermont is like a safari in Africa. They are New Yorkers to the bone; outside the city, they seem tentative, unfamiliar with the rules.
One can only admire Donald Westlake's continued Runyonesque infatuation with New York's low life. At a brutal time in the city's life, it is a major act of faith.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 2400 words

HEADLINE: Sea-Dumping Ban: Good Politics, But Not Necessarily Good Policy

SERIES: What Price Cleanup? -- Second article of a series.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
For millions of people from Montauk to Maryland, the broiling summer of 1988 will be hard to forget. It was the hottest year ever recorded. Repulsive trash slicks covered the Eastern shoreline. And borne upon a tide of public outrage, garbage emerged as a potent political issue.
In New York and New Jersey, where most of the waste appeared, health officials closed beaches by the score depriving sweltering people of relief. Pictures of used syringes, dead dolphins and human excrement scattered across the sand became a staple of the news. 
 Anger required action. So that fall, without registering a single vote of opposition, Congress banned the dumping of sewage into the ocean. The law prohibited New York City from dropping its processed waste into the sea and forced officials to find costly new ways to get rid of it.
 
The Rush to Ban
 "This is a turning point in human history," said a euphoric Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of New Jersey, after the vote. Other officials agreed, rushing to embrace the law as one of the most important environmental measures ever enacted.
There was just one problem.
Ocean dumping had absolutely nothing to do with the garbage that washed up on the sand that year. In fact, the problems that caused the mess on the beaches in 1988 -- overtaxed sewage systems -- were largely ignored, and the health risks they present are as serious as they have ever been.
Most scientists agree that using the sea as a garbage can was unpleasant and are pleased that it is no longer legal. Still, some argue that dumping sewage in the Atlantic Ocean 106 miles from the shore -- which saved New York and other cities billions of dollars over the years -- is less hazardous than most of the disposal methods that have replaced it.
But Congressional leaders, relying almost solely on the summer's vivid images of filth, pushed through a ban on ocean dumping. As Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, put it immediately after the vote: "It is unfortunate that it takes a situation like we have today with medical waste washing up on our beaches, to capture the attention of the American public and of Congress. But perhaps it is a blessing in disguise, since it has resulted in our action today to put a halt to the ocean dumping of sludge."
Representative Thomas J. Manton, Democrat of Queens, opposed the act at first, saying it would simply shift waste from sea to land, including land in his own district. But looking back to that time, he recalled: "If you opposed the bill you were treated like a leper or an environmental terrorist. Nobody wanted to discuss the relative risks or the merits. It had been a bad summer, and we all wanted to be able to say we did something. So we passed a law. I tried to have a debate. And it was like I was trying to destroy the planet."
Because of the Ocean Dumping Act, New York City spent $2 billion on giant plants that turn sludge into fertilizer. The city plans to spend at least $300 million a year over the next decade to dispose of its sludge in this way and in others -- many times more than it would cost to dump it in the ocean.
 
Better Ways to Spend
 Even some of the ban's most enthusiastic proponents at major environmental organizations, none of whom would be quoted by name, concede that the money might have been better spent on other problems, like fixing the extensive system of storm sewers that caused the waste to wash up on the beaches in the first place.
Indeed, the ocean dumping ban is a striking triumph of environmental politics over science, a clear demonstration of how environmental policy can often be directed by symbols and fears than by reasoned discussion of benefit and risk.
In 1988, and still today, the real problem came from New York's aged, 6,200-mile network of sewer pipes that mix household waste with rainwater. Normally, it is all treated together. But during storms, sewage treatment plants are quickly overwhelmed, and sewer pipes carry millions of gallons of raw waste directly to the rivers and harbors surrounding the city.
In fact, officials have closed beaches in the summers since 1988 more often than they did before the ban went into effect.
"There is no question that the New York City sewer system is the greatest cause of water pollution in the region; that has almost always been true," said Howard Golub, acting director and chief engineer of the Interstate Sanitary Commission, a regional regulatory agency that for 20 years has been trying in vain to convince people to pay attention to the problem.
"But a sewer system isn't sexy," he added. "It's expensive to fix, and nobody wants to hear about it. So people focused on what they understand -- and they understand that sewage and the sea don't seem nice together."
 
The Real Problem
Wallflower At a Political Dance
 Modern sewerage usually consists of two systems: storm sewers that carry off excess rainwater, and sanitary sewers that handle sewage that needs treatment.
But older, combined systems, like New York City's, serve almost 20 percent of the nation's population, about 50 million people living in the America's oldest cities. For decades they have been the major cause of beach closings and dangerous levels of bacteria in coastal waters. They generally work well enough in normal times; sewage and rainwater are treated together and then discharged.
During a heavy storm, however, so much water washes into the combined system that it is overwhelmed. The treatment centers cannot handle the load and everything -- storm water and sewage -- floods untreated out the pipe.
To solve the sewer problem, New York would have to build enormous subterranean tanks to hold waste water during heavy downpours, and the city Department of Environmental Protection says that could cost several billion dollars. Without them, many beaches in the area will continue to be closed after particularly heavy storms. Every time more than three-quarters of an inch of rain falls, 500 million gallons of mixed sewage pours into area rivers and harbors, the city says.
A report by the State University of New York estimated that sewage overflows cost New York and New Jersey $3 billion to $7 billion in lost jobs, lost fishing days and forfeited economic opportunities in the previous decade.
That report was published in 1988, just as the sewers were flushing syringes and other trash from streets and gutters onto the beaches. Still, almost nobody seriously questioned the need for an immediate ocean dumping ban.
 
'Congress Acted on Emotion'
 As Alan Rubin, a senior Environmental Protection Agency official in charge of determining the risks of disposing of sludge, put it in a recent interview: "By 1988, ocean dumping had become taboo, about as politically incorrect as any disposal of waste can be. Maybe it was a good thing that happened. Maybe not. But it was not decided on the merits. Congress acted on emotion, not on data."
Those who supported the ban now argue that two rights cannot make a wrong. They say that ocean dumping needed to stop and that bills get passed when they can, not always when they make the most sense.
"You take care of emergencies first in life and in politics," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the New Jersey Democrat who was a leader in the fight to end ocean dumping.
Senator Lautenberg agreed that sewage overflows pose a serious health risk, but he added: "Sludge dumping was the equivalent of a fire we could put out. Just because you have earthquakes on the horizon doesn't mean you should let the fire rage."
Mr. Lautenberg asserted that it was not as clear in 1988 as it is today that storm sewers, not ocean dumping, were to blame for most of the trash that appeared on the beaches. But he did agree that the barges heading out to sea provided an image that was too useful to ignore.
"There is simply a point when you have to look at the broader picture," he said. "When we passed the law, it was at the height of a couple of ugly seasons. The waste may not have been a direct result of the ocean dumping, but it did alert people to the fact that we need to stop pouring garbage into the ocean."
 
Unsavory Practice
Where to Put A City's Sludge
 Few people are genuinely unhappy about the demise of a practice in which 1.5 billion gallons of distilled sewage sludge was dumped each day 106 miles off the coast of New Jersey. Even those who say it makes sense to consider using the deep sea to store dangerous wastes acknowledge that the sludge was beginning to find its way into the food chain on the ocean floor.
And while most industrial waste, heavy metals and dangerous contaminants were removed from the sludge before it was dumped in the ocean, it was never possible to extract all the poisons found in a huge sewage system.
For decades, New York dropped its sludge only 12 miles off the coast -- turning vast aquatic reaches into home to nothing but slime. Environmentalists fought for years to end ocean dumping. As a compromise, the Federal Government decided to permit New York and several neighboring cities to shift its dumping to the edge of the continental shelf, where E.P.A. officials said it would do no harm.
But even at 106 miles, where there is no scientific proof that waste disposal causes illness in humans, ocean dumping of waste has proven to be less than ideal. Although researchers first thought sludge dumped there would never reach the bottom of the ocean, scientists now know that some of it does. And when it gets there, it is eaten by animals that are eventually eaten by man.
But scientists argue that it may be just as troublesome to dump the sludge anywhere else. Sludge in landfills can seep into ground water. Even beneficial uses, like turning sewage to fertilizer, costs millions in processing and shipping.
Whatever the ancillary benefits the ocean dumping ban may have offered, it also cost New York a great deal of money. And many officials now say that money could have been put to far better use by trying to resolve the more complicated -- and pressing -- dilemma caused by combined sewer overflows.
"Am I sad that we no longer dump sludge in the Atlantic Ocean? Absolutely not," said Albert F. Appleton, commissioner of New York City's Department of Environmental Protection. He has made clean water a major focus of his tenure. "In a perfect world we simply wouldn't dump our waste at sea. But is that how I would have spent our next $2 billion? Never in a million years."
 
Other Solutions
A Victory Draws Questions
 Tough new laws passed since the mess of 1988 govern the disposal of medical waste. So syringes and intravenous bags no longer show up on beaches with much frequency. And Coast Guard boats now skim coastal waters for other visible debris. But the levels of microscopic organisms that the E.P.A. considers harmful to humans and fish -- the real problem -- are no less serious than they have ever been.
"When environmentalists see a problem they tend to say, 'Let's have a total solution,' " Mr. Appleton said. "They don't say, 'How much bang can we get for our buck?' They don't say, 'Where is the garbage going to go if it isn't in the ocean?' " '
Mr. Appleton certainly considers himself an environmentalist. But he and many others like him say the movement risks its credibility by placing so much emphasis on crowd-pleasing maneuvers like the ban on ocean dumping.
Nina Sankovitch, a senior project lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council who worked for the ocean dumping ban, countered: "Environmentalists have a huge agenda. We can't sit around and calculate what percentage of a problem will any particular law solve. Priorities matter, but they aren't always easy to fit into neat little flow charts. Is dumping sludge worse than burning garbage? Is money spent on recycling better than money spent on clean water? There aren't answers to those questions. So when we have the opportunity to improve the environment we go for it. And the Ocean Dumping Ban Act was a great opportunity."
Ms. Sankovitch says she now focuses much of her attention on the problem of combined sewers. But she said she sees nothing wrong with using the images of 1988 to help ban dumping -- even though the two problems were not connected.
"A victory for the environment is a victory for the environment," she said.
But it is not completely clear that a ban on dumping was such an environmental triumph. The negative effects of burying sludge close to the shores have been documented with precision. But the dangers of dumping it in deeper water are less clear.
Studies have shown that sludge deposited 106 miles out does reach the ocean floor and, in the words of Dr. Frederick Grassle, director of the Rutgers Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences, "it has a minute but measurable impact on the deep-sea ecosystem." However, Dr. Grassle also said that health risks from the dumping appeared to be minimal -- primarily because the ocean rapidly diluted the waste below dangerous concentrations.
Some researchers have proposed the nearly lifeless plains at the bottom of the oceans as a relatively inexpensive, and safe, disposal site for sludge. They argue that at the deepest levels of the sea -- several hundred miles away from any coastline and under nearly 16,000 feet of water -- the sludge will rest undisturbed and harmless.
 
Short-Sighted Proposal?
 However, many environmentalists and some scientists view the research proposals for deep-sea burial of sludge as short-sighted.
"It will take 10 seconds of logic and $10 million to prove that this too will have adverse effects on the environment," said Dr. Elliott A. Norse, a marine ecologist who is chief scientist for the Center for Marine Conservation.
But John Edmond, professor of chemical oceanography at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said: "There are going to be impacts on our society of anything we throw away. That includes ocean dumping. But there is a real crisis in land disposal of our waste, and we have acted to ban even the consideration of ocean dumping.
"Even if we don't use the upper ocean -- and perhaps we should not -- we should think about the sea floor. But people are so emotional about these issues that they can hardly see or think straight."
Next: The problems with laboratory testing.
