HEADLINE: Seeking New Ties and Clout, Korean Grocers Join Voices

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The Korean-American Grocers Association of New York had a surprising guest give the invocation at its annual awards meeting last month: the Rev. Al Sharpton.
The grocers, for whom memories of a black-led boycott in Brooklyn are still fresh, have also sponsored spots on black radio stations honoring heroes like Thurgood Marshall. The Korean Produce Association ran a scholarship program for minority students in conjunction with The Amsterdam News. 
 On another front, the Korean-American Small Business Service Center of New York is fighting a city plan for zoning changes that would allow bigger food stores into the city, as well as lobbying the City Council to crack down on illegal food vendors.
 
Community Relations Efforts
 On a range of issues, Korean business owners in New York are using the strength of their numbers to try to increase their political influence, improve their business opportunities and, perhaps most important, mend their often bitter relations with other ethnic groups in the city.
"Our guys are small, corner store owners," said Myong Y. Juch, president of the grocers' group. "But they are not small when they get together."
The grocers have elicited municipal help to set up a huge new food cooperative to cut their costs drastically. Community relations initiatives by them and others have included taking black leaders on tours of South Korea and sending black students to study there.
And on a political level, the Korean immigrants are banding together to push their concerns by voting as a bloc in this year's mayoral race. Mayor David N. Dinkins, as well as his likely challengers, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Andrew J. Stein, are already campaigning among Korean-Americans.
"If it's possible to get together to support one single candidate, I think it's a great idea," said Bong Jin Sa, executive director of the Korean Produce Association.
In part, the new collective efforts have been prompted by resentment and fear -- resentment over what the Koreans see as misconceptions about them, and fear that they may be vulnerable to ethnic violence. Those concerns were fueled by the bitter black-led boycott of a Korean store in Brooklyn in 1990, and by the anti-Korean violence during the Los Angeles riots last year.
"They have made a collective response," said Pyong Gap Min, a sociologist at Queens College. "They realized they had to be united to survive."
For an immigrant group owning proportionately more small businesses than others, it is hardly surprising that the collective approach is centered around business concerns and articulated by businessmen. In the past, the Koreans have organized fierce and effective boycotts against suppliers who cheated or harassed them.
But this time, their emerging collective approach is necessarily more public. For one thing, the organizations are trying to change the behavior of Korean business people so that they are less likely to spur a negative response. This has been done partly through extensive advertising in New York's four daily Korean newspapers and three cable television channels, among other outlets.
A message repeated over and over is: "Be a Korean-American, not a Korean-Korean."
The business owners are also trying to reach out to other groups. More non-Koreans are being employed in stores, and seminars are being offered to teach Koreans to smile more frequently, something they say is rare in their culture.
 
Consorting With Giants
 "We have to keep contact with our neighbors, because they misunderstand," said Sang Y. Choi, who owns a grocery store on Staten Island. "Sometimes they feel Korean people are angry when they're not."
Mr. Juch counts 300,000 Koreans in the metropolitan region, a slightly higher estimate than some sources. He says they own more than 10,000 businesses, of which 3,500 are groceries, delis or supermarkets. These account for 15 percent of such businesses in the city.
Their total sales approach $1.5 billion. It was thus hardly surprising that the giants of the food industry, from Anheuser-Busch to General Mills, streamed to the association's second annual Food and Trade show last month.
"Just name the company," Mr. Juch declared. "All the largest ones were there, and some small, local companies, too."
Mayor Dinkins and Mr. Stein spoke, and President Clinton and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo sent greetings.
"From the corner deli to the supermarket, Korean-American businesses play a vital role in our communities and country," the President said in his letter.
 
Advice on American Customs
 The grocers' association began in Brooklyn in 1985 with 20 businesses as members, and now has 2,500. Its first task, a continuing one, was to help grocers, most of whose English was at least somewhat lacking, adjust to American business customs.
New shopkeepers learn where to get plastic bags and commercial quantities of ice cream. They also are repeatedly told that four or five Korean grocers are killed annually, and that they must never try to resist robbers.
Hany Sal Ma, an employee of a store in Flatlands, Brooklyn, that was held up by three armed men last week, absorbed the lesson. "We gave them everything that was in the register," he said. "It's better than giving them your life."
Above all, the grocers have been urged to learn American ways. "Turn on your TV and watch it, even if you don't understand it," Mr. Juch implores.
It has been a long, uphill climb for Koreans who began flowing here in 1965 after immigration laws were eased. They gravitated to food stores because language was not such a barrier in that business, and because they could scrape together enough to buy stores in marginal areas. The success of the first wave of immigrants -- who developed the formula of being open long hours and offering glistening fresh vegetables -- spawned imitation.
 
Following a Well-Worn Path
 But many of the grocers fervently hope that their children will be able to escape their own 17-hour workdays by finding other careers. One of Mr. Juch's sons aspires to be a computer expert, while the other hopes to be a cartoonist.
The Koreans see their still-evolving path as almost identical to that followed by other immigrants. "We are no different than the Jews, Italians and other Europeans," Mr. Juch said.
Mr. Juch predicts that there will be a slight increase in the number of Korean grocers over the next decade, then a decline as today's grocers -- who were found to average 42.3 years old in a survey -- retire and are not replaced. The Koreans who remain in the food business, he thinks, will operate much larger stores or be wholesalers.
In the shorter term, the businessmen are banding together to try to accomplish specific objectives. Sung Soo Kim, president of the Korean-American Small Business Service Center, said his group has recently convinced the city's health, consumer affairs and sanitation departments to alter their enforcement procedures for small businesses in ways that make it more predictable.
"Mom-and-pop stores should be firmly protected," Mr. Kim said.
The most pressing issue for Korean merchants is clearly the proliferation of sidewalk food vendors. Mr. Juch says many vendors work for companies holding perhaps 100 licenses, with each employee working a shift, so carts are seldom idle.
 
Fighting Sidewalk Competition
 These competitors have none of the overhead of stores, including insurance, utilities and 14 kinds of direct and indirect taxes. They can also commandeer the best locations.
More than any other issue, it is peddling that is energizing Korean store owners to register and vote. Their goal is to force the city to crack down on illegal vendors and more tightly regulate legal ones.
"We're really going to cry out," Mr. Juch promised, saying he hopes to deliver at least 6,000 votes to the mayoral candidate whose stand on vending seems best. "That's the only way we're going to show our power," he said.
Mr. Sa of the produce group said Koreans' bitter memories of Mayor Dinkins's handling of the year-long boycott in Flatbush, Brooklyn, which was also criticized by the United States Civil Rights Commission, may offer help to his challengers.
"Generally speaking, the Korean community is not quite happy with Dinkins's achievements for the Korean community," he said, stressing this is not necessarily his personal view.
 
Getting Along With Neighbors
 Perhaps the most ambitious project of the Korean businessmen is the New York Korean-American Cooperative, which is moving beyond the research stage after a year and a half. The idea is to escape buying from wholesalers by banding together to buy as a group, and thereby attract lower prices directly from manufacturers.
If this is successful, other such centers may follow. The idea, Mr. Juch emphasized, is not to exclude other ethnic groups but to invite them to join. In particular, he has been calling Dominican organizations to try to interest bodega owners.
But everything will depend on how well the Koreans are able to get along with their neighbors. They remember all too well the nine-month boycott of the Brooklyn grocery in 1990, and the Los Angeles riots, in which many Korean businesses were destroyed. "I thought my store was going to be burned down," Mr. Juch said. "I was giving up on life in New York."
One thing that is certain is that Korean attempts to be involved in the neighborhoods where they do business will be more visible.
For years, in relative anonymity, Korean grocers have given turkeys to the needy, and Korean dry cleaners have distributed unclaimed clothes. By contrast, the 10 minority students winning $1,000 scholarships in the grocers' "Share the Dream" essay contest, co-sponsored by Coca-Cola, will be honored at Harlem's Apollo Theater.
The Rev. Timothy Mitchell, the black pastor of Ebenezer Baptist Church in Flushing, Queens, said the Korean efforts at community outreach as represented by the scholarships are helping. "But there has to be a step further than the giving of moneys," said Mr. Mitchell, who also rents a building to a Korean church group for services. "There's got to be an approach for people to know each other on a personal, comprehensive level."
Mr. Mitchell's hope is that Korean-Americans and blacks can come together in joint commercial ventures. "The problem is that, many times, we don't see the best of each group," he said. "Joint ventures would give us a chance to see the objective reality."

HEADLINE: Russia and Realpolitik

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
As events unfold in Moscow with dizzying speed and unpredictability, the Administration is struggling to temper its strong support for President Boris N. Yeltsin with a dose of Realpolitik.
Ultimately, the Administration knows that what is most important in Russia -- the continuation of democratic and economic reform -- transcends the personal fortunes of one man. 
 In the short term, however, the Administration is clearly reluctant to loosen its embrace of Russia's only democratically elected leader, even when his actions fall short of Western standards of democracy. That is because there is a strong sense in Washington, particularly among those who know and respect Mr. Yeltsin, that he makes the reform movement stick and gives it its dynamism.
 
Russia's de Gaulle?
 To hear some officials talk, Mr. Yeltsin is a sort of Russian-style, present-day de Gaulle poised to deliver his country from chaos by assuming authoritarian powers the way the French war hero did in 1958.
The impulse to forgive Mr. Yeltsin and the conviction that he is more democratic than many others was captured in statements today by Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American representative at the United Nations.
On the ABC News program "This Week," she said, "He is the only one in 1,000 years of Russian history that has been elected by all the Russian people. The others -- the Parliament -- was elected in peculiar ways and contains a lot of very hard-liners." She characterized Mr. Yeltsin as a person who, by ordering national balloting, rightfully wants his fate to be decided directly by the Russian people.
She added that "taking something to the people seems to be the appropriate thing to do as you're evolving democratic institutions."
When asked whether that meant that the Communist-era Constitution and those elected under it are without legitimacy, she replied, "They certainly, in my mind, have less legitimacy."
 
U.S. Supports 'All Reformers'
 But there is another emerging view in the Administration: that while Mr. Yeltsin best embodies the reform movement, he is by no means its only advocate. For that reason, Mr. Clinton and his advisers made sure that in the carefully drawn statement of support for Mr. Yeltsin on Saturday, they pitched a tent large enough to include all those who favor reform in Russia.
It is not that the Administration is drawing up lists of "all the reformers" as potential successors to Mr. Yeltsin, but that Washington recognizes that process is more crucial than personality. Mr. Clinton made that point when he said on Saturday, "What matters most is that Russia is and must remain a democratic country moving toward a market economy."
The importance to the United States of democratic reform and free enterprise -- the process -- in Russia will be the centerpiece of a speech in Chicago on Monday by Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
He is expected to say what he has already articulated piecemeal: that for every American, the stakes of reform in Russia are monumental; that if reform succeeds, it will enhance global security well into the next century. But if it fails, the price will be an increased nuclear threat, a return to higher military spending and a setback for democracy.
Mr. Christopher is likely to emphasize the importance of helping Russia on its long road to reform, which he has called the country's greatest national security problem over the next decade.
 
Sensitive Issue for Clinton
 Part of the Administration's problem in deciding how vigorously to support Mr. Yeltsin stems from the extreme sensitivity to criticism that Mr. Clinton is over-personalizing his diplomacy. Mr. Clinton himself criticized President George Bush during the campaign for investing too much political capital in President Mikhail S. Gorbachev during the Soviet leader's final months in power.
But senior Clinton Administration officials argue that Mr. Bush clung to Mr. Gorbachev even after it became clear that he was resisting the reforms Mr. Yeltsin was propelling forward. They say Mr. Clinton is supporting Mr. Yeltsin because he is a democratically elected leader committed to more, not less, reform.
Leading lawmakers are looking beyond Mr. Yeltsin, even as they continue to embrace him.
Representative Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, told interviewers on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" today that while it is in the national interest to support Mr. Yeltsin now, "there are many other democrats in Russia, and we must be prepared to support them."
And Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, told the group that, of course, the United States supports Mr. Yeltsin, but should be talking to other "key players" as well. "It's not Yeltsin exclusively," he said.
In an effort to hear alternative points of view, Mr. Clinton met quietly last week at the White House with Valery Zorkin, the head of Russia's Constitutional Court. Although Mr. Zorkin helped Mr. Yeltsin compromise with the Russian Congress last December, on Saturday he declared Mr. Yeltsin's assumption of virtually unlimited powers unconstitutional.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN MOSCOW;
Europe Cautiously Supports Yeltsin

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, March 21

 BODY:
Germany, France and other European countries sided cautiously today with President Boris N. Yeltsin as the elected leader of Russia in his showdown with the Russian Parliament, a holdover from the Communist era.
In statements that reflected a consensus that Mr. Yeltsin was the best hope for continued democratic and economic change, European leaders expressed hope that the confrontation would be short-lived and peaceful. 
 The German Government said in a statement that Mr. Yeltsin represented "the unhindered continuation of democratic and free-market reforms" in Russia. The President had Germany's understanding, the statement said, for his declaration of "special rule."
The statement said Bonn backed President Yeltsin because "the last Congress of People's Deputies unilaterally threw into doubt the principle of separation of powers, a key element of any democratic constitution, to the disadvantage of the freely elected President of Russia."
Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, welcomed the Russian Government's profession of continued support for democracy.
 
France Renews Call for Summit
 France renewed its call for a special summit meeting of the Group of Seven major industrialized countries to consider ways of channeling more aid to Mr. Yeltsin and the forces for democracy and economic change in Moscow that he represented. A special summit meeting was "more necessary than ever," Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said.
The French President, Francois Mitterrand, has been pressing to hold such a summit concurrently with President Clinton's planned meeting with the Russian President in Vancouver on April 3 and 4.
Mr. Clinton has also supported calls for more economic aid for Russia, but has apparently not agreed to an emergency Group of Seven meeting.
The German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, said today that foreign and finance ministers of the Group of Seven -- the United States, Germany, France, Japan, Italy, Canada and Britain -- would probably meet in Tokyo on April 20 to discuss a new aid package.
 
Japan Called Obstacle to Aid
 The main obstacle to more aid for Russia, Mr. Kinkel said, was Japan, which has refused to discuss it until the Russians agree to discuss the return of four northern islands that the Soviet Union seized in World War II.
Germany says that since 1989, it has provided more aid to Russia and other states of the former Soviet Union than any other country, a total of nearly $50 billion, including debt forgiveness. But, Mr. Kinkel said on German television, "We were not supported by all our partners."
"The Japanese are the biggest holdouts," he said. "We and the Americans have to press the Japanese harder to help."
The German and French foreign ministers said Mr. Yeltsin's move had not come as a surprise. The Russian leader told Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Moscow early this month that extraordinary measures might be necessary, and in Helsinki last Tuesday, the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, told foreign ministers of states bordering on the Baltic Sea that he had been called back to Moscow to an emergency meeting.
 
G-7 Governments Were Briefed
 Mr. Yeltsin also told President Mitterrand in Moscow last Tuesday that he might have to take strong measures, according to Mr. Dumas.
German officials said that on Saturday evening, at least 90 minutes before Mr. Yeltsin went on Russian television to announce his moves, Mr. Kozyrev called in ambassadors of the Group of Seven countries in Moscow. Separately, he also briefed the Danish ambassador, who represents the current presidency of the 12-nation European Community, these officials reported.
Despite such assertions, neither Germany nor any other European industrial democracy now appears to be able or willing to provide large amounts of economic aid to keep the Russian economy from collapsing.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Support From Japan
 TOKYO, Monday, March 22 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Government expressed optimism today that President Yeltsin's reform policies would be supported by the Russian people in a vote on April 25.
The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Masamichi Hanabusa, said that Japan "strongly expects that President Yeltsin's reform policies will gain the support of the Russian people, and that with stable relations between the Administration and Parliament, the reforms that President Yeltsin has thus far pursued will be continued."
Japan is attempting to organize a meeting at the Cabinet level in Tokyo in mid-April of the Group of Seven major industrialized nations, as part of what Mr. Hanabusa termed "further efforts toward reaching a consensus" about how to support Mr. Yeltsin's reforms.

HEADLINE: The Price Of Tobacco: The Basics

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 21

 BODY:
Ever since the Depression, the Government has lent tobacco farmers a hand by bolstering the prices paid to them on the market. But the farmers like to point out that unlike the growers of other crops whose prices are supported by the Government, they receive help that entails no net cost to the taxpayers -- that is, no "subsidies" in the usual sense.
The tobacco growers' boast, although accurate today, has been strictly true only in the last 11 of the 60 years since the Federal price-support program for tobacco was adopted. And even during this latter period, the Government has had to step in to bail the growers out once, in 1986. The cost was $1.1 billion. 
 The tobacco support program shores up the farmers' prices by limiting production of their crop, setting a minimum price for it at market and providing for loans from a Government agency to farmers' cooperatives.
Along with price-support programs for other crops, it began as a New Deal effort to help bring farmers out of the Depression. It sought to lift prices by limiting the acreage that a given farmer could plant, and it also frequently provided the farmer a subsidy.
In fact, the farmer could receive two subsidies: the Government paid him for acreage that he had been allocated but did not plant, and it made up the difference if the price that he received for his crop at market fell below a target price that had been set for that year.
 
The First Change
 By the end of World War II, the tobacco growers were eager to administer their own support program. So the Government began relinquishing much of that task, at the same time abandoning direct tobacco subsidies.
To replace the old system, Congress in 1946 created a group of farmer-administered "stabilization associations," or cooperatives. Through annual referendums among farmers, the associations set production allotments. The Government's continuing role was to set minimum prices for tobacco and, through its Commodity Credit Corporation, provide loans to the associations. The associations used the money to buy, at the Government-set floor price, any part of a farmer's tobacco allotment that he could not sell on the open market.
The tobacco bought by the farmer associations was stored until it could be sold -- most often at a discount but occasionally at a price higher than the floor. The proceeds were earmarked to pay off the Federal loans and the interest on them.
From time to time, though, the associations came up short. Of the $5 billion in Federal loans granted to the tobacco support program through 1982, $57 million was not paid back. In addition, unpaid interest on the loans amounted to $152.8 million, and agricultural economists say that because of accounting anomalies, that figure actually understates the amount of unpaid interest the Government was forced to write off.
 
Attack on the Industry
 By the early 1980's, tobacco growers were under heavy attack by a coalition of anti-smoking forces and groups opposed to any program that protected farmers through Government-sanctioned limitations on supply. Scrambling to remake the program before the coalition could gain any more allies, Federal lawmakers from the Southeast tried to eliminate anything that could be viewed, even remotely, as a tobacco subsidy.
Under the reshaped program, which took effect in 1982, the farmer associations continued to borrow from the Commodity Credit Corporation, at interest rates pegged to the Government's own cost of borrowing. But they also began to impose an annual assessment on farmers to build up a reserve for times of cash shortfall. No longer would the Government be asked to absorb a loss.
That was the idea, at least. But in 1985, cigarette manufacturers' increasing use of cheaper tobacco grown abroad sent sales of domestic tobacco plummeting. The farmer associations borrowed heavily to buy up the unsold crop, and the assessments on farmers soared to 25 cents for every $1.40 they were receiving at the market. (By comparison, that rate of assessment is roughly 20 times the rate that prevailed last year.)
 
Aid Reduces Assessments
 Against a backdrop of growing crisis, the manufacturers agreed to buy up a surplus of 547 million pounds of tobacco over the next several years (although at deeply discounted prices) and to join the farmers in paying annual assessments, sharing the cost of running the price-stabilization program. In addition, a new mechanism was established to predict more accurately manufacturers' needs for domestic tobacco in any given year, an effort to avoid the market glut of 1985.
The Government pitched in, too. In 1986, it wrote off $1.1 billion in loans that it had made to the farmer associations, a step that allowed the assessments on individual farmers to begin dropping back to normal.
These days the program is back on footing that allows a tobacco grower to be absolutely truthful when he says it imposes no net cost on the taxpayers.

HEADLINE: Mayoral Race Is On (Well, Sort Of);
It's Unofficial, but Dinkins Is Squaring Off With Four Rivals

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The Democratic mayoral primary is six months away, with the general election two months after that. None of the major candidates for mayor has formally announced his candidacy, and the radio and television airwaves have yet to be littered with self-aggrandizing commercials.
But make no mistake about it: the New York City mayoral race has begun, though in a quiet way. 
 The mayoral candidates and their handlers are in a sort of political spring training, trying out themes and honing messages away from the glare of publicity that will magnify every action and remark in the campaign's later stages.
In his first overtly political appearances of the race, Mayor David N. Dinkins last week sketched out the framework of his campaign, asserting that New York was a safer, more fiscally secure and more just city than when he took office in 1990 -- despite the deep and prolonged recession.
For their part, the three other Democrats and the Republican who want his job have been appearing before community groups in all five boroughs, depicting a very different city. Each in his own way has argued that the Mayor's efforts have failed and that New Yorkers are still fearful of crime and worried about the local economy.
Last week, for the first time, Mr. Dinkins and his three Democratic challengers -- City Council President Andrew J. Stein; Herman Badillo, the former Bronx borough president, and Roy Innis, the president of the Congress of Racial Equality -- appeared separately at a candidates' forum, held on Tuesday at Wagner College by the Staten Island Democratic Committee.
The previous week, both Mr. Badillo and Mr. Stein inadvertently picked the same day to attack the Mayor at City Hall. Mr. Badillo stood on the front steps to criticize Mr. Dinkins for what he described as a deliberate policy of cutting back on arrests of street-level drug dealers. Mr. Stein chose City Hall Park for a rally with about 100 senior citizens opposing the Mayor's proposed budget cuts at centers for the elderly. And the Mayor's probable Republican opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney in Manhattan, has also been campaigning informally, speaking almost daily, but with little fuss or fanfare, to neighborhood and community groups throughout the city.
Political strategists' conventional wisdom is that voters do not really concentrate on an election until a campaign's final days, and so candidates' oratory is not likely to begin heating up until the weather does.
Even so, like avid baseball fans, New York City politicians have been eagerly awaiting the official opening day of the 1993 mayoral race, which most have long presumed would be Mr. Stein's formal announcement that he was challenging Mr. Dinkins.
 
Stein Trailing in Polls
 Mr. Stein, trailing the Mayor by almost 30 percent points in several recent polls, has been promising an unusually early and very expensive media campaign to bring his candidacy to the voters' attention. The Council President has maintained that once New Yorkers were aware of what he proposes to do as mayor, his showing in the polls would improve dramatically. In fact, Mr. Stein said last month that by mid-April his television campaign would so improve his standing that he would be within 6 or 8 percentage points of Mr. Dinkins.
But Mr. Stein acknowledged in an interview on Friday that he was behind schedule. He said he now expected to begin airing his television ads in about a month. Asked why his timetable had been set back, he said, "It's a creative and complicated process."
He argued that he would still be on the air much earlier than the other candidates, and much earlier than virtually all previous mayoral campaigns. "We're getting started a little later, but we're still giving ourselves plenty of time," he said.
Mr. Stein also dismissed speculation that he was considering a withdrawal from the race. He said he would definitely run and insisted that he was still supremely confident he would win. "I think that in the spring, in May or June, this will be a very tight race," he said.
But even without a formal announcement or the start of the elaborate television campaign that Mr. Stein envisions -- including Perot-style "infomercials" and audience participation specials -- he has been busy campaigning.
At the forum on Staten Island, he sounded themes he has been polishing in appearances around the city. Mr. Stein contended, for example, that Mayor Dinkins had failed to make city workers more productive, that he had not adequately addressed concerns about crime and that he had not done enough to counter the recession.
He noted that the Mayor often cites statistics that show crime decreased significantly in the city over the last two years. "He said that people feel safer in this city," Mr. Stein said. "Mr. Mayor, what city do you live in? I don't think it's this city because I don't think people feel safer."
 
'Not Arresting Anybody'
 "The reason crime statistics are down is that they are not arresting anybody," he added. "People are selling drugs all over this city in broad daylight, and this administration's official policy is not to arrest them.
"They are also closing jails. Dave, when I'm mayor I'm going to open the jails and I'm going to put those drug addicts in them because that's where they belong."
Mr. Stein also outlined proposals to get municipal workers to be more productive by introducing the element of competition, with private companies bidding to do work now performed by city employees. He said he would change Civil Service rules so the city could pay incentives to workers who do a good job and penalize or even dismiss those who do not.
He pledged to "fundamentally change the way the city does business," and he contended that by doing so, he could simultaneously enhance city services and reduce taxes.
Mr. Badillo and Mr. Innis also derided the Mayor's claim that crime was declining. Mr. Innis, perhaps the most conservative of the four Democrats, criticized school officials for introducing the disputed curriculum for teaching respect for homosexual families and for distributing condoms. Mr. Badillo said he would press for higher standards and better performance in public education.
The Mayor, who spoke first at the forum, offered a different perspective. "It's been my task to lead our city through some of the most difficult challenges in our modern history," he said, citing soaring unemployment and welfare caseloads. "Under difficult circumstances I think we've done a pretty extraordinary job of making the tough choices."
Mr. Dinkins listed at length what he views as his administration's accomplishments, from reducing the size of the municipal work force to freezing corporate and property tax rates to balancing the city budget each year.
He also described his major initiatives: the expansion of the police force and a shift toward community policing; the opening of new primary-care health clinics in poor communities, and the creation of so-called beacon schools, which are open from early morning to late evening and offer adult education, recreation and social services. On Friday, he said for the first time that he hoped to make the mayoral race a referendum on his proposal to restructure the Board of Education to give the Mayor control over the schools.

HEADLINE: Motor Vehicles Moves to Shed Its Poor Image

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Aware that they run New York State's most hated bureaucracy, officials in the Department of Motor Vehicles are planning a broad overhaul of services that promises to make the agency trimmer, more efficient and much more user-friendly within 18 months.
The officials, who have requested $6 million from the Legislature for the changes, say that their primary aim is to improve customer service and that they hope to eventually shed the unpleasant image that has long been associated with their agency. 
 For years, the reasons for dissatisfaction have been obvious to anyone who visited a district office: endless waits, surly clerks, poor information and a bureaucratic system that often forces people to spend half a day on a transaction that might take only 15 minutes in another state.
Mob scenes that have characterized the department's New York City offices will now be eased, officials say. Some changes are as simple as they are overdue, like an automatic queuing system that allows a person to take a number and a seat rather than stand in line. The system will be installed in the Staten Island office this week and in others by the end of next year.
 
'We Need a Cultural Change'
 Other changes are more ambitious, like tightening management so that the atmosphere in district offices is more businesslike and less openly antagonistic. Some recent customer experiences, like being yelled at after waiting in line seven hours, and being caught in a stampeding crowd at opening time, may become rarer.
"We are the beast of state government," acknowledged Patricia B. Adduci, New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. "We need a cultural change."
The need for an overhaul, she said, is widely recognized among officials in Albany. After all, she noted, this is the department that in 1984 was dead last in the nation to put photographs on drivers' licenses.
Ms. Adduci said the department's plan was developed after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo asked late last year for a proposal on how to improve service. The plan will be made public if financing is approved in the budget due April 1.
Some changes have already begun. Identification numbers have been cut from 19 digits -- even Ms. Adduci did not know why the numbers were so long -- to 9 digits on new licenses. The department has also made it easier to get special license plates.
 
Private Driving Tests
 More substantive changes, Ms. Adduci said, will be made within 18 months: private driving schools will give written and road tests, and telephone service will have more and better-trained operators who can give answers about a license or registration, reducing the number of people who need to visit a district office.
There are plans to open "quick stop" offices in midtown Manhattan and suburban malls, with automatic tellers to renew a license or registration. This year, three more offices will open, one in Brooklyn at Coney Island, and two in Queens, in College Point and Rockaway.
At the existing Queens office, at 165th Street and 92d Avenue in Jamaica, an overhaul is long overdue. Its dank, mustard-colored waiting room, usually crowded with a thousand or so drivers and car owners shuffling slowly in long, snaking lines, is a picture of lethargic bureaucracy.
Of the three dozen clerks in the main hall at 2 one recent afternoon, about half sat far behind the counter, chatting and laughing or wandering about without any apparent purpose. Those actually at work by the counter were unsmiling and slow moving.
 
A Trick: Go at Closing
 "You want to know the quickest way to get through here?" asked Edward Young, a limousine driver waiting to pick up new license plates. "You come at 4:30, just before they close. The clerks want to go home, and they help everyone as fast as they can."
Indeed, after 4 P.M., almost all the clerks who had been chatting two hours earlier were now serving customers at the counter.
Dozens of people besides Mr. Young were willing to tell a favorite story about the department's problems. But no one could top the experience of Roy Brown, who waited in lines for seven hours one day late last month only to be told he would have to come back another day.
"I may have to kill somebody," Mr. Brown said, his frustration competing with exhaustion. "I really don't understand why it has to be this way."
Mr. Brown arrived at 9:45 A.M. to renew the registration for the seven ambulance vans that are the centerpiece of his family's business. He waited in line for an hour to be told that for multiple renewals he had to go to another line, at the window for bulk transactions. There was no sign.
 
Yelled At After 7 Hours
 A clerk explained that the bulk window closed at 9:30 A.M., 30 minutes after opening and 15 minutes before he arrived. The van registrations expired the next day, so Mr. Brown was determined to renew them even if it meant standing in the regular line seven times, once per van.
By 4 P.M., having run outside every half-hour to put 50 cents in a parking meter, Mr. Brown was in a long line of weary car owners for the fourth time, and was nearing the end of his patience. His mother, Edna Brown, cut her afternoon classes at York College to come help, and she would apply to renew one of the vans herself. Or maybe two, she said, if the clerk seemed nice.
Mother and son ended up at adjacent windows. The clerk serving her approved two van registrations. His clerk, who recognized him from an earlier transaction, rejected the one he submitted and yelled: "Get out of here! We told you already: bulk window for bulk transactions!"
Sheila Seabrook, director of the Queens office, would not answer questions about why identical applications, submitted at adjacent windows, were treated differently. She referred all questions to the department's headquarters in Albany.
 
Improved, but Under Review
 Robert Waters, executive deputy director of the department, said that the handling of multiple transactions would be reviewed as district office management is improved.
But he insisted that service had improved in the past two years. As more drivers renew a license or registration by mail, he said, average waiting times have dropped.
He also cited Brooklyn's new office, which opened last September on Hudson Avenue at Flatbush Avenue to replace the former office on Schermerhorn Street. The office was laid out to keep lines orderly, and in a recent visit there, the clerks were seen to be noticably more courteous than their counterparts in Queens.
Yet the Brooklyn office is not without problems. One day recently Orlando Ivey took his place in line outside the office about 6:45 A.M., more than two hours before the doors opened, hoping to beat the crowd.
 
Guard Watches Stampede
 When the doors opened at 9 A.M., however, Mr. Ivey watched in dismay as the line dissolved and several hundred people stampeded through the doorway, shoving one other as a lone security guard watched helplessly.
"I don't understand why they don't do something about this," said Mr. Ivey. "It wouldn't be that hard for them to first let in the people who arrived early."
Department officials hope that the changes will eventually produce economic efficiency. But Ms. Adduci could not offer a timetable for the savings. And in the coming fiscal year, she acknowledged, the plan requires more money, not less.
It counts on $6 million in new financing that is part of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's $178 million budget proposal for the department, which requires legislative approval. Michael J. Bragman of Cicero, chairman of the Assembly's Transportation Committee, said that most of his colleagues would support anything likely to improve service by the department -- a heavy source of constituent complaints -- but added that only part of the budget increase may be approved.
 
Concern Over Private Testing
 Another proposal that may draw opposition is the plan to transfer all the written and road tests to private driving schools. Ms. Adduci said that it makes sense for new drivers to be tested at the same place where they learn to operate a car. She said the plan would allow the department to concentrate on other services, like issuing licenses and registrations.
However, driving examiners fear that putting the testing into the hands of private driving schools will encourage abuse.
"It's an obvious conflict of interest to have the same school teach students and then give them a road test," said Arthur Handel, a supervisor in the Motor Vehicles office in Yonkers, who worked as a driving instructor until he joined the department a dozen years ago. "You could easily have schools skimming over the instruction, and approving anyone who paid a full fee."
Ms. Adduci responded that supervision of the schools could be tightened.
For many New York drivers, the department will have to change greatly, but for others, the irritation is not as bad as it could be.
Bai Youngmin, 39, a security guard who arrived from China two years ago, said the office in Queens where he stood in line for two hours was nothing like the bureaucracy he encountered in his native land.
"It took me four years to get a driver's license in China," Mr. Bai said. "This is easy."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Amsterdam News's Blunt Publisher Still Has Visions of Running The Post

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
To many, the news that The New York Post's prospective owner, Abraham Hirschfeld, had agreed on Friday to rehire Pete Hamill, the newspaper's editor, seemed to suggest that there would be no role at the paper for Wilbert A. Tatum, the publisher of The Amsterdam News, whom Mr. Hirschfeld had previously announced as his choice for editor.
But for Mr. Tatum, there is no such assumption. "I will be the co-publisher and editor in chief-designee," he said in an interview Friday night. "As co-publisher, I am essentially going to be Pete's boss. As co-publisher, I am in a position of authority." 
 Indeed, these have been days of uncertainty and controversy for Mr. Tatum, the 60-year-old publisher of the largest weekly newspaper aimed at black New Yorkers. He is accustomed to controversy.
In the 22 years Mr. Tatum has led The Amsterdam News, he has been cheered and vilified by readers for editorial positions: his defense of Tawana Brawley; his printing the name of the Central Park jogger who was raped; his stinging weekly diatribes against Mayor Edward I. Koch. While the staff of The Post last week gained attention by publishing dozens of unflattering articles about Mr. Hirschfeld, they also attacked Mr. Tatum and his journalistic values.
A man who speaks in a clipped, declamatory, almost theatrical manner -- he will even suggest the punctuation for his own quotes to an interviewer -- Mr. Tatum is a bundle of complexities.
 
Subordinates Are Careful
 Few among his staff at The Amsterdam News would speak about him for attribution. But privately, they describe a man who expresses passionate views on fairness for minorities, yet who is so stubborn and occasionally petty that he alienates even those who agree with him.
Andrew Cooper, publisher of The City Sun, a competing black weekly newspaper based in Brooklyn, is also a detractor. "He is egomaniacal and, more than anything, he likes to frequent those social affairs at which he can rub elbows with rich white people," said Mr. Cooper, a writer and columnist for The Amsterdam News from the mid-70's to the early 80's.
Mr. Tatum "controls everything that goes into that newspaper," he added. "If you're talking about editorial integrity, it ain't there."
But the publisher has his admirers, as well. "He is bold and daring," said Chuck Sutton, president of Apollo Theater Productions, an arm of the Inner City Broadcasting Company, in which Mr. Tatum is a major shareholder. "He has provided leadership on a number of political issues," Mr. Sutton said. "You might not agree with him, but he's refreshing."
Mr. Tatum describes himself as a manager who "gives people a chance to use their heads to the fullest and let them run with the ball."
Of Mr. Cooper's criticism, he said: "Cooper is unimportant. He is making an effort to ride the reputation of The Amsterdam News, to make a place in the sun for himself. For all intents and purposes, he is without class."
Some of the harshest criticisms against Mr. Tatum have included accusations of anti-Semitism, based on the critics' interpretations of some of Mr. Tatum's editorials. "It is a bald-faced lie," he said of the charge. "There's no one in the world who can point to a single statement I have made that could be construed as being anti-Semitic."
Some of the anti-Semitism accusations arose from Mr. Tatum's defense of Leonard Jeffries, a black professor who was removed last spring from his position as head of African-American studies at the City College of New York because of his comments about blacks and Jews "In the Jeffries case, I insisted on his right to say whatever he wanted to say," Mr. Tatum said.
Through all the controversy, his Amsterdam News has usually held its own financially, surviving recessions that have killed or badly bruised other black publications.
The paper is privately owned, and few details of its financial condition are known. Selvin Michael, its controller and vice president, said The Amsterdam News, which is the principal component of the Amnews Corporation, has been profitable for 7 of the last 10 years.
 
Response to Strike
 A notable year of unprofitability was 1983, when the paper endured a six-month strike by reporters, editors and advertising personnel of the Newspaper Guild. When the strike was over, Mr. Tatum cut the staff by a third and slashed other costs.
But losses continued until 1986, when the paper had increases in local and national advertising amid improvement in the broad economy. Mr. Michael said that final figures for 1992 had not been compiled, but that "it looks like it will be a profitable year." The paper had revenue last year of about $4 million, Mr. Michael said, twice the level of 10 years ago.
The Amsterdam News was founded in 1909, and Mr. Tatum's stewardship represents only the third ownership group in the paper's history. He bought the paper with a group of investors, among them Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President; H. Carl McCall and John L. Edmonds, a lawyer.
All but Mr. Edmonds sold their shares. The ownership by Mr. Tatum and Mr. Edmonds has been characterized by a relentless battle over who, in fact, has a controlling interest in the paper. Mr. Tatum contends that he owns 65 percent of the shares, with Mr. Edmonds owning the balance.
Mr. Edmonds has contended in a lawsuit that Mr. Tatum illegally issued additional shares in the company to dilute Mr. Edmonds's stake.
Some who have studied the black press say that Mr. Tatum has given The Amsterdam News a distinctive voice. "He has given the paper more toughness and has increased the coverage beyond the black community locally," said Roland E. Wolseley, a retired journalism professor at Syracuse University and author of "The Black Press, U.S.A."
Mr. Tatum has long had an interest in running The New York Post. In 1988, he made a $35 million bid to acquire it, with the backing of Michael Milken and Drexel Burnham Lambert, which agreed to provide financing. But The Post, then owned by Rupert Murdoch, was instead sold to Peter S. Kalikow.
A 60-year-old native of North Carolina who lost his Southern accent by speaking in high school oratory contests, Mr. Tatum began in journalism working for three small newspapers founded by his father to provide information to black farmers.
Moving to New York, he became active in the community, and in 1966 was named by Mayor John V. Lindsay as assistant director of community relations for the Buildings Department. Later, he held urban-renewal posts.
Mr. Tatum and his wife, the former Susan Kohn, a Jewish refugee from Czechoslovakia, own a real estate holding company. They and their 22-year-old daughter live in a restored town house in the East Village.
 
But Why The Post?
 In the interview, Mr. Tatum said his interest in The Post was fed by the belief that "nowhere in America is there a major journalistic organ that can combat racism in the media." He added, "There is no voice in journalism that can take a lie one hears from radio, television or reads in a paper, and explain why that lie was told."
He said Mr. Hirschfeld had offered him a "significant" equity stake in the Post, but that the details had not been made final.
Asked what Mr. Hirschfeld was up to in rehiring Mr. Hamill, he replied: "I give up."
As to the notion of The Amsterdam News and The Post being combined in some way, which Mr. Hirschfeld briefly tossed out early last week, he said there was no plan for a merger, but that if it happened, "there will be joint marketing and distribution only."
"The Post will have nothing to do with the editorial policy of the Amsterdam News, and vice versa," he added.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN MOSCOW;
Muscovites Answer Yeltsin, And Their Verdict Is Mixed

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 21

 BODY:
As demonstrators gathered by the Russian Parliament building today on the banks of the Moscow River, President Boris N. Yeltsin got his first set of early returns from the Russian people, who will be asked in a month to break the country's political stalemate.
By midafternoon, two opposing crowds had formed, facing off across barricades reinforced by rows of parked jeeps and buses. One was rallying under a forest of red Soviet flags, symbol of the Communist-nationalist opposition to Mr. Yeltsin's Government; the other, across the street, was waving the white, red and blue of the Russian tricolor, which has become Mr. Yeltsin's emblem. 
 The two crowds never met, but the mood on both sides reflected a deep division in Russian society between those loyal to Mr. Yeltsin and his program of economic and political change and those who blame him for the collapse of a system, a country and a way of life that they still hold sacred.
 
Yeltsin's Ratings Up
 It is too early to tell which way the balloting will go on April 25, the date set by Mr. Yeltsin for a vote of confidence in his leadership and on his proposals for a new constitution. His rating rose slightly in recent public opinion polls -- from 30 percent to 36 percent -- after the recent session of the Congress of People's Deputies, where he received a drubbing at the hands of the majority.
By contrast, his archrival, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, the Speaker of the Congress -- whose sarcastic asides and harsh oratory are regarded by many as unseemly -- was given positive ratings by only 12 percent of Muscovites polled by the Independent Institute of Sociology and Parliamentarism.
After Mr. Yeltsin's appeal to the nation and his assumption of virtually unlimited powers on Saturday, only a few thousand pro-Yeltsin demonstrators turned out in Moscow today. The anti-Yeltsin crowd outweighed his supporters in numbers and in vehemence. At one point, a group of jeering Communists attacked an ABC News camera crew, a sign of the anti-Western sentiment that is rising among the opposition.
Milling around the parking lot behind the White House, as the Parliament building is called, a mostly elderly crowd held up an eclectic collection of Stalin portraits, signs mourning the loss of the Soviet Union and banners accusing Mr. Yeltsin of staging a coup and declaring a dictatorship.
One sign, a parody of an old slogan that says Lenin still lives, captured the demonstrators' contempt for Russia's first elected President. "Yeltsin drinks, drank and will always drink," it read, to the delight of passersby.
 
Echo of Resistance
 On the other side of the road, among the "democrats" as the old opponents of Communism are still called, there was a faint echo of the passions that had collected around the White House in August 1991, when Mr. Yeltsin was leading the resistance to an attempted coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
"We elected him as President, and we will stand by him until the end," Bogdan Titov, a 45-year-old historian, said of Mr. Yeltsin. "What we have now in the country is a vacuum of power, and that is frightening."
Mr. Titov described the two demonstrations as opposing electrical fields, one positive and one negative.
"For retired people, with little money, these are difficult times," he said. "Before, people could count on having enough money to pay for their own burial. Now they can't. Those are people who think only about today. Here, we already think in a more modern way. Our world has become wider in these last few years."
 
Elsewhere, Calm
 Beyond the area around the White House, Moscow was quiet, as most Russians went about their Sunday business, absorbing the latest in a series of political shocks that have jolted their lives over the last few years. But most people were well aware of Mr. Yeltsin's speech, and the reaction it spawned among his opponents and supporters.
For some, the President's speech came as a relief, the first resolute step that might finally end the political cacophony that has filled their television screens for several months now.
"We need to come to some kind of decision," said Olimpiada Blinova, a 54-year-old engineer. "I think he should have done this a long time ago, and now I am afraid it is too late."
Support for Mr. Yeltsin has waned over the last year, as people struggle to survive with inflation that has been rising at a rate of 25 percent a month. "I was for Yeltsin during the coup and afterward," said Vika Revazova, an 18-year-old art student. "I thought he would somehow improve our lives and this country. Now I've lost confidence."
But for all the grumbling, Mr. Yeltsin still has no serious rivals for the people's affections. "There is no one else to support but Yeltsin," said Aleksandr Sidarov, a 30-year-old doctor. "At this moment, there is no one else out there."
"Life is hard," said Mariya Voloshina, a 53-year-old doctor from Yekaterinburg, Mr. Yeltsin's hometown. "I think that in the country, people don't really understand what this is all about. We haven't had human rights and freedom for that long. People don't know what freedom is."

HEADLINE: CLINTON CONSIDERS MEASURES TO HELP TROUBLED AIRLINES

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, seeking to reverse the financial plight of the nation's airlines, is considering loan guarantees and tax relief for the companies and the lifting of restrictions on foreign ownership of airlines.
The proposals are part of a broad approach that includes creation of a 15-member commission that will have 90 days to come up with recommendations. The commission has been authorized by the House; the Senate is expected to approve the idea shortly. 
 In coming to the aid of the airline industry, which has lost $10 billion in the last three years, the Administration is poised to play a far more active role than its market-oriented Republican predecessor.
Representative Norman Y. Mineta, Democrat of California and chairman of the Committee on Public Works and Transportation, said that during the Reagan and Bush Administrations, "whenever there was a problem, the Department of Transportation felt, 'Let the marketplace do its thing,' " adding, "This Administration will be much more proactive."
 
Four-Point Strategy Urged
 The General Accounting Office, the research arm of Congress, earlier this month recommended a four-point strategy; relax restrictions on foreign investment and control; enhance access abroad for United States airlines; reduce barriers to competition, including frequent-flier programs and computer reservation systems that favor the airline owning the system, and examine pricing practices, especially those of bankrupt airlines.
Yet for all the planning, there is a growing consensus in and out of Washington that an improved economy will solve many of the industry's problems, helping fill airplane seats and presumably leading to higher fares.
"Boeing told us that the best way to improve their business in Seattle was to improve the economy," Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said in an interview in his office overlooking the Potomac River. "That's the foundation of our strategy."
While some airlines, particularly weaker ones, have been courting foreign partners, an alternative under discussion in Washington is Government-sponsored loan guarantees.
 The guarantees would help airlines get lower-interest loans for the renovation or replacement of 2,600 older aircraft by the year 2000, a move required by a 1990 law that directs the airlines to use newer, quieter aircraft. This could prove a boon to the United States aircraft manufacturers, Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, which President Clinton has promised to help in the face of stiff competition from Airbus Industrie of Europe.
 
 
Example of Chrysler and Conrail
 "We've done that before, as a matter of domestic policy, to help Chrysler and Conrail and other transportation sectors," Mr. Pena said. "What's so different about the airline industry?
"If we think it's important to have domestically owned American airlines, we have to make sure we support that policy and not simply assume that we should allow foreign investment to occur willy-nilly and wake up in the year 2010 and realize that every airline in the U.S. has substantial ownership by foreigners."
A cautious note was sounded by Representative James L. Oberstar, Minnesota Democrat and chairman of the Aviation subcommittee, who warned: "It may be that the best thing we can do is not do anything. My biggest concern is that people are looking for a quick fix."
 
 
Industry Is Divided
 The airline industry itself is divided on several key issues. While the weaker airlines want an easing of restrictions on foreign ownership as a way of obtaining much-needed investments, stronger airlines oppose the move on the ground that it would give foreign airlines greater access to the United States domestic market but may do nothing to secure more competitive foreign markets for American carriers that fly overseas.
The stronger airlines seek tightening of the bankruptcy laws, a move opposed by the airlines that have already filed for protection from creditors. America West, T.W.A. and Continental Airlines are still in Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
Although many airline woes are self-inflicted -- overcapacity, overexpansion of routes and fare wars -- the White House and many legislators believe some problems stem from unfair competition from overseas airlines.
"Our domestic carriers don't have the same opportunities to access foreign markets as do foreign carriers accessing domestic markets," Mr. Pena said. "If you look at some of the bilateral agreements, they were not drafted in such a way as to give our carriers open access to European markets.
 
 
'I'm the Equalizer'
 "I'm the equalizer," he continued. "My job is to open those markets, and make sure that our domestic carriers get a fair shake and a fair break." Thus, in approving last week the British Airways investment in USAir, the Clinton Administration stipulated, in effect, that Britain had one year to provide a better operating climate for United States airlines.
Signaling his new role, Mr. Pena in February approved complaints against Japan and Australia for restrictions on American airlines that he said violated their agreements with the United States. Unless these practices are ended, Mr. Pena is empowered to limit the access of foreign airlines from those countries to the United States.
Mr. Pena is on record as favoring the current 25 percent limit on voting stock owned by foreign investors and the 49 percent limit on their overall investment, but he said that the commission would study the issue. Mr. Oberstar said the 25 percent limit should be loosened "only if foreign carriers give us the same opportunity for ownership."
 
 
Some Outdated Concerns
 The G.A.O. has noted that some of the reasons the restrictions were adopted -- protecting a fledgling industry, for example -- are no longer a concern. Allowing greater foreign investment could help some United States airlines remain competitive, the agency said, but it also acknowledged national security concerns and recommended that Congress authorize the Defense Department to review foreign ownership transactions.
Washington is sympathetic to the airline industry's request for tax relief. The industry has been hit hard by the alternative minimum tax, which assures that corporations and individuals with substantial deductions have to calculate their taxes in a manner that assures some payment.
"We have the unconscionable situation in which our carriers have lost a great sum of money but have been obliged to go out and borrow money to pay taxes," said James E. Landry, president of the Air Transport Association, which represents the major American carriers.
The AMR Corporation, American Airlines' parent company, reported a loss of $280 million for 1990 and 1991 but paid an alternative minimum tax of $234 million for those two years, said Michael J. Durham, the airline's senior vice president and chief financial officer.
 
 
Tax Relief Sought
 Since the airlines will be hit by the proposed increase in the fuel tax, some Washington policy makers say that the carriers deserve some relief from the alternative minimum tax. "If you take the cumulative effect of all these taxes and charges, it clearly affects the industry," Mr. Pena said.
The stronger airlines also want a review of the bankruptcy laws to prevent the numerous extensions received by some airlines in bankruptcy protection, under which they do not have to pay all their bills.
Mr. Durham of American Airlines said: "We failed to foresee a situation in which failed carriers would be artificially kept alive, thus perpetuating capacity excess to the market's needs. Airlines that have obviously failed and are being sustained only by the life-support system of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code are imperiling the future of all U.S. carriers."
Representative Mineta noted that "America West just got its fifth extension," adding: "This puts other carriers at a disadvantage. They have to pay all their bills on a daily basis. Bankrupt airlines are always looking for ways to increase their cash flow and offer lower fares."
 
 
Bankrupt Airlines Defended
 Representative Oberstar disagreed. "Bankrupt carriers are not the problem," he said. "It wasn't Continental or T.W.A. that offered 50 percent fares or allowed parents to fly free with kids, it was American and Northwest. To blame the bankrupt carriers for the problems of the industry just doesn't add up."
Another change Washington is contemplating is rolling back the passenger ticket tax to 2 percent from 8 percent. Also under review will be the $3 passenger charge imposed by some airports. "A great many worthwhile projects have been built with this money," Mr. Mineta said, "but a new and largely uncontrolled cost burden has also been put on the airlines at precisely the time they can least afford it."
Lowering the consumer's cost by cutting ticket taxes and passenger charges may encourage more travel, airline officials say.
The airlines also strain under the weight of what Mr. Durham of American Airlines called "unnecessary, cost-inefficient regulation."
 
 
Relief from Regulations
 One regulation that the Clinton Administration may change for airlines is the 1988 drug-testing requirement. Airlines, like trains, bus and truck companies, are required to test half their employees at random every year. "I think the alcohol and drug testing went too far," Mr. Oberstar said.
The Government is also likely to review a security measure imposed in 1989 that required airports to install elaborate computer-based employee screening systems at 270 airports. Although the initial cost estimate was $168 million, the cost now exceeds $500 million, according to Mr. Landry of the Air Transport Association.
"We now have crews unable to get to their aircraft without being escorted by security personnel," Mr. Landry said.
The airlines also say they need more runways and expanded air-traffic control capacity. Last week, the Federal Aviation Administration announced an additional 14-month delay in its modernization program, already four years behind schedule, for the air-traffic control system.
The National Business Aircraft Association, which represents the major airline associations, attributed the delay to overly optimistic schedules, a shortage of qualified F.A.A. officials, outside contractors, internal organizational problems, supervision lapses and policy mistakes.

HEADLINE: Apple Offers New System For Desktops

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 19

 BODY:
In a shift that would have been unthinkable a decade ago, Apple Computer Inc. will introduce on Monday a line of multi-user computers designed to make the company's desktop systems more appetizing for corporate buyers.
The new computer family, which features three "server" computers to store and retrieve data for networks of desktop machines, is a sharp contrast to the "one worker, one computer" credo on which Apple has stood since it was founded in the mid-1970's. 
 The new computers, called Workgroup Servers, are the first major products from Apple's enterprise systems division, a new organization that is part of the strategy of Apple's chairman, John Sculley, to place the company in a range of markets from hand-held computing to centralized corporate systems.
So-called client-server computing based on specialized data storage computers connected to desktop machines is rapidly displacing the traditional mainframe and mini-computers of the 1960's for cost and performance reasons.
 
Seeking Market Inroads
 Apple is hoping that it can defend its installed base of Macintoshes and make inroads into the rapidly growing server market by taking advantage of Macintosh ease-of-use features.
"No one has really figured out the server market at the application level," said Douglas A. Cayne, a market researcher in the Santa Clara, Calif., office of Dataquest Inc., a market research company. "Apple is absolutely in the ball park, but the big challenge is to break out of their image of being a Mac-only niche player."
The Apple Workgroup servers will range from $3,000 to $5,000 for the low-end model 60 and $9,000 to $15,000 for the high-end model 95. The systems have two to four times the data- transfer performance of Apple's top-of-the-line Quadra models.
Apple executives said there was a clear demand for the new systems from the company's customers, including classroom users and desktop publishing operations.
They also said they believed that the new Apple systems would make inroads in markets based on specific applications provided with the new computers.
 
'A Credible Offering'
 "We believe we have a credible offering and will be able to go head to head with servers offered by Compaq, I.B.M. and clone makers," said Morris Taradalsky, vice president and general manager of Apple's enterprise systems division.
Apple is counting on its ability to simplify complex programs like Oracle's relational data base management to attract corporate buyers who see ease-of-use as a cost-saving factor, Mr. Taradalsky said.
The company is also counting on interest in an innovative text-search program originally developed in Apple's advanced technology group as a research project. The program, called Applesearch, is designed to index unstructured text documents stored on a central server computer.
Applesearch is an early example of what computer scientists call "agent" software technology. These are programs that can be trained to perform some specialized task -- digesting a news wire, for example, and formatting it into a daily newspaper displayed on a computer screen.
Applesearch will also allow a computer user to search through thousands of documents quickly and find the closest relevant match to a particular query.
