SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 4; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1727 words

HEADLINE: Shakespeare Festival's Boss: Idealistic, Romantic and Busy

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
It was about a month ago, George C. Wolfe recalled, that he was asked by the executive committee of the New York Shakespeare Festival's board if he'd be interested in taking over the reins of the institution from JoAnne Akalaitis. He was. Then they asked him what he'd do with it.
"I told them what I'm passionate about," he said in an interview. "I said you can't create an oasis for writers but you can create a home for them. You can say to someone, 'I like your play; I'm going to produce it.' And then when the play is falling apart in previews, you can say, 'I'm going to produce your next play.' In New York, everyone wants a new virgin they can put on display, but careers happen over time, by feeding and nurturing. That's where you get brilliant work." 
 He also spoke to the committee about establishing a working environment for actors, where the polished and experienced work in tandem with the youthful and promising "so there's a passing on of information and technique." And he spoke about producing a regular program of classics and of his "overriding passion" for diversity in programming and casting.
"We've got to create a theater that looks, feels and smells like America," he said. "You don't wait until February to discover Negroes. You don't do Latin writers for a week."
 
'Idealistic and Romantic'
 Mr. Wolfe, a man who barely needs prodding to vault into loquacity, managed to restrain his enthusiasm for a moment. "Of course this is very idealistic and romantic," he said. "But I haven't started yet. It's the time to be idealistic and romantic."
Romance and idealism are, unfortunately, only a couple of the requirements of the task Mr. Wolfe assumed with the board's announcement of his appointment last Monday. He will, the board hopes, restore the vibrancy and eminence of the festival and its primary venue, the Joseph Papp Public Theater, that many felt had been dissipated since Papp's death in October 1991. Like Ms. Akalaitis, Mr. Wolfe comes to his new post with estimable credits as an artist, but few as producer and none as administrator or fund-raiser.
He is taking the reins of an institution that has been running at a deficit for eight years, and whose reserve fund -- largely the money earned by "A Chorus Line" which the Shakespeare Festival produced -- has dipped from $19 million to about $15 million since 1985.
"The fiscal picture is sobering but not fatal," said Larry E. Condon, the chairman of the board's executive committee.
A three-year-budget, enacted by the board in 1992 in response to the institution's slipping fortunes, cut administrative expenses by 40 percent and staff by 50 percent, though at the same time the budget for productions was increased slightly, the idea being that it is what the festival puts on the stage that draws not only audiences but also corporate and private donor interest. To put it another way, the more excitement the place generates, the more people with money want to be associated with it.
 
Donations Run Behind
 Board members confirmed, though not for attribution, that one reason they soured on Ms. Akalaitis was that her artistic choices -- her reputation is for favoring a bleak-viewed and somewhat arcane strain of drama -- did not create that kind of buzz. Indeed, charitable donations from both private and business sources are running slightly behind board projections this year. Among board members there was evidently some irritation at Ms. Akalaitis's choosing to present a limited run of a large, expensive production -- " 'Tis Pity She's a Whore,' " which she directed herself last year -- while several stages at the Public remained persistently dark.
Of course it remains to be seen whether Mr. Wolfe's choices as producer will prove more economically prudent, more multifarious or more ingratiating. But already there are signs that philanthropic sources have perked up.
"We've gotten inquiries from several people who want to join the board," said John Breglio, a lawyer for the festival, adding that a number of them are wealthy. "They want to sit on the board because they think there's real hope here."
Mr. Condon said the committee briefly considered candidates other than Mr. Wolfe. "But there was no one else we approached directly," he said. "We looked at his work historically; we looked at his recent work. And Joe had wanted George to have a role at the Public. He'd wanted him to have a theater. It's important to put the Joe connection in there. Ultimately the choice was quite natural."
 
Busy Days and Nights
 But it isn't as though he needed the job. Mr. Wolfe, who is just 38, already had plenty on his plate. He has been spending his days lately directing rehearsals of "Angels in America," Tony Kushner's long-awaited play, part one of which opens on Broadway next month, and many of his nights finishing the editing of "Fires in the Mirror," a film version of Anna Deavere Smith's one-woman show he's directing for American Playhouse. Then there are the cast changes in "Jelly's Last Jam," the Broadway musical he wrote and directed. Mr. Wolfe has been helping Ben Vereen and Brian Mitchell -- who are replacing Keith David and Gregory Hines, respectively, over the next several weeks -- get ready for their roles.
"January February March have been this vrrrooom!" Mr. Wolfe said, using, characteristically, an onomatopoeic plosion to make a point, and punctuating it with a sweeping hand gesture meant to approximate a whirlwind.
Mr. Wolfe is a slight man, bespectacled, a little owlish, with a brand-new short-short haircut whose graying stubble he runs his hands over a lot. Expressive in manner, maybe a little moody, he can go from belly laugh to teasing wisecrack to rumination in a couple of winks. He pays attention and reacts quickly, occasionally with a birdlike darting of his head, as if searching for answers in thin air.
A supremely confident writer and director, he is perfectly willing to call himself arrogant -- not unlike Joseph Papp -- and freely says he has a reputation among actors and playwrights "for being incredibly strong-willed, for not giving in, for always getting my way."
But it appears that also like Papp, he inspires intense loyalty among those who work with him. Indeed, Mr. Wolfe's reputation for ebullience and high energy was clearly part of his appeal for the festival board. Though board members cite, as the reasons for their selection of Mr. Wolfe, his interest in establishing an "inclusive" theater, his insistence on a classical presence at the festival and his desire to nurture writers, these were all stated goals of Ms. Akalaitis as well. It's also true that Ms. Akalaitis was chosen to succeed Papp by Papp himself.
 
Courage if Not Charisma
 Ms. Akalaitis is also frequently described by her supporters -- and indeed, even by the board members who ousted her -- as "an uncompromising artist," a woman "with the courage of her convictions." But what few people would grant her is Mr. Wolfe's charisma, a quality that for an institution competing for both artistic talent and charitable funds, is obviously a plus if not a necessity.
George C. Wolfe grew up in Frankfort, Ky., where his mother was a teacher, then the principal, of the all-black grade school he attended. His father was a clerk in the state government. As he described his growing up, it was clear where his ambition and outlook come from.
"I was 13 or 14 before I was thrust into the white world," he said. "And ever since then it's become clearer and clearer to me that I was part of a generation of black children who were raised like integration soldiers, who were groomed to invade white America.
"I don't know how conscious it was, but with my parents it was definitely: 'They think you're less than; you've got to be better than.' There's this warrior energy I learned early on that has served me well in the theater."
Mr. Wolfe attended Pomona College in California, where he studied acting and design. After graduation he went to Los Angeles, where he began writing, directing plays and teaching at a culture center in the inner city.
He moved to New York in 1979, he said, "and I struggled for six or seven years." Then in 1986 his play "The Colored Museum" was produced at the Shakespeare Festival. "That's when my career started to feed me," he said.
Since then he has written "Spunk," an adaptation of three stories by Zora Neale Hurston, which he also directed at the Shakespeare Festival. There, he also directed Thulani Davis's adaptation of Brecht's "Caucasian Chalk Circle." He was responsible for bringing "Fires in the Mirror" to the Shakespeare Festival two years ago, and he has twice produced, at the Public, a series of performance pieces by artists of color.
It was three years ago, Mr. Wolfe said, that Joseph Papp approached him with a proposal to give him a theater to run under the auspices of the New York Shakespeare Festival. He turned the offer down to work on "Jelly's Last Jam," which was about to go into workshop at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles.
 
Entirely in His Hands
 But as of this moment he has got the whole shebang. He'll be overseeing a festival production budget of roughly $4 million next year, the schedule for which will be entirely in his hands. Given his other obligations, he said, "I'll obviously have to move in in stages."
For now, Mr. Wolfe said, he'll be concentrating on learning the organization; his plans, he said, include changes in both artistic and business personnel. Asked if he found his looming administrative responsibilities daunting, Mr. Wolfe scoffed. "Daunting is the responsibility of trying to create a cultural institution that allows old and new ideas to blend," he said. "Daunting is making the place into a reflection of my passion for what theater can and should do." As for his administrative role, he added: "I'll get better at it every day. I can learn rules."
The one pressing artistic decision is to fill a hole in the summer Shakespeare program in Central Park -- Ms. Akalaitis has withdrawn from her scheduled direction of "Henry VIII" -- which he will do in conjunction with the festival's newly named artistic associate, Kevin Kline.
And the rest of next season? "It's too soon," he said. "But I've got lots of exciting things in my head. Stay tuned."

GRAPHIC: Photo: George C. Wolfe, who is directing a rehearsal of Tony Kushner's play "Angels in America," which is to open on Broadway in April. (Joan Marcus)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
For Toronto, the Change May Not Be for the Better

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUNEDIN, Fla., March 21

 BODY:
Making changes, one baseball theory goes, is good for a championship team because it keeps the remaining players from becoming complacent.
"It depends on the changes," Jack Morris, who has been around long enough to know all of the theories, said today. "I don't think it helped the Tigers much in the mid-80's. They made a lot of changes and it didn't help that club at all. They got progressively worse until 1990." 
 Morris pitched for those Detroit teams and knows whereof he speaks. As he spoke, however, he hoped he wasn't presaging the future of his current team, the Toronto Blue Jays. Between the time they won the World Series last October and the start of spring training, the Blue Jays made wholesale changes on their roster, shedding 9 of the 25 players (36 percent) who brought the World Series and the world championship to Canada for the first time.
 
/Winfield Key Loss
 Gone, among others, is the soul of the championship effort and the man who drove in the Series-clinching runs, Dave Winfield; gone is the man who hit a critical home run in the final game, Candy Maldonado; gone is the left side of the infield, Manny Lee and Kelly Gruber; gone is half of the starting pitching rotation, David Cone and Jimmy Key; gone is the relief pitcher who saved two of the four victories, Tom Henke.
"Sure, we lost a lot," Manager Cito Gaston readily acknowledged, "but we're not going to make any excuses. We'll have a different ball club this year."
But will they have as good a club? As Harold Reynolds, a veteran second baseman who moved from Seattle to Baltimore this off season, said Saturday: "Chemistry has so much to do with a team over the course of a season. Losing Dave Winfield might hurt them a little bit. He's a winner. He understands those principles. I think they'll miss him. You can look at the A's when they got rid of Dave Parker. They became a whole different club. There's something to be said about the stability of a ball club. Statistics don't tell you everything about a club."
 
Key Acquisitions
 The Blue Jays lost most of their departed players as free agents, some of whom they tried to re-sign, some they let go by economic design. To counter some of the losses, they signed two productive veterans, Paul Molitor to take Winfield's place as their designated hitter and Dave Stewart to shore up their starting pitching.
Duane Ward will replace Henke as the closer and Mike Timlin will try to take Ward's place as the closer's setup man, but the other positions remain unsettled two weeks before the start of the season.
Gaston most likely has a firmer idea of what he wants to do than he indicated today, but he named groups of players whom he said he is considering for left field, third base, shortstop and the fifth pitching spot. The jobs should go to Derek Bell for left, Ed Sprague for third, Dick Schofield for short and Pat Hentgen or Al Leiter for the starting rotation.
"What we lose," Gaston said of the changes, "is experience and defense. "We have a little more speed and less power unless some of the kids come through."
Morris, who with Winfield was brought in last year to drive the Blue Jays over the last hurdle, said he thought the team was good enough to win again but added: "It's a question of whether we have the attitude to win again. Do we have people willing to sacrifice like they did last year to win?"
Morris indicated that he hasn't seen that attitude this spring but quickly noted that it was still early. After the Blue Jays lost to the Texas Rangers, 5-2, today, they had a 4-13 exhibition record, but they won last year after having the next-to-worst exhibition record among American League teams.
Todd Stottlemyre, one of the remaining starters, suggested that some of the players who didn't contribute as much to the championship season as some of those who have departed will have to perform better this season. The right- hander, who had a 12-11 record, said he was one of those players.
"It's not like the club said O.K., we won, now we're going to cut and slash; we don't care," said Stottlemyre, whose spring record dropped to 0-2 when he gave up all five Texas runs in the fourth inning today. "This organization cares. One thing about this club is when they lose a player, they seem to bring in someone who is equal or better."
 
Weaker, Says Consensus
 The general feeling among baseball people, though, is the Blue Jays emerged from the flurry of changes with a net loss.
Molitor, playing for only his second major league team after 15 years with the Milwaukee Brewers, said it was too early to make that judgment.
"It's a difficult thing to measure," he said. "The irony is this is a championship ball club and it has such a different look from last year. There have been dramatic changes. There will be inevitable comparisons. When you're successful and you make changes and then if you don't do well, people will say if it ain't broke, why fix it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Todd Stottlemyre is one of the remaining starters on a Blue Jays team full of new faces. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Let This Home Port Die

 BODY:
Every community affected by the Clinton Administration's plan for military base closings is in an uproar, and New York is no exception. The Staten Island home port means jobs and economic activity in a recession-strapped city. But its champions no longer have a convincing argument.
The Navy's elaborate and costly system of dispersing the fleet to every Congressional district with a port never had a strong military rationale and was always a classic example of "port barrel" politics. But the Government claimed that the country needed a network of naval bases for national security and established 21 of them. 
 The end of the cold war weakened the argument that dispersing the Navy's ships would reduce America's vulnerability to surprise attack. As part of a broader base-closing plan, Defense Secretary Les Aspin proposes shutting down all or part of six home ports, including the Staten Island base.
Those elected officials fighting for the port, including Mayor David Dinkins, Borough President Guy Molinari and Senator Al D'Amato, would do better to pursue Federal aid to smooth the transition to civilian employment. President Clinton proposes spending $20 billion over five years to help defense workers find new jobs.
Elected officials have a key role to play, too, in devising productive uses for the home port's property and resources. There is no way that losing nearly 3,000 civilian and military jobs can be pain-free. But realistic leadership in New York and Washington can at least soften the blow.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Now That Home Port's Dead, Let's Put That Land to Good Use

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A list of proposed base closings that accompanies "2 California Bases Spared From List of Military Cuts" (front page, March 12) includes the Staten Island home port. But your article makes no comment on the local case. Now that Guy Molinari, Staten Island Borough President, and Representative Susan Molinari, his daughter, no longer have a friend in the White House, even former supporters of the base apparently see its closing as inevitable. 
 Not quite 10 years ago, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato stood on the deck of the aircraft carrier Intrepid and told us about all the economic benefits that would come to our city once this new base in the Stapleton section was completed. Pathetically few jobs ever materialized, though $200 million or more of Federal funds went into building a facility that many knew from the start was unnecessary and, worse, potentially catastrophic for this region once nuclear missiles were stationed there.
Now it is up to Senator D'Amato to make sure that as the base is decommissioned, this valuable waterfront land does not lie fallow behind barbed wire fences. At the very least, access to the pier for fishing and other public recreation must be promptly established and a few of the buildings must be immediately renovated to provide vocational training and other space needed by Staten Islanders.
Full redevelopment of this site requires careful study by city or state agencies. Even then, Senator D'Amato, Mayor David N. Dinkins and other elected representatives must see to it that the process is expedited so the home port becomes truly a port for its hometown, Stapleton, as soon as possible.
 
JIM MORGAN
Brooklyn, March 15, 1993

HEADLINE: Essay;
Obey The Law Of S.& D.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the long-ago days when I was a hotshot flack, I hired a young woman to place our clients on radio and television shows. She was terrific in ways it is no longer correct to use as criteria -- quick mind, great legs, go-get-'em attitude -- and after six months at $65 a week, she asked for a $10 raise.
Look, kid, I said with insufferable avuncularity, you deserve the 10 bucks. But there's this economic thing that restrains me called the Law of Supply and Demand. 
 She asked me to explain it in human terms. I pointed out how very few jobs existed with the glamour and excitement of radio-TV press agent -- ergo, low supply. And every ambitious, bright knockout in New York City wanted her job -- which meant high demand.
Put that high demand together with the low supply and you had a downward pressure on her salary; the result was a coolie wage, a term not then an ethnic slur. Sorry, kid, I told her, no raise yet; someday you'll thank me for the economics lesson.
That cruel-world episode was brought to mind when I was trying to discern the economic philosophy of the Clinton Administration.
On the redistribution of income, the Robin Hood approach is apparent in this week's budget resolution: steal from the rich and give to the poor and portray anybody who objects as the Sheriff of Nottingham.
On the control of health care costs, however, the shore is but dimly seen. We know that 37 million uncovered people (they're not naked; they just don't have insurance) are to be given coverage, thereby increasing demand.
What is to be done to increase the supply of medical services to offset the upward pressure of that new demand? We don't know; but before any long-range "managed competition" or "global budgets" are to be put in place, insiders murmur, Mrs. Clinton's secret committee plans to limit increases in health insurance premiums and place a ceiling (now rakishly worn as a "cap") on charges by hospitals, doctors and pill rollers.
Price control. The very phrase sends a chill up my spine, as it is the ultimate government interference with the free market's fundament, the Law of Supply and Demand.
If health-service cost is to be controlled by fiat, it follows that supply must be rationed. For price control to work, money can no longer determine what is bought, except on black markets.
Price control also ultimately means wage control: not just reducing the fevered swelling of the incomes of doctors, but freezing the wages of the hospital attendant who crashes your gurney into the elevator door.
Could it be that the task of Hillary's task force is force? A few weeks ago, trying to deep-background my way into the mind of a Clinton intimate, I was stunned by a counter-question: Wasn't it true that I had written President Nixon's speech of Aug. 15, 1972, imposing wage and price controls?
Look, kid, I said, reverting to type, that's not something for anybody, least of all a right-winger, to be proud of. Controls, a border tax, suspending the convertibility of gold, the whole statist works -- I wrapped it in words, even labeled it the New Economic Policy until somebody discovered in the nick of time that that was the name of Lenin's program. Some of the guys broke into the Watergate; I wrote the price-control speech -- where was the greater sin?
Peacetime price control was a colossal flop. Even Nixon, never big on contrition, rolls his eyes when he remembers that ignoble experiment. We put on a lid that distorted the free economy, and inflation was worse when the law of Supply and Demand demanded enforcement.
Hillaryites! Whatever you do to redistribute health care -- and we can all agree on the need to curb patient greed -- forget price control. It is always justified as an emergency measure, starts off popular, and winds up an unpopular mess. Instead, base your changes on the inexorable workings of the Law of S.& D.; make its freedom work for you.
Years after I denied that young woman a raise, I was impelled to call her with congratulations when she became the first journalist to break the million-dollar-a-year salary barrier.
"You remember that cockamamie law you told me about when we were a couple of kids?" said Barbara Walters (for it was she, as the sportscaster Bill Stern used to say). "It works both ways!"

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 443 words

HEADLINE: To the Barricades With Mr. Yeltsin

 BODY:
In a grim stab at arresting Russia's slide into chaos, President Boris Yeltsin is appealing to the people to shore up his flagging authority. By backing him, President Clinton has put the United States firmly behind efforts to build a new Russia that rests on the consent of the governed.
That is the right role for this country. America has no interest in taking sides in Russia's internal struggle over the proper relationship of the president and the Parliament. Nor can it prescribe the exact economic path for Russia to take. But it has an enormous stake in Russia's peaceful transition to democracy and prosperity. 
 The most immediate threat to democracy may not be authoritarian rule but the breakdown of all legal authority. For any economy, whether state-run or market-oriented, to work, contracts must be legally enforceable. For any democracy to function, the government needs the ability to act, with the support of its citizens.
Mr. Yeltsin has taken two steps to renew his own ability to govern, both of which the Parliament has begun to challenge. He has scheduled a referendum for April 25 to renew his popular mandate and to endorse a new constitution. In the meantime, he intends to rule by decree.
Former party hacks and state industry managers in the Parliament are using its authority, based on the outmoded Brezhnev Constitution, to wage a legalistic war against Mr. Yeltsin. He is turning to the people for authority, and a new constitution, to offset his opponents' destabilizing efforts.
Some of Mr. Yeltsin's opponents want to create chaos in order to restore the old order. And state managers are exploiting disorder to line their pockets. The central bank, under Parliament's protection, keeps printing rubles in order to keep their enterprises going and their profits flowing. But that is fueling hyperinflation. The resulting political ferment could sweep the hacks and the managers away, along with Mr. Yeltsin.
That's just one danger among many. Mr. Yeltsin also faces a battered and cynical public, breakaway regions of Russia and a restive military.
As Senator Sam Nunn suggests, Washington can rally the West to help Mr. Yeltsin by providing direct aid to those in need, like inoculations for the country's children and housing for demobilized military officers. At the same time the White House needs to think about what may follow if Mr. Yeltsin fails.
Until now Russia has had a remarkably bloodless revolution from above, directed by more or less reformist elites. Deep divisions in the elites now put that revolution at risk. By siding with Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton is trying to keep it going.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fights Loom as U.S. Nears Debt Limit

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
An old show is about to play Washington again -- the debt ceiling fandango. It hasn't been seen, mercifully, since the fall of 1990, when the Government bumped up against its limit on borrowing seven times from August through November.
Since then, the Government and Congress have enjoyed the longest respite from such scenes since World War II. But they will have at least two encounters this year over whether to raise the debt limit. 
 The stage was set for the showdowns last week with a ritual letter from Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen to the leaders in the House and the Senate. He rounded up the usual reasons and the usual subjects as hostages -- Social Security recipients.
 
April Deadline Looms
 "Currently, our best estimate is that the Treasury will run out of cash and room under the current $4,145 billion debt limit on April 7 as Social Security recipients and others attempt to cash their checks," he wrote.
As in previous seasons, that deadline will occur during a Congressional break. Congress is scheduled to leave Washington for a district work period on April 2. Congressional desires to go home on time might undermine any attempts to use the issue as a platform for debate on the Federal budget and the record budget deficit, if not worse mischief.
The stakes are high. Congress's failure or refusal to approve appropriations has led to the partial closing of the Government, the last episode being in the fall of 1990. But that is mild compared with debt ceiling battles, which have brought the Government to the brink of default, forced the cancellation or delay of regular Treasury auctions and even led the Government to dip into Social Security funds to avoid a crisis.
April 7 is the so-called drop-dead date for the Treasury. That is when the Treasury is expected to run out of cash and bump up against the debt ceiling, meaning it could not borrow to pay its bills.
 
Bentsen Asks for More
 Mr. Bentsen has asked Congress to approve an increase in the debt ceiling by Friday. The temporary limit would be $4.37 trillion and would likely accommodate Government needs through Sept. 30, the end of the 1993 fiscal year. At that time, the Treasury would seek another increase based on the budget and deficit-reduction plan that Congress is now considering.
If Congress does not act on Mr. Bentsen's request by Friday, the Treasury may have to announce its one-year bill auction for April 1 with the cautionary statement that the auction will not be held if the debt ceiling has not been raised.
 
Room to Maneuver
 These deadlines, however, are not precise. Much depends on the flow of money, like the corporate tax payments now coming in to the Government.
Louis Crandall, the chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said that his analysis showed the Government might be able to get past April 7 without additional borrowing authority.
The reason, he said, is that the Government's total borrowing will bump up against the ceiling for just one day, April 7. Because of the accounting of Social Security payments, the total Government debt will decline by several billion dollars the following day, giving the Treasury a little room for more borrowing.
This will happen because the Government will sell the securities in the Social Security Trust Fund on April 8 and 9 to cover the checks that go to recipients on April 2. These Treasury securities are included in the total debt calculation. As they are sold, the Government's borrowing total will fall below the debt ceiling, Mr. Crandall said.
With this breathing room, the Treasury could borrow more, he said, and probably make it to April 15.
The Treasury could even avoid bumping up against the debt ceiling, he suggested, by borrowing a little less in the 20-day cash management bill sale that is expected at the end of the month. If the Treasury reached the ceiling, it would not pose a serious problem as long as the Government had the cash to pay bills and did not need to borrow. But if the ceiling is reached and the Treasury waits until the decline in outstanding debt on April 8-9 to do more borrowing, the one-year bill auction expected on April 1 might have to be canceled.
 
Is Crisis Possible?
 Mr. Crandall is not advocating such a course. But his analysis shows how hard it can be to pin down the Government's drop-dead date and the potential for maneuvering to avoid a crisis. Treasury officials want to convince Congress that it must act, but they are also thinking of some angle to protect against default if Congress balks.
Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, said he did not see any leeway for the Treasury. But if the pace of corporate tax payments is faster than expected, the drop-dead date could be postponed because the Government would have the cash it needed on hand, he added.
When asked about Mr. Crandall's views, a Treasury official said Friday that current estimates show the Treasury will not have enough cash to pay all the bills due on April 7 even if it borrows up to the debt limit. Therefore, the Treasury has no room to maneuver, he said, to take advantage of its ability to resume borrowing after April 7 as the total debt declines.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN MOSCOW;
CHRISTOPHER BACKS YELTSIN VOTE PLAN; SEEKS MORE U.S. AID

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 22

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher today endorsed President Boris N. Yeltsin's call for a national referendum, and coupled it with an appeal to the American people to support increased financial aid to Russia.
In the Administration's fullest statement on Russia since Mr. Yeltsin claimed emergency powers on Saturday, Mr. Christopher described the Russian political crisis as the "greatest strategic challenge of our time." He gave strong backing to the embattled Russian leader, signaling that the United States would support him as long as he acted peacefully and guaranteed civil liberties. 
 In his first policy speech as secretary, at the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations, Mr. Christopher issued a clear warning to Mr. Yeltsin's opponents that the only hope for maintaining Washington's new friendship was a continued movement toward democracy and a market economy.
 
Faith in the People
 "President Yeltsin has called for a national plebiscite to resolve the constitutional impasse," Mr. Christopher said, referring to the referendum that Mr. Yeltsin announced on Saturday for April 25 in which the Russian people will have the opportunity to endorse Mr. Yeltsin's program and call for a new constitution and a new Parliament. "In doing so, he has again demonstrated his faith that the only force that can guarantee reform is the people, the Russian people," Mr. Christopher said. [Excerpts, page A13.]
"The most important point is that Russia must remain a democracy moving toward a market economy," he added. "This is the basis, the only basis for our new U.S.-Russian partnership."
Mr. Christopher's speech was part of was a steadily increasing campaign of support for Mr. Yeltsin by the Clinton Administration that followed Washington's initially hesitant reaction last week to the unfolding events in Russia. On Tuesday, the President is expected to take up the effort at his first formal White House news conference, scheduled for 1 P.M. Eastern time.
 
A Hint to Wealthy Nations
 Mr. Christopher's speech had numerous purposes beyond trying to shore up Mr. Yeltsin: to show America's leadership on the world stage, to rally the American people and Congress behind aid to Russia at a time when domestic concerns are foremost, and more broadly to persuade Americans not to move into isolationism. He also seemed to be trying to nudge some of the other industrialized nations, most notably Japan, to come to Russia's aid.
Mr. Christopher delivered his speech today in the subdued, nearly deadpan manner typical of the lawyer-turned-diplomat. But the language was unusually categorical for a Secretary of State as he pledged stepped-up economic aid to Russia and tried to make a case for spending more money overseas.
"Helping the Russian people to build a free society and a market economy -- this is the greatest strategic challenge of our time," he said. "Bringing Russia, one of history's most powerful nations, into the family of peaceful nations will serve our highest security, economic and moral interests."
Before an audience of about 800 business executives and Government officials, he added: "For America and the world, the stakes are just monumental. If we succeed, we will have established the foundations for our lasting security into the next century."
Mr. Christopher warned that if Russia plunged into anarchy or despotism, the United States could pay a severe price, including a renewed nuclear threat, higher military spending, the loss of new markets and spreading instability.
Asserting that the United States must not walk away from its role as world leader, Mr. Christopher compared the choice America now faces to those faced in two of the century's watershed moments.
"We stand again at a historical crossroads," he said. "It is very reminiscent of the crossroads that we faced in 1918 and 1945. Then we were summoned after conflicts to lead the world by building a new peace. After World War I we chose to retreat, and the consequences were disastrous. However, after World War II, our leaders had the wisdom to answer the call."
 
Support for Reformers
 Mr. Christopher did not predict who would win the showdown between Mr. Yeltsin and the Russian Parliament, but he did say that there would be ups and downs in Russia's moves toward democracy and that Washington must continue to back the democratic reformers even when they are down.
"Our engagement with the reformers must be for the long haul -- when they're out as well as when they're in, when they're down as well as when they're up," he said.
Mr. Christopher said Mr. Clinton would outline his plans for helping Russia when he meets with Mr. Yeltsin in Vancouver, British Columbia, on April 3 and 4. Nonetheless, his speech hinted at several aid programs that the wealthy nations may be planning to help Moscow.
He talked of the need for a safety net for Russia's neediest children, old people and unemployed workers. He also said that it was important to provide more help to Russia's decaying oil industry, which he said could ultimately provide huge amounts of export income for Russia, and talked of providing more help for Russia's privatization efforts and for dismantling its nuclear weapons.
 
Meeting of Wealthy Nations
 He said that the foreign ministers and finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations might meet in April to discuss an aid package for Russia. He also disclosed that President Yeltsin had been invited to the meeting of Group of Seven leaders scheduled for Tokyo in July. The Group of Seven includes the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan.
"We should extend to the Russian people not a hand of pity, but a hand of partnership," he said.
He said this was vital because Russia was carrying out three simultaneous revolutions, all of them difficult: from totalitarianism to democracy, from a command economy to one that is market-based, and from an empire into a modern nation-state.
"Russia's reformers are now looking to the West for support in this moment of extreme difficulty," he said. "The United States has a deep self-interest in responding to this historic challenge."
Mr. Christopher said he did not intend to neglect Ukraine or other former Soviet republics. But he asserted that he was focusing on Russia partly out of concern for the welfare of all, saying "the future security of Russia's neighbors depends so heavily on the success of Russia's own democratic revolution."

HEADLINE: The Health Agenda: 6 Weeks and Counting -- A status report.;
Clinton Health-Care Planners Are Facing Delicate Decisions

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
In a marathon series of meetings over the weekend, Administration officials started to whittle down the options and to draft recommendations for President Clinton's ambitious plan to reinvent the American health-care system.
The President and his health team already know their general approach to curbing runaway medical costs and extending coverage to all Americans: a vast change in the way medical care is organized and delivered. Most patients and doctors would join groups like health maintenance organizations, accepting limits on their choices in return for lower costs. 
 But in the six weeks remaining in the President's timetable, as the planners refine details and begin to confront fiscal reality, Administration officials face some painful choices.
 
Ideas and Hazards
 They have said they want not only to guarantee coverage for more than 35 million people who are now uninsured, but also to include costly items like long-term care, prescription drugs and mental health care among the basic benefits guaranteed to all Americans.
But the politically hazardous prospect of additional taxes, on top of those already proposed in the President's economic package, may force the Administration to scale back its desires, and in coming weeks the health task force and Mr. Clinton may have to drop some cherished goals.
From public statements by officials, interviews with members of the President's health team and internal documents, it is possible to outline many of the main choices that must still be made by May 1, when Mr. Clinton has said he will send his proposal to Congress.
Such a status report discloses that many of the most politically sensitive decisions remain to be made, including what new requirements to impose on small businesses, whether to levy new taxes on employee health benefits and what kinds of cost controls to install. Already, though, it is clear that Mr. Clinton will propose one of the most far-reaching changes in American social policy in a half-century. The health care industry industry accounts for one-seventh of the nation's economy, and the President's proposal will touch the lives of virtually all Americans.
"Reforming the health-care system will involve Government-led changes on a scale not attempted since Social Security," says Ira C. Magaziner, the manager of Hillary Rodham Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform.
As numbingly complex as it is far-reaching, the proposal is certain to become a focus of bitter debate, and its prospects in Congress are unclear. Some liberals fear that the plan may give too much power to large insurance companies, while some conservatives say it will mean too much government meddling with the freedom of doctors and patients. Hospitals, doctors, insurers, employers and consumers will all be profoundly affected and can be expected to try to reshape the details or the basic approach.
Even some of Mr. Clinton's allies say the initiative may be too ambitious, too complex and too costly.
But Administration officials insist that a comprehensive proposal, reorganizing the entire health system, is necessary for both humanitarian and pragmatic reasons: to aid the millions of people who have inadequate health insurance or none at all, and to control costs that have soared to a level of nearly $1 trillion a year, 14 percent of the national output last year.
 
Basics Are Decided
 The President has decided on the basic strategy: "managed competition" by networks of doctors, hospitals and insurance companies, operating within the framework of a national budget for all health-care spending, public and private.
What that means is a transformation of American health care, offering the prospect of lower costs and more security, in return for less choice by consumers and doctors, most of whom may be forced to join prepaid plans like the health maintenance organizations that many people belong to now.
A snag in the complex process developed over the weekend when Mrs. Clinton's father suffered a stroke. She scrapped her health-care-related meetings today, and the White House said she has not decided when she will leave Little Rock, Ark., where her father is hospitalized, and resume her schedule.
What follows is a guide to issues in the debate and options that are currently being considered.
 
The Strategy
Health Coverage For Everyone
 Some critics of Mr. Clinton's managed competition approach argue that a system like Canada's, in which the Government pays for most health care with tax money, would be simpler and more fair. But that system would collide with strong anti-government sentiment in American politics, while the managed competition approach combines free-market forces with Federal regulation.
The Clinton plan would guarantee coverage for all by requiring employers to provide a package of basic benefits to their workers, with the Government paying for the unemployed. The plan would seek to hold down costs by creating a more competitive market.
At the heart of the plan would be large purchasing groups, representing at least a million people in a state or region. These, and the big private employers, would shop around for high-quality health care at a low price. The purchasing groups would act as bargaining agents for their members, which would include small employers and individuals, negotiating prices with networks of doctors, hospitals and insurance companies. Most networks would operate like health maintenance organizations, offering a wide range of services in return for fixed monthly payments.
 
The H.M.O. Dispute
 Forty million Americans are now clients of in health maintenance organizations. Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, many more Americans would be pushed into such prepaid group plans, one of the most disputed aspects of the approach.
Health economists say H.M.O.'s offer the best means of standardizing the quality of care and curbing costs. They note that while patients might lose some accustomed freedoms, they could gain peace of mind because the Government would guarantee comprehensive coverage at predictable prices, even if workers changed jobs or developed serious illness.
Consumers could buy extra coverage with their own money. And they would have a wider selection of practitioners as more doctors joined the local network.
But many people are apt to resist a change in the family doctor, and some experts fear that competition over price among health groups could lead to dangerous scrimping on care.
 
<The Employer's Role
The Burden Is on Business
 By requiring employers to provide insurance for workers and their dependents, Mr. Clinton's plan would have business, not Government, pay most of the bill for covering those who are now uninsured. Roughly 85 percent of the uninsured live in families headed by workers.
Now White House officials are trying to decide how to define "employer" and "employee." The question is important because more and more workers hold part-time jobs, and many small businesses say they cannot afford to pay for health benefits. Mr. Clinton's plan is certain to generate hostility from some small businesses or those that pay low wages. Should an employer have to buy health insurance for an employee who works 17 hours a week? Or 25 hours? Or for an employee earning the minimum wage?
Work papers from the task force say, "Employers will be required to make at least a partial payment for the cost of each worker's health insurance."
The employer's share ranges from 50 percent to 80 percent under the various options. If the employer's contributions were limited in this way, there would be a strong incentive to choose the cheapest plan. Neither employers nor employees would have the option of choosing to remain outside the system.
 
The Basic Benefits
Health Insurance Becomes a Right
 Under the plan being considered, all Americans would have a legally enforceable right to a standard package of benefits. The package will probably be modeled after that now required of H.M.O.'s. It will cover medically necessary doctors' services and hospital care. It will emphasize basic and preventive care, including prenatal care, immunizations, mammograms and routine check-ups.
Congress could prescribe the benefits in great detail, or it could leave those decisions to a national health board. Any forum for discussion of the standard package will be a cockpit for fierce lobbying, as doctors, dentists, podiatrists, equipment suppliers and others, plus consumer groups, seek coverage of particular services and new technology.
If a national board tries to cut costs by eliminating coverage of treatments deemed ineffective or too costly, consumers and patients are sure to complain that the Government is depriving them of necessary care.
Administration officials say they also want to cover prescription drugs, mental health care and long-term care. Despite strong political and medical reasons to include such items in the standard package, health-care experts say it is difficult to calculate and control costs of these services.
 
The Financing
Delicate Debate On More Taxes
 Administration officials estimate that it will cost the Government anywhere from $30 billion to $90 billion a year to guarantee health care for all Americans. Businesses will cover most of the uninsured, but new taxes are inevitable because the savings in national health spending under the plan will come slowly and will be spread throughout society.
Mr. Clinton has said he favors higher taxes on cigarettes as a source of revenue. The Federal tax is now 24 cents a package. The Administration is considering proposing an increase to $1 or $2 a package.
The Government collected $5 billion in tobacco taxes last year. A $2 cigarette tax might produce as much as $20 billion a year. But it would also probably reduce smoking, and Federal officials are trying to refine their revenue estimates to take account of that.
Businesses can now take a tax deduction for the full amount they pay for employee health plans. The Administration is considering a proposal to limit such deductions to the value of the standard package of benefits, as offered by the cheapest H.M.O. in a region. This would in theory lead companies to encourage their employees to join low-cost plans.
Similarly, the Government could impose a limit on the health benefits that employees receive tax free, but for political reasons, the Administration is unlikely to propose what would be, in effect, a new tax on workers.
While Congress clearly wants to act on health care, many lawmakers will be reluctant to approve tax increases this year beyond those in the President's economic plan.
 
The Cost Controls
Complicated Search For Spending Limits
 To curb the soaring cost of health care immediately, if for no other reason than to staunch the flow of tax money into Medicare and Medicaid, Mr. Clinton may ask Congress for the power to impose "interim cost controls" on doctors, hospitals, drug companies, clinical laboratories and suppliers of medical equipment.
Such a regulatory regime sounds simple, but would be difficult to design and enforce because the health-care industry is infinitely complex and continually changing asnew technology appears.
Work papers from the task force show Mr. Clinton is considering several options: "an absolute freeze" on prices charged by doctors, hospitals and other health-care providers; Federal limits on increases in private health insurance premiums, or a Federal decree stipulating that private insurers must use formulas for computing payments to doctors and hospitals similar to those established over the last decade for Medicare, the Federal insurance program for the elderly.
By restricting increases in private health insurance premiums, the Government would limit the revenues of health insurance companies, which would then have a strong new incentive to limit payments to doctors and hospitals. Health-care providers warn that such limits may lower the quality of care.
 
The Timetable
Striving to Hasten A Tangled Process
 The Administration is determined to make a swift transition to the new health-care system, if only to show some results before the 1996 elections. Work papers from the task force say it will take at least 20 months for the new system to begin operation after a bill is signed into law.
Under one option listed in the documents, the Federal Government would establish health insurance purchasing cooperatives in each state within six months or a year after Congress authorized them. Another option says that "states shall designate" such purchasing groups within six months or a year. The Administration is considering various forms of "financial and technical assistance" to encourage the rapid growth of consumer purchasing groups and networks of health-care providers like H.M.O.'s.
Federal officials suggest that they have no desire to make immediate changes in Medicare, so elderly people can probably keep the doctors they use now. But officials are considering gradual changes to make Medicare compatible with the new program. For example, the scope of Medicare benefits might be increased or decreased, and there would be new incentives for elderly people to join H.M.O.'s.
The Administration is also considering big changes in Medicaid, the Government medical program for low-income people, leading perhaps to its elimination as a separate program. Medicaid recipients would eventually be expected to get private insurance coverage through large purchasing groups, still paid by Federal and state governments.
 
 
 
The Language of Health-Care
Employer mandate. A requirement for employers to provide or arrange health insurance coverage for their employees. Typically, such proposals require coverage of workers' families too.
 
Fee for service. An arrangement under which doctors or other health-care providers are paid separately for each service they perform. Some economists say this method of payment may give doctors a financial incentive to provide more care than is needed.
 
Global budget. A limit on all health-care spending, public and private. The limit could be enforced through regulation of doctors' fees and hospital charges. But such price controls are not always included in the idea of a global budget.
 
Health insurance purchasing cooperative (HIPC, pronounced "HIP-ick"). An entity that buys insurance coverage and medical care for a large number of people, including employees of small businesses.
 
Health maintenance organization (H.M.O.). A prepaid group health plan, which provides a wide range of services in return for fixed monthly premiums.
 
Managed care. A method of delivering, supervising and coordinating health care, often through H.M.O.'s and other networks of doctors and hospitals. The purpose is to eliminate inappropriate services, control costs and assure access to effective treatments.
 
Managed competition. A health policy that combines free-market forces with Government regulation. Large groups of consumers and businesses buy health care from organized networks of doctors and hospitals, which are supposed to compete by offering low prices and high quality. President Clinton has embraced this idea, proposed by health-care executives and policy analysts who meet in Jackson Hole, Wyo.
 
Medicaid. Program that provides health care for low-income people, including children and pregnant women, as well as some elderly residents of nursing homes. It is financed jointly by the Federal Government and the states.
 
Medicare. Federal health insurance program for the elderly and the disabled. Eligibility is not based on a person's income.
 
Tax cap. A limit on Federal tax breaks for health insurance. The limit could apply to employers or employees or both. Under current law, employers can deduct the full amount of premiums paid for workers' health insurance, and none of the benefits are considered taxable income for the employees or both.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN MOSCOW;
Excerpts From Christopher Speech on Russia: 'Monumental' Stakes for U.S.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 22

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech today by Secretary of State Warren Christopher on relations with Russia, delivered to the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations:
Bringing Russia, one of history's most powerful nations, into the family of peaceful nations will serve our highest security, economic and moral interests. For America and the world, the stakes are just monumental. If we succeed, we will have established the foundation for our lasting security into the next century. 
 But if Russia falls into anarchy or lurches back to despotism, the price that we pay could be frightening. Nothing less is involved than the possibility of renewed nuclear threat, higher defense budgets, spreading instability, the loss of new markets, and a devastating setback for the worldwide democratic movement.
This circumstance deserves the attention of each and every American. Over the days and weeks ahead, the Clinton Administration will set forth a comprehensive strategy to support Russia's democracy and its efforts to build a market economy.
My intention today is not to announce a detailed program of new initiatives. Rather, what I'd like to do is try to provide a strategic context for the approach that we will follow. I want to explain the tremendous interest we have in doing everything we can to help Russia's democracies succeed.
Let me stress here today that by focusing on Russia, I do not mean to neglect the other new independent states. The well-being of Ukraine, of Kazakhstan, of Belarus, of Armenia, and indeed each of the former republics, is a matter of utmost importance to America.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
 
Dependent on Russia
 Indeed it is partly out of concern for their welfare that I want to concentrate on Russia today, for the fact is that the future security of each of these neighbors of Russia depends so heavily on Russia's own democratic revolution.
Let me step back for just a moment and analyze with you the breathtaking benefits that the end of the cold war has brought to the United States and the world.
To mention just a few of the results: Historic agreements have been reached to slash the nuclear arsenals that threatened our country with annihilation. The nations of the former Warsaw Pact are now free of Soviet domination and of the burden of Communism. The possibility of a superpower conflict on the European conflict -- continent -- has now all but vanished, allowing us to bring home thousands of troops and to reduce our defense budgets.
Around the globe totalitarian regimes that look to the Soviet Union for help and support are now isolated and on the defensive.
And from Vilnius on the Baltic to Vladivostok on the Pacific, vast new markets are opening, opening slowly, but nonetheless opening to Western business.
With a reforming Russia, all of these historic achievements were possible, but without it, many will not be sustainable.
 
A Historic Crossroads
 So we stand again today at historic crossroads. It's very reminiscent of the crossroads that we faced in 1918 and 1945. Then we were summoned after conflicts to lead the world by building a new peace. After World War I, we chose to retreat. The consequences were disastrous.
However, after World War II, our leaders had the wisdom to answer the call. We fostered institutions that rebuilt the free world's prosperity, and we helped to lead a democratic alliance that contained and ultimately drained Soviet Communism.
Today, for the third time in a century, we have an historic opportunity to build a more secure world. We must redouble our efforts to help the Russian people as they struggle in an effort that has no historical precedent.
With great courage they are attempting to carry out three simultaneous revolutions. First, transforming a totalitarian system into a democracy. Second, transforming a command economy into one based upon free markets. And third, transforming an aggressive, expansionist empire into a peaceful modern nation-state. If they succeed in this tremendous experiment, we will all succeed.
Now it appears that another turning point has been reached in Russia's transition. For months a constitutional crisis between President Yeltsin and the Parliament has paralyzed Russian politics.
That crisis came, as you all know, came to a head over the weekend. President Yeltsin has called for a national plebiscite to resolve the constitutional impasse. In doing so, he has again demonstrated his faith that the only force that can guarantee reform is the people, the Russian people.
We welcome President Yeltsin's assurance that civil liberties, including freedom of speech and of the press, will be respected at this difficult moment. We also welcome his firm rejection of imperial and cold war policies.
The most important point is that Russia must remain a democracy during this period moving toward a market economy. This is the basis, the only basis, for the U.S.-Russian partnership.

 	 	 		. . .	 	On that basis Russia can be assured of our full support in the days ahead.
Now, today's crisis in Russia results from one indisputable fact: The pain of building a new system virtually from scratch is exacting a tremendous toll. The patience of the Russian people is wearing thin, a fact that is reflected in Russia's current political stalemate. Nevertheless, we should notice that over the last year President Yeltsin and Russia's other democrats have demonstrated their commitment to reform in many ways.
Civil liberties have been dramatically expanded; the military budget has been significantly cut; prices have been freed in most sectors -- and the result has been the once long lines that formed outside Russia's stores have come to an end. Tens of thousands of shops, restaurants and other firms have been put into private hands, and a real start has been made on the most difficult process of even privatizing the large enterprises.
As a result of these steps, the share of the work force engaged in private commerce has more than doubled over the last two years.
I'm glad to say that over the weekend President Yeltsin recommitted his Government to economic reform. He laid out in clear and strong language the key elements of such a program: continued privatization of firms, selling land to farmers, stopping inflation and stabilizing the ruble.

 	 	 		. . .	 	To succeed we must first change our mind-sets. We must understand that helping to consolidate democracy in Russia is not a matter of charity but a security concern of the highest order. . . .
 
Meeting With Russian
 Tomorrow and the next day in Washington, President Clinton and I will meet with the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev. We will communicate to him our support for Russia's continued democratic development, and we will reiterate that the current situation in Moscow must be resolved peacefully and in a way consistent with civil liberties.
At his meeting with President Yeltsin next month in Vancouver, President Clinton intends to spell out the tangible steps we will take to assist Russian reform. The President is still considering the specific measures he will announce, but our bottom line is it will be increasing and accelerating our support for Russia's democracy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	One area of possible assistance where America's vital interests are directly engaged is our effort to dismantle the nuclear weapons of the former Soviet Union.
The $800 million program established through the leadership of Senators Nunn and Lugar to destroy these weapons is a direct investment in our own security.
Unfortunately, some bottlenecks, both here and in Russia, have allowed only a small fraction of the $800 million to be spent up to this point.
Part of it has been caused by bureaucratic delays in Washington, and we are fully determined to remove these obstacles. We want to see these weapons dismantled in the very shortest possible time.
Another important goal we should have is strengthening the groups in Russia that will form the bulwark of a thriving democracy.
There are public opinions in Russia, too, as you know, and time after time they show one thing. By large margins it's the younger generation that expresses the greatest sympathy for democracy. . . . Ultimately, whatever the results of today's political turmoil, this is the group that will carry the day for Russia's successful transition to democracy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
 
Free Media Needed
 The existence, to take another example, of a strong independent media, is also essential for a democratic society. While Russia's free press has experienced tremendous growth in recent years, there is still a real need for professional training of reporters, editors and newsmen. Here technical assistance can make a real difference.

 	 	 		. . .	 	At a time of great domestic challenge, some would say that we should delay bold action in the foreign realm. But history will not wait. As Abraham Lincoln advised his countrymen, we cannot escape history; we will be remembered in spite of ourselves. . . .

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Warren Christopher after speaking in Chicago. (Cynthia Howe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Revoke Bail, Prosecutor Says to Court

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 22

 BODY:
A prosecution campaign for the immediate jailing of three former Glen Ridge football players convicted of sexual assault last week is to go before New Jersey's Supreme Court on Tuesday.
The court's seven justices have been asked to revoke the modest bail for the three and send them to the Essex County jail on the grounds that they are a danger to their community and might flee before their sentencing, scheduled for April 23. 
 In their request to the state's highest court, trial prosecutors also cited a third and "possibly most compelling reason" -- what they called a "community belief" that the justice system has a racially inspired double standard for convicted defendants.
 
'Treated Differently'
 "There is a sense in the community that defendants convicted of gang rape are treated differently depending upon their social status, race or ethnicity," one Glen Ridge prosecutor, Elizabeth Miller-Hall, said in a legal brief. "In particular, there exists a perception that defendants who are poor or members of a minority group are more likely than other defendants not so situated to be remanded to jail post-conviction."
Ms. Miller-Hall's trial colleague, Robert D. Laurino, made a similar argument to the trial judge, R. Benjamin Cohen, last Tuesday, immediately after the three men, Christopher Archer and Kevin and Kyle Scherzer, were found guilty of assaulting a mildly retarded schoolmate with a baseball bat and broom handle in March 1989.
Ms. Miller-Hall's filing of the brief was the first time that the authorities had injected race or socio-economic status into the four-year-old case. All parties involved are white and grew up in an upper-middle-class community of 7,000 about five miles west of downtown Newark.
In an opposing brief to the Supreme Court, a defense attorney, Thomas Ford, who represents Mr. Archer, called the state's assertion groundless and "frightening." Mr. Ford said it would be unconstitutional to use race or ethnicity as a basis for bail.
 
Allegations of a Rape
 Ms. Miller-Hall argued in her brief that the three young men were "sexually aggressive" and contended that Judge Cohen made a "clear error in judgment" when he rejected the prosecution's request to revoke bail immediately after the conviction.
Regarding Mr. Archer, she repeated Mr. Laurino's courtroom allegation that Mr. Archer had "raped" a female college student several months after he was arrested in the Glen Ridge case. No charges have been filed in this case, and documents relating to it have been sealed.
After graduating from Glen Ridge High School in June 1990, Mr. Archer attended Boston College for two years. Mr. Ford said in his brief that the "alleged rape" occurred in October 1990 and noted that no criminal or civil charges had been filed, and none are "contemplated."
"Consequently, since these charges have not been proven, they should not be a basis for the revoking of bail at this point in time," Mr. Ford said.
In her brief, Ms. Miller-Hall said that Kevin Scherzer had exposed and fondled his genitals in high school classes before he graduated in 1989 and that he had once told opponents in a baseball game about a "rape we did." She offered no explanation of what Mr. Scherzer was referring to.
Ms. Miller-Hall also noted that Mr. Scherzer was arrested by a New Jersey state trooper for drunken driving on March 7 -- three days after jury deliberations started in the Glen Ridge trial -- after he drove through a red light.
Her brief contained no specific comments about Kevin Scherzer's 22-year-old twin, Kyle. His lawyer, Louis Esposito, noted in his brief that "the state has not made one allegation concerning Kyle Scherzer."
Mr. Esposito argued that the twins had been prompt and attentive throughout the five-month trial and have "extremely strong and longstanding roots" in Glen Ridge.
 
'Meager' Bail Amounts
 He argued that Kevin Scherzer's drunken-driving charge and the assertion he had fondled himself in high school classes did not show he was a danger to the community.
Mr. Archer and Kevin Scherzer have been free on bail of $2,500 and Kyle Scherzer on bail of $2,000 since shortly after their arrests in May, 1989.
Ms. Miller-Hall called the amounts "meager," in light of the "substantial prison sentences" the three face. Mr. Archer and Kevin Scherzer were convicted of two first-degree assault charges, which carry a maximum term of 40 years. Kyle Scherzer was found guilty of one first-degree and one second-degree count of assault and faces a maximum sentence of 30 years. Their actual sentences could be considerably less, however, because of discretion granted the sentencing judge.
The state's motion asks the Supreme Court to reverse Judge Cohen and revoke bail immediately. In the alternative, Ms. Miller-Hall asked for higher bail or for a full hearing on the bail issue before Judge Cohen.
The court is to consider the matter in a private conference.

HEADLINE: Senate Republican Plans to Force Vote on Social Security Tax Rise

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
A test vote in the Senate this week on President Clinton's proposal to raise taxes on the Social Security benefits of the most affluent retirees will offer the clearest insight to date on whether Democratic lawmakers are willing to cast politically unpopular votes to support the President's program.
Social Security is one of the most venerated aspects of Democratic dogma. By forcing a vote on the matter, a vote that will have no binding effect, Republicans hope to embarrass and divide the Democrats. 
 The vote, which could come as early as Tuesday, will be part of the Senate's consideration of Mr. Clinton's overall budget plan and a companion measure to spend $16 billion in the next two years to stimulate the economy and create jobs. The House of Representatives approved the budget framework and the stimulus bill last week.
A central element of the Clinton plan to lower the budget deficit is the proposal to raise to 85 percent from 50 percent the portion of Social Security benefits that are subject to income taxes for couples with total incomes of more than $32,000 including retirement benefits and single retirees with incomes above $25,000. The Social Security payments of taxpayers with incomes below those thresholds are not now taxed and would not be under the Clinton plan.
 
Senator Plans Amendment
 The proposal would raise about $30 billion over the next five years, one of the largest tax increases in the Clinton budget.
The budget package went before the House last week under parliamentary rules that restricted amendments, so the Social Security tax never came to a vote. But the Democrats will not be so fortunate in the Senate, where Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, plans to force their hand.
The budget resolution before the Senate merely sets overall tax and spending levels and does not address which taxes should be raised or cut or how much money should be spent on which programs. But Senator Lott plans to submit an amendment that would reduce the total tax level by precisely the amount the Social Security tax increase would raise. A preamble to the amendment states that its purpose is to scrap Mr. Clinton's Social Security proposal.
"It's a clever way to push the Democrats into a hard vote," said Lawrence T. Smedley, executive director of the National Council of Senior Citizens.
Mr. Smedley and most others who lobby on behalf of retirees are opposing the Lott amendment, saying it would be politically unwise to do otherwise.
Two weeks ago in the Budget Committee, Mr. Lott offered an amendment similar to the one he plans to offer to the full Senate. The amendment failed in committee on a party-line vote, but several Democrats who voted against it then said they were sympathetic and might change their votes when they really counted. "Many of us have concerns about it," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, referring to the tax increase.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that only the most affluent 23 percent of retirees would be affected by the new tax next year, a figure that would rise to 30 percent by 1998.
The Clinton Administration argues that the proposal would raise revenue important for reducing the deficit, while protecting most people with low and moderate incomes from additional taxation.
The Administration maintains that the tax increase would actually amount to a spending cut, since its practical effect would be to limit Social Security benefits to some retirees.
Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said, "We have to limit the rate of growth of entitlement programs, including Social Security. Entitlements are gobbling up the budget."
The Administration, Mr. Altman noted, has promised to use all revenue from the additional tax to shore up the Medicare program, which provides medical insurance for retirees. This is mainly a bookkeeping promise, but it has helped keep the lobbyists for retirees at bay.
A study by the Congressional Research Service, a nonpartisan branch of the Library of Congress, found that, to take one example, a retired couple with $15,000 in Social Security benefits and $35,000 in other income from a private pension, interest and dividends, would owe an additional tax of $551 under the Clinton proposal.
Normally, such a couple, with an annual income of $50,000, would not be considered particularly well off. But since even the most generous private pension plans rarely pay ordinary retirees more than about $20,000 a year, the couple would probably have to have an investment portfolio of several hundred thousand dollars.
Votes in the Senate on issues like this are difficult to handicap. But the best bet now is that the Clinton forces will squeak by, at least this week.
"The pressure for Democrats to stick together should carry the day this time," said a staff assistant who has been following the issue closely. But no one is predicting what will happen several weeks from now when the Senators actually vote on the tax and not just on a symbolic amendment.

HEADLINE: For Mayor of Detroit, This Race Is Different

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 22

 BODY:
For nearly two decades, the Detroit mayoral race has taken exactly the same course: Coleman A. Young runs, and Coleman A. Young wins.
But Mr. Young is now 74, and the city that made him its first black mayor in 1974 has suffered a sharp decline in population and economic health, and has become one of the most violent and drug-ridden cities in America. 
 As Mr. Young contemplates a run for a sixth four-year term, many of his allies have concluded that his time has passed and are contributing to other Democratic candidates. Polls show that up to 80 percent of the city's registered voters want the Mayor to retire.
Mr. Young, who rarely ventures out of the executive mansion these days, has given no clear signal of his intentions. The filing deadline for the Sept. 14 primary is June 22.
 
He Can Still Bite
 Regardless of how Mr. Young's political allies now feel, the Mayor's popularity in this city of 1.2 million people, about 70 percent of whom are black, has been enormous. Mr. Young controls a $4 million campaign fund and still has some political bite, snapping at friends who have turned on him.
Of Dennis Archer, the former State Supreme Court Justice who has mounted the most serious challenge for the Democratic nomination, Mr. Young reminded reporters last month, "He got his job as judge through my recommendation."
Of Dave Bing, the former basketball star for the Detroit Pistons who supports Sharon MacPhail, another opponent and former Young protegee, the Mayor said, "Right now, my people are putting together a package trying to rescue Dave's steel company."
Mr. Bing says his business is not in need of the city's help.
In response to criticism that Mr. Young has allowed Detroit's ills to fester, the Mayor says the auto industry slump and white flight to the suburbs have caused unemployment, which in turn has promoted crime and drug use.
 
Different Election Likely
 Jack Moore, an independent poll taker here who found in a survey last month that nearly 80 percent of the voters believe Mr. Young should not run again, said the next mayoral election could be very different from those of the last two decades. "There's no doubt that the erosion of quality of life in the city over the last four or five years is going to be a factor," he added.
But political analysts say it is far too early to count Mr. Young out. Even voters who want him to retire say they will vote for him again if he runs.
"If I was him, I would step down," said Rheuben Blackmon, a 68-year-old parking attendant. "But I voted for him before, and I'll vote for him again."
By putting pressure on Mr. Young to retire, editorialists and political opponents may only re-ignite his zest for public office. "I've told the newspapers that if they'd leave him alone he may go, but no politician wants to be run out of office," said Paul Hubbard, a former City Hall intern who now heads a not-for-profit urban leadership coalition and is considering a run for mayor.
Privately, many of Mr. Young's confidants say he is seriously ill and is considering retirement. Bob Berg, the Mayor's press secretary, concedes that Mr. Young has emphysema, a respiratory illness that can be fatal, but scoffs at reports that he is too ill to serve. "The first stories about him needing oxygen started in 1974," Mr. Berg said.
On Feb. 26 Mr. Young appeared briefly at his annual fund-raising event, a $300-a-ticket affair that netted $1 million for his campaign fund.
Despite his large war chest, it is clear that the Mayor has lost the support of many corporate leaders, many of whom are now lining up behind Mr. Archer. Charles Fisher 3d, chairman of NBD Bancorp, skipped the Feb. 26 event and said he hoped Mr. Young would not run again. The Mayor responded by withdrawing his campaign money from Mr. Fisher's bank.
 
Most Serious Opposition
 Mr. Archer, who like nearly every power broker in the city is black, represents Mr. Young's most serious opposition since he became Mayor. Mr. Archer, who was born in Detroit, taught in the city's public schools before receiving a law degree from the Detroit College of Law. He was appointed to the State Supreme Court in 1985 and joined a prestigious law firm here in 1990. Almost immediately after leaving the bench, his name was circulated as a potential mayoral candidate.
In a Detroit News and Free Press poll, Mr. Archer led the Mayor and several other potential candidates. But his 32.3 percent of the vote, compared to 13.5 percent for Mr. Young, would only put him in a runoff election.
As of February, Mr. Archer reported raising only $155,000 in campaign contributions, far less than the $600,000 to $700,000 that previous mayoral candidates estimate is necessary to run a credible campaign. But many influential business leaders, including Joseph Antonini, chairman of the Kmart Corporation, signed up for Mr. Archer's $500-a-couple fund-raising event on March 12. It grossed about $150,000.
Mr. Archer, pushing an agenda of economic development and public safety, is offering an olive branch to white business interests that have fled to the suburbs. But there is a danger in this tactic: A great deal of Mr. Young's support has been built on opposition to white racism; the Mayor could try to arouse voters by accusing Mr. Archer of toadying to white, well-to-do interests from the suburbs.
"There's no doubt the Mayor would try to paint Archer as the great white hope and attack him for wooing the suburbs," said Bernard Klein, a professor of political science at the University of Michigan at Dearborn. "The questions would be whether he can make the charge stick, and whether Detroit voters would be influenced by such a charge."
