HEADLINE: Anheuser In Mexican Beer Deal

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
America's biggest brewing company, the Anheuser-Busch Companies, said yesterday that it would pay $477 million for an 18 percent stake in Mexico's largest brewer, which makes Corona and other brands.
The arrangement, expected to be made final by the early summer, represents another step in the globalization of the brewing industry. With foreign markets growing faster than the American market, Anheuser-Busch recently entered a joint venture in Japan, and the Miller Brewing Company bought stakes in Mexican and Canadian brewers. 
 The Anheuser deal is also an example of the type of cross-border investment expected under the North American Free Trade Agreement among the United States, Canada and Mexico, which is undergoing final revisions in Washington.
Anheuser's stock moved up $1 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $52.75.
 
 
Access to Expertise
 The deal gives the Mexican company, Grupo Modelo S.A. de C.V., access to Anheuser's marketing expertise. It calls for key marketing, planning and financing managers from both companies to spend a few years at each other's headquarters. The cash infusion will also help the Mexican company pay the costs of its eighth brewery, which is now being built.
Under the contract announced in St. Louis and Mexico City yesterday, Anheuser-Busch's Budweiser and Bud Lite brands will continue to be brewed in the United States and exported to Mexico for distribution by Grupo Modelo, as has been the case since 1989.
Both companies will continue to brew their own brands at home for export abroad; new distribution arrangements are not part of the deal. Four of Grupo Modelo's brands will continue to be distributed in the United States by two private companies, Barton Beers of Chicago and the Gambrinus Importing Company of San Antonio.
For Grupo Modelo, a strong incentive for the deal was the free-trade agreement, Valentin Diez, a Grupo Model senior vice president, said in a telephone interview from Mexico City.
"We knew that because of Nafta," he said, "it would be very convenient for any company to have a good and strategic alliance with the No. 1 brewer in the world."
Modelo's Corona is the top-selling beer in Mexico and accounts for some 55 percent of the country's total beer exports. The company has had success in the United States since the mid-80's with Corona, a light-tasting beer -- often served with a wedge of fresh lime -- that has become popular with many young adults.
Last year, Grupo Modelo sold 15 million cases of Corona, Modelo Especial, Negra Modelo, Pacifico and Corona Light in the United States, where the overall beer market exceeds 191 million cases.
Anheuser-Busch sold about one million cases of Budweiser and Bud Lite in Mexico last year. Mexico's beer market exceeds 16 million cases, and has been growing by 6.5 percent a year over the last five years.
The chairman of Anheuser-Busch International Inc., Jack H. Purnell, said Anheuser-Busch had been hurt by Mexico's existing 20 percent tariff on imported beer, which could make a six-pack of Budweiser in cans as much as 70 percent more expensive than a six-pack of Corona in bottles in a typical Mexican supermarket. Under the free-trade treaty, however, that tariff will be phased out over eight years.
Mr. Purnell said that even if the free trade agreement was signed, Budweiser would still cost more than Corona in Mexico, although the price differential would be narrowed. But he said the real thrust of the contract was to capitalize on international sales and overseas markets that are growing faster than the United States market.
"Nafta would be the icing on the cake, but the cake itself is very appetizing," Mr. Purnell said.
Anheuser-Busch recently entered a joint venture with the Kirin Brewery Company in Japan that gives each company the right to market the other's products at home. Also recently, the Miller Brewing Company, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, bought a 7.9 percent stake in a large Mexican brewer, Fomento Economico Mexicano S.A., as well as a 20 percent stake in Molson Breweries of Canada.
Anheuser-Busch will get three seats on Modelo's board, while a Modelo representative will be appointed to Anheuser-Busch's board.
 Mr. Purnell said Anheuser-Busch had an option to increase its equity holdings in Grupo Modelo to 50 percent. Grupo Modelo is privately held by a group of Mexican familes. Officials from both companies said that management of the Mexican company would remain in Mexican hands.

HEADLINE: U.S. Stocks Shrug Off Turmoil in Russia

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Investors at first shivered but then shrugged over Russia's turmoil yesterday, as stocks recovered from steep opening losses to close only moderately behind.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 24 points within minutes of the opening and soon lost further ground as the bond market also declined. But the Dow came back to close at 3,463.48, off 8.10 points. Big Board decliners outnumbered gainers by about 12 to 7 on moderate volume of 233.2 million shares. 
 Analysts were impressed with the market's resiliency yesterday, although some were cautious about the longer outlook. In the view of most investors, said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company: "Any price concession is bargain time. Some call it a confident market; others would call it a complacent market."
 
 
European Markets Sink
 European markets showed no such assurance, with several of them falling more than 1 percent.
American strategists worried that if President Boris N. Yeltsin was replaced by hard-liners, the anticipated cutbacks in American military spending and the resulting deficit reduction would be postponed. Some recalled the market's sharp decline and recovery after a coup temporarily pushed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev from power in August 1991.
"At this point, I think we've dodged the bullet," said David B. Bostian, chief investment strategist at Herzog, Heine & Geduld. Just as in the earlier power struggle, he said, "The probabilities favor the forces of democracy."
The concerns that could pull stocks down come April, he said, might include the Clinton health-care strategy and Senate tampering with the Administration's budget.
But even if military uncertainties grow, he said, the capital goods and cyclical stocks that have ridden the economic recovery so far might continue to shine. Forest products, metals and oils were among yesterday's better performers. Weyerhaeuser, Louisiana-Pacific, Inland Steel and Nucor were each up at least 1 point.
Meanwhile, some food, beverage and tobacco issues declined, with H. J. Heinz off 1 1/4, to 39 3/4, and Kellogg down 1 1/4, to 61 1/8.
Secondary stocks, typically more volatile, fared the worst yesterday, as the Nasdaq Composite index fell 6.10 points, to 676.62. Software and other computer technology stocks fell, as BMC Software lost 3 1/2, to 46 3/4, and Sun Microsystems dropped 1, to 29 1/8.
Still, some biotechnology stocks advanced, with Chiron gaining 1, to 51 1/2.
European markets posted steep losses, with London's Financial Times 100 index falling 36.20 points, or 1.25 percent, to 2863.90. The CAC 40 in Paris lost 23.41 points, or 1.19 percent, to 1,939.28, and Frankfurt's DAX index dropped 37.41 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,661.40.

HEADLINE: Report Says Man Killed by Police Was Shot in the Back

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
New York City's chief medical examiner said yesterday that a man who was shot and killed by the police outside a 24-hour diner in Manhattan early Saturday morning was shot in the back three times, a finding that contradicted the initial Police Department account that he had been shot in the chest and stomach.
The case of the killing of Bekim Ahmeti, a 20-year-old unemployed doorman from Staten Island, will be presented to a grand jury, as is standard in fatal shootings by police officers. It is also being investigated by a department firearms review board and the Internal Affairs Bureau, also standard procedure. 
 The police report said Mr. Ahmeti was shot about 5 A.M., after police officers responded to a fight at the Moonstruck Diner at 400 West 23d Street at Ninth Avenue. The police version said Mr. Ahmeti tried to run away, then turned and pointed a handgun at the officers. A .38-caliber revolver was recovered at the scene.
 
No Police Comment
 The police yesterday would not comment on the finding by the medical examiner, Dr. Charles Hirsch, which was first reported yesterday in Newsday. Suzanne Trazoff, the department's deputy commissioner for public information, said yesterday that she could not comment until the investigations had been completed. But, she added, she had received no information to indicate that the shooting departed from departmental guidelines.
According to the department's patrol guide, officers can use deadly physical force to stop a fleeing felon only under certain circumstances. One circumstance in which such action is considered justified is when the officer has probable cause to believe that the suspect is armed with a deadly weapon.
The medical examiner, Dr. Hirsch, said, "There's no question the bullets struck him in the back." He added that a bullet also entered the man's left hand.
Although the initial police report said Mr. Ahmeti had been shot in the chest, Ms. Trazoff said investigators at the scenes of shootings cannot always readily determine whether the wounds are entrance or exit wounds.
 
Reasons for Gun Wounds
 She said it was possible that when the first of six shots fired by the two officers struck Mr. Ahmeti, it spun him around so his back was turned. Or, she added, he may have turned his back at the last moment in an instinctive move to protect himself.
Ms. Trazoff said that when the officers arrived at the scene, about 15 to 18 people had spilled from the diner into the street. One, not Mr. Ahmeti, carried a lead pipe.
Mr. Ahmeti ran from the police, Ms. Trazoff said, possibly because he was on probation on a gun charge and did not want to be caught with the gun, which was unlicensed. In February 1992, he pleaded guilty to a charge of criminal possession of a deadly weapon after his arrest for shooting at some bus shelters on Staten Island, and received five years' probation.
Mr. Ahmeti's father, Arif, said that he did not know his son carried a gun but that about two months ago he had been shot in the back and right hand in a drive-by shooting.
 
Just 'Trying to get Away'
 Ms. Trazoff said she did not know whether Mr. Ahmeti turned toward the officers with the gun or not, but she added that when Mr. Ahmeti began to run, he was seen by at least one officer to reach into his waistband, and an officer yelled that Mr. Ahmeti had a gun.
Lieut. Michael Herer, 37, fired two shots from his .38-caliber revolver and Officer Joseph Dalton, 32, fired four rounds from his 9-millimeter Smith & Wesson.
Several friends of Mr. Ahmeti have disputed the police account of the shooting.
One of them, Omar Hernandez, 22, who was about 20 feet away when the police began to chase Mr. Ahmeti, said yesterday that he heard an officer yell that Mr. Ahmeti had a gun. But Mr. Hernandez said that he never saw Mr. Ahmeti reach for or draw a gun and that Mr. Ahmeti never turned toward the officers or made a threatening move.
"He was just running, trying to get away," Mr. Hernandez said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Advance Slightly

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities bounced around yesterday and ended slightly higher as concerns about inflation seemed to keep traders and investors in check.
The intensifying struggle in Russia between President Boris N. Yeltsin and Parliament did not have a major impact on the American bond market. But traders noted that the tension was a cause of declines in both bond and stock markets in Europe. 
 In Germany, long-term bonds were off about 1/3 point in moderate trading. In France, bonds were down slightly and did not seem to get a lift from the better than expected performance of the conservative coalition in the first round of elections Sunday. In London, bond futures were off about half a point, in part because of the announcement of an auction on Friday.
 
Problems In Russia Cited
 In the United States, the problems in Russia seemed to give a little support to shorter maturities, some traders said. But because the dollar did not strengthen, it does not appear that there is a significant flight to the relative security of United States investments.
The auction of two-year and five-year Treasury notes this week is on the mind of every trader, and analysts will be looking to see if the results give any signal about the direction of the market, which has been locked in a narrow trading range for two weeks.
Early in trading yesterday, the focus turned to inflation and the jump in the closely watched Commodity Research Bureau index of commodity prices, like lumber. The index rose to a 1993 intraday high of 214.27 before easing back to finish the day at 213.03, down from Friday's closing high for the year of 213.67.
Since Feb. 8, the index has jumped from 198.46. If the rise continues, traders and analysts could find it more difficult to argue that moderate economic growth will bring the index back down again. Already, the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index for February have risen more than expected.
Nancy Lazar, an economist at the ISI Group, said that if the index broke though the 214 level, she would begin to be worried about her prediction that the rate of inflation will decline this year. The expectation of a decline in inflation is why many investors are still interested in buying long-term Treasury issues even though their yields are at their lowest levels in many years.
There have been several instances in the last two years when the CRB index has jumped higher but then fell back again, Ms. Lazar said. The largest of these short-lived increases was a 7 percent jump, and if the index can break though 214, that would be more than a 7 percent rise.
"We're fighting the tape given the rise in the CRB and the bad readings in the P.P.I. and the C.P.I.," she said of her forecast.
But she said that she still expected the CRB index to fall because her forecast is that the economy, instead of picking up steam, will continue to move along at only a moderate pace. There are several reasons for this, she said, including the very slow growth in the nation's money supply; the continuation of layoffs around the country, and the recent decline in indexes of consumer confidence.
Other forecasters are watching the CRB index closely but are less worried. Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, said that he will not worry about the index until it pierces the 225 level.
 
30-Year Bonds Prices Are Up
 In late trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond was up4/32 , to 104 6/32 and the yield was down to 6.80 percent, from 6.81 percent Friday. The price of the 10-year note was also up 4/32 as the yield inched down to 5.93 percent from 5.95 percent.
The effect on short-term rates from the turmoil in Russia may have been reflected in the weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills. The average discount rate was 2.94 percent for the three-month bill, down from 3 percent a week ago, and the average discount rate was 3.05 percent for the six-month bill, down from 3.12 percent.
In the when-issued, or pre-auction, market, the two-year note was trading at a yield 3.90 percent, down from 3.97 percent Friday, while the yield on the five-year note was at 5.17 percent, down from 5.20 percent. The two-year note will be auctioned tomorrow, the five-year note Thursday.
Following are the results of the three-month and six-month bill auction yesterday:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Stages an Advance As Fears Mount on Yeltsin

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar staged a tentative advance against leading European currencies yesterday amid mounting unease about the future of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
The lackluster advance, however, underscored the weakness of the dollar, which has failed to break out of its current trading range against the German mark despite lower German interest rates and Russian unrest. 
 Gold prices rose modestly. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $332.90 a troy ounce, up $1.10 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold ended at $332.70 an ounce, up $1.20.
Yesterday, President Yeltsin stood firm against hard-liners' efforts to impeach him. The Constitutional Court convened to weigh the legality of a decree by Mr. Yeltsin declaring emergency rule.
 
Pall Over Currency Markets
 The unrest shook European stock and bond markets and cast a pall over their currency markets.
"The situation in Russia has put a floor under the dollar for the moment," said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "What you had was more selling of D-marks and selling of European currencies rather than any inherent dollar strength."
The dollar's luster as a safe investment haven has been dulled by a slow United States economic recovery and a soaring Japanese yen. Government officials in Japan and the United States have pronounced their support for a stronger yen as a way to whittle Japan's bulging trade surplus with foreign countries.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 116.02 yen, down 0.08 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 115.67 yen. The dollar continued to fall in New York, briefly touching a new low of 115.30 before settling at 115.63 yen, down from late Friday's 116.10 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4880, from $1.4895 late Friday. In New York, sterling fetched $1.4870, less than late Friday's $1.4915.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.6380 German marks, up from 1.6340; 1.5140 Swiss francs, up from 1.5080; 5.5705 French francs, up from 5.5685; 1,581.00 Italian lire, up from 1,575.00, and 1.2473 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2465.
